abstract: In spite of the prevalent caloric last evening, a fair audience assembled at Stuyvesant Institute to hear sundry speeches before the Young Men's Republican Union. President ROGERS, promptly at 8 o'clock, introduced A.J. SPOONER, of Brooklyn, who beguiled the audience for half an hour with an off-hand address, giving the Republican view of the approaching Presidential campaign. He was anxious to hear Hon. O.S. FERRY speak, because -- among other citizens of Brooklyn -- he was interested in the ferry question. [Laughter.]

abstract: On Monday afternoon as a lady named Mary B. Lewis, was passing through Lexington avenue, her porte-monnaie, continuing $20, was snatched from her hand by Isaac Gesner, a young pickpocket. Officer Hutchinson, of the Eighteenth Precinct, witnessed the transaction, pursued the thief, arrested him and recovered the money. Yesterday morning the prisoner was taken before Justice QUACKENBUSH, at the Jefferson Market Police Court, by whom he was held to answer. A few hours later he was removed for trial to the Court of Special Sessions, where, having been found guilty, he was sentenced to confinement in the Penitentiary for four months. Scarce fourteen hours elapsed between the time of the arrest and conviction, and if such instances of the speedy measuring out of justice were less rare, doubtless a marked decrease in the number of offences would be the result.

abstract: HANOVER, Saturday, July 28, 1860. We are completely disappointed in Dartmouth  Commencement. Mr. EDWARD EVERETT has failed to deliver his expected oration before the United Literary Societies, the "Social Fraternity" and the "Brothers in Unity." In lieu, however, Col. E.G. PARKER, of Boston, delivered an address on "True Statesmanship and False Demagogueism," which evinced extensive learning in illustration and a deep penetration into the political history of America.

abstract: The Emmet Guard, of New-Haven, arrived in the City early yesterday morning, by the steamer Elm City, and were received at the landing by Company A. Sixty-ninth Regiment. Capt. FLOOD, whose guests they will be during their stay in the City. Col. CORCORAN and Lieut. Col. NUGENT, together with a detachment of Company F., Fourth Regiment, under the command of Capt. MAHON, also joined in the reception of the Guards on their landing. As the steamer approached Peck-slip, a salute of nine guns was fired, and a large concourse of people soon collected, who greeted the Guards on their landing with welcome cheers. The Emmet Guard numbers about seventy-five men, and is a fine appearing company. Following are the names of the officers:

abstract: DEPARTURE OF AN ALLEGED MURDERER FOR NEW-ORLEANS. -- DOMINIQUE MERA, an Italian boatman, who has been in confinement at the City Prison since the month of June last, awaiting identification by the authorities of New-Orleans, yesterday departed for that city in custody of Sheriff MARTIN, of Plaquemines Parish, La. It is charged, that a little over three years ago MERA and a number of his companions murdered NICHOLAS SAVELLI, a Catholic priest of whom he was a creditor. Several of the men were subsequently arrested and confined in the New-Orleans jail, pending a trial for the murder, but they devised a successful scheme to break out of prison. MERA fled to Texas, and has since wandered through various countries, but his movements have been closely watched by the officers of the law, who finally traced him to this City. Information of his presence here having been communicated to Ex-Capt. SEAMAN, late of the Fourth Precinct, a search was prosecuted, which, after much trouble, eventually led to his apprehension, just as he had taken passage on a merchant vessel about to sail for Europe. The fact of MERA's arrest was communicated to the municipal authorities of New-Orleans, who immediately dispatched Sheriff MARTIN, (to whom the suspected man was well known,) with the Governor's requisition for the prisoner's return to Louisiana. The man having been identified was accordingly yielded into his custody. The evidence against MERA is said to be very clear, and he will doubtless be hung.
lead_paragraph: DEPARTURE OF AN ALLEGED MURDERER FOR NEW-ORLEANS. -- DOMINIQUE MERA, an Italian boatman, who has been in confinement at the City Prison since the month of June last, awaiting identification by the authorities of New-Orleans, yesterday departed for that city in custody of Sheriff MARTIN, of Plaquemines Parish, La. It is charged, that a little over three years ago MERA and a number of his companions murdered NICHOLAS SAVELLI, a Catholic priest of whom he was a creditor. Several of the men were subsequently arrested and confined in the New-Orleans jail, pending a trial for the murder, but they devised a successful scheme to break out of prison. MERA fled to Texas, and has since wandered through various countries, but his movements have been closely watched by the officers of the law, who finally traced him to this City. Information of his presence here having been communicated to Ex-Capt. SEAMAN, late of the Fourth Precinct, a search was prosecuted, which, after much trouble, eventually led to his apprehension, just as he had taken passage on a merchant vessel about to sail for Europe. The fact of MERA's arrest was communicated to the municipal authorities of New-Orleans, who immediately dispatched Sheriff MARTIN, (to whom the suspected man was well known,) with the Governor's requisition for the prisoner's return to Louisiana. The man having been identified was accordingly yielded into his custody. The evidence against MERA is said to be very clear, and he will doubtless be hung.

abstract: These famous Clubs met in battle array on Tuesday at the Putnam ground, the knights-errant being the second nines; and after a series of manoeuvres of more than three hours' duration, victory again perched on the Atlantics' banner. The Putnams were short of their regular second nines -- they say -- but the substitutes did not show such muffy play as might have been expected; as it was, they played very fairly at the bat, and deserved more runs, but for the extraordinary fine fielding of the Atlantic's second "first nine." The changes in the positions of the Putnam men were too frequent, and nothing was made by it. The general play of Van Valkenourgh, Chapman and Sandford deserved most commendation. French made a home run. The Atlantic's, without exception, played well in every respect; A. McMahon, as catcher: Phelps as pitcher, and George Seinsoth as second base-ball, played exceedingly well, and each made home runs. But three balls passed McMahon which counted against his side. Hawkhurst played finely at right field. A large and respectable attendance of persons was present to witness the watch, who toot great interest in the game as it progressed. In the report of Mutual vs. Atlantic match, by a mistake it was stated that no home run was made by the Atlantics -- their tall batting included several.
lead_paragraph: These famous Clubs met in battle array on Tuesday at the Putnam ground, the knights-errant being the second nines; and after a series of manoeuvres of more than three hours' duration, victory again perched on the Atlantics' banner. Hawkhurst played finely at right field. A large and respectable attendance of persons was present to witness the watch, who toot great interest in the game as it progressed. In the report of Mutual vs. Atlantic match, by a mistake it was stated that no home run was made by the Atlantics -- their tall batting included several.

abstract: At the entrance of the arcades of St. Peter's Place, our wagon stopped; the balance of our way we had to make on foot, of course, under cover of the roof. In one corner the Swiss guard was seated, dressed in old-fashioned Spanish striped pants and jackets, their pikes leaning against the wall, and the helmets glittering on their heads. Between them, on the ground, was the bassero, for the benefit of their frozen hands and feet. They idled their time away in playing cards, a bench serving them in place of a table. I imagined myself carried back to the times of Quentin Durward, for in a similar manner the Scotch soldiers have probably amused themselves in the castle of King LOUIS XI. Our letter told us that we would be received by the Pope in the Galleria di Arrazzi, to reach which we would have to pass the Scala Regia, and afterwards the staircase of the Sicilian chapel. The beautiful and wide Scala Regia had also some marks of Roman mud on its white marble steps -- a profanation which even the Swiss guard at the foot of the stairs had been unable to prevent. This magnificent staircase leads only to the hall, in which the Popes, in the days of their splendor, were accustomed to receive kings. Hence the name. In a similar way there is a Scala Ducale in the Vatican for the reception of dukes, princes, &c., whose, different orders of rank have all been minutely divided by the Roman ceremonial.

Our letter told us that we would be received by the Pope in the Galleria di Arrazzi, to reach which we would have to pass the Scala Regia, and afterwards the staircase of the Sicilian chapel. The beautiful and wide Scala Regia had also some marks of Roman mud on its white marble steps -- a profanation which even the Swiss guard at the foot of the stairs had been unable to prevent. This magnificent staircase leads only to the hall, in which the Popes, in the days of their splendor, were accustomed to receive kings. Hence the name. abstract: The steamship Great Eastern arrived here at 8 o'clock this morning. She has two thousand and eighty-seven passengers. One steamboat accompanied her to the bar last evening. She got over the bar safely at 7.12 P.M., (at which hour it was high tide,) and had two feet to spare under the keel.

abstract: -Among our foreign advices is the brief announcement of the advance of forty thousand Russian troops upon Peking, with a comment implying the improbability of the rumor. Nothing, however, is more probable. Russia has never permitted any European intervention in Chinese affairs without seizing the occasion to grasp a principal share of the advantages; insomuch, that the successive missions of the British Envoys, Lords MACARTNEY and AMHERST, are well known to have had no other effect than to draw the Court of Peking into closer alliance with that of St. Petersburg. At the approach of the Anglo-French expedition of 1858, two treaties, embodying valuable concessions, were obtained by Russian diplomacy; concessions so valuable, as not only to admit a Muscovite embassy to Peking, but to enlarge the Asiatic Empire of the Czar by the long-desired acquisition of the Amoor region, embracing the larger portion of the Province of Manchootia, where the actual Chinese dynasty had its origin, and where the bones of its Emperors are always entombed. With the short-sighted politics of an Oriental Power, the present Emperor confided in the favor thus secured with the Russians to strengthen him in his ignominious treatment of the allies; and when the backs of these were turned, and danger from that quarter was no longer imminent, the Russians received a taste of Tartar perfidy, in a practical refusal to surrender the Amoor valley. The Russian settlements along the river have been infested by Chinese war-parties; Chinese officers have exacted tolls and collected customs; and so great have been the vexations and molestations of the settlers, that the progress of Muscovite energy in that direction has been entirely suspended. Nor have the treaties been in other respects better regarded. Diplomatic intercourse between the two Powers has been surrounded with augmented difficulties. The Russian college in Peking is little else than a jail. The imposts upon traffic through Kiachta have experienced no ameliorations. In these circumstances, possessing so many valid grounds of complaint, and distrusting further employment of diplomacy, even if the channels of negotiation were open, Russia can hardly be expected to refrain from recourse to arms as the only practicable means of enforcing the repudiated treaties. An opportunity such as is promised by the formidable armada of the French and English is not to be neglected; and there need be no surprise if the triumph of first capturing and occupying the capital of the Chinese Empire should fall to the Muscovite.

The Russian settlements along the river have been infested by Chinese war-parties; Chinese officers have exacted tolls and collected customs; and so great have been the vexations and molestations of the settlers, that the progress of Muscovite energy in that direction has been entirely suspended. Nor have the treaties been in other respects better regarded. Diplomatic intercourse between the two Powers has been surrounded with augmented difficulties. abstract: The screw-steamship City of Washington, Capt. JEFFREY, which sailed from Liverpool at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 18th, and from Queenstown on the 19th of July, arrived at this port yesterday morning. Her advices have been anticipated, but we find in our newspaper files additional details of interest.
lead_paragraph: The screw-steamship City of Washington, Capt. JEFFREY, which sailed from Liverpool at 11 o'clock on the morning of the 18th, and from Queenstown on the 19th of July, arrived at this port yesterday morning. abstract: JOSEPHINE KEPLER, a German woman, residing at 746 Third-avenue, was fatally injured on the night of the 1st inst., by the explosion of a fluid lamp which she was engaged in replenishing. Soon after the accident the poor woman was removed to Bellevue Hospital, where her death occurred yesterday. Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest upon the body.
lead_paragraph: JOSEPHINE KEPLER, a German woman, residing at 746 Third-avenue, was fatally injured on the night of the 1st inst., by the explosion of a fluid lamp which she was engaged in replenishing. abstract: The recovery of the country from the financial depression growing out of the crisis of 1857, has hitherto been checked, if not embarrassed, by bad crops in one portion of the land or the other. The grain failure, season before last, was almost general. Last year, the West produced a partial wheat crop and a fair average of Indian corn. A general good harvest throughout the agricultural States was reserved for the present season. While the yield is now conceded to be large and well distributed in the great staple of wheat, and the season produces abundance, later in the year, in the not less important product of corn, we hear some complaints coming from the planting districts of the South. There has been too little rain for cotton, and the drouth and extreme heat have been damaging, in a large degree, to the auxiliary crops of corn and potatoes. The absence of rain was also injurious to the wheat yield in Georgia, Alabama and some portions of Tennessee. These facts qualify in a measure the otherwise general congratulations through the middle and Northwestern States in regard to the harvest. Their surplus will undoubtedly be large, and there is little danger of famine prices in the less favored sections in the lower Mississippi Valley and on the Southern Atlantic seaboard; the less so, as the export demand for grain and flour from France and England is likely from present appearances to be at moderate rather than at extravagant rates. That this demand is already here, and is to continue within a moderate scale of prices, there is little or no question, notwithstanding the favorable turn in the harvest weather in the west of Europe. The very latest accounts are significant of a continued good demand for foreign grain in London and Liverpool, without reference to the precise extent of the English yield. The active and profitable employment of manufacturing labor throughout the Kingdom has an important bearing, of course, on the consumption of cheap bread, and as the old supplies of English-grown wheat are conceded to be moderate and the new yield not likely to be above, if equal to, a fair average, the question of demand on this country, with its liberal supplies nearly or quite ready for market, would seem to be already decided.
lead_paragraph: The recovery of the country from the financial depression growing out of the crisis of 1857, has hitherto been checked, if not embarrassed, by bad crops in one portion of the land or the other. The grain failure, season before last, was almost general. Last year, the West produced a partial wheat crop and a fair average of Indian corn. A general good harvest throughout the agricultural States was reserved for the present season. While the yield is now conceded to be large and well distributed in the great staple of wheat, and the season produces abundance, later in the year, in the not less important product of corn, we hear some complaints coming from the planting districts of the South. There has been too little rain for cotton, and the drouth and extreme heat have been damaging, in a large degree, to the auxiliary crops of corn and potatoes. The absence of rain was also injurious to the wheat yield in Georgia, Alabama and some portions of Tennessee. These facts qualify in a measure the otherwise general congratulations through the middle and Northwestern States in regard to the harvest. Their surplus will undoubtedly be large, and there is little danger of famine prices in the less favored sections in the lower Mississippi Valley and on the Southern Atlantic seaboard; the less so, as the export demand for grain and flour from France and England is likely from present appearances to be at moderate rather than at extravagant rates. That this demand is already here, and is to continue within a moderate scale of prices, there is little or no question, notwithstanding the favorable turn in the harvest weather in the west of Europe. The very latest accounts are significant of a continued good demand for foreign grain in London and Liverpool, without reference to the precise extent of the English yield. The active and profitable employment of manufacturing labor throughout the Kingdom has an important bearing, of course, on the consumption of cheap bread, and as the old supplies of English-grown wheat are conceded to be moderate and the new yield not likely to be above, if equal to, a fair average, the question of demand on this country, with its liberal supplies nearly or quite ready for market, would seem to be already decided.

abstract: Thomas Saffern vs. The Mayor, &c., of New-York. -- The following decision was delivered by Judge SUTHERLAND in this case, yesterday, in Supreme Court, Special Term. The sole and only relief asked for by the complaint is that the defendants may be restrained by injunction from passing a certain resolution or ordinance set forth in the complaint or any resolution or ordinance for widening Grand street, on the south side from Broadway to Varick-stree, and for extending Grand-street when so widened to Canal-street, and from taking any steps to carry such resolution or ordinance into effect, or from making any petition or application to the Supreme Court in pursuance of any resolution or ordinance, or in conformity therewith.

abstract: -The Board of Aldermen has declared its confidence in the Japanese Committee, by voting the payment of $105,000 required by BOOLE and his fellows. There was a feeble and doubtless sham effort to obtain some of the items; but items were not to be had. In reducing the amount of their little bill from the possible figure of $150,000, to that which proved acceptable to the Aldermen, the Committee had made every concession consistent with its dignity to the universal outcry of the public. To go further would have been to admit the equality of a City Father with the civic children, and, in general, the right of the tax-payers to know how their money is disposed of; -- innovations which must clearly overthrow the entire framework of municipal government to the very foundations. From this point of view, the result cannot otherwise than satisfy the true conservative, who has the slightest regard for local traditions, and who believes that the City has seen few brighter eras than that of the ever-memorable forty thieves.

abstract: It is thought that the fire on Monday night, in Fowler's Buildings, Nassau-street, was kindled by an incendiary. It broke out on the fourth floor, which was untenanted, and this fact leads to the belief that it was the work of design; while the supposition is supported by another circumstance, viz. : the finding of some pieces of paper, apparently saturated with camphene, which had blown into the street.
lead_paragraph: It is thought that the fire on Monday night, in Fowler's Buildings, Nassau-street, was kindled by an incendiary. abstract: ARREST OF FOUR BOYS FOR BURGLARY AND ATTEMPTED ARSON. -- Detectives FROST and DENTON, of the Inspector of Police office, yesterday arrested four boys, named JACK POWERS, THOMAS QUIRK, JAMES MORRIS and WILLIAM JOHNSON, for the double crime of burglary and attempted arson. The oldest of these boys is 19 years of age, and the youngest about 15 years. They were arrested, at first, on suspicion of having robbed the house of NATHANIEL MILLS, on Gold-street, last Saturday night. Upon being locked up, one of them confessed not only to this, but also to various other offences, committed during the last two weeks, the most important of which are the following. They broke into St. Peter's Church, on State-street, where, finding no plate, as they had anticipated they would, they took possession of a contribution-box containing a few coppers, and then attempted to set the church on fire. The fact that the building was not burned down was owing more to the want of skill than of any good will on their part. While looking about for something to steal, they espied a surplice, which one of the party, in pure wantonness, commenced to tear into pieces; but another, apparently having more respect for the clerical robe than for the place, interfered to prevent this sacrilege, and the result was a fight over the ecclesiastical garment. Their next exploit was in an unoccupied house on Duffield-street, which they robbed of several hundred weight of lead pipe, and also of a quantity of brass cocks. Some time last Saturday night they entered the house of Mr. MILLS. The family being in the country, they had everything pretty much their own way, and were probably in the house nearly all night, but towards morning they became alarmed at the vigilance of a policeman in the vicinity, and made a precipitate retreat, taking with them but a small portion of the clothing they had selected and packed ready to carry away. This house, too, they attempted to set on fire, in one of the closets, but the flame which they had kindled went out of its own accord. The boy POWERS, who has manifested a desire to become a witness for the people, was formerly in the employ of GEORGE LAMBERTSON, in the Montague Hall Billiard Saloon, and is well known in that connection. He says that the party was organized only a few weeks ago, for the purpose of more successfully carrying on the business of robbery. Each took an oath of constancy to each other under any and all circumstances, with a fearful penalty attached for violating the obligation. Finding his companions and the business they were engaged in not quite so congenial to his feelings as he had anticipated, he was apparently rather pleased than otherwise at being arrested, and now expresses a strong desire to be afforded an opportunity to amend his ways. The whole party will be examined to-day before Justice CORNWELL.

abstract: A systematic effort is to be made to establish a regular steam communication between this port and the Island of Jamaica. The infrequency and great irregularity of communication heretofore have been a serious hindrance, even to the limited commerce existing between New-York, Kingston and other Jamaica ports, and have tended to keep that little commerce within the control of a few large houses, who have monopolized the trade for their own benefit. Encouraged by a recent act of the Colonial Legislature, authorizing the Government to pay a subsidy for the establishment of a regular mail service with New-York and Aspinwall, Messrs. BREAKSPEAR, FRENNO & CO. have arranged to put steamers upon that route, and on Saturday they sent forward the first vessel of the line -- the screw steamer Baltimore -- with a full assorted cargo, and a number of passengers for Kingston. As soon as the contract shall have been completed for carrying the mails, a second steamer will be placed on the route. They will each carry about 500 tons of cargo, independent of coal, leaving the between decks for fruit and other perishable articles. It is intended also, if the proper encouragement be afforded, to have the steamers touch at Turk's Island and Port au Prince, Hayti, going and returning. They will connect at Kingston with the Royal Mail steamers from England and the Windward Islands, and then proceed to Aspinwall, from whence they will bring the products of the Isthmus, such as hides, coffee, cochineal, &c.

abstract: HOW ALABAMA STANDS. -- Col. CLEMENS, late editor of the Memphis Enquirer, in a letter to that paper, says of the prospects in Alabama, where he is now staying: "Placing no great reliance upon the reports I hear daily from other parts of the State, and judging only from the feeling manifested in this stronghold of Democracy, I tell you with entire confidence that you may set down Alabama as lost to BRECKINRIDGE. He could not carry the State to-day, and will grow weaker from this time until November. The only thing which ever gave the Secession Party any strength in Alabama was its assumption of the name of Democracy, and when that is torn away they will dwindle into a faction too contemptible to excite the fears, or disturb the peace of the country." The Mobile Tribune cannot stop to count the BRECKINRIDGE papers in the State, but numbers sixteen DOUGLAS journals already. It puts it down as certain that Mr. BRECKINRIDGE cannot carry the State.

abstract: At the opening of the Statistical College, now in session in England, Lord BROUGHAM thought it proper to call the attention of Mr. DALLAS, who was present by invitation, to the fact that a negro was in the room. Lord BROUGHAM undoubtedly meant this as a piece of pleasantry, but by this act he convicted himself not only of a violation of Parliamentary rules, scarcely to be expected from one of his years and experience, but also of a decided breach of common politeness. The majority of the meeting appeared to view the observations in this light, and greeted it with very partial applause; while Mr. DALLAS did not even vouchsafe his thanks for being informed of so interesting a fact. The negro referred to so pointedly stood up and assured Lord BROUGHAM and all present that he was a man -- a lesson in natural history that seemed scarcely called for by the occasion and the assemblage, unless it is the custom in England to class negroes with gorillas and other animals of the bifurcated order. A Democratic Congressman, not long since, drew attention to the British Minister, while in the House, by calling him by name, but the discourtesy was promptly rebuked. Such an example is the last that a cultivated scholar and refined gentleman like Lord BROUGHAM would be expected to adopt; and it is, therefore, gratifying to observe that the venerable peer has sought an early opportunity to make proper apologies to Mr. DALLAS.

abstract: Senator SEWARD, with a large party of NewYorkers and others, has been visiting Little Sodus Bay. abstract: European advices five days later are received by the arrival of the steamship Prince Albert at St. Johns, N.F., en route for this port, from Galway on the 24th inst. There is nothing new from Syria. Active preparations for an armed intervention were making by France, and it was reported that Russia also had expressed a desire to co-operate with France and England in the restoration of order. The Turkish Sultan had written to both France and England, expressing his grief for what had transpired, and promising to make an effort to reestablish order. From Naples we learn that the Ministry had concluded to withdraw their resignations, the King having taken measures in accordance with their desires. Still further concessions had also been ordered by the Government, such us the removal of the Royal Guard, the abolition of the punishment of the bastinado, and the discontinuance of the custom of imprisonment in secret dungeons. No further fighting in Sicily is mentioned. GARIBALDI had announced his intention to annex Sicily to Sardinia. Advices from China to June 7 are received. It is announced that hostilities were about to commence; and in connection with this fact it was reported that a Russian army of 12,000 men were marching on Peking. This report, however, needs confirmation. Our dispatch, together with our files by the City of Washington, which arrived at this port yesterday, from Liverpool on the 18th and Queenstown on the 19th ult., affords various other items of interest.

abstract: The suit between the New-Jersey Railroad Company, as proprietors of the bridges across the Hackensack and Passaic Rivers, and the Hoboken Land Inprovement Company, was decided on Monday by Chancellor GREEN. It will be remembered that last Winter the Hoboken Company obtained from the Legislature a charter for a railroad connecting Hoboken with Newark.
lead_paragraph: The suit between the New-Jersey Railroad Company, as proprietors of the bridges across the Hackensack and Passaic Rivers, and the Hoboken Land Inprovement Company, was decided on Monday by Chancellor GREEN. It will be remembered that last Winter the Hoboken Company obtained from the Legislature a charter for a railroad connecting Hoboken with Newark. This result was only attained after a desperate struggle -- the forces in favor of the charter being led by Mr. E.A. STEVENS, the President of the Hoboken corporation, and also of the Camden and Amboy Railroad, while the opposition mustered under Mr. JOHN P. JACKSON, the Vice-President of the New-Jersey Railroad Company. While beaten in the Legislature, the latter had left the stronghold of the Courts, uniformly partial in New-Jersey to the interests of close corporations. The New-Jersey Railroad threw itself upon certain old charters for toll-bridges across the two rivers separating Hoboken from Newark, and contended that the monopoly secured by those papers must bar the prospects of their antagonists. The cause was argued at great length and learning before the Chancellor, who in his decision has ruled against the Hoboken party on all the points raised by it, except one, and that happens to give the entire victory to that side. Chancellor GREEN holds that a special privilege granted seventy years since, for a toll-bridge, was designed to apply to such modes of locomotion and transportation as existed at that time; and it could not have been in the minds of the legislators to apply it to locomotion and steam, and rail, for the very obvious reason that such facilities of travel were then not even dreamed of. He therefore regards a bridge exclusively used for the transit of Railroad trains as not in conflict with the rights of the New-Jersey Company; and so renders his dictum. The case will doubtless be carried to the Court of Errors, where there is little prospect of so wise a decision being reversed.

abstract: DROWNED MAN IDENTIFIED. The body of the man found floating in the water at the foot of Yorkstreet, on Monday afternoon, was identified yesterday morning as that of DANIEL CUMMINGS, owner and captain of the sloops Lucy Ann and Senator. It appears that on Friday last deceased attempted to ...
lead_paragraph: DROWNED MAN IDENTIFIED. -- The body of the man found floating in the water at the foot of Yorkstreet, on Monday afternoon, was identified yesterday morning as that of DANIEL CUMMINGS, owner and captain of the sloops Lucy Ann and Senator. It appears that on Friday last deceased attempted to fasten the rope found grasped in his hand to the jib-boom of the sloop Senator, which was lying in the North River, opposite the Sectional Dock, Jersey City, and, missing his footing, fell overboard and was drowned before assistance could be rendered him. The deceased was a man of temperate habits, about 25 years of age, and leaves a wife and two children, residing in Water-street, New-York.

abstract: This case, which has excited so large a degree of attention throughout the State, was yesterday decided by Chancellor GREEN in favor of the defendants -- the motion for injunction being denied and complainants' bill dismissed with costs. In view, however, of the appeal which it was understood would be taken to the Court of Errors and Appeals, the Chancellor agreed to grant a temporary injunction until the close of the next term of Court -- the plaintiffs to give bond for the payment of all damages which may accrue to the defendants because of such delay in the construction of their road.
lead_paragraph: This case, which has excited so large a degree of attention throughout the State, was yesterday decided by Chancellor GREEN in favor of the defendants -- the motion for injunction being denied and complainants' bill dismissed with costs. abstract: The war of the Allies to prop up Turkey, cost, it is estimated, half a million of "Christian" lives, if troopers and sabreurs, Zouaves, Chasseurs d'Afrique, and swearing and drinking guardsmen, can be called by that heavenly name; -- cost them not simply by disembraining and disemboweling in hot conflict, or by the tender mercies of long-ranges, but by the cruelest horrors of the hospital, the ghastly facts of which, as regards the French troops, have never come to light in French journalism, and are imperfectly known even in the British, whose "own correspondents," sought to have light shed on them. The world will will never have official knowledge that sometimes three-fourths of the French cavalry and infantry died without ever striking a blow. It should apply to the British transport-ship captains who took allies for the nonce out to the Crimea, and carried back but a fourth of the original number, for the slight reason that the rest had gone to eternity, through exposure, sickness and a bad commissariat. We trust that some day the real cause of the havoc may come out; but meanwhile would ask was not the whole war a piece of folly and a sham, in view of the recent part Turkey has taken in massacres of the Christians?
lead_paragraph: The war of the Allies to prop up Turkey, cost, it is estimated, half a million of "Christian" lives, if troopers and sabreurs, Zouaves, Chasseurs d'Afrique, and swearing and drinking guardsmen, can be called by that heavenly name; -- cost them not simply by disembraining and disemboweling in hot conflict, or by the tender mercies of long-ranges, but by the cruelest horrors of the hospital, the ghastly facts of which, as regards the French troops, have never come to light in French journalism, and are imperfectly known even in the British, whose "own correspondents," sought to have light shed on them. abstract: A regular meeting of the Board was held last evening, the President in the Chair.  Among the communications was one from the Street Commissioner, asking, on behalf of the Pilot Commissioners, an appropriation of $20,000 for the excavation of Coenties Reef, to the depth of 20 feet at low water, which it is thought will enable any vessel to pass the reef without difficulty. Referred to Committee on Finance.

abstract: Perhaps no administration that has swayed within our time the destinies of England has presented a greater combination of extent of experience, breadth of culture, brilliancy of genius, and enlightened sympathies with the people than the present Cabinet, as typified by Lord PALMERSTON, Lord JOHN RUSSELL, Mr. GLADSTONE, and the Duke of NEWCASTLE, who has been so wisely selected as the mentor of the youthful British Telamachus, whom the telegraph tells us landed yesterday on our shores. Nowhere perhaps, has the influence of the true statesmenship of these men been more visible than in the desire they have exhibited, often under severe trial, to cement the alliance with this country. For whatever difference may exist with regard to peculiar institutions, there can be no question that on all great subjects tending to jeopardize those principles of liberty which are the keystone of both English and American life, the two nations must naturally appeal to each other, and derive from their union a moral strength and positive power, which cannot fail to prove invaluable auxiliaries in any contest of civilization, whether on this or the other side of the ocean. Whether to the statesman's desire of cultivating more intimate relations with America, or to the kindly feeling of the Queen of England towards a country in which her name has been held, even in its republican extent, in almost loyal reverence -- as exhibited in the cordiality and gracefulness of her letter to her "good friend," JAMES BUCHANAN -- we owe this visit of her son, it is equally wise and well-timed. At the same time, it is impossible not to mark the judicious line of demarcation which has been drawn between the visit of the Prince to his mother's English possessions and that to the American Republic. The latter he proposes to visit with the quiet dignity of a private traveler, the other with a parade of royalty which will bring the moral weight of institutions that have stood the test of centuries, upon colonies which, geographically at least, may be said to be exposed to the freaks and passions of our restless, wild, and eccentric Republic. England, with all kindness for Young America, thus exhibits her determination to hold her own, and perpetuate among the people of her distant possessions, that abiding attachment for old English institutions which cover the hearts of her people at home. Nor does this visit, which hereafter will belong to the romance of history, derive the least of its poetic interest from the fact that one of the oldest among the monarchies has chosen for its first personal representative to a young world a boy of but nineteen. There is something in the youth of the Prince as contrasted with the antiquity of the crown he represents, which wears in itself a color of romance.

abstract: -- The nobility of England are coming to a very singular complexion. It is but a few days since the son of a Duke was committed to a debtors' jail, and now a Prince figures in a Police Court. Last arrivals tell us that His Royal Highness Prince EDWARD, of Saxe Weimar, unlawfully passed through a toll-gate, refusing to pay the toll amounting to 3d., for which offence he was brought before the Hammersmith Police Court, and sentenced to pay that sum and 2s. costs. Noblesse oblige will henceforth have a wider and more singular signification than ever. A Peer bankrupt for a paltry Â£1,000, and committed to a common jail in default of payment; and a Prince declining to pay a three-penny toll except on compulsion; -- what sadder commentary on patrician institutions can be imagined, what sadder picture of patrician poverty can be presented? It is quite likely that we may yet be called upon to contribute for the relief of English peers and princes as we have before for the relief of Irish peasants.
lead_paragraph: -- The nobility of England are coming to a very singular complexion. Noblesse oblige will henceforth have a wider and more singular signification than ever. A Peer bankrupt for a paltry £1,000, and committed to a common jail in default of payment; and a Prince declining to pay a three-penny toll except on compulsion; -- what sadder commentary on patrician institutions can be imagined, what sadder picture of patrician poverty can be presented? It is quite likely that we may yet be called upon to contribute for the relief of English peers and princes as we have before for the relief of Irish peasants.

abstract: Dr. LIVINGSTONE and Dr. KRAPF have made simultaneous explorations of the eastern coast and equatorial region of Africa, -- the latter proceeding from the North and the former from the South, and both ending long and perilous journeys at points not five degrees distant one from the other. Between the discoveries of these two explorers, our geographical knowledge is materially increased. The present volume describes the topography, languages, people, customs and traditions of the tribes inhabiting the countries east of Ukambani. Dr. KRAPF's residence among these people for eighteen years, as a missionary, gave him access to abundant sources of information, of the advantages of which he has fully availed himself. Receiving the valuable assistance of his missionary colleagues, REBMANN and ERHARDT, he was able to reconcile with his duties to the Church the more difficult task of scientific observation. While diligently propagating a knowledge of the Gospel among the heathen, he and his co-laborers found leisure for the study of philology, for tracing the courses of undescribed streams, for measuring the altitude of mountain-chains, for meteorological investigation, and for entering unexplored wildernesses. Some of the results of Dr. KRAPF's former travels were published in the year 1843, while his later and move important journeys, ending in 1855, are described in this work.

abstract: The Boston Herald sketches an interesting habeas corpus case now on trial in that city. Mrs. ELIZABETH F. THORNDYKE, as she is now entitled to call herself, if the divorce laws of Indiana are valid, was married to Mr. HENRY G. RICE, of Baltimore, in 1860.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Herald sketches an interesting habeas corpus case now on trial in that city. Mrs. ELIZABETH F. THORNDYKE, as she is now entitled to call herself, if the divorce laws of Indiana are valid, was married to Mr. HENRY G. RICE, of Baltimore, in 1860. She and her husband became estranged soon after the birth of a boy, to recover possession of whom Mrs. THORNDYKE brings suit, and she appealed to the Indiana Courts and obtained a divorce. Subsequently Mr. RICK obtained a divorce from her on the ground of desertion, and commenced proceedings to have the Indiana divorce set aside, on the ground of fraud, and made diligent efforts to recover the custody of the child. Last December an agreement was made between the parties, by which. Mr. RICE was to have the custody of the child, except at stipulated seasons, (which also had been decreed to him in the Maryland Court;) and a condition of the agreement was that he should discontinue his proceedings to quash the Indiana divorce. The child was placed in the custody of his father last Spring, but when Mr. RICE found as he alleges, that the visits of Mrs. RICE to her son produced an injurious effect upon him, by making him unruly and disobedient he declined to fulfill the agreement, and after six visits made by the boy to his mother in April last, she has been debarred from further intercourse with him. Mr. RICE came with his family to resice at N[???]hant the 1st or July, and Mrs. THOR[???]DYKE has brought the pending suit to compel the restoration of the joint custody of her boy, in fulfillment of the before mentioned agreement. Able counsel are employed in the cause, J.G. ABBOTT and WILDER DWIGHT appealing for the petitioner; SIDNEY BARTLATT and DAVID THAXTER for the respondent. The ci[???]orced husband and wife have been placed on the stand, also several relations of the respondent's family, and the boy has been examined separately by Judge BIG[???]LOW. The decision in the case will soon be given.

abstract: The opening of steam communication between New-York and Jamaica has revived a hope, long entertained by the planters of the island, that large numbers of our colored population could be induced to emigrate to the West Indies.
lead_paragraph: The opening of steam communication between New-York and Jamaica has revived a hope, long entertained by the planters of the island, that large numbers of our colored population could be induced to emigrate to the West Indies. The subject seems to have attracted attention in this country, for we have received several communications from parties inclined to emigrate, asking for advice and information. We have already expressed an opinion in regard to this matter. The British West Indies are capable of sustaining tenfold their present population. They appear to be a natural home for the colored races; their resources are great and yet undeveloped; their climate is tropical, but not unhealthy; they have the advantage of a free Government; and their laws are equally and justly administered. But the principal class of immigrants needed in Jamaica -- the only class asked for by the planters are day-laborers, and a day-laborer cannot earn as much there as he can here. He has, it is true, certain political advantages which many colored people may think more than an equivalent for high wages. This, however, is a point which every man must decide fur himself.
headline: {'main': 'Emigration to Jamaica.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Emigration to Jamaica.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We are not much surprised to see that many of the young and ardent Irishmen who went forth in the spirit of the old crusade to do battle for the Pope, are described as already weary of their new service and eager to return.
lead_paragraph: We are not much surprised to see that many of the young and ardent Irishmen who went forth in the spirit of the old crusade to do battle for the Pope, are described as already weary of their new service and eager to return. There can be but little romance for men whose fathers had but just, after tedious years of struggle, attained their own emancipation, in leaving their country to aid another sovereign in maintaining his subjects in that oppression from which they themselves have so lately emerged.

abstract: Our Special Correspondent at Palermo writes us that the existence of a secret treaty between France and Piedmont has been discovered by GARIBALDI. By the terms of this treats Piedmont will be allowed to annex the two Sicilias; but she must not touch Umbria and the Marches unless the populations first revolt, in which case these also may be annexed.
lead_paragraph: Our Special Correspondent at Palermo writes us that the existence of a secret treaty between France and Piedmont has been discovered by GARIBALDI. By the terms of this treats Piedmont will be allowed to annex the two Sicilias; but she must not touch Umbria and the Marches unless the populations first revolt, in which case these also may be annexed. As to Venice, Piedmont may win her from Austria if she can, but she must not count on aid from France. In return for all this. Piedmont is to relinquish to France the islands of Sardinia and Elba, and make other territorial grants. This treaty is alleged to he already signed, as truly as was that of P[???]ombieres, which surrendered Savoy and Nice to France.

lead_paragraph: About ten or twelve days ago, a tall, military-looking man, of elegant manners and gentlemanly appearance, arrived in this City took rooms at one of the principal hotels, representing himself to be Col. W.H. Quantrall, a Mississippi planter, of great wealth, who had come here intending to make an extensive northern tour. His vivacity in conversation, and other agreeable qualities, soon secured for him the confidence of a well-known merchant of this City who was boarding at the same [???] and through the medium of this gentleman, in the course of three or four days, he obtained introductions to the heads of several of first-class mercantile houses, who believed that in him they had found a desirable customer. In two instances his plausible story with reference to his immense means was so far credited, by merchants doing business s in Broadway, (whose name were given us confidentially, that arrangements had been entered into, and the requi[???]ne papers [???]wn, for his admission as co-partner in each firm to the extent of in interest for $40,000, but an exposure of his real character as a awi[???]ndler was ma[???] known are the negotiations were completed. His exploits as an impostor during the space of eight days, were mu[???] form and very successial.

abstract: The story of the Great Eastern steamer is a kind of providential consolation offered to the ruling classes of Great Britain. From the hour when the hammers first rung upon her iron ribs at Blackwall, to that in which she, yesterday released from her foul and steaming decks the last squad of hot and angry ...
lead_paragraph: The story of the Great Eastern steamer is a kind of providential consolation offered to the ruling classes of Great Britain. From the hour when the hammers first rung upon her iron ribs at Blackwall, to that in which she, yesterday released from her foul and steaming decks the last squad of hot and angry "excursionists," returning thirsty and unwashed from a "day of pleasure" at Cape May, the great work of RUSSELL and BRUNEL has been under the charge of the substantial British citizen. Four years ago, when the soldiers of VICTORIA were dying like sheep in the trenches of Inkerman, through lack of the food and the garments which were rotting at the same moment on shipboard in the roadsteads of Balaklava, the substantial British citizen, reading of those horrors in the brilliant columns of the Times; shuddered with indignation at the incapacity of the peerage, and the reckless stupidity of the gilded British aristocrat. The circumlocution office became a name of sc[???]n, and red tape a symbol of all that is effe[???], imbecile and worthless in the administration of human affairs. Then the world was given to understand that, if the management of England's public business were but taken from the white-handed, sarcastic talkers of the Clubs, and conferred upon the energetic actors of the City, all would go well once more in merry Britain. There would be no more men perishing in the surgeon's hands while the surgeon's stores were wasting a hundred miles away, no more Lord Cardigan charges of cavalry; no more Prince steamers.

abstract: From a correspondence printed in the NewOrleans papers, it seems that immense and recondite organization, the Knighthood of the Golden Circle, has offered its services to the Liberal Government of Mexico, and that they have been declined.
lead_paragraph: From a correspondence printed in the NewOrleans papers, it seems that immense and recondite organization, the Knighthood of the Golden Circle, has offered its services to the Liberal Government of Mexico, and that they have been declined. Indeed, the mere suggestion of such aid seems to have thrown President JUAREZ into the utmost consternation. Not only does he pronounce in emphatic terms against this specific tender, but he declares the indisposition of his Government to avail itself of any offers of the kind originating with Free Companies gathered in the United States, and hints broadly that the apparent friendship of that modern Jason, Gen. BICKLEY, is really a suggestion of the Reactionary adversary at the City of Mexico, eager to lead the progressives into temptation, and thence to ruin. Whether there be justice or not in this suspicion it is unsafe to conjecture; but very surely no more serious faux pas could be committed by either of the actual parties in Mexico, than to court the aid of American condottieri. So long as the ranks of either hostile army can be recruited by individual enlistments, or by the tender of commissions to foreign leaders of ability, there is no hazard of arousing and alarming national prejudices. Much of the actual strength of the Liberal forces is thus obtained. But in the employment of foreign mercenaries upon the Bickleian plan, a cry is at once furnished to the opposite party, who would not fail to rally a people so peculiarly jealous of their nationality in hostility, to the traitors who proposed to level the musket of the stranger at the heart of their countrymen. The career of WALKER in Nicaragua is too recent to be forgotten. That hero, with his band of ragmuffins and cut-throats, was invited by the confiding Liberals of the Central American State, to aid them in much the same sort of a struggle with Conservatism. He went, and served, and conquered. There was no strength in Spanish-American character, or courage to enable the people to resist his ambitious advances. They sank collapsed at his feet. The spectacle, so full of warning, is fresh in the recollection of the Mexican people, who watched the struggle with an interest naturally profound because sympathetic. No existing party would therefore venture to repeat an experiment thus obviously big with peril.

abstract: At the regular weekly meeting of this Board yesterday afternoon. Mr. VERPLANCK, the President, was the Chairman. The number of cases of ship lever landed at Castle Garden from emigrant vessels coming from Liverpool to yesterday, accounted to nearly 50. Most of them had arrived in the ship Cynosure, from that port. The matter was referred at the last meeting to the President and Council of the Board, who had not yet reported on that subject. No other business being before the Board it adjourned.
lead_paragraph: At the regular weekly meeting of this Board yesterday afternoon. Mr. VERPLANCK, the President, was the Chairman. abstract: The men possessed of the secret of making gold, whether as some ages ago, passing by the name of alchemists, or in the present day of railway and steam directors, have in all times found some difficulty in procuring the apparatus. It is with them, as with St. Denis without his head in the first step all the cost lies.
lead_paragraph: The men possessed of the secret of making gold, whether as some ages ago, passing by the name of alchemists, or in the present day of railway and steam directors, have in all times found some difficulty in procuring the apparatus. It is with them, as with St. Denis without his head -- in the first step all the cost lies. They know how to make tons of gold, but they must have a little somewhat to begin with. This appears to have been the great difficulty with a brace of gentlemen, Mr. LEVER and Mr. O'MALLEY IRWIN, who, from the report of the Committee of the House of Commons on Steam Contracts, seem to have been the great founders of the Galway steam line. Neither of them seem to have been troubled with much funds, but they were both men of vast enterprise. All they wanted was something to work on, and they selected, unfortunately, we fear for herself -- Galway. The port was one endowed with great natural advantages, bad been favorably reported as a station, and was looked on with a pardonable enthusiasm by its inhabitants as destined to be one day the great entrepot of the commerce of the two worlds. So Galway was selected. Mr. LEVER contributed a few old steamers which the close of the Crimean war had thrown out of work, and which were mortgaged to their full value or hired by the trip. Mr. O'MALLEY IRWIN contributed his influence.

abstract: A Republican Club has recently been organized in South Brooklyn, under the title of "Irrepressible Wide-Awakes of South Brooklyn," and the following officers have been elected: President, M. DEPEW; Vice-President, L.D. ST. GEORGE; Corresponding Secretary, ADDISON DOUGHERTY; Recording Secretary.
lead_paragraph: A Republican Club has recently been organized in South Brooklyn, under the title of "Irrepressible Wide-Awakes of South Brooklyn," and the following officers have been elected: President, M. DEPEW; Vice-President, L.D. ST. GEORGE; Corresponding Secretary, ADDISON DOUGHERTY; Recording Secretary A.G. FORNEY; Treasurer, H.B. SMITH; Commandant, H. BRISTOW; Lieutenants, N.A. HALEY and SAMUEL ST[???]TS. Thirty-one persons joined the Club at the first meeting, and quite a number have signed the roll since. The Club will make its first, turn-out at the dedication of the South Brooklyn Wigwam, which will take place some time next week.

abstract: MOVEMENTS OF THE EMMET GUARD. The Emmet Guard, of New-Haven, are enjoying the hospitalities of the City and having a good time generally under the guidance of the Irish Fusileers, whose guests they are during their stay in the City. The excursion to Newark Bay on Tuesday proved a very pleasant affair, and was highly satisfactory to all concerned.
lead_paragraph: MOVEMENTS OF THE EMMET GUARD. -- The Emmet Guard, of New-Haven, are enjoying the hospitalities of the City and having a good time generally under the guidance of the Irish Fusileers, whose guests they are during their stay in the City. The excursion to Newark Bay on Tuesday proved a very pleasant affair, and was highly satisfactory to all concerned. Yesterday the Guard spent the day in the City, under going a review by the Mayor in the forenoon, visiting Niblo's in the afternoon, and Wallack's in the evening. The review by the Mayor took place at 11 o'clock in front of the City Hall, the Guard being escorted thither from the Eagle Drill rooms via Fourth-avenue, Union-square and Broadway, by their hosts the Irish Fusileers. Col. Corcoran and Ex-Col. Doheny of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, and Lieut.-Col. Nugent, Capts. Kelly, Kirker and Breslin, Lieut. Carter and others were present at the review. The Mayor, accompanied by Aldermen Boole, Seagrist, Bagley, Barry and Cornell, and Councilmen Lent and Pinckney passed along the line of the Guard, who presented arms for the occasion. The Guard, with their escort, then marched to review before the Mayor, who was subsequently introduced to the several officers, and addressing Capt. CA[???]ILL, welcomed in a few words the Emmet Guard to the City of New-York Capt. CAHILL responded briefly, and the two Companies then marched several times around the inclosure, receiving the applause of the spectators. The Guard were then escorted to their head-quarters, the Westchester House, where, at half-past 12 o'clock, they sat down to dinner with their hosts, the Fusileers. An interchange of toasts followed the removal of the cloth, in response to one of which, complimentary to the Guards, Capt. CAHILL alluded to the action of an Ex-Governor of Connecticut, in disbanding the Company on account of their being foreigners. Such an act, he thought, was conceived in bigotry; and, although he was a native American himself, he was opposed to all proscription of Irishmen or others on account of their foreign birth. The Emmet Guard did not claim to be the beau ideal of a military organization, and he could not indorse the remark of a previous speaker, that they were "second to none;" yet they did claim to be always ready to do their duty, as good citizens to their State and to their country. At 2 o clock the Guard, accompanied by the Fusileers, visited Niobio's Theatre.

abstract: The bids for the erection of a new County Jail, which has greatly "exercised" the Board of Supervisors for several months past, were opened yesterday by the Committee on County Affairs, and the award was made as follows: James Owens, for carpenter work, $3,599: Robert Foster, for mason work, at $31,500. The building is to be of brick, faced with Dorchester stone, and with a metal root, but as only $25,000 have been appropriated for its erection, the Supervisors will have to loot to the next Legislature to supply the deficiency.
lead_paragraph: The bids for the erection of a new County Jail, which has greatly "exercised" the Board of Supervisors for several months past, were opened yesterday by the Committee on County Affairs, and the award was made as follows: James Owens, for carpenter work, $3,599: Robert Foster, for mason work, at $31,500. The building is to be of brick, faced with Dorchester stone, and with a metal root, but as only $25,000 have been appropriated for its erection, the Supervisors will have to loot to the next Legislature to supply the deficiency.

abstract: JOHN BROWN's LAWSUIT. -- A civil suit, left as a bequest to the courts by JOHN BROWN, is likely to become famous for the questions involved, and the singular circumstances now connected with it. When PERKINS & BROWN were in the wool-trade here, a Mr. WARREN, of Pittsfield, N.Y., let them have a large quantity of wool, on which they advanced. The price of wool afterwards went down, and they sued WARREN to recover $5,000 which they had overpaid him on the market value of the wool. WARREN resisted the claim, on the ground that he sold them the wool outright, and not on commission. The suit was commenced in 1850, and after a trial lasting thirty-seven days, it was decided in favor of PERKINS & BROWN. But the defendant appealed, and this appeal has not yet been argued and is still pending. Meanwhile PERKINS has failed and his assignee is substituted in his place; JOHN BROWN is dead; Mr. JENKINS, the attorney for the plaintiffs, is dead; the defendant, WARDEN, is dead, and so is his attorney. New attorneys are engaged on both sides; but the defendant's estate has all been swallowed up, and his bail also has become worthless. Then there are costs to the amount of over $3,000 in the case unpaid. So that, on the whole, although the case may be interesting to the lawyers, it does not promise any great returns for the labor to be expended upon it. -- Springfield Republican, July 30.
lead_paragraph: JOHN BROWN's LAWSUIT. -- A civil suit, left as a bequest to the courts by JOHN BROWN, is likely to become famous for the questions involved, and the singular circumstances now connected with it. But the defendant appealed, and this appeal has not yet been argued and is still pending. Meanwhile PERKINS has failed and his assignee is substituted in his place; JOHN BROWN is dead; Mr. JENKINS, the attorney for the plaintiffs, is dead; the defendant, WARDEN, is dead, and so is his attorney. New attorneys are engaged on both sides; but the defendant's estate has all been swallowed up, and his bail also has become worthless. abstract: Times have altered. Ever since I came here I have been lying in wait to see some of "Podgers'" boasted fleas, but my cabinet is not yet supplied with one. I got me a terrible little Scotch terrier as a trap, but not a flea yet. Either civilization has driven the tribe like red men before it or, by locating on a hill-top, I am missing a valley privilege.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, Friday, July 6, 1860.

abstract: On Monday, as the telegraph has already informed us, Senator DOUGLAS was in Burlington, Vt. On arriving at the Rutland and Burlington depot, he was escorted to a carriage in which was seated Hon. GEO. P. MARSH, Hon, D.A. SMALLEY, and JOHN G. SAXE.
lead_paragraph: On Monday, as the telegraph has already informed us, Senator DOUGLAS was in Burlington, Vt. On arriving at the Rutland and Burlington depot, he was escorted to a carriage in which was seated Hon. GEO. P. MARSH, Hon, D.A. SMALLEY, and JOHN G. SAXE. A procession was formed, which passed through the principal streets of the town, and the finally entered the Town Hall, where Mr. DOUGLAS was welcomed formally by Mr. SAXE.

abstract: KINGS COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS THE DEAD HOUSE OFFICERS ELECTED SURROGATE'S FEES.  An adjourned meeting of this Board was held last evening in the County Jail building, Raymond street, President CROSWELL in the Chair.
lead_paragraph: KINGS COUNTY BOARD OF SUPERVISORS -- THE DEAD HOUSE -- OFFICERS ELECTED -- SURROGATE's FEES. -- An adjourned meeting of this Board was held last evening in the County Jail building, Raymond street, President CROSWELL in the Chair. There was a full attendance of members. The annual report of the Store Keeper for the County was submitted, from which it appears that the following articles were used in the Bakery during the past year: Flour, 2,087 bbls.; Indian meal, 17,275 lbs.; rock salt, 17 bbls.; hops; 75 lbs.; malt, 17 bushels. With which 532,136 lbs. of bread were b[???]ked, and distributed as follows: Almshouse. 149,966 lbs.; Hospital, 87,600 lbs.; Nursery, 59,658 lbs.; Lunatic Asylum, 124,112 lbs.; Penitentiary, 119,800 lbs. A resolution was adopted authorizing a Committee to enter into contract with E[???]BITS HOPKINS, mason, at $652. and WRIGHT RAMSDEN, plumber, at $89, to proceed forthwith and erect upon the Hospital grounds fronting on Willoughby-street, a brick building, one story high, to be used as a Dead House, according to plans and specifications presented. Much the largest portion of the session; was occupied with matters pertaining to the appointment of a Keeper and Assistant Keepers of the Penitentiary. The Board, for first time within the memory of the oldest inhabitant, has a decided Republican majority. The Democracy have heretofore had everything their own way, and have accordingly filled every office in the gift of the Board with a working Democrat. In June last the Republicans in the present Board made an attempt to remove several officers, but for the time the matter was laid upon the table, and passed by. Yesterday the subject was called up by Supervisor COLT of the Sixth Ward. He moved to adopt the report of a Committee, in effect removing HIRAM HELMS, Democrat, Keeper of the Penitentiary. The motion was strenuously resisted by the Democrats, joined by several Republicans, but was finally adopted. A motion to proceed to ballet to fill the vacancy was then carried. Upon the result being announced, Mr. HELMS, having received a majority of all the vo[???]es cast, was declared elected. A motion was then made and adopted, after much opposition, declaring the office of Assistant Keeper vacant, and a resolution, offered in June last, embracing the names of the Republican nominees, was adopted. Soon afterwards the of[???]covery was made that the resolution provided that the new officers should commetee their duties on the 1st of July next, and a long squabble was then had over a motion to reconsider and amend so as to read, "on the 1st day of August 1860" and readopt, all of which was finally accomplished. The names of the keepers removed and appointed are as follows: William L. Jones, Joseph Ritze, John Bradshaw, William H. Butts, John Van Zandt, P.H. Moore aim William M. Brown, in place of James Willis, Thomas Gascoyne, Alexander Land, William Willis, O.B. Strickland, James Campbell and William Pearsall. Contracts for various supplies were awarded as follows, coal, James Bell, at $4,50 per ton; wood, Kelsey & Loughlin, at $5 97 per cord; soft [???]eap, Arthur Welwood; at 75c. per barrel. The Surrogate sent in a report of fees received by him to $4,478 20 received in the respective months as follows: August, $278; September, $122 75; October, $401; November, $334 25: December, $405 50; January, $317 50; February, $402; March. $358 75; April, $327 75; May, $428 75; June, $110 95 July, $391. A communications from the County Judge asking for repairs to the room in which [???]e holds Court was referred to a Committee with power. A resolution to appoint WILLIAM C. B[???]DICT, M.D., physician to the County Jail, was laid on the table, and a similar fate awaited a motion to appoint Dr. J.L. ZABRISEIE to the same position in the Penitentiary. The Board adjourned to the first Tuesday in August, as required by statute.

abstract: On Wednesday afternoon, on the Hamilton ground, at the corner of Gates and Grand avenues, after over an hour's delay, caused by the absence of several of the Hamiltons, the above clubs began a game, and at the end of five innings the Enterprise had a very fair prospect of victory.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday afternoon, on the Hamilton ground, at the corner of Gates and Grand avenues, after over an hour's delay, caused by the absence of several of the Hamiltons, the above clubs began a game, and at the end of five innings the Enterprise had a very fair prospect of victory. The play of the Enterprise throughout the innings was most excellent in all respects, the only apparent difference being that some of their fielders had more work than others. Their base play was unexceptionable, while Leland, at right field, and Weddle as pitcher, were very effective in their positions in batting there was general excellence, but O'Niel, Start, Cornwall, Boyd and Leland were most successful Boyd making a fins home run.

abstract: At a regular meeting of the Club held at No. 765 Broadway, last evening, Vice-President C.E.L. STUART in the chair, it was moved by Mr. VANLOOM, and seconded by G.J.V. abstract: Archibald Wilson, an officer of the Court of General Sessions, residing at No. 87 West Eleventhstreet, was arrested on Wednesday night for having wantonly assaulted, in a violent manner, Mrs. Mary Fawcett, residing at No. 28 Amity-street. Mrs. Fawcett, accompanied by three other ladies and a gentleman, had been in Broadway, and while returning home, she and one of the other ladies allowed their friends to get half a block in advance of them.
lead_paragraph: Archibald Wilson, an officer of the Court of General Sessions, residing at No. 87 West Eleventhstreet, was arrested on Wednesday night for having wantonly assaulted, in a violent manner, Mrs. Mary Fawcett, residing at No. 28 Amity-street. Mrs. Fawcett, accompanied by three other ladies and a gentleman, had been in Broadway, and while returning home, she and one of the other ladies allowed their friends to get half a block in advance of them. On arriving at their residence, the gentleman, having an engagement, did not stay to see the ladles into the house, and while the first two waited on the steps until their companions came up, Wilson, it is alleged, stepped across the street to where they stood and applied to them the most opprobrious names. Fearing violence at his hands they entered the house and slammed the door a moment or two before Mrs. Fawcett and the other lady reached it. Wilson then turned to them and renewed his offensive language, after which he seized Mrs. Fawcett by her dress, dragged her from the stoop, threw her down and beat her most shamefully, besides tearing her garments. Her cries, and those of her companion, brought Officer Warren to her assistance, and the ruffian was arrested. The attack was altogether unprovoked, as the character of the ladies is beyond impeachment. Yesterday Wilson was taken before Justice QUACKENBUSH, who required him to furnish $1,000 bail for his appearance to answer the complaint which was preferred against him. The only defence that he offered for his behavior was that, in his opinion, the women were disreputable.

abstract: The regular meeting of this Board took place yesterday afternoon, at the Rotunda, in the Park. Commissioner BELL took the chair during the absence of Mr. DRAPER, the President.
lead_paragraph: The regular meeting of this Board took place yesterday afternoon, at the Rotunda, in the Park. Commissioner BELL took the chair during the absence of Mr. DRAPER, the President. According to the weekly statement, the number of inmates at the various institutions under the care of the Board, amount to 7,551, an increase of 140 since the last meeting. A number of communications from various sources were received and referred to the Committee on the Whole, with power. The following is an abstract of the report of the Committee on the Whole, which was submitted and unanimously adopted. In regard to the City Prisons, the keeper of the Essex Market Prison was instructed to prepare separate cells for the boys and girls therein incarcerated, so that they might be kept from communicating with adults, -- the change to be complete, immediate and thorough. From the 20th of July to the 2d inst. 635 persons, male and female, were transmitted to the Workhouse on Blackwell's Island as vagrants. A census being taken at Bellevue Hospital on the 18th ult., showing that the number of inmates there was 947, while the books showed the number of 995, making a difference of 48 inmates. Instructions were given to the Warden of the Island Hospital to remove the dead bodies forthwith, and not to retain them for several days, as had been done heretofore. The salary of Mrs. Heaton, matron at the Almshouse, was fixed at $350 per annum. The salaries of Miss Bell and Mrs. Lloyd, matrons at the Workhouse, were fixed at the rate of $350 per annum each. An inclosure was formed around the Lunatic Asylum to limit the promenade and exercise ground of the inmates for the purpose of keeping them better under supervision. The excavations for the new Lunatic Asylum are now complete, and the architect was notified to proceed with his work. The repairs to the border at the Randall's Island Hospital have been ordered to be done by a competent person, and directions have been given to the Warden to have a sufficient number of men engaged in getting out stone for the base of the new building. At the opening of bids for the erection and extensions of buildings, Charles Vandervoort was awarded the contract for the carpenter's work at $5,700; and D.E. & B Weeks were awarded the contract for the mason work at $1,476. The Board then adjourned.

abstract: The Tribune is anxious to know whether the "gentlemen of the Common Council imagine they can carry through the Japanese robbery with impunity." We should think there could be no ...
lead_paragraph: -- The Tribune is anxious to know whether the "gentlemen of the Common Council imagine they can carry through the Japanese robbery with impunity." We should think there could be no doubt on this point after the case is fairly stated. The "gentlemen of the Common Council" can hardly be supposed likely to plan a "robbery." But as the public is somewhat inclined to doubt whether the proportion of "gentlemen" in the Common Council is much larger than was the proportion of "righteous men" in the Cities of the Plain, this consideration is hardly of a nature to reassure the suffering tax-payers of the metropolis. Our cotemporary goes on to warn the rest of the Councilmen whom it describes as "scoundrels," that a fearful retribution awaits them, for they will neither be "forgotten nor forgiven." We fear that these sinners will prefer even a place in the memory of their fellow-citizens, and the portion of the "impenitent thief" to the sacrifice of their share in the spoils of BOOLE's ball. Whatever the "gentlemen" may think of the matter, the "scoundrels" at least not only "imagine" but fully and fervently believe on the faith of a pretty large past experience that "they can carry through the Japanese robbery with impunity;" and we suspect they will act accordingly.

abstract: I have but very little news to transmit from this quarter by the steamer which is to sail from Aspinwall to-day. The country is still in a disturbed state, and the consequence is we can receive no reliable accounts from the interior as to the movements of either the Federal troops or the revolutionists, and I have, therefore, to rely on rumors and speculations.
lead_paragraph: PANAMA, Wednesday, July 25, 1860.

abstract: Last week Judge LEONARD, sitting at Supreme Court Chambers, released a woman from confinement on Blackwell's Island on the ground of Irregularity in the commitment, inasmuch as the warrant held them for two months, while the Revised Statutes provided that the term of imprisonment should not exceed sixty days. Yesterday, another of this class of vagrants applied for her release by virtue of this decision, but, in the meantime, the notice of the Court having been brought to a statute by which the Magistrates of this City are authorized to commit vagrants for a period as long as six months, the Judge refused the application.

abstract: The Secretary of the Great Eastern Company has vouchsafed an explanation which it is quite possible that he may regard as an excuse for the failure of his Company to fulfill the terms of their contract with the excursionists, who seethed and sweltered and suffered, in the noble ship on her recent coasting trip to and from the Capes of Delaware.
lead_paragraph: The Secretary of the Great Eastern Company has vouchsafed an explanation which it is quite possible that he may regard as an excuse for the failure of his Company to fulfill the terms of their contract with the excursionists, who seethed and sweltered and suffered, in the noble ship on her recent coasting trip to and from the Capes of Delaware. He states that before leaving England the managers, whom he represents, abdicated their control of the ship's commissariat to a certain Mr. Cox, stipulating with that individual for such a full and satisfactory performance of his duties as should put the larder of the leviathan on a level with that of "first-class hotels." As in this clause we presume the larder of the "first-class hotels" of London and not of New-York was intended, it is highly probable that Americans who have undergone an experience of Long's or the Clarendon, those marvellous caravanseries of the British capital, may be inclined to acquit the scape-goat Cox of any failure to meet his obligations.

abstract: THE ANNUAL BUDGET. -- The Joint Board of Aldermen and Supervisors reassembled in the Common Council Chamber, last evening, to make up the tax Budget for the year. They were in session nearly three hours without reaching any satisfactory result as to the appropriations to be made for a single purpose. The appropriation for Fire Department purposes was greatly increased over what the Mayor and Comptroller, or even the Committee recommended, and adopted; but no one supposed for a moment that the Beard intends to embarrass the city with such an enormous sum. It will doubtless be reconsidered at the next meeting. The resolution declaring the estimated "city revenue" at $117,400, was adopted without any opposition, and in reality that was the only advance made. The representatives of the Eastern District endeavored to reduce the amount recommended to be raised in that section of the city to pay off old claims and interest, by showing that the Committee had called for a larger sum than was necessary; but all of their motions were voted down and the matter was laid on the table. The Board adjourned for one week.
lead_paragraph: THE ANNUAL BUDGET. -- The Joint Board of Aldermen and Supervisors reassembled in the Common Council Chamber, last evening, to make up the tax Budget for the year. They were in session nearly three hours without reaching any satisfactory result as to the appropriations to be made for a single purpose. The appropriation for Fire Department purposes was greatly increased over what the Mayor and Comptroller, or even the Committee recommended, and adopted; but no one supposed for a moment that the Beard intends to embarrass the city with such an enormous sum. It will doubtless be reconsidered at the next meeting. The resolution declaring the estimated "city revenue" at $117,400, was adopted without any opposition, and in reality that was the only advance made. The representatives of the Eastern District endeavored to reduce the amount recommended to be raised in that section of the city to pay off old claims and interest, by showing that the Committee had called for a larger sum than was necessary; but all of their motions were voted down and the matter was laid on the table. The Board adjourned for one week.
