abstract: The Exercises of Anniversary week at Auburn commenced with examinations of the classes on Monday and Tuesday. On Tuesday evening, at 7 3/4 o'clock, an address before the Society of Inquiry, in the presence of a good audience, was delivered at the town hall, by Rev. Dr. SAMUEL HARRIS, of Bangor. An address, not connected with the anniversary exercises, but of much interest, was delivered in the chapel, at 9 o'clock Wednesday morning, by M. BEAULIEU, of Illinois. The object of this was to present the claims of those families of the Canadian Reformed Catholics who declined following Father CHINIQUY into the Presbyterian Church, not feeling that they had sufficient knowledge of Protestant differences to join any denomination, and, therefore, preferring to remain in the Congregational form of worship. These amounted to nearly half of the nine hundred families. Father BRAULIEU gave a sketch of his own life and conversion, and of the causes which led so many French Canadians to leave their homes and the Catholic Church, and seek refuge in Illinois. The Sermon to the Alumni, at 10 1/2 o'clock on Wednesday morning, was to have been delivered by Rev. Dr. WAYLAND, of Providence, but in his absence on account of illness, Professor PHELPS, of Andover, preached from the text: "Confess your faults one to another, and pray one to another." -- John 5, 16 -- and from several kindred texts. At the annual meeting of the Alumni, Rev. Mr. MALTBY, of Taunton, presided. The Standing Committee and Secretary of last year were rechosen. Also, for preacher of the next annual sermon, Rev. Dr. WAYLAND, and as substitute, Rev. Dr. THOMPSON, of East Windsor, Conn. Rev. PHILIP SCHAFF, D.D., of Phillipsburgh, Penn., spoke before the Porter Rhetorical Society on Wednesday afternoon, and in the evening there was an exhibition of the Society of Inquiry and of the Porter Rhetorical Society in the Town Hall. Yesterday morning the Commencement exercises took place -- ELDRIDGE MIK, of Atwater, Ohio, delivering the salutatory, and CHARLES W. THOMPSON, of Montpelier, Vt., the valedictory. The graduating class numbers thirty-three, out of some thirty-six who originally entered. Of these, four or five have dedicated themselves to the foreign mission fields, six or seven to pastorates in the West, and five or six are called to pastorates in New-England.

abstract: The Charleston Mercury furnishes us with a column of indifferent composition to "show," it says, "the TIMES and its kindred bullying terrorists, that we of the South neither are the fools nor the cowards it supposes us to be." The argument shows the TIMES and ...
lead_paragraph: The Charleston Mercury furnishes us with a column of indifferent composition to "show," it says, "the TIMES and its kindred bullying terrorists, that we of the South neither are the fools nor the cowards it supposes us to be." The argument shows the TIMES and perhaps its shrewdly named associates in terrorism, that the Mercury is not guilty of cowardice; but the other indictment of folly and an additional one for excessively bad grammar remain to be tried. The latter offence, of which a specimen is supplied in the words we have quoted, we leave to the mercies of any volunteer Aristarchus. The folly it is better to investigate on the spot.

abstract: The circumstances attending the stabbing of HENRY PAEBLER, a German, 32 years of age, who died at Believue Hospital on Wednesday morning,  were yesterday investigated by Coroner JACKMAN. The inquest resulted in a verdict against ADAM JAGER, who inflicted the fatal injury. It appeared from the testimony of PHILIP RICHARD, a witness of the affray, that a difficulty between JAGER and deceased occurred at MEYER'S lager-bier saloon, in Third-street, on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: The circumstances attending the stabbing of HENRY PAEBLER, a German, 32 years of age, who died at Believue Hospital on Wednesday morning, were yesterday investigated by Coroner JACKMAN. The inquest resulted in a verdict against ADAM JAGER, who inflicted the fatal injury. It appeared from the testimony of PHILIP RICHARD, a witness of the affray, that a difficulty between JAGER and deceased occurred at MEYER'S lager-bier saloon, in Third-street, on Sunday night. JAGER was in the saloon, when his wife came and asked him to go home, but he refused to accompany her, and deceased thereupon remarked something which JAGER construed into an offence. Shortly afterwards witness and deceased left the place, and when near the corner of Avenue A and Third-street, witness saw JAGER and a man named FRIES coming toward them. Witness stopped and spoke to them, after which they remained talking together for some time. While thus engaged JAGER's watch dropped from his pocket and he accused all of them of a design to ro[???] him. In his rage he drew a knife and cut the back of PAEBLER's coat. The latter, however, did not know of the attempt to stab him, and started to go home, but had not proceeded far when witness told him of JAGER's act, and they immediately returned to where the prisoner stood. PAEBLER asked JAGER why he had stabbed him, when be again took out his knife and inflicted a terrible wound in PAEBLER's abdomen. He then ran away but was quickly overtaken and secured by Officer SCHIFF, of the Seventeenth Ward. Upon this testimony the Jury rendered a verdict to the effect that "HENRY PAEBLER came to his death by a stab at the hands of ADAM JAGER, and that the wound was wilfully inflicted." The accused is 23 years of age, a tailor by occupation, and a native of Germany. He declined to make any statement with reference to the charge against him, and was committed to the Tombs.

abstract: At 11 1/2 o'clock last night a fire broke out among some loose cotton in the basement of the extensive felt-hat manufactory of Mr. HENRY A. BURR, situated at the corner of Frankfort and Cliff streets. It was soon extinguished, but a quantity of furs, stored in the cellar were injured by water to the extent of a few hundred dollars. The loss is covered by insurance.

abstract: PATTI AT NEWPORT. New-York in the Summer means Newport. It means several other places also, of course; that is, to a certain extent. But it means supremely and particularly Newport, and this above all, in the month of August. Naturally, therefore, the Opera ...
lead_paragraph: PATTI AT NEWPORT. -- New-York in the Summer means Newport. It means several other places also, of course; that is, to a certain extent. But it means supremely and particularly Newport, and this above all, in the month of August. Naturally, therefore, the Opera goes to Newport, for the Opera follows New-York as the day the sun. And so PATTI, who, though lost so long to sound is still to memory dear, has gone to Newport, also, and when Newport is most itself -- that is when it is most New-York -- that is on the very middle of August, to wit the 14th -- PATTI will awaken fond recollections of the Winter that is past and bright hopes of the Winter that is to come, by singing her sweetest at the Ocean House. For Newport and New-York this is a pleasing piece of intelligence, whereof we beg that they will be good enough to "make a particular note."

abstract: NAPOLEON III. has once more struck a decisive blow at a decisive moment, and advanced the standard of France beyond the limits of that uncertain and misty chaos of opposing interests and incoherent notions which passes in the Europe of to-day for diplomacy.
lead_paragraph: NAPOLEON III. has once more struck a decisive blow at a decisive moment, and advanced the standard of France beyond the limits of that uncertain and misty chaos of opposing interests and incoherent notions which passes in the Europe of to-day for diplomacy. In 1856 France, at the head of civilized Europe, secured the admission of Turkey into the family of nations, imposed upon the Porte the obligations and threw around the throne of the Sultan the guarantees of the public law of Christendom. In 1860 France again puts herself at the head of civilized Europe, to decide whether the action of the Congress of Paris on the Turkish question can be maintained with justice to the people of the great empire over which that action provisionally confirmed the supremacy of the Osmanli, or whether the Ottoman has become finally "tolerable and act to be endured."

abstract: In the session of the Statistical Congress, held in London on the 18th ult., Lord BROUGHAM called upon Judge JERVIS to read the report from the United States. In coing so he said: "I exceedingly regret that the observations I made on the first day have been interpreted into something disrespectful to the United States. No one who has known me will accuse me of such an intention. I respect our brethren of the United States, even when I differ from them. When I called attention, in the presence of our friend, Mr. DALLAS, to the, in my opinion, important statistical fact, that a most respectable colored gentleman from Canada was a member of the Congress, I only called his attention to it just as I would the attention of our excellent friend the representative of the Brazils, who is here to-day; and God knows I do not entertain the slightest disrespect for the Brazils. I ought also to have called the attention of the Count DE RIPALDA (the Spanish representative) to the same subject; they have colonies, and they have persons of various colors in their possessions. I call his attention to it hereby. [Applause]

When I called attention, in the presence of our friend, Mr. DALLAS, to the, in my opinion, important statistical fact, that a most respectable colored gentleman from Canada was a member of the Congress, I only called his attention to it just as I would the attention of our excellent friend the representative of the Brazils, who is here to-day; and God knows I do not entertain the slightest disrespect for the Brazils. I ought also to have called the attention of the Count DE RIPALDA (the Spanish representative) to the same subject; they have colonies, and they have persons of various colors in their possessions. abstract: DEPARTURE OF THE GREAT EASTERN. -- The Great Eastern left her anchorage, in the North River, yesterday, at the hour appointed -- 6 o'clock P.M. A long time previous to weighing her anchor, the excursionists -- many of whom were Southern people who availed themselves of the opportunity to "say they had made a trip in the Great Eastern" -- continued to arrive on board by steam-tugs and small boats. The whole party numbered about two hundred persons. Small parties gathered on the adjoining piers, and others took passage on the Hoboken Ferry boats, to see her move. The facility with which she was rounded, her anchor weighed, and the whole ship got under headway, reflected credit on her pilot, Mr. MURPHY. She started slowly, and when opposite Jersey City fired two guns, first from her starboard, and next from her port quarter. Those intended as a compliment for the Cunarders were soon responded to, but there was no response from the shipping on the New-York side. She passed the Narrows about 7 o'clock P.M., and went over the bar about 2 o'clock, with a fresh breeze blowing from the southward. The entire absence of enthusiasm, and of the usual crowd to witness her departure were the general topic of conversation. In fact, the Cape May excursion, with its unlimited swindling, has, to use a vulgar, but expressive phrase, "played the great ship out;" Henceforward no individual will trust the Great Eastern under any circumstances, unless he is prepared to pay a dollar a basinfull for water. The "great ship" will reach Hampton Roads about five o'clock to-day. At 8 3/4 o'clock last night the Great Eastern was met and saluted by the steam-tug Jacob Bell, about ten miles from Sandy Hook and five miles off shore, under full headway, with screw and paddle going. The moon shone beautifully, and the steamer's appearance was very fine.

abstract: LAUNCH OF THE NEW FERRY BOAT. -- The new boat for the Jersey City Ferry, which we have before announced as in course of construction, was launched at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, from the yard of her builder, L. BURTIS, Esq., of Red Hook, L.I. As the boat touched the water, she was named the John P. Jackson. At 10 1/2 o'clock she was safely moored at HOWELL & RANDALL's boiler manufactory, foot of Morris-street, where she will receive her boilers. The John P. Jackson is 210 feet long, 33 1/2 feet beam, and is 800 tons burden. She is built in the most substantial manner, and will be finished in a style of elegance unequaled by any ferry-boat in the world. The engine, which is being built by WM. BIRBECK, at the Fulton Foundry, in Jersey City, is 45 inch cylinder and 11 feet stroke. The boat will be completed and put in use about the 15th of December. She will be able to accommodate 30 teams and 2,000 passengers.

abstract: Capt. JONES, through Major S[???]EDWICK, of the United States Army, writes to the War Department, dating from camp on the Arkansas River, 2d July 1860. He "regrets to report want of success in finding any trail of the hostile Kiowas or Comanches." The severe service "has used up the horses so badly that a protracted delay in camp will be necessary." When reinforcements reach him the Captain "will again cross the Arkansas and proceed up towards the mountains."

abstract: The Cunard steamship Asia, from Liverpool on the 21st and Queenstown on the 22d ult., arrived at this port yesterday afternoon. Her advices have been anticipated by the Prince Albert at St. Johns, but we derive from our correspondence and foreign files very interesting details of late foreign news.
lead_paragraph: The Cunard steamship Asia, from Liverpool on the 21st and Queenstown on the 22d ult., arrived at this port yesterday afternoon. Her advices have been anticipated by the Prince Albert at St. Johns, but we derive from our correspondence and foreign files very interesting details of late foreign news. Accounts from Italy are of an important character. GARIBALDI was daily receiving large reinforcements, and, it is said, his preparations for renewing the war are now complete. The disaffection of the officers of the Neapolitan navy is so great as to be a serious danger to the Government. The Paris Moniteur has officially announced that in consequence of the deplorable events in Syria the Emperor of the French has deemed it his duty "to communicate his views without delay to the Cabinets of the other Great Powers and to the Porte, in order to concert the measures which circumstances demand." It is reported that a large French force will be sent to Syria. Our London correspondent comments on a variety of interesting intelligence from the British Capital.

abstract: Dispatches relating to the emigration from Canton have been recently presented to the British Parliament, which possess considerable interest for ship owners in this country. It appears that the acts of violence and fraud connected with the Coolie trade had reached such a pitch in the Spring of 1859 as to excite a general feeling of alarm throughout the Chinese community, accompanied by a degree of effervescent popular indignation which rendered it impossible for the authorities any longer to remain inactive. Several known kidnappers were murdered in the streets by the mob of Canton, and the native merchants called loudly for the intervention of the foreign consuls to restrain the subjects of their respective governments from the acts complained of. The allied Commissioners at once instructed their police to aid in the suppression of kidnapping, and the Chinese Governor, PIH-KWEI, took measures for the same purpose, at the same time authorizing the voluntary emigration of Chinese, which had been till then prohibited. PIH-KWEI died before any system of legal emigration could be organized, but in November last the allied Commissioners succeeded in establishing at Canton a system which had the full consent and support of the Chinese authorities. Gov. LAON, the successor of PIH-KWEI, addressed both the allied Commissioners and the foreign Consuls, requesting them to bring the subject under the notice of their respective governments, in order that they might require all their subjects or citizens engaged in the coolie trade to conduct it in future under such regulations as the foreign Consuls and the local Chinese authorities might decide upon. The British Government established a house for the reception of emigrants for the British West Indies, under the direction of Mr. AUSTIN, who issued a public notice of the official character of his emigration, and of the conditions under which he was prepared to engage laborers. The engagement is for five years, terminable at any time after the expiration of the first year, on payment of a fair proportion of the passage money; and married emigrants are allowed to take their wives and children, free of charge, without any stipulation for their services.
lead_paragraph: Dispatches relating to the emigration from Canton have been recently presented to the British Parliament, which possess considerable interest for ship owners in this country. The British Government established a house for the reception of emigrants for the British West Indies, under the direction of Mr. AUSTIN, who issued a public notice of the official character of his emigration, and of the conditions under which he was prepared to engage laborers. The engagement is for five years, terminable at any time after the expiration of the first year, on payment of a fair proportion of the passage money; and married emigrants are allowed to take their wives and children, free of charge, without any stipulation for their services.

abstract: ANTHONY TROLLOPE promises to be as prolific as JAMES, DICKENS, or BULWER. He throws off volume after volume with starting rapidity; and, what is more, his novels are generally piquant, crisp and readable.
lead_paragraph: ANTHONY TROLLOPE promises to be as prolific as JAMES, DICKENS, or BULWER. He throws off volume after volume with starting rapidity; and, what is more, his novels are generally piquant, crisp and readable. His Doctor Thorne, Bertram, Three Clerks, West Indies and the Spanish Main, have found American publishers and readers at the instant of publication, and Castle Richmond follows close upon the heels of half a score of his dashing stories. In the intervals between the issue of his larger works, Mr. TEOLLOPE amuses himself by such light-skirmishing as the writing of a serial for THACKERAY's Cornhill and sketches for Harper's Monthly. A very active and very lively gentleman, he follows the path of literature with a keen zest, and is rarely anything else than jolly.

abstract: The game which was begun on a former occasion between these Clubs having been brought to an unsatisfactory conclusion by the rain, they met yesterday afternoon to settle the mooted question of superior skill; and after the full number of innings had been played out, it was shown that the Harlems had concluded to export the ball -- the pledge of victory -- to New-Jersey, the first one they have been compelled to deliver up this season. The Eurekas won golden opinions from the spectators for their brilliant fielding and successful batting, and the general opinion was they were inferior to no Club save the Excelsior, of Brooklyn. At any rate, they will never make a bad show against any players, and victory can be wrested from them only by strong and well-sustained exertions in the field and at the bar. On their side, all played creditably; but among the most prominent features of their fielding may be mentioned the base play of Northrop and Pennington, the former of whom made a very fine fly catch; the success of Collins at centre field, Linen's pitching, Van Houten's fielding as short stop, and Rogers' catching. Their batting was heavy and wonderfully safe, and when once started, they heaped up the runs quickly and surely, as in the third and eighth innings. Rogers, Linen and Van Houten were most fortunate in this respect, but Pennington, Collins and Northrop were scarcely inferior. Two fine home runs must be credited to Collins, one to Oliver and one to Van Houten, the last clearing the three bases of their occupants. On the Harlem side neither their fielding nor batting were fully up to the mark, though neither was positively bad, the only show of strong batting being made in the third and last innings, when they seemed to enter into it with hearty good will. In the field Liscomb, Marsh, Robertson. Freeborn and Hughes excelled, while Mackellar and Marsh were most successful, the latter making a home run.

abstract: The British residents of New-York are already moving in the matter of preparations for the becoming reception of the son of VICTORIA, when he shall turn his steps towards the commercial Metropolis of America.
lead_paragraph: The British residents of New-York are already moving in the matter of preparations for the becoming reception of the son of VICTORIA, when he shall turn his steps towards the commercial Metropolis of America. Although the Prince of Wales will visit us, as the Japanese have it, nay-boon -- coming among us in the modest guise of a young British nobleman -- yet it would be the height of affectation, and something worse than an impropriety, to suffer him to leave our shores without some becoming and generous public manifestation of the very sincere good will felt by the immense majority of intelligent Americans towards the great nation over which he will probably one day be called to reign. The subjects of his illustrious mother may rely upon it, that whether they entertain their Prince at a grand ball, or wine and dine him in social state, they will have the ready sympathy and support in any reasonable manifestations of loyalty and respect, of the great community in the midst of which they live. This is so well assured to them, indeed, that we trust they will take in good part the hope which we cannot refrain from expressing, that special pains may be taken to avoid stamping upon any affections which may be offered to Lord REN[???]EW in New-York, an intensely or even a predominantly British and national character.

abstract: We fear, that with the best intentions in the world, our New-York Postmaster and the Washington authorities are advancing backward in the very important matter of the metropolitan postal delivery.
lead_paragraph: We fear, that with the best intentions in the world, our New-York Postmaster and the Washington authorities are advancing backward in the very important matter of the metropolitan postal delivery. The Practical result of the complicated system of prepayment adopted under the new arrangements now in force threatens to be a general mutiny against the Government post, and a riotous return per fas aut nefas to the system of private expresses. It is certainly intolerable that, after undertaking to reduce the cost and expedite the time of the postal delivery within the City limits, the Government should be found taxing the intercourse of society more heavily than before, and yet retarding its movement. As at present administered, he must be a bold man who will undertake to say what amount of money represented in Government stamps on the back of a letter dropped into one of the Government boxes at noon to-day in Walll-street, will secure its delivery in Madison-square at break-fast time to-morrow. Instances have been repeatedly brought to our notice in which notes bearing a three-cent stamp have been handed in to the person whose address they bore branded with a demand "for one cent additional." As the Government has undertaken to destroy at one blow both the business of the private expresses established in the City and the facilities which these expresses offered to the correspondence of our citizens, it is surely its duty to see that the citizens at least shall not suffer by its zeal. The New-York Post-office exists for New-York, not New-York for the Post-office. It is of very little importance comparatively to us who shall take charge of our correspondence, but of very great importance that our correspondence shall be well cared for, economically, promptly and safely. In Great Britain and France, and particularly in the former country, the Government has frankly recognized this fact, and the people of London and Paris enjoy, in consequence, a postal system which shames New-York back by the contrast into the days before ROWLAND HILL.

abstract: The price of gas, in this City, is altogether too high. Since the reduction, three or four years ago, from $3 to the present rate, the economies of the manufacture have made no small progress, and the charge for this exten- ...
lead_paragraph: The price of gas, in this City, is altogether too high. Since the reduction, three or four years ago, from $3 to the present rate, the economies of the manufacture have made no small progress, and the charge for this extensively-used article being now higher in New-York than in Boston, Philadelphia, and some other cities, the public will not be surprised to learn that our Gas Companies are beginning to feel the pressure from without, especially as considerable excitement has been recently produced relative to gas exactions, and one or two new Companies are starting up and threatening to put an end to the long-enjoyed monopoly. The Manhattan Company has just referred the price of gas to a Special Committee, and there is little doubt of an early change. Two dollars per thousand cubic feet is the rate which will probably be fixed. A lower price has in some quarters been looked for. But, so long as most of the coal distilled has to be brought here from mines 3,000 miles off, there is but little chance of any but inferior coal-gas being supplied in this City, at a price below that we have named. In London the rate charged is about $1 08, and as most of our gas-making requisites have to be purchased in Europe, the first cost of gas here amounts, at present, to about twice as much as in the capital of Great Britain. If, then, our Gas Companies will supply a pure, rich article, at $2, the public, in the existing state of the manufacture, will not be disposed to complain, and the increased consumption induced cannot fail to render the change advantageous to all parties. Until coal-gas is discarded, and we see the general introduction of some method for the cheap production of illuminating gas from other materials, a further decrease in price can scarcely fail to involve some mischievous falling off in quality.
headline: {'main': 'The Gas Question.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Gas Question.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: To-day it becomes our painful duty to announce the death of Brevet-Major Morton Fairchild, one of the New-York Volunteers. Major Fairchild attained his rank in the service for exemplary bravery during the Mexican War. He rose from the ranks, and was deemed by many worthy of the much coveted Jackson Medal, left by the hero of New-Orleans for the bravest man from New-York in the war succeeding his death. On the occasion of the contest before the Common Council Committee, in this City, for the possession of the medal, Major Fairchild advocated the merits of a fellow soldier, and modestly declined to forward his own claims. Major Fairchild was a member of the Scott Life Guard, and of the Order of Odd Fellows, and held a position for some time in the Custom-House. He has been ailing for several years, never having completely recovered from the effects of the Mexican climate. He was 54 years of age at the time of his death. The members of the various organizations with which he was connected, meet at the Eighth Regiment Armory the evening, to make arrangements for the funeral, which takes place on Monday, at 2 o'clock P.M., from the Governor's Room, City Hall.

abstract: There was sold, on July 21st, at the auction rooms of Messrs. PUTTICK  SIMPSON, in London, at the conclusion of the sale of the library of the late Mr. E.A. CROWNINGHIELD, of Boston, a most interesting and extensive collection of American ...
lead_paragraph: There was sold, on July 21st, at the auction rooms of Messrs. PUTTICK SIMPSON, in London, at the conclusion of the sale of the library of the late Mr. E.A. CROWNINGHIELD, of Boston, a most interesting and extensive collection of American autographs, including several of WASHIGNTON, ADAMS, ARNOLD, FEANKLIN, GATES, PUTNAM, and other great men of the era of Independence. The gem of the collection, however, was an unpublished letter of Gen. WASHIGNTON, of even greater historical interest than the one which was sold a short time since, in the same rooms, for [???]15. It is addressed to Hon. R.DINWIDDIR. Governor of Virginia, and is dated Winchester, Oct. 17, 1753. WASHIGNTON was at that time a Captain in the British service, his commission as Major being dated Oct. 31, in the same year. The French had, at that time, formed the design of uniting Canada and Louisiana, and inclosing the British colonies in America by means of drawing the Indian tribes under their influence. WASHINGTON was deputed by Gov. DINWIDDIE to remonstrate against the alleged encroachment and violation of treaty obligations. The interesting letter to which we have to call attention, was written before he received that mission, and evinces the far-seeing policy of the future first President of the United States. The letter is as follows:

abstract: Yesterday morning a train of cars on the Long Island Railroad, which left Syosset shortly after 7 o'clock, when near New-Brooklyn at 9 , ran over a cow which came on the track.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning a train of cars on the Long Island Railroad, which left Syosset shortly after 7 o'clock, when near New-Brooklyn at 9 1/2, ran over a cow which came on the track. The locomotive was thrown off, and ran tearing along about 100 yards, when it fell over on the side and became an entire wreck. A milk car, next the locomotive, was also thrown off, and an adjoining baggage car completely crushed. There were three passenger cars, of which the most forward was turned upon end and broken. JAMES LYNCH, 30 years of age, the fireman, was thrown under the engine and killed. DAVID EIDER, the engineer, was struck on the back, and it is thought fatally injured. SAMUEL CHESHIRE, conductor, was on the platform of one of the passenger cars when the accident happened, and was thrown against a brake-wheel and severely, though not seriously, injured. No other personal damage resulted beyond a few bruises. The escape of the passengers, 125 in number, was very narrow. The fireman, LYNCH, who was killed, lived at Jamaica, and leaves a little child. Through the energetic movements of Mr. MORRIS, the President of the Company, the track was cleared in two or three hours after the accident. One side of it is torn up for several hundred feet.

abstract: ATTEMPTED SUICIDE. -- ROBERT LECKIE yesterday morning attempted suicide at the Union Hotel in Liberty-street, by cutting his throat with a razor. He was found in his room with his windpipe severed and deep cuts on his left elbow and both wrists. He was taken to the Medical and Surgical Institute in Washington-street, and attended by Dr. BANER. It is thought he will recover, notwithstanding the serious nature of his wounds. He is a Scotchman, somewhat advanced in life. He was at one time an importer, and at another a broker in New-York. He has latterly suffered from pecuniary trouble, which fact probably stimulated him to the nearly fatal act. He has a brother formerly connected with the East India service.

abstract: THE LATE INCENDIARY FIRMS AT POUGHKEEPSIE. Two or three attempts have been made by incepdiaries to set buildings on fire at Poughkeepsie, since the late destructive ones in that city, but without success. On one occasion they were chased by a...
lead_paragraph: THE LATE INCENDIARY FIRMS AT POUGHKEEPSIE. -- Two or three attempts have been made by incepdiaries to set buildings on fire at Poughkeepsie, since the late destructive ones in that city, but without success. On one occasion they were chased by a a man who caught them in the act of setting me to a building at thelower landing, but they outran him and escaped. The two who were arrested for cutting the hose have since been let out on bail. Two or three nights since, a man was prowling about the stables at the corner of Washington and Lafayette streets. He was spoken to twice but did not answer, when a pistol was fired at him without effect. Before he could be fired upon again he had turned the corner of the building and escaped. A dog which he had with him at the time, first gave the alarm. Owing to the late sericus fires in this city, a number of night watchmen have been employed to watch property, and it is probable that if any incendiary now makes his appearance in Poughkeepsie, he will meet with a very warm reception. Many of those who were burred out have started business again. There has been considerable talk of late of procuring a steam fire-engine for the city. The following notice is posted all over Poughkeepsie:

abstract: Sundry correspondents are very anxious to know how the Great Eastern "gets over" our coasting laws, and converts herself into a passenger vessel between American ports.
lead_paragraph: -- Sundry correspondents are very anxious to know how the Great Eastern "gets over" our coasting laws, and converts herself into a passenger vessel between American ports. We can only presume that the leviathan slips over our laws as she slips over our bar, by American aid. Mr. MURPHY pilots her over the one; the general goodwill of the public probably carries her over the other. Still, as the Directors have done their best to destroy this general good-will, it may be worth while to take the matter up solemnly, and send the said Directors home again without their ship, "forfeited for violation of the American revenue laws." Once in our power, we might give the splendid vessel a thorough cleaning, refit and refurnish her throughout with American elegance and comfort, and then with music and a grand ball politely present her, in the name of the Republic, to his Royal Highness the Prince of Wales, for his return trip.

abstract: A volume dedicated, like this, to "all lovers and friends of Nature," might resonably be expected to furnish a natural account of the subject whereof it treats; an account divested of truisms ...
lead_paragraph: A volume dedicated, like this, to "all lovers and friends of Nature," might resonably be expected to furnish a natural account of the subject whereof it treats; an account divested of truisms and destitute of platitudes, and so fresh and free and graceful that no reader who loves Nature would willingly pass it by. What May be Learned, &c., gives no such account. On the contrary, although starting out with a fair promise, it lapses speedily and irrecoverably into the dismal dullness of commonplace. The author seems to have devoted numerous hours of contemplative leisure to the minute inspection of trunks, branches, leaves, soils and organisms, and all other things connected in any way with the growth of trees, until he had hammered out a sufficient array of words to make a book; and then the book was made. In parts, hut scattered at wide intervals, there are bits of fair writing, and occasionally we get a fleeting glimpse of an idea, -- but the bulk of the volume consists of such namby-pamby talk as the following:

abstract: Some sensation has just been created at Liverpool by the appearance in that port of a  vessel bearing the Liberian flag.
lead_paragraph: Some sensation has just been created at Liverpool by the appearance in that port of a vessel bearing the Liberian flag. It was the Eusebia N. Roye, a brig well-known in New-York waters, as the property of a gentleman who had earned merited wealth by more than Yankee enterprise; and whose principal object in visiting this harbor time and again was to secure such treatment for the commerce of the only American colony as it had obtained at the hands of other important Powers. For there is nothing about Liberia that is not American. Nine-tenths of its population, even accepting the widest latitude of boundary claimed by its Government, were born in the United States; the Republic was established by Americans shocked at the evils of Slavery; and when the actual Government of the United States has African captives on its hands, it has no scruple in adding them to the population of this dependent commonwealth.

abstract: According to the returns already received at the Census Bureau at Washington, the crops in all the Northern and Northwestern States are immensely heavy this year.
lead_paragraph: According to the returns already received at the Census Bureau at Washington, the crops in all the Northern and Northwestern States are immensely heavy this year. In Pennsylvania they are represented to be nearly if not quite double those of last year, and in other States they will probably be correspondingly heavy. This fully coincides with what we have been led to expect from the accounts which have reached us from other sources. The census returns, however, come in very slowly, and it will probably be some time before we shall be able to learn the full extent of our agricultural prosperity, although Superintendent KENNEDY manifests a commendable desire to satisfy the public curiosity on the subject at the earliest possible moment.

abstract: THE HALF-CENTURY SERMON OF REV. DR.SPRING,OF THE BRICK CHURCH. -- To-morrow, Rev. Dr. GARDNER SPRING, of the Old Brick Church, once in Beekman-street, but now of the church corner of Thirty-seventh-street and Fifth-avenue, will, in the latter edifice, preach his "half-century" sermon. Such a discourse falls to the lot of few ministers to deliver, or of few congregations to hear. Dr. SPRING has been so intimately connected with the growth of the City, so familiar with its changes and improvements, so intimate with its inhabitants -- (how many of them he has seen buried!) -- and has done such good service, not alone as a devoted minister of religion for fifty years, but as a man of education, progress, science, philanthropy, and whatever else is honorable during all that time, that he is entitled to be considered one of the most notable living "man-marks" of Manhattan Island. That his church tomorrow morning will be crowded, and that all that survive of the friends of half a century will be present, will be a matter of coarse. Every true New-Yorker who honors himself, will honor Dr. SPRING on this occasion.

abstract: Another contribution to medical literature is The Movement-Cure, just published by FOWLER  WELLS. The author is Dr. GEORGE H. TAYLOR, physician to the "Remedial Hygienic Institute" of this City.
lead_paragraph: -- Another contribution to medical literature is The Movement-Cure, just published by FOWLER WELLS. The author is Dr. GEORGE H. TAYLOR, physician to the "Remedial Hygienic Institute" of this City. The so-called movement-cure was introduced to the notice of a long-suffering and diseased public by PETER HENRY LING, a Swede, to whom the Swedish Government gave countenance and support some forty years ago. The author of this work visited Sweden, for the purpose of drinking directly from the fountain of curative wisdom, just as the water-cure disciples visited PRIFSSNITZ to take courses of wet-sheets. He returned fully charged with admiration of the practice of LING, and forthwith indited this book, in explanation and advocacy of the new system. The movement-cure, as herein expounded and illustrated, consists of a series of gymnastic exercises; the medical use of one's limbs and contortions of the body being the means relied upon for conquering all the ills of feeble frames. The sick, who may have tried, to their disgust, the relative virtues of allopathy, homeopathy, hydropathy, Galvanism, and half a dozen other methods of treatment, will find in Dr. TAYLOR's book full directions for a new series of experiments, -- if they have courage to undertake the task. It is not clear that a season at a gymnasium would not be the best "movement " cure. -- for LING's system is merely exercise in calisthenics -- nothing more.

abstract: FACING BOTH WAYS. -- That small and rapidly diminishing number of the faithful, who accept the Herald as their oracle, now and then find themselves in embarrassing straits. Not only are they continually called upon to turn corners so acute as to require the utmost agility to keep up with the march of their tangential leaders, but they are steadily put through a curious course of drill intended to perfect them in the singular art of facing both ways at the same moment; an art which might have its terrors, even in the eyes of a Chicago Zouave. On Saturday morning, for instance, the exacting Mokanna whom these poor people worship, made these two distinct and oracular declarations. Apropos of things political in general, he spake as follows:

abstract: Mr. DICKINSON, as already announced by telegraph, left Washington on Thursday afternoon for Baltimore. On his arrival, he took quarters at the City Hotel.
lead_paragraph: Mr. DICKINSON, as already announced by telegraph, left Washington on Thursday afternoon for Baltimore. On his arrival, he took quarters at the City Hotel. Immediately on his arrival being announced, considerable stir was manifested by his political friends, who called in large numbers during the early part of the evening. Shortly alter 10 o'clock, the "Zouave Band" took a position on Fayette-street, their services having been secured by the friends of Mr. DICKINSON, and proceeded to discourse many enlivening airs. This had the effect of collecting a considerable crowd, and loud calls were made for DICKINSON. He at length appeared on the second story balcony of the hotel, and being introduced by Judge MASON, spoke as follows:

abstract: Yesterday morning, Rev. Dr. GARDINER SPRING whose services as a pastor and guardian have been for half a century so intimately connected with the religious consolations and pleasant memories of our citizens, as well of these who have long since gone to their rest, as of those who happily survive, preached his semi-centennial sermon in the new Brick Church, in Fifth-avenue. The old Brick Church, at the corner of Park-row and Beekman-street, was not quite a century old when it was demolished, but for upwards of forty-seven years its pulpit was filled by Dr. SPRING, and our grandfathers and grandmothers there listened to him, the then young and rising preacher, to whom their grandchildren yesterday paid the most respectful attention, as their benevolent and venerable friend. Few such occasions transpire in our brief lives, and when they do, they command commemoration and remembrance.

Few such occasions transpire in our brief lives, and when they do, they command commemoration and remembrance.

abstract: "In reply to the inquiries addressed to us, we are authorized to say that Mr. SEWARD will meet the Republicans of Michigan on Saturday, Sept. 1; of Wisconsin, on Saturday, Sept. 8; of Minnesota, on Saturday, Sept. 15.
lead_paragraph: "In reply to the inquiries addressed to us, we are authorized to say that Mr. SEWARD will meet the Republicans of Michigan on Saturday, Sept. 1; of Wisconsin, on Saturday, Sept. 8; of Minnesota, on Saturday, Sept. 15. On his return he will fill engagements already made, by calling in the State of Illinois, where the State Committee shall appoint, and also at Cleveland, in Ohio, Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, and at Fredonia and Le Roy, in this State. The days for these latter places are to be determined when he shall have ascertained the probable time required in the Northwest."

abstract: ANNUAL EXCURSION OF THE SUN EMPLOYES  RETIREMENT OF MR. BEACH FROM THAT PAPER.  The annual excursion of the employes of the Sun office, together with their families and friends, came off on Saturday last at Glenwood.
lead_paragraph: ANNUAL EXCURSION OF THE SUN EMPLOYES -- RETIREMENT OF MR. BEACH FROM THAT PAPER. -- The annual excursion of the employes of the Sun office, together with their families and friends, came off on Saturday last at Glenwood. The steamer Mayflower was chartered for the occasion, and Dodworth's Cotillion Band was in attendance' so that the trip up the river was highly enjoyed by all on board. By the time the excursionists reached the grove of Glenwood the sun, after a moderate shower, was shining brightly, and in a short time the grass and leaves were dry enough to admit of the usual pic-nic sports, which were carried on animatedly until the middle of the afternoon. Mr. M.S. BEACH then addressing his audience, stating that he felt pained at having to announce to them that he was no longer proprietor of the Sun, but that Mr. WM. C. CHURCH would hereafter occupy that position, and he could endorse him as promising to be to those in his employ all that he (the speaker) had striven to be -- a faithful friend, kind, considerate and just. The announcement being wholly unexpected to all connected with the establishment, caused great surprise and sorrow. Mr. CHURCH briefly and appropriately addressed his hearers, stating that he would certainly endeavor to render himself as dear to those about him as he was happy to observe Mr. BEACH had been, and he hoped that he would be successful in meriting Mr. BEACH's indorsement. Three cheers were given for the new and three for the old proprietor, and at an early hour the excursionists returned to the City.

abstract: -- The New-York correspondent of the Mobile Register relates the following: Recently a gentleman returned from Europe; he had been absent with his family seven months. He paid his gas bill the day he left, and the house had not been opened for seven months, yet when it was, the gas man took a return from the meter, and a bill was made out for $52. Mr. GRINNELL went and complained to the Secretary, related the circumstances, and threatened exposure of such a barefaced robbery. He refused to pay the bill. "Very well, sir," said the Secretary. Mr. G. went home and told his wife. "Pay it," said she. "Why so?" said he. "Because," said she, "the day we left New-York, I had to go back to the house for some article I had forgot. The window-shutters were fastened; I lit the gas; the other day when we returned I found it still burning." The bill was paid, for a steady gas flamer had been burning for seven months. Gas stocks pay a heavy dividend.
lead_paragraph: -- The New-York correspondent of the Mobile Register relates the following: Recently a gentleman returned from Europe; he had been absent with his family seven months. The window-shutters were fastened; I lit the gas; the other day when we returned I found it still burning." The bill was paid, for a steady gas flamer had been burning for seven months. abstract: THE CITY POSTAL DELIVERY. -- We have received an elaborate communication on the subject of the new system of City letter-carriage which we publish in another part of this paper. The writer very justly remarks that it "is hard to make a thing understood," and illustrates this truth admirably by leaving us just as much in the dark as to the prospects of the public service under the system now in force as we were when we complained on Saturday morning of the unsatisfactory working of the new arrangements. He gives us, indeed, a very fair idea of the origin of these arrangements, and shows that Mr. DIX is in no manner responsible for them, except as an Administrative officer, charged to carry out the orders of the Post-office Department. But he by no means explains to us how it comes to pass that a prepayment of three cents upon a letter, which the Government undertakes to deliver for one cent, fails to carry the said letter to its destination. Another correspondent, whose communication also we publish to-day refers to no less than three instances of this phenomenon, as occurring within his own experience. We cannot think that in the face of such facts, society can be truly said "to stand just where it did before the private expresses were discontinued." Indeed, we have no reason for supposing that while the private expresses were still in operation, the Government found it either necessary or desirable to demand four cents for doing work covenanted to be done for one.
lead_paragraph: THE CITY POSTAL DELIVERY. -- We have received an elaborate communication on the subject of the new system of City letter-carriage which we publish in another part of this paper. The writer very justly remarks that it "is hard to make a thing understood," and illustrates this truth admirably by leaving us just as much in the dark as to the prospects of the public service under the system now in force as we were when we complained on Saturday morning of the unsatisfactory working of the new arrangements. He gives us, indeed, a very fair idea of the origin of these arrangements, and shows that Mr. DIX is in no manner responsible for them, except as an Administrative officer, charged to carry out the orders of the Post-office Department. But he by no means explains to us how it comes to pass that a prepayment of three cents upon a letter, which the Government undertakes to deliver for one cent, fails to carry the said letter to its destination. Another correspondent, whose communication also we publish to-day refers to no less than three instances of this phenomenon, as occurring within his own experience. We cannot think that in the face of such facts, society can be truly said "to stand just where it did before the private expresses were discontinued." Indeed, we have no reason for supposing that while the private expresses were still in operation, the Government found it either necessary or desirable to demand four cents for doing work covenanted to be done for one.

abstract: Much remark was recently excited in England by the fact that the British Association for the Advancement of Science declined to discuss the merits of Mr. DARWIN'S new theory of the origin of species.
lead_paragraph: Much remark was recently excited in England by the fact that the British Association for the Advancement of Science declined to discuss the merits of Mr. DARWIN'S new theory of the origin of species. The doctrine of Mr. DARWIN had been enounced, in the course of the preceding Winter, long enough before the meeting of the Association, to have provoked discussion, both popular and scientific, in all parts of the world. Coming from one of the most accomplished and respected of living naturalists, as the result of twenty years of unrelaxing study, travel and experiment, it could not fail to command the attention of the whole scientific guild, and not for these reasons alone, but also because the doctrine was at once novel in itself, in conflict with established beliefs, and seemed to offer solutions for a thousand difficulties which beset theories currently received. Review, magazine and newspaper had in turn expressed their more or less enlightened opinions of the book; but to the great annual conference of British science popular expectation was directed, as the criterion of the real scientific value of the discovery. The Association, to the disappointment of everybody, adjourned without passing any judgment upon the subject; in fact, it was only noticed cursorily, as furnishing an opportunity for a Bishop of the English Church to denounce its heretical tendencies. This denunciation seems to have stifled discussion; and a theory, which, whether true or false, is destined to distinguish the current year in the history of natural science, has not even been recognized by the most imposing scientific body of the period.
headline: {'main': 'The Advance of Science.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Advance of Science.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Prime Minister of Queen VICTORIA has given official voice, at last, to those fears of France, and that distrust of the Emperor NAPOLEON, which have been growing upon the public mind of England ever since the Crimean war made Paris once more the centre of the politics of Europe.
lead_paragraph: The Prime Minister of Queen VICTORIA has given official voice, at last, to those fears of France, and that distrust of the Emperor NAPOLEON, which have been growing upon the public mind of England ever since the Crimean war made Paris once more the centre of the politics of Europe. Lord PALMERSTON, the recognized champion of the Anglo-French Alliance, and the twice-consecrated martyr of his faith in the ruler of France, has announced on the floor of Parliament, and with financial emphasis, his conviction that England can no longer re y upon continued peace with hertoo powerful neighbor across the Channel, and that the political "horizon is charged with clouds which betoken the possibility of a tempest." The most British of British statesmen, the "pluckiest" of Ministers, and not the least boastful of orators, has been forced to avow that France stands to-day to her British ally in the attitude of the stronger Power, and as such may "expect a submission which the weaker Power may not be disposed to give." What unrevealed secrets of the Foreign Office lower behind these simple but ominous words, it may not be difficult for those who have carefully followed the recent course of European politics to conjecture. In the internal condition of Germany; in the unsettled questions of Italy and of the East; in the revival of the power of Spain; France has interests at stake, and an influence to be asserted which must inevitably come into conflict with the interests and the influence of England, if England is still to be governed as Whigs and Tories seem alike to agree that she shall be, by the traditions of 1815. The hope of peace for the world has lain for years in the prospect that these traditions might wear out their own life in England before France could become strong enough to insist upon their disappearance from the policy of the British Government. Upon this prospect, it seems, we are no longer to count. The most conspicuous friend of the French Imperial Government in England, whether as a sacrifice on the altar of political expediency or as the result of serious convictions matters little to the present purpose, has formally indicted the strength of France as a terror for England. The British Premier has given all the sanction of his high office and of his personal reputation to the doctrine that England has a right to decide how large an army France has a right to keep in the field, and that a positive "naval superiority to all other Powers is absolutely necessary to the existence of England as a nation." The importance of such language, from such a source, cannot easily be over-estimated, and the speech made by Lord PALMERSTON on the 23d of July may, without exaggeration, be described as a new and formidable cloud upon that horizon of which it professedly laments the dark and ominous aspect, and the "ragged rims of thunder, brooding low."

abstract: The consecration of the new synagogue of the congregation B'nai Israel, located on the corner of Stanton and Forsyth streets, took place yesterday afternoon. The building, which is capable of holding about 800 people, was formerly a Baptist Church, but has recently been purchased, and converted into a synagogue by the above congregation, most of whom are natives of Holland.
lead_paragraph: The consecration of the new synagogue of the congregation B'nai Israel, located on the corner of Stanton and Forsyth streets, took place yesterday afternoon. The building, which is capable of holding about 800 people, was formerly a Baptist Church, but has recently been purchased, and converted into a synagogue by the above congregation, most of whom are natives of Holland. The interior transformations required to convert it into a synagogue were not extensive or costly -- the only change being a shifting of the position of the pows, so as to leave a space for the "reading desk" in the centre of the church, and the erection of a semioircular ark in the place of the pulpit. The reading desk is the same as that used in the old synagogue of this congregation, in Christie-street, made of rosewood, and surrounded by an inclosure, or railing, about ten feet square, and of elegant workmanship. On the four corners of the inclosure are gas fixtures, in imitation of candies, and over head depends a magnificent bronze chandelier, with numerous jets, all of which were kept burning during the consecration service. The "Ark" is also made of rosewood, with sliding doors, and, when closed, is screened from public view by rich damask curtains, which were presented by the ladies of the congregation.

abstract: A NEW SWINDLING DODGE. On Friday, Sergeant LEICH, of the Ninth Precinct, arrested a German named LEFORT on a charge of defrauding Mr. DOLCIUS and Mr. MOORE, of the Eastern District, in the sum of $325.
lead_paragraph: A NEW SWINDLING DODGE. -- On Friday, Sergeant LEICH, of the Ninth Precinct, arrested a German named LEFORT on a charge of defrauding Mr. DOLCIUS and Mr. MOORE, of the Eastern District, in the sum of $325. His mode of proceeding is thus described: Being proprietor of a sowing machine establishment in Orange-street, he would advertise for a partner, and to the person replying would make representations as to the magnitude of the business carried on. He would agree to give the applicant an interest on the latter putting in five machines, to be purchased at a specified place. When the machines were brought to the factory they were seized by a confederate of the accused and carried off, to satisfy a claim under an alleged judgment. For the machines purchased $65 each was paid.

abstract: Elections take place, to-day, in Missouri, Arkansas, Kentucky, Alabama, and Texas. In the firstnamed of these States, a Governor, State officers, and seven members of Congress are to be chosen.
lead_paragraph: Elections take place, to-day, in Missouri, Arkansas, Kentucky, Alabama, and Texas. In the firstnamed of these States, a Governor, State officers, and seven members of Congress are to be chosen. Four candidates are in the field for Governor, viz.: HANCOCK JACKSON, Breckinridge Democrat; CLAIBORNE F. JACKSON, Douglas Democrat; SAMPLE ORR, Union; and JAMES B GARDENHIEE, Republican. The Democratic Convention, held previous to the Charleston Convention, nominated C. F. JACKSON, for Governor; but, as he recently came out for DOUGLAS,the Breckinridge men advanced HANCOCK JACKSON. abstract: The steamship Australasian, which arrived at this port on Saturday evening, brings us European advices to the 25th ult., and the Kangaroo, which arrived off Cape Race on Saturday, to the 26th.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Australasian, which arrived at this port on Saturday evening, brings us European advices to the 25th ult., and the Kangaroo, which arrived off Cape Race on Saturday, to the 26th. The news by these arrivals is highly interesting and important. From Syria we learn that peace had been restored between the Druses and the Maronites, the latter of whom there seems to be good reason for charging with the original responsibility of their own disasters, and that the Porte had protested against the intervention of France. It is also reported that the Syrian question will be dealt with summarily in a Conference of the Powers at Paris. Sicily had been entirely evacuated by the Royal troops, and GARIBALDI, in whose councils the MAZZINI misleaders seem to be gaining a perilous influence, was supposed to be on the point of passing over into Calabria. The interest of the public, however, will be partially drawn away from the Syrian and Sicilian questions by a very remarkable speech of Lord PALMERSTON on the national defenses, which had caused a fall of the funds at Paris, and provoked strong expressions of dissatisfaction from Mr. BRIGHT and Mr. BERNAL OSBORNS, the latter of whom declared that cordial relations between France and England had been made impossible by the language of the Premier.

abstract: The Belgian Chamber of Deputies had presented an address to the King, congratulating him on the completion of the twenty-ninth year of his reign. The address attracted attention from the fact that it condemns in strong terms, the aggressive policy of France, and indirectly appeals to Europe for protection against French designs. The address was adopted unanimously and enthusiastically.

abstract: One very grave error was impressed upon the public mind by the returns of the census of 1850, and, doubtless, will again be by those of that now gathered, owing to an attempt to collect statistics upon a subject which experience has proved to be unattainable by mere inquiry from house to house.
lead_paragraph: One very grave error was impressed upon the public mind by the returns of the census of 1850, and, doubtless, will again be by those of that now gathered, owing to an attempt to collect statistics upon a subject which experience has proved to be unattainable by mere inquiry from house to house. We allude to the statistics of mortality, by which the state of the public health must be measured. No subject can be of greater importance than this, inasmuch as "national health is national wealth;" and yet there is no subject, perhaps, upon which the census returns have been, and probably again will be, more defective. And the inhabitants of sundry cities or wards are, doubtless, already flattering themselves with the idea of the small number of deaths reported, and their apparently sound sanitary condition, who, were the true figures known, would be using every exertion to diminish the high state of mortality which actually prevails amongst them.
headline: {'main': 'The Census Some Inevitable Errors.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Census Some Inevitable Errors.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: An inquest was held at the Almshouse, Blackwell's Island, by Coronor Gamble, on the body of Lorenzo Faber, a German, 60 years of age, whose death is alleged to have been hastened by violence inflicted by Wm. Santey. These men occupied a room together, and on the 3d inst. a dispute arose between them in relation to having the door of their room open.
lead_paragraph: An inquest was held at the Almshouse, Blackwell's Island, by Coronor Gamble, on the body of Lorenzo Faber, a German, 60 years of age, whose death is alleged to have been hastened by violence inflicted by Wm. Santey. These men occupied a room together, and on the 3d inst. a dispute arose between them in relation to having the door of their room open. During the quarrel, Faber struck Santey a blow with his fist, which so aroused the ire of the latter that he seized a stick and struck his assailant several powerful brows on the head. At the time, deceased was suffering from congestion of the lungs, and the violence inflicted so aggravated the diseases that death ensued. A verdict of death from congestion of the lungs, hastened by injuries inflicted by Wm. Santey, was rendered by the jury. Santey, who is a man 72 years of age, is now in custody at the Almshouse, where he will await the action of the Grand Jury. The prisoner admits striking the deceased, but says he did it in self defence.

abstract: The leading jewelers of Boston, says the Traveller of that city, have been slightly excited the past week, in consequence of the mysterious disappearance of one LOUIS GOLDENBERG, a German Jew, born in Russia, a jeweler by trade, for ten years a resident of this country, and for the last six years in the employ ...
lead_paragraph: The leading jewelers of Boston, says the Traveller of that city, have been slightly excited the past week, in consequence of the mysterious disappearance of one LOUIS GOLDENBERG, a German Jew, born in Russia, a jeweler by trade, for ten years a resident of this country, and for the last six years in the employ of Messrs. CURRIER & TROTT, as a watch, repairer with a liberal salary. His employers had every confidence in him, and his standing with the trade and the community generally was of the highest character. Some time since Mr. GOLDENBERG informed his employers that he had teen authorized by a friend to get up a costly article of Masonic jewelry, and as they had no diamonds of the quality wanted, they allowed him to go to New-York to select them, giving him letters to their correspondents in that City. He brought back from New-York about $1,000 worth of diamonds, from which he selected several of the value of $350, for his purpose. But now commenced the most extraordinary part of this affair. Taking these jewels, he went round to the leading jewelers, and stating that his friend who had employed him to make up the Masonic Emblem, though perfectly good, was for the moment short of the cash required to get up the article, has borrowed from one place and another, in sums varying from $300 down to $75, about $1,200 or $1,500. In this way six prominent jewelers were swindled. In one case he employed a journeyman jeweler to manufacture about one hundred rings, which were delivered, and in consequence they are a total loss to the industrious manufacturer. But his operations did not stop here. He went round to his personal friends, who had the greatest confidence in his good character, and borrowed of one and another on similar grounds, until the total reached nearly five thousand dollars. In one case he victimized an old shipmaster to the tune of $800. In a number of cases, as a slight token of his appreciation of the "accommodation," he insisted upon taking the valuable watches of his respective friends, for gratuitous cleaning, thus relieving them of both time and money. Having in a brief period accumulated together a little fortune, he informed a neighbor last Friday that in the absence of his wife, who had gone into the country, he felt quite lonely and should follow her, which he did, without, however, the slightest knowledge on the part of any one of his rather extensive operations. Since that time he has not been seen by his friends, who are unable to obtain any particulars as to his whereabouts. He is about 55 years of age, and has a wife and several children.

abstract: These Clubs played a fly-game of Base Ball on Saturday, on the Putnams' ground, which terminated,  after some fine play on both sides, in favor of the Excelsiors.
lead_paragraph: These Clubs played a fly-game of Base Ball on Saturday, on the Putnams' ground, which terminated, after some fine play on both sides, in favor of the Excelsiors. Their batting was of the usual fine order, but some bad fielding on the part of the patnams' second base, gave the Exceisiors a great advantage in the first innings. The play of Russell, Pearsall, Holder, as well as Leggett -- who caught six man out on foul balls, some of them on the fly -- was excellent; Pearsall put out seven men on first base, and three on foul balls. Creighton's pitching in just the thing to suit Leggett as catcher, who can hardly be beat in the position; Brainerd caught out three patnams on the fly, Reynolds two, and Pearsall and Holder one each. Russell and whiting put two men out on foul balls, for which they run a long distance. To show how good the Exceisiors batting was, only one foul was caught, and that was finely taken by Masten; while twelve men were run out by different players by passing balls to Stinson at first base, and nine were caught on the fly; Burr, McKinstry, and McDonald caught two each; and one each by Dakin, W[???]zier, and van Va[???]kenburg; Brown putting four men out on second base.

abstract: A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, President KALBFLSISCH in the Chair. A motion to approve the minutes provoked a somewhat lengthy and acrimonious discussion, for the reasons annexed:
lead_paragraph: A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held last evening, President KALBFLSISCH in the Chair. A motion to approve the minutes provoked a somewhat lengthy and acrimonious discussion, for the reasons annexed: At the last meeting of this body, pending the consideration of a report of a Committee on a communication of the Commissioners to adjust and settle claims against the late City of Wilhamsburgh, the Chairman decided mat the hour of 8 o'clock having arrived, according to the rules, he could not entertain any motion, unless relating to the business pending. Alderman DAYTON appealed from the decision of the Chair, whereupon the Chairman reiterated his previous statement, when alderman DAYTON moved to refer the report under consideration to the Counselor for his opinion, when the motion having been agreed to the Chair announced that the hour of 8 O' clock having arrived, in pursuance of the rules the Board stood adjourned to meet on Monday, Aug. 6, at 5 O'clock P.M.

abstract: Miss ADELINA PATTI is to sing on Thursday evening next at Saratoga -- for with this week Saratoga dies in aromatic pain -- and on Tuesday of next week at Newport -- for with the next week Newport begins its perfect life.  The calendar of fashion could hardly be more charmingly interpreted.  The two musical journals of New-York, the Musical World and Musical R[???], have run together like two drops of water into one. "To this marriage of true minds" let us not only "offer no impediment," but contrariwise pronounce upon it our benediction. Mr. WA[???]DWELL, of the World retains the management of the harmonious household, and Mrs. BRINK[???]HOFF, the most graceful of critics, will still wield its attractive te[???]ors.  We wish the twain made one an indefinite increase of their domestic circle.

abstract: We beg leave to call the attention of the defenders of American honor or Southern rights the two, of course, are one and the same thing) to the atrocious conduct of a distinguished body of French savans, the "Soci t  d'Economie Politique."
lead_paragraph: We beg leave to call the attention of the defenders of American honor or Southern rights the two, of course, are one and the same thing) to the atrocious conduct of a distinguished body of French savans, the "Soci t d'Economie Politique." At the last meeting of this Association, one of its most accomplished members, M. QUIJANO, had the audacity to say that, "in some particulars, it might be doubted whether the separation of the great North-American Republic from the mother-country had been exclusively beneficial to the colonies." "It is possible," said this blasphemous person, "that the immense progress made by the United States might have been made without a separation, for Canada, remaining faithful to the British Crown, has advanced, under less favorable conditions of soil and climate quite as remarkably as the United States. At all events, North America, if united to Great Britain, would to-day have been delivered from the curse of Slavery, which tarnishes her splendor, diminishes her power, and will one day bring on her political [???], as it has already achieved her moral decadence." Will it be believed by the enlightened statesmen who have demonstrated that African Slavery is the foundation-stone of all our greatness, that this person was not instantly ejected from The learned Society which he disgraces as an incompetent and fanatical blockhead? And who can longer question the propriety of selecting our foreign ministers from the slaveholding States? Every envoy whom we send abroad from the cotton-fields of the Gulf States, or the tobacco plantations of Virginia, is a missionary whose services are most urgently needed by the most [???]ivilized nations of the Old World.

If any journal in the country is entitled to be heard as an authority on sectionalism and its remedies, it is certainly the Charleston Mercury. lead_paragraph: The Pony Express arrived at St. Joseph on Sunday night, with advices from California to the 25th of July, Japan to the 26th of June, and China to the 26th of May, and also later news from the West Coast of Mexico. From California we learn that business remained much depressed. The arrivals of silver ore from Washoe at San Francisco continued very heavy, the shipments being estimated at one hundred tons per mouth. Still further discoveries of silver mines are also reported.

abstract: RIOT AT THE ROCK TAVERN. Between 2 and 3 O'clock Monday morning, a descent was made by Constables JAMES LYNCH and COLGAN, of Hudson City, and Aid, J.L. AYRES, with Officers BRADLEY, VAN VOOR HIES and DALY, of Jersey City, upon a house known as Rock Tavern, situated at the foot of the hill on the Hoboken Road, and eight persons were taken into custody.
lead_paragraph: RIOT AT THE ROCK TAVERN. -- Between 2 and 3 O'clock Monday morning, a descent was made by Constables JAMES LYNCH and COLGAN, of Hudson City, and Aid, J.L. AYRES, with Officers BRADLEY, VAN VOOR HIES and DALY, of Jersey City, upon a house known as Rock Tavern, situated at the foot of the hill on the Hoboken Road, and eight persons were taken into custody. This house has long been the resort of the vilest characters of both sexes. On Sunday evening, about a dozen young men, some of them belonging at the tunnel, congregated at the Tavern, and conducted themselves in a most disorderly manner. Two or three persons who passed that way were assaulted, as is supposed, with a view to robbery, but fortunately they succeeded in effecting their escape. About midnight the rowdies, who had become quite intoxicated, took possession of the house and helped themselves to liquor, some charge from the till and whatever else they saw fit to appropriate to their own use. When the proprietor remonstrated he was set upon and beaten in a most shocking manner. The female inmates raised a cry of murder, which was heard by the Police of the Fourth Ward in Jersey City, four of whom went un and assisted the officers from Hudson City in arresting the [???]ters. The furniture and everything movable in the bar room had been demolished; the landlord has received serious injuries, and one of the women had nearly every particle of clothing stripped from her. Subsequently the prisoners were taken before Justice MARTIN, of Hudson City, who, after hearing the facts, committed them to the County Jail to await the action of the Grand Jury. The names of the prisoners are Isaac B[???]azy the landlord, Margaret McCulle, Ellen Campbelt Michael Maly, John Rorke, Samuel Johnson, John Lewis and Wm. Davis.

lead_paragraph: The players representing the above sections of this continent met on yesterday on the Fox Hill ground at Hoboken -- a ground that has been the scene of more contests than any other in this country. It was formerly as good as could be desired but the improvements of the Hoboken Land Company have cut off a large slice of it and greatly lessened its value for cricketing purposes, it being necessary to resort to that unsatisfactory proceeding of limiting the runs for hits out of bounds.

abstract: Capt. W.M. GARDNER, of the Second Infantry, writing from Fort Acercombe, on July 10th, gives an exceedingly interesting account of an impromptu method of crossing a river which was not properly laid down on the maps. His command, consisting of Companies A, D, and I, Second Regiment of Foot, left Fort Randall on the 5th July.
lead_paragraph: Capt. W.M. GARDNER, of the Second Infantry, writing from Fort Acercombe, on July 10th, gives an exceedingly interesting account of an impromptu method of crossing a river which was not properly laid down on the maps. His command, consisting of Companies A, D, and I, Second Regiment of Foot, left Fort Randall on the 5th July. The passage of the Missouri was commenced on the 10th and perfected on the 13th. "On the morning of the 27th," reports the captain. "we arrived at the Big Liout River, which, to my surprise, I found to be a stream about thirty yards wide, very rapid, and not fordable. At the point we struck, there was not a bush or tree in eight. Two wagon-beds were covered with canvas, and a connection made with the opposite bank by men swimming over with a rope. In these beds the command and stores were crossed over, an occupation that occupied twelve hours, the men working constantly. On the 30th, crossed a part of the St. Peter's River in the same manner that we crossed, the Liout." Capt. GARDNER contributes a very valuable description of the route over which he traveled. Parts of it, he judges, are well adapted for settlers.

abstract: On the night of the 28th of February last, the dwelling house and liquor-shop of Frank Hughes, No.103 Cherry street, was burglariously entered by means of false keys, and robbed of $350 in bank bills and gold coin.
lead_paragraph: On the night of the 28th of February last, the dwelling house and liquor-shop of Frank Hughes, No.103 Cherry street, was burglariously entered by means of false keys, and robbed of $350 in bank bills and gold coin. The burglar, who is alleged to be Pat Conway, was seen in the act of breaking into the premises, by a woman named Mary Johnson, but before the could sound the alarm and get help, Conway had escaped with the treasure. Search was made for the fellow, but he was not seen again till the 30th ult., when James Donovan, of No. 33 Cherry street, met Conway. They had a few words together concerning the burglary, whereupon Conway drew a bow[???]e knife of immense size, with, which he struck Donovan across the arm, inflicting a very severe wound. The assailant then escaped, and kept out of the way till Sunday night, when he was arrested by Officer Creighton, of the Fourth Ward. The moment he was seized, Conway showed fight, and struck at the officer with the same bowie knife with, which he had attempted the life of Donovan, but fortunately without doing any damage. He was secured after a Severe struggle, and subsequently taken before the magistrate at the Tombs, and committed for a hearing on two charges of assault and battery, and likewise for burglary.
