abstract: MEETING OF THE MANAGERS OF THE AMERICAN BIBLE SOCIETY At the last meeting of the Managers of the American Bible Society, five new auxiliaries  were recognized: one in Ohio, one in Georgia, and there in Texas.
lead_paragraph: MEETING OF THE MANAGERS OF THE AMERICAN BIBLE SOCIETY. -- At the last meeting of the Managers of the American Bible Society, five new auxiliaries were recognized: one in Ohio, one in Georgia, and there in Texas. Letters were received from Rev. Dr. BUTLER, carefully, India, Superintendent of Methodist Missons, returning thanks for former grants of books by the Society, and requesting further and; from Rev Mr. BUSBNELL, of the G [???]boon Mission, Western Africa reporting the good use, by the na[???]ves, of portions of the Sculptures published in [???]pong we, and the progress of translation, also asking a grant of Bibles and Testaments in English, for the supply of the skipping; form Rev. Mr. BLISS, Agent for the Levant; Rev. Mr. BEEGNE, Secretary B. &F.B.S.; and Rev.Dr. ANDERSON, Secretary A.B.C.F.M., in reg[???]r to a preposed revision of the Turkish Biore by Rev. Dr. SCHAUFFLER, under the joint auspices of the two societies; from Rev. C.H. WHEELER and others, a committee of the North American Mission, Kharp[???]ot, Asia Minor, showing the increasing deman[???] for the scriptures among Turks, Bulgarians and Armenians in that field, and urging the importance of increased efforts to supply that demand; [????]Rev. A. BEN OHLEL, Oran, informing of the successful opening of a Bible depot in that place, and asking a grant of books for distribution; from A.N. SEWELL, Esq, Hayti, acknowledging the receipt of the Bible and accompanying letter to be presented to the President of the Republic, and assuring of the pleasure with which be will carry out the wishes of the Society; from Agent THOMPSON, Mexico, giving account of a visit to Monterey. and the wide opening for Bible operations in that vicinity; from Rev. Dr. CROOKS, accepting appointment as a member of the Committee on Versions; and from Rev. Dr. FORSYTH, reporting his attendance, as delegate of this Society, at the late Anniversary of the Bible Society of Virginia.

abstract: The last express brought news of the appointment of Judge KINNEY as Chief Justice of Utah, and of ALEXANDER WILSON as Associate Justice. abstract: There is a strange fatality about the ancient office of Alderman. Once the glory of the Saxon aristocracy, it has come to be the shame of American Democracy; once significant of honest wisdom in peace, and of active valor in war, it has come to be synonymous in America with astute knavery, and in England with obese imbecility.
lead_paragraph: -- There is a strange fatality about the ancient office of Alderman. Once the glory of the Saxon aristocracy, it has come to be the shame of American Democracy; once significant of honest wisdom in peace, and of active valor in war, it has come to be synonymous in America with astute knavery, and in England with obese imbecility. We need not illustrate the peculiarities of the American Alderman for the benefit of New-York readers fresh from their amazement at Boole's big ball! but the following type of the British City Father deserves commemoration. Since the famous "apple of discord, which was destined to pour forth the deluge of anarchy and kindle the flames of insurrection," there has been nothing more ample in the way of rhetorical rigmarole. At a recent meeting called in London to denounce the Lords for throwing back the paper-duties upon the Commons, Alderman RYLAND delivered himself of the following sentiments:

abstract: A Christian Union Camp Meeting commenced yesterday at Yonkers, N.Y., and will continue during the present week. It is in continuation of the Union Camp Meeting conducted at the same place last year under the auspices of the Methodist Protestant and Congregational Methodist churches.
lead_paragraph: A Christian Union Camp Meeting commenced yesterday at Yonkers, N.Y., and will continue during the present week. It is in continuation of the Union Camp Meeting conducted at the same place last year under the auspices of the Methodist Protestant and Congregational Methodist churches. It [???]gusted in a call by a number of Congregational and Methodist Prote[???]ant churches, and Messrs, I[???]real Bacher and D. Hibbard of Brooklyn, J.D. Broen of Yenkers, SAMUEL Curry of New-york, and Thomas P. Bunvel of Williamsburgh, were appointed a Committee, with full power to attend to all the requisite arrangements. Among the de[???]minations participating are the Metho[???]ist pre[???]stant, Congregational Methodist, Boptist, protestant, Congregational Methodist, Bop[???]st, Presbsterian, Congregatinal Methodist, Bap[???]st, Prenbsterian, Congregatinalist, Reformed Durch, Episcopation, Methodist Episcopal, and Wesley and Methodist, principally from New-York, Brocklyn and Yoskers. Among the clergymen who are to officiate in the exercises, are Henry Ward Beochet, president smith, of the Methodist Protestant coaferance; Prof. Matreson, of New-York; Ezra Withey, of A[???]ney-street Church; Rev. Mr. Baker, of Sixteenth. street pilgrim Chruch; Rev. abstract: John Schneff, Emil Bergur, and Wm. M. Johnson, the young men recently arrested on a charge of wilfully firing the old name dwelling No. 146 Churchstreet, were on Monday taken before Justice WELSH, who locked them up in the Tombs to await examination. While yet in the station-house, Schneff and Bergur stated to the Fire Marshal that they knew Johnson fired the place.
lead_paragraph: John Schneff, Emil Bergur, and Wm. M. Johnson, the young men recently arrested on a charge of wilfully firing the old name dwelling No. 146 Churchstreet, were on Monday taken before Justice WELSH, who locked them up in the Tombs to await examination. While yet in the station-house, Schneff and Bergur stated to the Fire Marshal that they knew Johnson fired the place. They say that on Saturday afternoon, about 3 o'clock, they saw Johnson but a lot of shavings in to a hole under the floor, and soon after the fire broke out. Rergur, however, get some water and put it out but not until Johnson had cried to prevent him doing so. The building was uninhabitable as a dwelling, and vagrants were in the habit of crawling into [???] at night to sleep. Both say that they saw Johnson light a match and apply it to the shavings. He did it, he said, to burn out the "bummers." Independent of their statement, there is proof that one or more of the three had a hand in [???]ing the building with intent to burn it down.

abstract: DEATH OF MRS. GARDINER SPRING. Mrs. SUSAN SPRING, wife of Rev. Dr. SPRING, the venerable pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, died in this City yesterday morning.
lead_paragraph: DEATH OF MRS. GARDINER SPRING. -- Mrs. SUSAN SPRING, wife of Rev. Dr. SPRING, the venerable pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, died in this City yesterday morning. Mrs. SPRING was attacked by paralysis some weeks since, and the nape or not recovery had been very slight for several days previous to her decease. She was so low on Saturday last that it was thought doubtful whether Dr. SPRING would preach his semi-centennial discourse. On Sunday morning, however, her symptoms seemed to improve, but only to return with greater violence, until they assumed a fatal aspect at an early hour yesterday morning. Her age was 72 years. The funeral will take place to-morrow (Thursday), at 3 P.M., from the Brick Church in Fifth-avenue. The death of Mrs. SPRING will be a severe blow, not only to her immediate family, but 10 many whom her charity had be friend.

abstract: The steamship Canadian, from Liverpool on the 26th, via Londonderry on the 27th ult., arrived at Quebec yesterday. The advices brought by this steamer are one day later than those received by the Kangaroo, whose arrival off Cape Race was announced in our impression of Monday.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Canadian, from Liverpool on the 26th, via Londonderry on the 27th ult., arrived at Quebec yesterday. The advices brought by this steamer are one day later than those received by the Kangaroo, whose arrival off Cape Race was announced in our impression of Monday. It is reported that an agreement relative to the intervention of the Great European Powers to arrest the Syrian outbreak, was signed at Paris on the 26th ult. Further particulars are received of the massacre at Damascus, from which it would appear that the Druses invited ABD-EL-KADER to assist them in their war against the Christians, but he positively refused to give them any countenance. From Italy there is a rumor, indorsed by the London Times' correspondent, that GARIBALDI had landed on the Neapolitan coast, and was marching on the capital. The speech of Lord PALMERSTON on the British Defence question, published some days ago in this journal, is reported to have caused great excitement in Paris. We learn from an announcement of the Atlantic Telegraph Company that the efforts to restore the cable at Newfoundland have been unsuccessful. The prospectus of a new Ocean Telegraph Company- has been issued in London.

abstract: An adjourned meeting of this Board was held last evening, President CROWELL in the Chair. A communication was received from the keeper of the Penitentiary, notifying the Board that nine prisoners made their escape on Monday, about noon, and giving the names of the Deputy-keepers on duty at that time.
lead_paragraph: An adjourned meeting of this Board was held last evening, President CROWELL in the Chair. A communication was received from the keeper of the Penitentiary, notifying the Board that nine prisoners made their escape on Monday, about noon, and giving the names of the Deputy-keepers on duty at that time. It appears by the keeper's statement, that some sixty prisoners were sent to work on the Lunatic Asylum Extension, under the care of five Deputy-keepers and at about noon, nine of the prisoners made a break for the woods, and succeeded, in making their escape. The matter was referred to the Penitentiary Committee for investigation. A resolution was called from the table, reducing the. pay of the Sheriff for feeding prisoners in the County jail, from 25 cents to 20 cents per day each; also, another resolution directing that a prisoner must be kept in the jail 24 hours before the Sheriff could claim pay for one day's board. It was slated that during the last four months 543 persons had been committed by the Sheriff, and that on each prisoner he had received pay, for one, day more than the prisons had remained in the jail, and that it was a very common practice for the Courts to sentence men to imprisonment for one day, and that in all such cases the prisoner was locked up and immediately there after discharged, and for this service the fee has been $1 for, each prisoners The resolution reducing the per todiem pay 20 cents was adopted to take effect on the1st of September next and the last resolution was lost.

abstract: THE ESCAPE OF COL. CROSS, THE NOTORIOUS FORGER. -- The Philadelphia Ledger narrates the following incident in the life of Col. CROSS, who has already gained a wide-spread notoriety for counter-felting exploits: "On Saturday morning Col.J. BUCHANAN CROSS, who was awaiting sentence for forgery, escaped from JOHN PORTER, one of the tip-staves of the Quarter Sessions, who was bringing him to Court. A motion for a new trial was pending, and was to have been argued on Saturday, but owing to some misunderstanding between CROSS and his counsel, the defendant was satisfied that the motion would not be argued, but that he would receive his sentence. When Mr. PORTER stopped for him at the prison, he requested the officer to get a carriage, as he wished his wife to accompany him, it being the last opportunity which would be afforded him previous to his sentence. The officer got the carriage, but no wife appeared, and CROSS and PORTER alone started off. On the way down, the Colonel requested as a favor that he might be taken to Miller's Hotel, corner of Washington-avenue and Moyamen-sing-avenue, so that he might arrange his trunk, which had been left there when he was arrested. To this the officer agreed, and the parties drove to the hotel, where they went up to the third story. The room was darkened, and while CROSS was pretending to unlock the trunk, he asked Mr. PORTER to open the shutters, and as he stepped to the window to do so, CROSS sprang to his feet, and was out the doorway, and had the door locked upon the officer before he could well recover from his surprise. Down stairs at full speed he went, dropping his hat on the way, out into the yard, and then over the fence, his escape being facilitated by two chairs which were standing in the yard. Once in the street, he jumped into a covered wagon which seemed to be there in waiting, and was driven off at a rapid rate, before Mr. PORTER could escape from his room, Mr. PORTER had to kick out the panels of the door before he could get through, and when he reached the sidewalk he was in time to see the wagon disappearing from his sight. He ran after it, but the pursuit was fruitless. "The matter was brought to the notice of the Court as soon as it had opened, and Mr. PORTER was suspended. Further proceeding were held in abeyance until it should be ascertained whether the measures taken for the arrest of the fugitive should prove successful.

abstract: It will be gratifying to the friends of Rev. WM. S. MORRISON and lady to learn that letters have been received announcing their safe arrival at Anjer on May 17, on their way to the Missionfield in China.
lead_paragraph: -- It will be gratifying to the friends of Rev. WM. S. MORRISON and lady to learn that letters have been received announcing their safe arrival at Anjer on May 17, on their way to the Missionfield in China. It will be recollected that Mr.and Mrs. MORRISON sailed hence in February last, in he ship N.B. Palmer. The agreeable society and courteous attention of Capt. Low and his amiable lady had rendered the voyage thus far an exceedingly pleasant one to the Missionaries.

abstract: This match was resumed on the cricket-ground at Fox Hill, Hoboken, on Tuesday morning about 11 o'clock, and by 4  in the afternoon it terminated in favor of the United States, they still having four men to send in when the necessary runs had been got.
lead_paragraph: This match was resumed on the cricket-ground at Fox Hill, Hoboken, on Tuesday morning about 11 o'clock, and by 4 1/3 in the afternoon it terminated in favor of the United States, they still having four men to send in when the necessary runs had been got. Everything looked very bright, the borders of the ground, containing about five hundred spectators, shielding themselves from the burning fun under tents, umbrellas, and such other means of shelter as they could find. Among these lookers on were a goodly number of ladies, who seemed on both days of the match to view it with great interest. The New-York Club, however, on whose ground the match took place, and who had charge of the arrangements showed an entire disregard of the courtesies usually extended to the members of the Press, not only .offering ho facilities for obtaining information, but, in the person of their scorer, offering obstructions. The possession of the correct score is due entirely to the kindness of the scorer for the Canada Eleven.

abstract: THE RUMORED DEATH OF THE EMPEROR OF CHINA. -- The Allgemeine Zeitung of Augsburg reports, by way of Russia, that it was believed in Chinese official circles that the Emperor HIEN-FUNG had died, or was dying, of an old trouble in one of his legs, Should this report be confirmed, it is quite possible that the Allies may receive propositions of peace from Peking. The death of the Emperor who refused to entertain Lord ELGIN's version of the treaty of Tien-Tsin would relieve the Chinese authorities from the necessity of carrying out his policy, and enable them to renew negotiations with the Allied Ministers without the appearance of quailing before the armaments which are assembling so rapidly about the Poi-Ho.
lead_paragraph: THE RUMORED DEATH OF THE EMPEROR OF CHINA. -- The Allgemeine Zeitung of Augsburg reports, by way of Russia, that it was believed in Chinese official circles that the Emperor HIEN-FUNG had died, or was dying, of an old trouble in one of his legs, Should this report be confirmed, it is quite possible that the Allies may receive propositions of peace from Peking. The death of the Emperor who refused to entertain Lord ELGIN's version of the treaty of Tien-Tsin would relieve the Chinese authorities from the necessity of carrying out his policy, and enable them to renew negotiations with the Allied Ministers without the appearance of quailing before the armaments which are assembling so rapidly about the Poi-Ho.

abstract: Yesterday morning, about 4  o' clock, two fishermen found near the Monmouth House, Long Branch, N.J., a stick of cord-wood covered with hair and clotted blood.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, about 4 o' clock, two fishermen found near the Monmouth House, Long Branch, N.J., a stick of cord-wood covered with hair and clotted blood. Near it, in the sand, were marks of blood, and a closer examination discovered marks which indicated that a body had been dragged to a boat about 30 feet distant. This boat, apparently, had been dragged along the sand to the surf, where it was pushed into the water. It had again been brought to land 15 or 20 yards from this spot. The sail of the boat, which lay in the bottom, was covered with blood. Some pennies were found in the sand where the struggle appeared to have taken place, and tracks made with bare feet led to and from the wood-pile from which the club had been taken. Everything indicated that a murder had been committed, but up to the date of the latest information, no facts had been developed which tended to fasten suspicion on any person. Soon after 12 o'clock last night two pistol-shots were heard by Mr. T.A. SLATER, of the Tremont House, and a colored woman, employed as cook at one of the restaurants, stated that at about the same hour she heard the noise of a scuffle, and immediately after two discharges of a pistol in rapid succession. Other persons also state that they heard the reports of a pistol.

abstract: A SAD CASE OF HYDROPHOBIA. -- In February last, as a Mrs. TUCKER, of Toulminville, Ala., was walking in the street, she was assailed by a dog and her hand badly mangled. It appears that the medical men of that section doubt whether a genuine Cass of hydrophobia ever occurred at the South, or could occur in that climate, and the physician to whom Mrs. TUCKER, applied to have her hand dressed, disliked to resort to the severe measures necessary in such cases, as there was no positive proof that the dog was mad, and the wound was treated in the 'ordinary manner. The hand became healed in due time, and no trouble was experienced from It until the 17th of July, when Mrs. TUCKER was attacked by pain in the right hand and arm, (the one bitten,) which extended to her right side. She was also a little feverish and had some headache. On the second day after she died. The peculiar and distressing symptoms which marked the progress of her terrible disease are thus described by her physician In a letter to the Mobile Tribune:

abstract: An accident occurred on Monday afternoon on the Hudson River Railroad, by which a man named JOHN DONOLLY was instantly killed, and another named ROBERT COON so injured that his life is dispaired of. The particulars of the occurence are as follows:
lead_paragraph: An accident occurred on Monday afternoon on the Hudson River Railroad, by which a man named JOHN DONOLLY was instantly killed, and another named ROBERT COON so injured that his life is dispaired of. The particulars of the occurence are as follows: The track between Schodac and Stuyve[???]ant is double. On the down track was a freight train which had stopped to cool a hot journal. On the other track, a short distance above, was a gravel train and opposite the freight train was a hand car, on the same track as the gravel train, with Mr. COON and Mr. DONOLLY upon it. They did not notice the gravel train, which was slowly backing, until it was within ten or fifteen feet of them, when Mr. COON saw it and sprang from the car. He might easily have escaped uninjured, but he attempted to pull DONOLLY off the car, as the latter had not noticed either the approach of the train or Mr. COON's leap. Mr. COON had scarcely seized DONOLLY when the rear car of the train struck them both, instantly killing DONOLLY, and crushing in the back part of Mr. COON's head. He was alive at last accounts, but insensible, and his recovery is considered impossible. The occurrence was purely accidental. DONOLLY resided at Germantown, and leaves a wife and six children, who were dependant upon him for support. He was about 45 years of age. An inquest was held upon the body, and a verdict of accidental death rendered. Mr.COON is boss of the rock gang, and is about 40 years of age. He also resided at Germantown, and has a wife and several children. Mr. COON has been in the employ of the Company several years, and by his kindness and gentlemanly conduct, has made many friends.

abstract: That astonishing creature, JOBSON, has once more brought himself before the eyes of the world. As a type of the civilized Bedouin, and the Ishmaelite of every-day experience, JOBSON is unrivaled.
lead_paragraph: That astonishing creature, JOBSON, has once more brought himself before the eyes of the world. As a type of the civilized Bedouin, and the Ishmaelite of every-day experience, JOBSON is unrivaled. His exploits on this side of the Atlantic were too numerous and too brilliant to need recapitulation here, but he has outdone himself in his latest appearance on his native soil of Britain. There was once a man who lived in honor all his days on the strength of having been kicked by the King of France. This worthy seems to have come to life again in JOBSON, whose dearest delight it is to haul himself into publicity at the coat-skirts of some tormented and indignant "imp of fame." Mr. GLADSTONE, LOLA MONTEZ, and Sir JAMES CLARK have each in turn served his purpose. He has now attached himself to a certain Sir JAMES FERGUSON, M.P., whom he has pursued with libels and lampoons tall the unhappy Baronet has been forced to drag him before a London Police Court, and with him no less important personages than Mr. DISRAELI and Mr. HORSMAN, M.P.

abstract: Frances Hayes, a woman living on board the barge George E. Frank, lying at the foot of Perry-street, accidentally fell overboard on Monday night and was drowned. Her body was subsequently recovered, and Coroner O'KEEFE held an inquest upon it.... John Smith, an Englishman, 60 years of age died on Monday at the New-York Hospital, in consequence of injuries received a few days since by falling on the sidewalk in Ninth-avenue, at the corner of Twenty-sixth-street. An inquest was held on the body by Coroner O'KEEFE. ... Hugh Gillen, an Irishman, 40 years of age, attempted to commit suicide on Monday afternoon by cutting his throat. He did not accomplish his purpose in that manner, but afterwards threw himself from a fourth-story window of his residence, No. 472 Fourth-street, and was instantly killed. Coroner O'KEEFE held an inquest upon the body, and a verdict was rendered in accordance with the facts.

abstract: The last of the African slaves were sent on board the ship Star of the Union, on the 19th inst., and she sailed the same afternoon for Sinon, Africa. The number placed on board was 385, constituting what was known as the cargo of the unknown or "unnamed" French bark. The total number delivered over to the three vessels for return is 1138, the balance of the original number have died.

abstract: In our report of the meeting of the Board of Councilmen, on Saturday morning, there was noted the passage of a resolution directing the Croton Board to suspend all proceedings in reference to laying the new four-foot iron pipe, from the Receiving to the
lead_paragraph: In our report of the meeting of the Board of Councilmen, on Saturday morning, there was noted the passage of a resolution directing the Croton Board to suspend all proceedings in reference to laying the new four-foot iron pipe, from the Receiving to the Distributing Reservoir, through the Fourth-avenue. There was also noted the fact, that in July a resolution was passed through both branches of the Common Council, authorizing the Croton Board to proceed with that work without entering into a contract; and on Monday the work was commenced, when some three hundred men were set at work, Yesterday, however, the Croton Board received a communication from the Mayor's Clerk, acting on which, they at once stopped the work, and discharged he men employed. The history of this operation is one of some interest to tax-payers, and we therefore give the official correspondence which has brought about a result so disastrous to householders and consumers of Croton Water. Before any action was taken by the Croton Board, a letter was addressed to the Mayor with a view to ascertaining his opinions as to the step they proposed to take, and to which the following reply was received:

abstract: When the thermometer is at its present altitude business naturally flags in law Courts, civil and criminal. A man's indignation must be high indeed, if he can get higher than "Phoebus Apollo" has reached during the past two days.
lead_paragraph: When the thermometer is at its present altitude business naturally flags in law Courts, civil and criminal. A man's indignation must be high indeed, if he can get higher than "Phoebus Apollo" has reached during the past two days. Consequently, although persons were present perforce, in the Court of Sessions, (for no longing for "green fields and pastures new," would have been of avail to them,) yet prosecutors were generally distant, and witnesses in their excessive love of nature, were as hard to catch as shad at Christmas. There was no Grand Jury impanneled, as a matter of course. How could a quorum be obtainable with Saratoga, Niagara, Cape May, Long Branch, the White Mountains, the Catskills, &c., &c., inviting over-broiled citizens to quit the City? Recorder BARNARD, who holds Court this term, is a patient man, who never shirks his duty, but does it assiduously and honorably, but if he were in the country instead of on the Bench, he would undoubtedly feel cooler and enjoy himself more. Mr.SEDGWICK, the Assistant District Attorney, looks as if a rural district in Massachusetts would please him better than his snug seat in the Court-room. The petit jurors appear miserable and the reporters are undeniably indignant. Put the thermometer down eight or nine degrees, and outshines will go on in earnest, but unless the sessions of the Court were held in an ice-house, it would be folly now to expect the attendance of witnesses or prosecutors. Nevertheless, some parties who pleaded guilty to various offences have been sentenced by the Recorder to the State Prison for two and three years each. Let a good breeze spring up, the thermometer descend to " Point Comfort," and the wheels of justice will revolve as fast as the paddles and screw of the Great Eastern.

abstract: The most extraordinary admission made in the extremely guarded speech of the British Prime Minister, reproduced in the TIMES of Monday, is that the wooden walls of England no longer avail to protect the island, and that Britannia at last acknowledges the need of bulwarks and "towers along her steep." Lord PALMERSTON declares the British Navy not ...
lead_paragraph: The most extraordinary admission made in the extremely guarded speech of the British Prime Minister, reproduced in the TIMES of Monday, is that the wooden walls of England no longer avail to protect the island, and that Britannia at last acknowledges the need of bulwarks and "towers along her steep." Lord PALMERSTON declares the British Navy not only insufficient to protect the country against the possible danger of a French, invasion, but even incapable of defending itself and the national dock-yards against tie approach of a French f[???]ctilla. In these circumstances he invites an appropriation almost equal to the actual national debt of the United States, to provide a show of protection for the very nary upon which England relies for her own safety!

abstract: The JAPANESE BILL. -- Two, at least, of the Board of New-York Councilmen, Mr. LENT and Mr. STARR, seem to be a little ashamed of the company they keep, and of the deeds for which the people hold them officially responsible, Mr. LENT last night declared his intention of insisting upon a bill of items before he would consent to the passage of the appropriation necessary for transferring $105,000, good and lawful money of the people of New-York, from the City Treasury into the pockets of the farmers who tilled the Japanese while they were with us. The indications previously were, that this enormous charge would be admitted like the account presented by a Vermont hotel-keeper to a foreign prince on his travels, in which the sum of $100 was set down as the cost of "making a d -- d fuss generally." We are happy to note so feeble a protest at so late an hour as Mr.LENT has now raised -- more, let us tell him, in the interest of his good name and of the good name of the body to which he belongs, than in behalf of the City. Plundered as New-York is, and for years has been, the loss of a hundred thousand dollars would hardly excite any special indignation, nor will its saving call for any astonishing gratitude. But it is a vital matter to the few members of the City Government who have some lingering hope of preserving their private reputations that they should clear themselves emphatically and openly of all complicity in a "job" which excites peculiar attention only because its real nature happens to be peculiarly evident to the whole community.

abstract: An adjourned meeting of Company E, Ninth Regiment, was held at the Armory, No. 481 Broadway, last evening, to discuss the project of organizing a Zouave Company of the Regiment. In the absence of Capt. ATTERBURY, Sergeant FITCH was called to the Chair. Lieut. COPPINGER stated that since the
lead_paragraph: An adjourned meeting of Company E, Ninth Regiment, was held at the Armory, No. 481 Broadway, last evening, to discuss the project of organizing a Zouave Company of the Regiment. In the absence of Capt. ATTERBURY, Sergeant FITCH was called to the Chair. Lieut. COPPINGER stated that since the last meeting, a communication had been received from the Governor, through the Adjutant-General, in answer to the application of Company E to be allowed to organize as a Zouave or Light Infantry Company of the Regiment, stating that the plan was approved of by the Commander-in-Chief, but that before it could be carried out, some modification in the Militia Law would be required, which would necessitate an application to the Legislature. At the same time, the Governor thought that the Company should obtain the approval of the Division Board to which they belonged. Lieut. COPPINGER said that the plan had been submitted to the Division Board, by whom, for certain reasons, it was not approved. Nevertheless, the thought their objection might be overcome; and as no organization could be effected until an application was made to the Legislature, all the company could do would be to go on and drill in the Light Iniantry tactics., so that by the time their new organization was effected, they would be in a great measure perfeet in the new drill. The plan proposed by some gentlemen, at the last meeting, to organize an independent Company of Zouaves was impracticable, as the law expressly forbids the organization an independent Company of Zouaves was impracticable, as the law expressly forbids the organization of independent companies. Every Regiment, however, is allowed two flank companies, of, which one might be a Light Infantry Company, and the only practicable mode would be to organize Company E into such Light Infantry Company. In conclusion, he offered, a resolution that Company E commence drilling immediately in HARDE[???]'s Light Infantry tactics, and that such persons as choose to join them be invited to enroll their names and attend the dril[???]s.

abstract: We are very sorry for the Bostonians. Atnonians without an Athens, although they have all the will in the world to hear or to tell some new thing, they can never get any new thing, least of all any "big thing" to hear or to tell.
lead_paragraph: -- We are very sorry for the Bostonians. Atnonians without an Athens, although they have all the will in the world to hear or to tell some new thing, they can never get any new thing, least of all any "big thing" to hear or to tell. They made a desperate clutch at the Japanese, sending an embassy of Aldermen to wrest TOMMY and SIMMEBUZEN from the embraces of BOOLE, but on that occasion only BOOLE appeared to the Japs in the light of a friend and protector. They clung to BOOLE in order to escape Boston -- of two evils choosing the least. The Great Eastern was the next disappointment of our oriental friends. Although themselves the "Great Easterns" of America, they would have the leviathan in their harbor, reckless of all the damage she might do to all the "Islands" by turning suddenly round in the Bay. This, too, was refused them. As a last effort, they have now dispatched their Mayor, Mr. LINCOLN, all the way to Halifax to beg the Prince of Wales to come their way. Mayor LINCOLN went to Halifax, saw the Royal Highness, apologized for Lexington and Bunker Hill in the handsomest manner, gave the Duke of NEWCASTLE some preserved "chowder" as a bait, promised the Prince an evening with EMERSON, a review on the Common, a comedy at the Museum, and an article,discussing his Highness' whole career, past, present and to come, in the Atlantic Monthly. But it was all in. vain. Mayor LINCOLN was sent ruefully home again, to wait on Lord LYONS and Providence. We are sorry for Boston, really; but why can't' she be contented with DOUGLAS, whom she has had, and BLONDIN, whom we dare say she can have after the people get through with him at Niagara Falls. Small towns should not cry for the moon.

abstract: Mr. JOHNSON, counsel for the claimants, yesterday summoned up before the Commissioners, and replied at length to the positions of the opposing counsel.
lead_paragraph: Mr. JOHNSON, counsel for the claimants, yesterday summoned up before the Commissioners, and replied at length to the positions of the opposing counsel. He argued that the act of the Legislature clear ly provided for an assessment and award of damages accruing from a loss of the claimants' property by fire. In consequence of the burning of the Marine Hospital and other buildings. The term property was undoubtedly intended to embrace all classes of property, both real and personal, and "damages" was intended as a recompense for injuries sustained as specified in the act. In order to make this a recompense in the meaning of the act, it must cover the losses arising from any unwarrantable interference with the rights and property of another, which amounted to an injury. This would embrace the actual value of the property, with interest thereon from the date of its destruction until the award is made and paid. The boatmen's claim for rent was proper, as the destruction of their houses resulted In depriving them of employment, and, assuch deprivation was caused by the conflagration of the Hospital establishment, they must be indemnified. The stevedores were entitled to recover on the same principles, as their arrangement with the Health-Officer to do the stevedoring was broken up by the tame causes: and the workhouse dock was specially assigned for their use. The claim of Dr. WALLER for rent was also good, as well as that of Dr. THOMPSON, who was expressly required by law to reside within the Quarantine inclosure: he was employed for two years, and had a lease of the house for that period; this house was destroyed, and Dr. THOMPSON thus sustained damages which he had an unquestioned right to recover. As a rule the claimants should be allowed the full value of the property at the time of the fire, with interest from the date of the destruction of the property. For the injured property, the difference in its value should be allowed, which, in some cases, was sufficiently indicated by the cost of repairs; in others it had to be established by the uncontradicted statement of witnesses. Interest should also be allowed on the damages to the property saved, and, if the property was destroyed by a mob, the claimant was entitled to recover as though the property was burred; it should also cover the expenses of cartage and assistance while making provision for the family on the night of fire, with interest.

abstract: The Milwaukee Sentinel of the 2nd gives the following account of the rescue of SHERMAN M. BOOTH, who has been confined for some months in the Custom House in that city for aiding in the rescue of fugitive slaves: A few minutes after 12 o'clock, ten determined ...
lead_paragraph: The Milwaukee Sentinel of the 2nd gives the following account of the rescue of SHERMAN M. BOOTH, who has been confined for some months in the Custom House in that city for aiding in the rescue of fugitive slaves: A few minutes after 12 o'clock, ten determined men walked leisurely up the Custom House steps. They might hare been taken for merchants having business with the Collector. They seemed entirely unconcerned, and were talking of every-day matters. They, however, did not visit the Collector; and the Marshal they could not see. for he was luxuriating in pork and beans -- eating his accustomed dinner in all the security and repose of a peaceful conscience and a masterly appetite. The vigilant BURKE, whose eye never sleeps, nor is known to wink, was alone visible. One of the gentlemen presented Mr. BURKE with a card of admission to see Mr, BOOTH. The vigilant BURKE took it, eyed it, spelled it, turned it over, and was exerting the whole of his intellectual powers to read it, when one of the other gentlemen caught him by the arms. A revolver gleamed before him. He heard the key turn in the door, and in another moment Mr. BOOTH Stepped lightly over the thresh hold and waving an affectionate au r[???]voir, went down the iron steps as comfortably as though on his way to a tea party. Mr. BURKE did not reply to the parting words -- unfortunately for what he had to say -- he found himself thrust into the room, and the key again turned. An, vigilant BURKE!

abstract: LOSS OF A FRENCH TRANSPORT -- The Allegmenies Zeitung announces the loss at Amery of the steam-transport Isere. His vessel went down in deep water, with the loss of 400 tons of powder and much material of war.

abstract: The expedition which went to Labrador to view the recent eclipse of the sun, was at Sydney, Cape Breton, on Friday. They had a fine view of the eclipse, although the sky was somewhat, cloudy during the eclipse. They noticed among other phenomena great magnetic disturbance. The expedition will go to Newport, where its members will doubtless receive a hearty welcome from the Scientific Convention now in session.

abstract: ANOTHER STEAMBOAT EXPLOSION. -- The steamboat La Crosse exploded her boilers on the morning of the 2d inst. just after she had left New-Orleans for Sabine Pass and Galveston. R.B. DAVIS, Captain; CHAS. WILLIAMS, Purser; ANDREW ROQUE, first engineer, carpenter, cook, steward and two deck hands, names unknown, were killed; and JNO. WILLIAMS and JAMES MARTIN, passengers, are missing. The La Crosse was valued at $30,000, and was insured for $17,000, as follows: Crescent Office, $5,000; Marchants', $4,000; New-Orleans, $4,000; and Star, $4,000. Her cargo was as follows: 500 sacks corn, 400 barrels flour, 330 barrels potatoes, 5 barrels lard, 6 kegs butter, 130 bales bagging, 5 cotton gins, and 64 packages merchandise. Capt. DAVIS was 32 years of age, and a native of Fairhaven, Conn., where both his parents are now living. He was unmarried. The Purser, Mr. WILLIAMS, was a native of New-York, about 30 years of age, unmarried, and has a brother and father in Texas, employed by the railroad company.

abstract: EXCITING AFFAIR AT HAMILTON, OHIO -- SHOOTING OF A CITIZEN BY A JUDGE OF THE COURT OF COMMON PLEAS. -- We learn, says the Cincinnati E[???]irer, of the 4th inst. that an exciting shooting affair took place in the city of Hamilton yesterday afternoon. The history of it, with the preceding circumstances, are about as follows: A minister over one of the religious congregations of the city received several anonymous communications through the post-office, in which the author professed a desire to join his church, but did not wish to become associated with such persons ascertain ladies of his congregation. These letters were finally shown to the husband of one of the ladies, a prominent merchant, who thought he recognized the handwriting of another citizen, and subsequently charged him with being the author of the slanderous communication, and a personal encounter followed. This occurred several days ago. The fact finally came to the knowledge of one of the most prominent lawyers of Hamilton that the same anonymous calumniator had attacked his wife in the same contemptible way, and, taking means to satisfy himself of tie anthership, resolved to inflict summary punishment. While passing along the street, yesterday afternoon, in a buggy, he discovered the supposed author of the letters in a store, and, alighting from his wagon, he walked in and commenced an attack by firing at him with a revolver. The individual attacked attempted to escape, and succeeded in so far avoiding his assailant as to dodge all but one shot, which took effect in the shoulder, inflicting a severe but not a dangerous wound. The interference of other parties present put an end to the affair for the time being. Much excitement existed through out the city, all the parties to the scandal being among the most prominent and well-known citizens. For reasons which will suggest themselves, we forbear giving names, which may, perhaps, be made public through an investigation."

abstract: On Sunday last a party of about one thousand Germans made an excursion to Staten Island on the steamer Mercury and barge L.R. Mellen, and, on their return to the City, landed at the foot of Harrisonstreet.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday last a party of about one thousand Germans made an excursion to Staten Island on the steamer Mercury and barge L.R. Mellen, and, on their return to the City, landed at the foot of Harrisonstreet. After the company had disbursed Mr. A. Berger, the caterer of the occasion, undertook to remove his crockery and so much of the wine and provisions as had not been disposed of, when a turner of ruffians came on board the barge and created a disturbance by helping themselves freely to everything they wanted. Mr. Berger and his assistants having remonstrated, were so badly beaten for their temerity that they had to fly from the barge, leaving it in full possession of the rowdies, who subsequently destroyed nearly everything. The police of the Fifth Ward were notified of the affair, but, it is said, refused to act in the matter, consequently Mr. Berger, yesterday, related his grievances to the General-Superintendent, who has promised to investigate the alleged dereliction of duty on the part of the Police.

abstract: The Second Annual Aquatic Festival of the Mendelssohn Union, of this City, occurred on Monday night, and will long be remembered as a pleasant incident by those who were so fortunate as to participate in it.
lead_paragraph: The Second Annual Aquatic Festival of the Mendelssohn Union, of this City, occurred on Monday night, and will long be remembered as a pleasant incident by those who were so fortunate as to participate in it. The weather was all that could have been desired. The members of the Association, accompanied by a few selected friends -- the aggregate numbers being just sufficient to make the occasion one of unalloyed social pleasure -- left the City at 5 o'clock in the afternoon, on board the capacious excursion-barge Baltimore, Capt. REYNOLDS, the tow of the tug Seymour, and visited the Highlands of the Hudson, returning at 2 A.M. The hours glided by as if with winded feet, spent as they were under circumstances so enchanting. The strains of sweet music, ever soothing, -- having their influence enhanced in this instance by the adjuncts of soft moonlight, romantic scenery and the hushed solitude of Nature, -- seemed to carry the listener above mundane things.

abstract: The visit of the Prince of WALES to America has been, and is likely still to be, sufficiently discussed from the political and historical point of view. It is obvious to every capacity that ...
lead_paragraph: The visit of the Prince of WALES to America has been, and is likely still to be, sufficiently discussed from the political and historical point of view. It is obvious to every capacity that nothing could be more interesting than the spectacle of the representative of GEORGE III, receiving friendly hospitalities at the hands of the successor of WASHINGTON. The edge of this striking event has been, indeed, a little dulled by the previous and not less remarkable visit of NAPOLEON III. to Windsor Castle; but it is still most impressive, and everybody will be sure to comment upon it before the Prince leaves our shores. Then, too, nothing can be more noteworthy than the recognition of the growth and dignity of her Colonies, which England offers in sending the heir of VICTORIA to listen to long speeches, and to make short ones in reply, all the way from St. John to Montreal. We may safely trust our Canadian and Provincial friends generally to "improve" this text. It assuredly has no bearings which they will not find out, no meanings which they will not extract, and copiously administer to themselves first, and to the whole world afterwards.
headline: {'main': 'The True Prince in America.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The True Prince in America.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The New Haven Palladium, of the 7th, says: "Another very brilliant meteor was seen on Monday, August 6, by persons in Branford. Just at sunset, the sky being clear, a fire-ball like a star was observed near the south-eastern horizon, sailing around slowly and gradually through the north eastern quarter of the heavens, and a few degrees above the horizon, and disappearing some degrees west of north.
lead_paragraph: The New Haven Palladium, of the 7th, says: "Another very brilliant meteor was seen on Monday, August 6, by persons in Branford. Just at sunset, the sky being clear, a fire-ball like a star was observed near the south-eastern horizon, sailing around slowly and gradually through the north eastern quarter of the heavens, and a few degrees above the horizon, and disappearing some degrees west of north. The motion was very slow, and the time of the flight may have been from 20 to 30 seconds. Had this phenomenon occurred after dark, we should doubtless have seen a meteor rivaling in splendor and general glory the famous one of July 20. We hope to hear from our Northern neighbors more about this celestial stranger. Perhaps this is one of the outsiders of the shooting stars expected on the mornings of the 9th and 10th instants."

abstract: Prof. ROGEES, whose extremely interesting optical investigations have been already mentioned, to-day gave same fresh illustrations of the metaphysics of vision, in his paper on our inability from the Retinal Impression alone to determine which retina is impressed. Although it would seem almost necessary that the retina receiving an image should have consciousness of its place, yet there are simple experiments showing that the eye, unassisted by the Judgment from other sources, has no such power. Take a sheet of pasteboard with a short tube in the centre, and placing it in the front of the eye of a second person, adjust the tube centrally before the right eye: when he directs his view, both eyes being open, to a distant point, he will feel as if he saw the bright aperture equally with both eyes, and will be wholly unable to decide which eye is impressed. By moving the aperture a little nearer the nose, but still out of the view of the other or left eye, he will feel as if it were before his left eye, although actually invisible to it, Again, placing a white spot of paper on a black stereoscope slide, so that the spot shall be directly in front of either eye, it will appear as if seen just as much by one as by the other, and without closing one of the eyes or same other extraneous help, the observer will be wholly unable to decide before which eye it is placed. In all these cases it is not the retina that perceives, but the optical part of the brain behind the retina, and common to both eyes, in which the perception is formed. These considerations explain the experiment which forms the foundation of the instrument called the pseudo-dyoscope, lately described, and which has been erroneously supposed to illustrate same new law of vision. In fact, the principle is as old as an observation of LEONAEDO DA VINCI, that a small object entirely opaque might yet be made to appear transparent by placing it near the eyes. Holding a paper-cone with its small aperture directed forward and its base against one of the eyes, having it so supported as to rest between the thumb and hand, on directing both eyes forward to a distance, the hand will appear as if perforated through the centre, and distant objects will seem to be seen by the eye immediately behind the hand as if a hole had actually been bored through it. Prof. HOLMES, whose versatile genius shines not less in optical and other scientific inquiries than in the finer walks of literature, has employed an experiment with the stereo-scope, and single objects, in part analogous to that above described, and endeavored to deduce from it a theory which he has designated as reflex vision.

abstract: The telegraph, hailing under the pressure of an over-charged atmosphere, briefly announces to us, to-day, that the Conference of the Great Powers summoned to meet at Paris and decide on the proper settlement of affairs in Syria, has not yet been convened and may not be assembled at all. However this may be, there can be no doubt that France and Russia at least are determined not to wait upon diplomacy in the discharge of a great duty to civilization and public law.
lead_paragraph: The telegraph, hailing under the pressure of an over-charged atmosphere, briefly announces to us, to-day, that the Conference of the Great Powers summoned to meet at Paris and decide on the proper settlement of affairs in Syria, has not yet been convened and may not be assembled at all. abstract: LAYING THE CORNER-STONE OF AN M.E. MISSION CHURCH. The corner-stone of an M.E. Mission Church in Twenty-fourth street, between Eighth and Ninth avenues, was laid yesterday afternoon by Bishop JANES, with appropriate ceremonies. There were some two hundred persons present mostly ladies interested in the success of the Mission.
lead_paragraph: LAYING THE CORNER-STONE OF AN M.E. MISSION CHURCH. -- The corner-stone of an M.E. Mission Church in Twenty-fourth street, between Eighth and Ninth avenues, was laid yesterday afternoon by Bishop JANES, with appropriate ceremonies. There were some two hundred persons present -- mostly ladies interested in the success of the Mission. The exercises were commenced with prayer by Dr. OSBOEN, and staging by the congregation. Dr. THOMPSON, of the Christian Advocate, delivered a brief address, after which Rev. Mr. FERRIS, pastor of the Mission Church, made a statement of the organization and progress of the Mission. It was organized about three years ago, and at that time the congregation worshiped in a little wooden church, situated near the site of the building now in progress. Last year the little church was burned down. The Mission Society, which numbers about 100 members, afterwards purchased the present site, at a coat of about $8,000, and the building now in progress of erection, would, it was estimated, cast about $6,000. The first story of the building is already tip, occupying 50 feet of front by 100 feat in depth and 11 feet in height. It is not the intention of the Trustees, at present, to raise it beyond the first story, unless $3,000 additional is subscribed to enable the work to proceed. In case that amount is not now guaranteed, a temporary roof will be constructed the floor and ceiling of the first story finished, and the congregation will worship there until the building shall have been completed. It is to be built of brick the front to be trimmed with Nova Scotia stone. When Mr. FERRIS had concluded his remarks, a collection was taken up; an address was delivered by Bishop JAMES who also laid the corner-stone, after which the congregation separated.

abstract: The New-Jersey Republican State Convention for the nomination of Electors of President and VicePresident, assembled at Trenton Yesterday. There was not so large a gathering at the New-Jersey Capital, as on the occasion of the triple Conventions held there three weeks ago; nevertheless, the various sections of the State were fairly represented, and the proceedings were very harmonious, and were carried through with commendable dispatch.

abstract: ITEMS. -- A number of public functionaries visited Governor Swift at Barren Island yesterday to examine the offal works on that Island...The Republican primary meetings are to be held on the 15th inst....A Republican ratification meeting will be held in Roslyn, L.I., to-day....A fire broke out in the ship-yard of Mr. E. WILLIAMS, at Greenpoint, yesterday morning. The fire was extinguished with a loss of $50.... Coroner HORTON held an inquest yesterday on the body of MARGAREET WELSH, 6 years old, who was drowned on Tuesday by falling into a cistern at house No. 19 Garrison-street. A verdict of accidental drowning was rendered....About a dozen persons were arrested in the Ninth Ward yesterday for keeping hogs in violation of law. They were all taken before Justice CORNWELL and required to pay the usual fine of $5 each....Justice CORNWELL rendered a decision yesterday in the case of the Ninth Ward Bone-boiling establishments. He decides that they are nuisances and prejudical to the public, and has issued orders for the business to be stopped.

abstract: THE PRESIDENT AND HIS PARTY -- The telegraph surprises us with the intelligence that the President is unhappy about his henchmen in New-York. He suspects the best and bravest of being Douglas men in disguise, and refuses to be comforted. He is more afflicted than David in the days of Absalom and Joab. This is very strange. For the President's organ, in giving us yesterday a most musical account of the Breckinridge Convention at Syracuse, assures the whole world that "the resolutions indorsing the wise and conservative administration of President BUCHANAN provoked cheer on cheer in the Convention tonight. The Herald's prophecy that BUCHANAN would yet have justice done him, proves true."
lead_paragraph: THE PRESIDENT AND HIS PARTY -- The telegraph surprises us with the intelligence that the President is unhappy about his henchmen in New-York. abstract: Hon. A.H. Stephens, of Georgia, met with an accident as he was leaving his residence in Athens, which may interfere with his proposed stumping tour. The heel of his shoe caught in the door sill, and be was precipitated a distance of four or five feet, falling on his face, which was much bruised and scratched by coming so suddenly in contact with the graveled walk.

abstract: From the largest mass of statistics ever collected on this subject, viz: 1,252 cases, furnished by Dr. HOWE, Dr. ELLIOTT has constructed a biometre or life-table for the blind; by which we are able to compute a number of interesting and practical problems.
lead_paragraph: From the largest mass of statistics ever collected on this subject, viz: 1,252 cases, furnished by Dr. HOWE, Dr. ELLIOTT has constructed a biometre or life-table for the blind; by which we are able to compute a number of interesting and practical problems. He showed that the average of life among the blind was not nearly as great as among others, and traced their short-livedness to three causes: 1.Inherent deficiency in vital power; 2. Narrow range in the choice of employments and amusements; 3. The loss of this important sense exposing them to accidents and depriving them of the opportunity of protecting themselves.

abstract: To the Editor of the New-York Times:  A meteor of nearly equal brilliance and size of the one of July 20, was seen passing along the western sky this evening at about twenty minutes after sunset. Its course was from south to north, in an almost straight horizontal line, and its velocity about the same as that of the meteor of the other evening which it much resembled and forcibly suggested.

abstract: The Texas papers come to us with extended details of the recent conflagrations in that State. On the 24th ult., the steam mill of GEORGE GLANCOCK, Esq., at Austin, was set on fire, and totally destroyed. It contained machinery valued at $30,000, and 450 bushels of wheat. The house of Dr. W.W. STELL, of Lamar County, was fired by a negro on the 16th, and completely burned.

abstract: The remarks of last week apply equally well to this, as far as the trade in milch cows is concerned. There is much less doing in this line than there was one year ago. Gentlemen are mainly out of town, and are not wanting to buy, so that only milkmen are purchasers. They would buy more freely if there was such a demand for beef that they could turn out their fattest and partially dry cows to the butcher.

abstract: The "mysterious circumstances" connected with the supposed murder of some unknown person at Long Branch, on Sunday night last, continued to agitate the people of the immediate neighborhood of the supposed crime until yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The "mysterious circumstances" connected with the supposed murder of some unknown person at Long Branch, on Sunday night last, continued to agitate the people of the immediate neighborhood of the supposed crime until yesterday. The bloody woodpile stick besmeared with hair, the blood-stains in the boat, the stained "cob" with which the victim was supposed to have been gagged before he was finally knocked on the head; the pistol-shots which -were heard by the servants, and the evidence of a struggle in the sand -- all furnished material for exciting more or less learned discussion among both the visitors and citizens' of the place. The Coroner, anxious to show all due diligence in his first case, was promptly on hand, and took into his possession such material proofs of crime as he could obtain. Investigation was also made in all directions with a view, first to discover the "body," and second to ascertain if anybody was missing. The roll was called at all the boarding-houses, and, so far as could be ascertained, every person who hadwisited the place and registered themselves, answered to their names, or had paid their bills and gone home. The "Southern Planter" who had been run short of funds, and sent for and received a three thousand dollar (!) remittance, with the knowledge of his servant, could not be found, though he was diligently sought after by several anxious landlords; the "darkies" who were missing " that morning" went ou1 a little earlier than usual to take a much-needed bath, and came back in season to wait on the breakfast-table -- in a word, nothing whatever could be discovered to confirm the theory that anybody had been foully dealt with, and the impression is now universal that the whole affair was a. wanton and mischievous hoax, got up by' some brainless fellows to create a sensation,' and possibly with the stupid design of drawing a crowd to the place. The evident arrangement of the mysteries of the bloody stick, &c, with a view to attract, instead of escaping detection of the crime, now fully satisfies every one that it was a wicked, though too successful hoax, and the citizens, instead of offering a reward for the " body," are more inclined to search out the authors of the mischief and visit exemplary punishment on them for the injury inflicted on the place, From cautious remarks of certain persons, overheard by a well-known gentleman who come up yesterday from Long Branch, he was satisfied that the blood seen in the boat was imported in a quart bottle from a neighboring slaughter-house, and that all the bloody details were got up for effect. With this view of the matter, and in the absence of all clue to any erime, the affair will be permitted to subside.
headline: {'main': 'The Long Branch "Murder."; THE AFFAIR PRONOUNCED A HOAX.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Long Branch "Murder."; THE AFFAIR PRONOUNCED A HOAX.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A singular coincidence in the movements of two men-of-war, which took place recently, is worth remarking. An English frigate, prized by all loyal Britons for having captured a Yankee craft, and a Yankee frigate, whose heroic defeat and seizure of two British national ships, fill so glorious a page in our naval annals, both being, in maritime parlance, invalids, have, within a few days of each other, been equipped for a cruise and sent to sea. Her Majesty's frigate Shannon, the captor or the Chesapeake, left Portsmouth, England, a few days ago, to make her annual cruise, and "Old Ironsides," commanded by an officer of 1812 notoriety, a little while after left Portsmouth, United States, for a cruise, preparatory to taking her station at Annapolis. Each was about to be broken up some years ago, and each was saved by a song-writer, Messrs. HOLMES and TENNYSON having poetically remonstrated with "the powers that be" against destroying "those old monuments of naval heroism."

abstract: THE LOST STEAMER HUNGARIAN. -- A correspondent of the Boston Transcript, writing from Cepe Sable, N.S.; under date of July 24, says: "On Sunday afternoon I attended church on the Island. Quite a large congregation was in attendance. To my surprise, I found the ladies dressed in full costume, with silks and satins, flowing ribbons, and bon ton bonnets, (via Cheapside, London.) Upon inquiry, I learn that the inhabitants have extensive and valuable wardrobes, from the wreck of the ill-fated steamer Hungarian. It is a common thing for the females who assist in curing fish to be dressed in silk, with a bugle head-dress, &c. On Monday, the 23d inst., I accompanied Capt. PRATT, of the steamer Dirigo, of Bangor, Me., to the vicinity of the wreck to take no "a snarl." One of Capt, BAZLY's divers, from Halifax, went down in 8 fathoms of water, and made fast to "the snarl," which was hoisted by the steamer Dirigo, and taken into Clark's Harbor, about five miles from the wreck. It consisted of a part of one of the steamer's boats, wound around with broadcloths, silks, ginghams, calicoes, and other textile fabrics, estimated when taken up to weigh ten tons. Upon taking this snarl apart, we found the corpse of a lady, supposed from her dress to be a cabin passenger. Some of her hair remained, and several pieces of clothing covered, her remains, but nothing was found to give the least clue to her name. She was buried this (Tuesday) evening at 6 o'clock, near the church on the island. An American ensign was used as a pall over the rough coffin, and the funeral procession consisted of Capt. PRATT, of the steamer Dirigo, with his officers and crew, Capt. GLENNIE, of schooner Rechab, with his crew, Capt. BAZLY of schooner Cora, and his crew, together with several residents of the Island. The burial-service of the English Church was read at the grave by Capt. GLENNIE, of the Rechab, in a very solemn and appropriate manner. Several trunks and valises, hats and other articles of clothing, have been recovered from the wreck, of which the friends will be notified as soon as their addresses can be ascertained.

abstract: Quite an excitement exists among the medical profession, relative to a quarrel between a well-known ex-professor of midwifery and a leading surgeon of this City. Unprofessional conduct is said to be the charge of the former against the latter, and it is suggested that the Ethical Committee of the Academy of Medicine will again have an opportunity for their grave sessions and non-committal reports.

abstract: The latest advices from Europe, which reach us this morning, are singularly negative in character. This is especially true of the intelligence which comes to us from the focus of Italian revolution in Sicily. We are simply informed that the evacuation of Messina, which was last week announced as on the point of completion, has been arrested, and that GARIBALDI is suffering from a wound received at Melazzo. In the current confusion and uncertainty of news, both official and unofficial, it is hardly fair to assume that the retreat of the royal troops from Sicily must have been countermanded by the King of Naples. A vacillation of this sort would be too perilous to the hopes of the King on the mainland to be wantonly ventured upon. Whatever may be the momentary state of things in the island which has so heroically cast off the yoke of the Bourbon dynasty, the waves of popular disaffection are running too high about the very palace-gates of Caserta to permit the heir of Bomba to indulge, just at present, in any freaks of hereditary treachery beyond the Strait of Reggio. Scylla is too menacing to allow her lord to make free with Charybdis. Signor DELLA GRECA, the special Envoy of FRANCIS II. to the Court of the Tuileries, has frankly admitted to the Emperor NAPOLEON that the liberal proclamations of the King have produced the very slightest effect in calming the public mind or conciliating the good will of the nation. On the 18th of July a grand manifestation indeed took place at Naples in favor of the Bourbon sway, on the occasion of the inauguration of the National Guard. At that time everything was done to propitiate the Constitutional party. It was publicly announced that the King had sent into the country these regiments of the Royal Guard which had been guilty of anti-liberal demonstrations on the 15th. But all this produced the very slightest effect. On the very next day the leading officers of the Neapolitan Navy went in a body to the Count D'AQUILA, the Grand Admiral, to renew their oaths of fidelity to the King as a protest against the desertion to GARIDALDI of the war steamer Veloce with her crew; but they all took the oath with a reservation, to the effect that they were never to be employed in battle against any Italian power. GARIBALDI himself could hardly have quarreled with loyalty of this guarded and peculiar stamp. That the King should have accepted or even allowed its expression is a most pregnant sign of the extremity in which he finds himself. It proves that he fully appreciates the truth that his only hope for the salvation of his dynasty lies in an alliance of policy and principle with Sardinia. This hope itself is apparently growing more shadowy every day.

abstract: The Republicans of the Nineteenth Ward have recently completed a wigwam on the corner of Thirdavenue and Sixtieth-street, capable of holding twentyfive hundred persons. Last evening a grand mass meeting of the voters of the Ward was held in it, for the purpose of dedicating it to the interests of LINCOLN and HAMLIN.
lead_paragraph: The Republicans of the Nineteenth Ward have recently completed a wigwam on the corner of Thirdavenue and Sixtieth-street, capable of holding twentyfive hundred persons. Last evening a grand mass meeting of the voters of the Ward was held in it, for the purpose of dedicating it to the interests of LINCOLN and HAMLIN. At an early hour the area in the wigwam was completely occupied by an enthusiastic crowd, occasionally giving vent to their enthusiasm by stunning cheers for the Republican principles and candidates. It is proper to say that the greater portion of those present could easily be identified as the hard-fisted laboring class of the Ward.

abstract: The commencement exercises of this University at Hamilton, New-York, will be opened on Sunday evening next, by Rev. Dr. ARMITAGE, of this City, with a sermon before the Society for Inquiry. On Monday evening, the Eonian and Adelphian Societies will hold their Anniversary. Dr. E.G. HOLLAND, of Springfield, Mass., will give the oration. Mr. STARK is the Pastor. On Tuesday, Rev. Dr. HAGUE will deliver the annual oration before the Alumni. Rev. Dr. MIKELS, of this City, will address the Education Board on same afternoon. Wednesday will be devoted to the Commencement exercises proper, in the evening the usual reunion of the Alumni and friends will take place. The Theological Department holds its commencement on Thursday.

abstract: The meteorological characteristics of the present Summer bid fair to signalize it at least in the annals of Mr. MERIAM. A season at its outset so remarkably reduced in temperature as to strike despair to the souls of patient waiters upon the coming of warm weather, and attended by celestial and atmospheric phenomena of unusual frequency and rare splendor, it offers to the student of this curious class of topics a highly interesting field of investigation. The early spring witnessed repeated displays of the northern Aurora, to the serious derangement of telegraphic communication. Yesterday, the magnetic perturbation, arising from the same source, was so extreme as for hours to suspend the transmission of our European dispatches from Halifax.

abstract: On the 13h of May, Mr. Silas Gregory, of Croton Falls, lost a valuable horse, which he had every reason to believe was stolen. Indeed, he could have lost him in no other way.
lead_paragraph: On the 13h of May, Mr. Silas Gregory, of Croton Falls, lost a valuable horse, which he had every reason to believe was stolen. Indeed, he could have lost him in no other way. He communicated immediately with the police of this City, who set to work to discover and arrest the thief. Success did not crown their efforts until yesterday afternoon, when Officer Flavin, of the First Precinct, and officer Hillard, of the Mayor's Office, detected him at the foot of Forty-second-street, in the act of entering the ferry-boat for Weehawken. They at once secured him, and conveyed him to close quarters, whence he will be taken, this morning, before a magistrate. The officers then proceeded to Weehawken, where, from information they received, they found the missing horse, which they also took into custody, for the purpose of restoring it to its owner. These officers deserve great credit for their action in this matter. The thief's name is Jeremiah Waddington. He was formerly a keeper of a sailor's boarding-house in Liberty-street, and is well known as a most hardened and dangerous character.

abstract: The activity in the market continues with a grad  ual upward tendency in prices. Receipts have been moderate, with an undiminished demand for export.
lead_paragraph: The activity in the market continues with a grad ual upward tendency in prices. Receipts have been moderate, with an undiminished demand for export. Over 3,500 firkins have been shipped to Liverpool and Glasgow during the week. The transactions for shipment are mostly of store-packed Western and State Butter, of which the stock is greatly reduced, and we are advising all our shippers to forward their store-packed Butter now, and take the present market rather than hold with a slim prospect of a better. Fine Butter is very scarce, with a brisk demand at our outside figures. Orange County pails are quickly taken at our quotations:

abstract: Dr. NEWBXERY ("On the late extinct floras of North America") gave a sketch of the succession of different floras on the North American continent, remarking that the Devonian and Carboniferous floras had been carefully, studied and characterized by the prevalence of eyptogamous plants, as ferns, &c, and that the floras of America during these ages was strikingly like that of Europe of the same epoch. The Permian flora was scarcely known in this country; it was but a continuation of the carboniferous. He observed that the Triassic and Jurassic floras were characterized by the prevalence of numerous and beautiful Cycadaceous plants, which had been studied and beautifully illustrated by European fossil botanists, but had hitherto been very little known in this country. "Recently he had procured a large number of fossil plants of this age from New-Mexico and elsewhere, which had shown that, as in Europe, the flora of America, during the period of deposition of the New Red Sandstone, was cycadaceous in character and similar to that of Europe. At the commencement of the cretacious era, however, the flora of the continent was revolutionized, and apparently suddenly, though doubtless gradually. The broad-leaved dicotyledonous plants were introduced, and the vegetation of the continent assumed the general aspect which it has at the present day. Among the cretaceous plants are found species of Liriodendron, (tulip tree,) Liquid-amber, (sweet gum,) Sassifras, etc, etc. -- genera now living in our forests, of which the first two existed on the continent of Europe during the tertiary ages, but are not now known there: Dr. NEWBXERY concluded by saying that the aspects of nature, as far as vegetation is concerned, on our continent, are of an antique type, and that the plants, as was the case with many of the fishes, were old-fashioned forms. The climate of the United States, as indicated by these plants, had been, through the crustaceous epoch, temperate and much as now; but during the tertiary it had been slightly warmer than at present, but still temperate, and cooler than the climate of Europe at the same epoch.
lead_paragraph: Dr. NEWBXERY ("On the late extinct floras of North America") gave a sketch of the succession of different floras on the North American continent, remarking that the Devonian and Carboniferous floras had been carefully, studied and characterized by the prevalence of eyptogamous plants, as ferns, &c, and that the floras of America during these ages was strikingly like that of Europe of the same epoch. "Recently he had procured a large number of fossil plants of this age from New-Mexico and elsewhere, which had shown that, as in Europe, the flora of America, during the period of deposition of the New Red Sandstone, was cycadaceous in character and similar to that of Europe. At the commencement of the cretacious era, however, the flora of the continent was revolutionized, and apparently suddenly, though doubtless gradually. Among the cretaceous plants are found species of Liriodendron, (tulip tree,) Liquid-amber, (sweet gum,) Sassifras, etc, etc. -- genera now living in our forests, of which the first two existed on the continent of Europe during the tertiary ages, but are not now known there: Dr. NEWBXERY concluded by saying that the aspects of nature, as far as vegetation is concerned, on our continent, are of an antique type, and that the plants, as was the case with many of the fishes, were old-fashioned forms. The climate of the United States, as indicated by these plants, had been, through the crustaceous epoch, temperate and much as now; but during the tertiary it had been slightly warmer than at present, but still temperate, and cooler than the climate of Europe at the same epoch.

abstract: The corps of Cadets in the Military Academy is at present encamped on the plain, all studies having been abandoned for the time, that the opportunity might be given for instruction in the practical details of military life. The following is a brief schedule of the regular routine: At 5 A.M. the reveille is beaten, the several companies are formed, and the roll is called by the First Sergeants.
lead_paragraph: The corps of Cadets in the Military Academy is at present encamped on the plain, all studies having been abandoned for the time, that the opportunity might be given for instruction in the practical details of military life. The following is a brief schedule of the regular routine: At 5 A.M. the reveille is beaten, the several companies are formed, and the roll is called by the First Sergeants. At 5 1/2 o'clock company drills take place, under the charge of Lieuts. MCCOOK and DODGE, of the army. These drills are very severe, and continue for an hour. At 7 o'clock the Battalion is marched down to the mess-hall, for breakfast, when some two hundred and fifty hungry individuals quickly dispose of the "hash" and bread, the dishes which compose the meal. At 8 o'clock the morning parade takes place, and guard mounting and stacking of arms follow. At 9 the foot and mounted batteries are manned by the Second, Fourth and Fifth Classes, while members of the First Class act as instructors. At 11 A.M. the drum beats for target practice. Rifled muskets, similar to those used in the regular army, are employed in this exercise. The object fired at is an iron man, with a white "bull's-eye" where the heart is supposed to be, placed at a distance of two hundred yards from the marksmen.

abstract: Among the really important communications of to-day, though it most be confessed, very technical in its character, was an account of the principal results of certain scientific observations made by the expedition under command of Dr. KANE, and the reduction and discussion of which by Mr. SCHOTT of the Coast Survey, Mr. BACHE complimented in the highest terms, affirming that no single year's observations had produced such rich and good fruit, and that they threw great light on the tides of the great Polar seas. They show a remarkable agreement of observations with the deductions of theory, and an astonishing fidelity in carrying out these observations under circumstances of extreme difficulty.
lead_paragraph: Among the really important communications of to-day, though it most be confessed, very technical in its character, was an account of the principal results of certain scientific observations made by the expedition under command of Dr. KANE, and the reduction and discussion of which by Mr. SCHOTT of the Coast Survey, Mr. BACHE complimented in the highest terms, affirming that no single year's observations had produced such rich and good fruit, and that they threw great light on the tides of the great Polar seas. They show a remarkable agreement of observations with the deductions of theory, and an astonishing fidelity in carrying out these observations under circumstances of extreme difficulty.
