abstract: In opening the question it was remarked by Prof. PUGH ("Investigations on the Assimilation of Gaseous Nitrogen of Plants,") that there are two sources whence plants might be supposed to derive a nitrogen either from combined nitrogen in its varied forms or from the gaseous nitrogen of the atmosphere.
lead_paragraph: In opening the question it was remarked by Prof. PUGH ("Investigations on the Assimilation of Gaseous Nitrogen of Plants,") that there are two sources whence plants might be supposed to derive a nitrogen -- either from combined nitrogen in its varied forms or from the gaseous nitrogen of the atmosphere. It has long been admitted that plants can derive this element from the former source; the present investigation was to discover whether or not they can obtain it from the latter. This question derives a practical importance from the fact that in agricultural practice one of the most expensive elements in manures is nitrogen, and the question arises as to how far supplies may be drawn from the nitrogen of the atmosphere. The question, further, has a high theoretic importance due to the fact that no vegetable growth can take place without the presence of combined nitrogen, this being an indispensible element in cell-formation. This question has occupied the attention of chemists and vegetable physiologists from the time of INJENHOUSE, PRIESTLEY and DE SAUESSURE, who about 100 years ago, investigated this subject with discrepant results. More recently BOUSINGAUNT DRAPEE, of New-York, and Mr. GEORGE VILLE have in like manner devoted considerable time to this question, though the conclusions they have arrived at are diametrically opposed to each other. In this question two general modes of investigation suggest themselves: one in which the air in which the plant grows is analysed at successive periods of its growth in order to ascertain whether the quantity of nitrogen contained undergoes any change, which change must have been due to the assimilation of nitrogen to the plant; the other, by examining the plant itself at different periods of its growth, to ascertain whether the quantity of nitrogen it contained has changed. BOUSSIXGAULT and VILLE followed the latter method, the one getting results proving that plants can assimilate nitrogen, and the other that they can not. Indeed, the results were of such a character as to reduce themselves to a question concerning the moral character of the respective investigators. On chemical principles they were irreconcilable. The speaker had no doubt of the conscientious accuracy with which BOUSSINDGAULT had given his results (leaving the audience to make an inference no favorable to the character of the other gentleman, Mr. PUGH undertook an elaborate series of investigations, extending over three years, and of which he now gave the results. And the speaker could no omit the opportunity of stating that all the expenses, amounting $6,000, had been generously met by Mr. LAWES, of Rothamsted, England. With out going into details touching the means he had employed details touching the means he had employed to avoid error, enough to say that no assimilation of gaseous nitrogen was found to take place -- a result coinciding with that arrived at by BOUSSINGAULT. The experiments had been conducted with the chief cereals -- wheat, barley, oats, peas, beans, buckwheat, clover and tobacco. In regard to all but the leguminous plants, there was no doubt as to the above result With the latter, the experiments were less decided in consequence of their not having given results so satisfactory as in the case of the otters.

abstract: The sole-leather Tanners of the States of NewYork and Pennsylvania held a semi-annual meeting in the Astor House yesterday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: The sole-leather Tanners of the States of NewYork and Pennsylvania held a semi-annual meeting in the Astor House yesterday afternoon. NORTHRUP, President of the Association, who occupied the Chair, stated, at the opening of the meeting, that there was an impression abroad that some of the members of the Association had not acted honestly in regard to the curtailment of the manufacture of sole-leather, recommended at the last meeting of the Association. It will be remembered, by those interested, that at the meeting of the Association in March last resolutions were adopted unanimously recommending, in consequence of the flooded state of the market, 'a curtailment of thirty-five per cent, in the manufacture of sole-leather. The members had just ceased to manufacture the article, when the Western tanners exported it in abundance to New-York -- perpetuating the over-stock which the Association intended to reduce. The efforts of the Association, however, to equalize the stock were only partially paralyzed by the action of outside tanners. The present reduced stock of sole-leather on hand, it is said, will prevent the reduction in the price of leather which the recent failures of some members of the trade in Great Britain might otherwise create.

abstract: The Rocky Mountain News, of the 25th, gives full details of several murders lately committed at Pikes Peak. One of the guilty parties was JAMES A. GORDON, who became engaged in a quarrel with the barkeeper of a saloon where he had been indulging freely in liquor, and finally shot him, inflicting a dangerous wound. This outrage he followed up, on the next day but one, the 16th. of July, by shooting and instantly killing one GANTZ, another barkeeper in the same town. Then GORDON thought it was time to put himself beyond the reach of the law. No one started in pursuit until the next morning after the murder had been committed, and then all efforts to arrest the scoundrel proved unavailing.
lead_paragraph: The Rocky Mountain News, of the 25th, gives full details of several murders lately committed at Pikes Peak. One of the guilty parties was JAMES A. abstract: There is a story which we all remember. It was among the first that were told to us, of the sleeping beauty in her enchanted palace. We were told how, through centuries of slow years, sleep brooded dull and heavy over the walls of the castle, whose inmates never woke or stirred. Adventurer after adventurer tried in. vain to force his way through the close-woven, thickset hedge of trees and briars that barred all approach, and failing to win an entrance, gave his life in exchange for his rash attempt. But at last one comes -- the fated breaker of the spell. The prince nobler than all the rest.

abstract: The Soutern Guardian, of Columbus, S.C., says about 7 o'clock, on the evening of the 2d, a meteor was seen in the northern part of the heavens, and at 10 o'clock a very large meteor made its appearance, which, according to the accounts we have received from those who noticed it, was quite a brilliant affair.
lead_paragraph: The Soutern Guardian, of Columbus, S.C., says about 7 o'clock, on the evening of the 2d, a meteor was seen in the northern part of the heavens, and at 10 1/2 o'clock a very large meteor made its appearance, which, according to the accounts we have received from those who noticed it, was quite a brilliant affair. Its nucleus was apparently about two feet In diameter, and, taking a westerly direction, showed a tall about one hundred or one hundred and fifty feet in length. After going a short distance it seemed to explode, giving the idea of a mammoth sky-rocket.

abstract: The Republican Ratification meeting for the Eastern District was held last evening in the Odeon, the large hall of which was filled to overflowing. The meeting was organized at 8 o'clock by electing THOMAS W. FIELD, Esq., Chairman, and the usual number of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries. Addresses were delivered by J.L. WOODWARD, Esq., of New-York, Gen. BRUCE, and others.

abstract: Mr. West, of the firm of West & McDougal, commission merchants in Cincinnati, was surprised, on returning from a business trip in Indiana, to find both his partner and book-keeper absent from the store. He waited for their reappearance until late in the evening, when, becoming uneasy, he thought it best to investigate affairs. He soon ascertained that, by forced sales of stuffs consigned to the house, sales of drafts on their correspondents, discounting of bills receivable, &c., Messrs. McDougal and Montague had realized $30,000. With which they had left for Canada. A reward of $1,000 was offered for the arrest of McDougal, and detectives at once started after the fugitives.

abstract: The regular exercises of commencement week at Amherst College opened on Sunday with the baccalaureate sermon by the President. His text was II. Timothy, chap. iv., verses 6,7,8. The subject of the discourse, which was most impressive and appropriate, was "the principles which should control the Christian student in the choice of his profession."

abstract: When a Government is systematically inhuman, the instincts of our common humanity, and the dictates of Christian civilization, demand and justify its overthrow. This is the case with the Bourbon dynasty at Naples. A few years since, an eminent member of the British Parliament -- Mr. GLADSTONE -- personally investigated, the condition of the political prisoners of that country, and his report thereof excited the horror and indignation of Christendom; a few weeks since, Count PAERIO argued in the Sardinian Assembly against the proposed treaty between Naples and Piedmont, on the ground of the traditional perjury of the former Government. In no part of its dominions have the wrongs against humanity been so continuous and terrible as in Sicily; her isolated position, the absence of a Free Press and facilities of intercourse, with the infamous police system, have enabled tyranny to perpetrate, in secret, outrages at the mere name of which humanity shudders; a torture-chamber, such as we read of in the annals of the Spanish Inquisition, has lately been exposed to public execration. Thousands of her best citizens have suffered death, banishment and captivity on the mere suspicion of liberal opinions or patriotic hopes. I have wandered over that beautiful Island, and beheld the most abject human degradation in the midst of exuberant fertility and Arcadian loveliness. A more melancholy contrast between man and nature it is impossible to imagine. If ever a revolution was a moral necessity that sanction existed in Sicily. We are familiar with the marvelous details of GARIBALDI's landing advance and capture of Palermo, through the graphic narrative of the London Times' correspondent; a more brilliant achievement, a more humane enterprise, greater moderation in victory, or wisdom in provisional sway, no page of modern history records. At this moment the bells of the countless churches of that picturesque capital -- whose perpetual chime seemed to sound the keynote of superstition's bondage -- are being molded into cannon to thunder a triumphant protest against the encroachments of despotism!

abstract: The Board of Police Commissioners met yesterday afternoon, and received the first quarterly report made by Sergeant LORD, of the Sanitary Squad. The report includes the operations of the Squad up to the 1st inst., and shows that the total number of nuisances abolished, and dangerous buildings made, secure, is 5,819. In regard to steam boilers the Sergeant was unable to make a correct return.

abstract: Among the latest news from Europe in the scientific world, is an eloquent essay of the eminent REICHENBACH proving the identity of comets and meteorties. This intellignece, interesting as it is to scientific men, will doubtless at this time interest a large portion of the general public here, on account of the recent appearance of a most magnificent meteor.
lead_paragraph: Among the latest news from Europe in the scientific world, is an eloquent essay of the eminent REICHENBACH proving the identity of comets and meteorties. This intellignece, interesting as it is to scientific men, will doubtless at this time interest a large portion of the general public here, on account of the recent appearance of a most magnificent meteor. The cosmical origin of meteors and meteorites first recognized, by the celebrated CHLADNI, and so brilliantly confirmed by our own Prof. OLMSTED, is now generally admitted. Comets are as generally admitted to consist of a loose transparent mass of solid particles (based on ob served absence of light-refracting power,) and to be cosmical bodies that must be considered still in a state of development. And REICHENBACH'S theory simply and beautifully explains the connection between the two phenomena, as follows: Most meteorites -- R. has made a collection of 150 different specimens -- can be proved to be an aggregate of distinct particles, inclosed in a dark mass or stroma. Each particle is, as it were, an independent individual, and existed before the en closing mass did: being an older meteorite inside of a younger, like a fossil shell in chalk. If we conceive a space as large as the comet's tail, originally filled with a gaseous substance, in which the atoms of these particles were suspended; and if we furthermore conceive a tendency in these atoms to precipitate and crystalize, -- it is clear that this process, going on at innumerable points at the same time, milliards of crystals will form: each not much larger than the original atoms, be cause the matter is taken up synchronously by all neighboring crystals. These crystals being an easily moved mass from the 'tail' of the comet, and by friction and pressure among themselves, from the various motions observed in comets, they become at last those particles which still show traces of crystalline laminated structure. Unequal distribution of the different elements and the action of their forces will produce at some points denser aggregation than at all others, and from this results the phenomenon of one or more 'heads' or nuclei. The process of condensation may continue, and the nucleus, at the expense of the tail, may thus become enlarged and finally consolidated, as shown in the compact masses of the meteorites," "Thus is the comet the building material of the meteorite; but a meteorite is a small planet, the destination of which is to unite with a larger planet, to advance by one step the world's process of increase. Thus do we arrive from atoms of matter, isolated in the universe to smallest crystals, to the cometary tail, to the nucleus of the comet, to the meteorite, and to the planet upon which we walk."

abstract: The steamship Europa, from Liverpool on the 28th and Queenstown on the 29th ult., arrived at Halifax yesterday morning. Her advices, which are two days later and meagre in the extreme, have been briefly telegraphed. It was reported incorrectly that a Convention had been signed at Paris relative to the intervention of the European Powers in the Syrian outbreak.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Europa, from Liverpool on the 28th and Queenstown on the 29th ult., arrived at Halifax yesterday morning. Her advices, which are two days later and meagre in the extreme, have been briefly telegraphed. It was reported incorrectly that a Convention had been signed at Paris relative to the intervention of the European Powers in the Syrian outbreak. Such a Convention, it is expected, will soon be signed, and to that end conferences were being held in the French capital. GARIBALDI is said to be at Messina, which appears to be still in the possession of the Neapolitans. He is supposed to have been wounded in the affair at Mclazzo. Rome is in a feverish state of excitement, and a rising of the people may be expected there at any moment.

abstract: The circumstances attending the death of RoBERT FOSTER, an infant four days old, are at present under investigation by Coroner GAMBLE. From the information so far obtained, it appears that the parents of deceased reside at No.159 West Eleventh-Street, and the child being supposed to need medical attention, Dr. BUCK, of Grand-Street, physician to the family, was sent for.
lead_paragraph: The circumstances attending the death of RoBERT FOSTER, an infant four days old, are at present under investigation by Coroner GAMBLE. From the information so far obtained, it appears that the parents of deceased reside at No.159 West Eleventh-Street, and the child being supposed to need medical attention, Dr. BUCK, of Grand-Street, physician to the family, was sent for. He, however, was out of town and having arranged with Dr. ALLEN to attend his patients, that gentleman called to see the babe, and prescribed for it a mixture containing two grains of opium, with direction to administer it in four doses, The father of the child procured the medicine from a druggist at No. 163 Avenue-A, who remarked, upon being informed that it was intended for a child, that the quantity was much too large, and seemed reluctant to make up the prescription. He finally, however, handed it to Mr. FOSTER, but the latter having been alarmed at the hesitation of the druggist to give him the medicine, determined to administer to the infant only one-half of the quantity which the physician had directed. Soon after having done so, the child was thrown into convulsions and died. Dr. ALLEN was summoned before its death, and it is said that he remarked that the little sufferer was under the effects of poison, and that there had been no necessity to give it medicine at all, but that he had ordered the prescription to satisfy its mother. The quantity of opium thus prescribed is said to have been sufficient for an adult, and Dr. ALLEN will be called upon to explain his reasons for making an error which has resulted so sadly. On account of the necessary absence of a member of the jury, Coroner GAMBLE has adjourned the inquest for a few days. Dr. WOOSTER BEACH, J[???]., made an examination of the body of the infant, but failed to discover any disease sufficient to have caused its death. The Doctor has, as yet, however, given no authoritative opinion on the subject, but it is understood that the post-mortem developed the fact that the intestines and stomach were much inflamed.

abstract: On Wednesday night Constable FARRELL, of Jersey City, proceeded to the old tenement-house known as the "Ship," near the upper end of Newark-avenue, to arrest a man named PATRICK O'SHAWNESSY, a well-known desperate character. Upon entering the room and making his business known, O'SHAWNESSY, together with his wife and son, assaulted the officer, who drew his club and made the best possible use of it, but the odds were too great against him. The woman seized a knife, and succeeded in cutting FARRELL several gashes upon the face and head. A number of the inmates of the den gathered around, but did not heed the demand of the officer for assistance, and he was forced to make a retreat. Subsequently, several Police Officers made a descent upon the "ship," and succeeded only in arresting the son, about eighteen years of age, O'SHAWNESSEY and his wife having succeeded in making their escape, Yesterday. Chief of Police MARINUS arrested BARNARD MCELORY on a charge of refusing to assist the Constable, The "ship" is an old, long, three-story wooden building, with apartments for about forty families. Its occupants are composed of the vilest and lowest dregs of humanity, with whites and blacks living on an equality, while amalgamation is not unfrequent. A descent by the Mayor, Recorder and Chief of Police was contemplated a few days since, but the inhabitants of the den becoming aware of the intention paid their rent in advance and thus thwarted them. The next Grand Jury should take the matter in charge.

abstract: Grant H. Adams vs. The Mayor, &c -- This was an action against the City to recover $1,420 83 alleged to be due the plaintiff for services as Health Warden of the Eighteenth Ward. The plaintiff was removed from office on the 15th of May, 1858, but still claiming to be entitled to his salary, brought this action to recover for services subsequent to his removal. The matter was referred to James M. Smith, Jr., Ex-Recorder, who reported in favor of the plaintiff, no defence having been put in.
lead_paragraph: Grant H. Adams vs. The Mayor, &c -- This was an action against the City to recover $1,420 83 alleged to be due the plaintiff for services as Health Warden of the Eighteenth Ward. The plaintiff was removed from office on the 15th of May, 1858, but still claiming to be entitled to his salary, brought this action to recover for services subsequent to his removal. The matter was referred to James M. Smith, Jr., Ex-Recorder, who reported in favor of the plaintiff, no defence having been put in.

abstract: As we stated yesterday, nothing further has occurred to shed any light upon the alleged fearful tragedy at Long Branch, and for the best of reasons -- nothing can be said of the affair except that it is all a hoax. The people at the boarding-houses are now anxious to have the whole matter hushed up. The Herald of yesterday, with others of our contemporaries, filled its columns with the mysteries and bloody details of the "murder." One of them "expressed" itself to the effect that the body of a man had come ashore, which, in general appearance resembled the missing Southern planter. This body turns out to have been that of a rollicking, good-natured fisherman and wrecker, familiarly known at the Beach as "JOE, or ROASE WEST." He had been missing from a very late hour of the previous night, and came ashore at 6 o'clock in the morning, in his skiff, with a handsome haul of fish, which he proceeded to pack into his customary ice-box and dispatch to the City.

abstract: The recent elections in the South and West show unexpected and curious results. Gen. COOMBS has probably been elected to office in Kentucky, -- receiving a good many Douglas votes in addition to those of the Bell party and the Republicans. BLAIR is elected to Congress, in St. Louis, and everything indicates a substantial union of the Whigs, Americans and Republicans in that State. The election in North Carolina developed an unexpected degree of strength on the part of the Opposition, although the State remains in the hands of the Democracy. These things show that in the Slave States the Democratic strength has been greatly overrated, and that there is a very large and powerful minority in all of them, and in some an absolute majority, who will not be dragooned into giving the Slavery question that absolute and despotic predominance in national politics which has been asserted for it. They render it more than probable that Kentucky, Tennessee, Maryland, Delaware and Missouri will cast their votes against the Presidential candidate who has been nominated as the special representative of the slave-holding interest. Missouri may vote for DOUGLAS: -- the others named will probably vote for BELL. But they will all pronounce decisively and loudly, not only against the secessionism of YANCEY and his gang of conspirators, but also against the disunionism of those who, with BRECKINEIDGE for their leader, would make Slavery the paramount interest of the Republic.

abstract: The town is overflowing. At least 500 guests are at the Mountain House from all parts of the State. Over fifty registered their names this morning. Among those present are Gen. FOSTER, H.M. Tne Douglasites are in strong force, and will probably present, as an ultimatum, the calling of a new Convention, on which there will doubtless be an exciting debate.

abstract: JOINT BOARD OF SUPERVISORS AND ALDERMEN. -- An adjourned meeting of the Joint Board of Supervisors and Aldermen, to make up the tax-budget of 1860 -- I, was held in the Common Council chamber last evening. The members representing the Eastern District of the city -- late Williamsburgh -- submitted a statement showing the sums named in the resolution heretofore adopted, appropriating moneys for interest and principal on city loans, to be excessive; the amount "to pay off debt of the City of Brooklyn prior to 1855" in the resolution adopted, is $6,000, but should be, according to the figuring of the Eastern District members, $7,800. An item "to pay off principal of School Debt Loan of 1855," should be $67 70 less. Item -- "1-15 of Williamburgh Street-liability Loan, issued in 1857, payable in 1872," $6,133 33, should entirely be stricken out, because $5,876 07 has been collected from assessments and paid in, and the amount actually required is $3,735, so that this year there is a surplus of $2,141 07. Item "to pay off principal of City Hall Loan, $5,000, issued in 1847, payable from 1861 to 1870," should be $3,275, that being amply sufficient to be raised each year to pay off the loan at maturity, making a total excess, according to the report of the Committee and as adopted, of $7,926 03. The Board refused to reconsider the former action taken. On motion of Alderman STRONG, however, the Board did subsequently consent to deduct $2,715 90, collected by assessments, from the Williamsburgh Local improvement Loan. The appropriation for principal of loans was then adopted, amounting as amended to $155-621 01. The salary appropriation was next considered. A motion to increase the amount $4,000 to meet the increase in salaries made at the last meeting of the Board of Aldermen, was lost, for want of a two-third vote. The full salary appropriations as adopted is $96,800. The Corporation Counselor, in compliance with a request of the joint Board, sent in a communication, stating that in his opinion the joint Board and not the Board of Aldermen should determine the amount to be raised for school purposes. The Common Council construed the law differently and voted the appropriation, which includes $10,000 for books for public schools. Alderman STRONG, to prevent any future difficulty, moved to insert $10,000 in the school budget for the same purposes, but this was lost. The Board adjourned to one week.

abstract: This match somewhat changed its character of being the return match with the Montreal Club, as two of the Canadians were sick and urgent business despatches had compelled the absence of two others. The St. George's Club therefore waived their right and consented to play an eleven, with Mr. Vernoll, of Philadelphia, giver. This having been arranged satisfactorily, Messrs. T.D. Phillipps and H. Phillipps commenced handling the willow for the Canadians. The former, who is one of the heaviest scorers of Upper Canada, being prettily caught by Waller, at point from Butt, H. Phillips made a splendidly played-for 29, by drives, cuts and by-hits for threes, twos and ones, and was prettily stumped out by the celebrated wicket-keeper of the St. George's Club, Mr. Lang, from a fine ball from H. Wright, Messrs. Hardinge and Daly's scores of 11 each were well got by good cricket -- the rest did nothing, and the innings closed for only 64, the bowling of both Wrights and Brett was excellent.

abstract: It is rumored that Secretary CASS contemplates a resignation. This rumor seems to be without foundation, however, as a letter received at the Department to-day announces his good health, and his intention to return about the 1st of September.

abstract: FUNERAL OF MRS. GARDINER SPRING. -- On Sunday last the venerable pastor of the "Old Brick church" preached the semi-centennial sermon of his ministry in this City. It was an occasion worthy of commemoration and the surviving friends of the Rev. Doctor -- those who were youths with him, (very few they were,) those who knew him in early manhood, those who, in successive years, have attended his (church -- were gathered together on that occasion. It was known then that his esteemed wife was sick, and that, being advanced in years, her health might never again thoroughly be restored; but it was not anticipated that the end was so near. The sermon was preached on Sunday -- on Tuesday she died. The funeral solemnities took place yesterday afternoon, at the Fifth-avenue Brick Church -- the same edifice in which the semi-centennial sermon had been preached four days before. Of course, it was filled with mourners. The preliminary services were held at Dr. SPRING's house, in Thirty-seventh-street, after which the body was borne to the Church -- Messrs. Horace Holden, Shepherd Knapp, Abner L. Ely, Thomas Egleston, Moses Allen, Peter Naylor, Guy Richards, Jasper Corning, Samuel Marsh and Daniel Lord acting as pall-bearers. Dr. SPRING followed the corpse, reported by his four sons. Dr. HOGE commenced the services by reading the fifth Chapter of Paul's Second Epistle to the Corinthians. After the singing of a [???]mn, Rev. Mr. PHILLIPS invoked the Divine blessing, and Dr. HOGS followed in a touching address, a binding with, eloquent earnestness to the merits of the deceased end her honored husband. At the close of his impressive words there was hardly a dry eye in the congregation. Rev. Mr. PLUMMER of Virginity, made the closing prayer. The body, which was occased in a rosewood coffin with silver mountings and surrounded with flowers, was viewed by many at the close of the services, and was then placed in the vault of the Church preparatory to inter-[???]ountin the family vault in second avenue Cemetery.

abstract: The Court met yesterday an hour before the usual time, in order to expedite business and clear the City Prison of its inmates as soon as possible. Recorder BARNARD took his seat on the beach at 10 o'clock, and remained there for seven hours, during which no less than sixteen cases were wholly or partially disposed of, making the greatest number, -- most of them being highly important, -- that have been treated in one day for several years past.

abstract: -- For the past month there have been rumors, sometimes contradicted and sometimes generally believed, that Mr. GLADSTONE was about to' retire from the English Cabinet. The last news from England reported that the Right Hon. gentleman's resignation was again considered imminent. He is understood to be in a state of hesitancy, but the probabilities are that he will withdraw. In the event of quitting office, it is Mr. GLADSTONE's intention to retire for a time from Parliament and public life. It appears. from a Liverpool paper, that Mr. GLADSTONE was lately spoken of in the pulpit, by Rev. Dr. M'NEILE -- a preacher of great reputation and eloquence -- as the "insane popular Chancellor of the. Exchequer," to the great astonishment of an attentive congregation.

abstract: Policemen, like other mortals, must have their amusements, and anything in reason we should be sorry to refuse them. In London the chief delight of this interesting class of the community is to slip down areas in pursuit of imaginary burglars, whom of course they do not find, accost comfortable cooks at the kitchen windows, and "bring up" finally before a leg of cold mutton and a mug of good ale. In Paris, where a sharper watch is kept upon their vagaries, they are forced to confine themselves to pouncing suddenly upon young conscripts, who can talk nothing but their native patois, and charging them with unlawful absence from barracks. In New-York the Policeman's range is wider -- so wide, indeed, as sometimes to include sports not altogether compatible with the serene and regular administration of the law. One of these sports, in particular -- a sudden access of which usually comes upon the guardians of the public peace at about this time of the year -- is decidedly too perilous to the general welfare to be overlooked.
lead_paragraph: Policemen, like other mortals, must have their amusements, and anything in reason we should be sorry to refuse them. abstract: The thermometer, in our City at least, behaved itself better yesterday than on any day since Sunday. On that day the mercury was rapidly in the ascendant, on Monday it ascended, further, on Tuesday still further, and on Wednesday further still; so that in a corresponding ratio of ascension, blood heat should have been reached to-day at noon, and about Monday next the quicksilver could have stopped at nothing short of the celebrated 212 degrees, boiling point. But fortunately for us, the mercury took its "Excelsior" behavior into consideration, and, disregarding our State motto, and the youth who through an Alpine village bore a banner with a strange device, it commenced to descend, very gradually, however, be it said, until last night it reached the comfortable figure of 84. At that figure men, women and children can sleep at night, and in the day time, by avoiding extra exertion, can summon energy sufficient to sit upright at dinner time. If the thermometer will behave itself so well for the remainder of the dog days, we will forgive it for its recent loftiness of expression.

At that figure men, women and children can sleep at night, and in the day time, by avoiding extra exertion, can summon energy sufficient to sit upright at dinner time. If the thermometer will behave itself so well for the remainder of the dog days, we will forgive it for its recent loftiness of expression.

abstract: On Wednesday afternoon, the Atlantic ground, corner of Marcy and Gates avenues, Brooklyn, was the scene of the greatest gathering that has yet appeared on a ball ground, excelling in numbers even the great assemblage on the Excelsior ground on the occasion of the former match between these two Clubs. The ground was completely inclosed by a wall of human beings; this was well lined on the inside with ladies, and strongly entrenched without by numerous vehicles crammed to overflowing. Hundreds of representatives of the Clubs of cities and villages far and near, -- from Buffalo, Rochester, Albany, Troy, Newark, Elizabeth, Rahway, Boston, etc., were on the ground, and altogether the scene was one of unwonted excitement. The friends of both parties were out in full force, and any success on either side was greeted with loud applause, the Atlantic throats being in the ascendancy. During the first three innings the Excelsior play was very fine, the Atlantic's not scoring a run, but in the fourth innings they played quite loosely, and the Atlantics succeeded in scoring two runs, Leggett permitting two or three balls to pass. Up to this point the Atlantics fielding was very unsteady and the throwing quite wild, P. O'Brien letting several balls pass by him without stopping them, and Hawkshurst missing an easy chance on the bound. They profited, however, by a mistake on the part of the Excelsiors, for some outsider calling out foul for a ball struck fair, deceived and became the means of putting out two of their players. In the first innings Smith made a very fine fly catch from a staver sent by Brainerd to the third base. In the Atlantics sixth innings Joe Oliver distinguished himself by a splendid hit past second base, on which he made his third. John Oliver was put out by a fine stop, and thrown by Whiting from the third to Pearsall at the first. In the Excelsiors sixth, Smith made a wild throw to the first base, sending Creighton, but a good bound catch by M. O'Brien and two neat plays by Jno. Oliver and McMahon left him there and the Excelsiors without a run, amid great cheering. In the next innings of the Atlantics their batting was very powerful and safe, and the outside excitement was most intense, McMahon sending two men home and making his second on a strike to left field, and P. O'Brien also making his second on a similar strike. Jno. Oliver struck a splendid ball over the left fielder, on which he made his third; this was the best hit of the game. Price was caught in the left field by Russell, acknowledgedly one of the most beautiful catches ever witnessed on a ball ground. A miss on the fly by Brainerd and a ball passing the catcher gave Pierce, a run. The innings was one of the finest on both sides that has occurred at any time, the batting bordering on the terrific, and the throwing of the Excelsiors being splendid. The Excelsior seventh was marked by a good fly catch by Smith; a good hit to the centre field, which took Leggett to his second, but was left there by a tip from Holder's bat, which ended operations. Russell was put on to pitch instead of Creighton, and with the best success, the Atlantics making nil. In the corresponding Excelsior innings, Joe Oliver made a very pretty bound catch at left field, disposing of Whiting.

abstract: We learn, from late English papers, that Mr. BUXTON has given notice of his intention to bring the question of the African Slave-trade before the House of Commons on the 31st of July. Mr. BUXTON, like his father before him, has been a consistent champion of freedom, and whatever he says on the present occasion will not pass unheeded, in directing attention to the rapid increase of the Slave-trade during recent years, Mr. BUXTON will move that, in the opinion of Parliament, it is the duty of the British Government to enforce upon the Government of Spain the immediate execution of the treaties regarding the Slave-trade -- firstly, by demanding the repayment, with interest, of the two million of dollars paid by England to Spain upon the condition that the Slave-trade should be abolished; and, secondly, by suspending diplomatic relations with Spain until the treaties are fully carried out.

abstract: The lover of law and order, devoutly believing in the wisdom of democratic institutions, must look with questionable satisfaction at the course of affairs in Texas. The story of a contemplated insurrection among the negroes, which was received here originally with distrust, appears to have had foundation in fact. The programme, according to the newspapers and letter-writers, involved the destruction by fire of all stores and dwellings, and a general uprising of the blacks, aided by white confederates, on August election day, when the white population was to be massacred without mercy or reservation. Depositories of arms have, it is said, been discovered; a host of the conspirators, colored and colorless, have been arrested, and correspondence implicating leading men at the North has been found.
lead_paragraph: The lover of law and order, devoutly believing in the wisdom of democratic institutions, must look with questionable satisfaction at the course of affairs in Texas. The story of a contemplated insurrection among the negroes, which was received here originally with distrust, appears to have had foundation in fact. The programme, according to the newspapers and letter-writers, involved the destruction by fire of all stores and dwellings, and a general uprising of the blacks, aided by white confederates, on August election day, when the white population was to be massacred without mercy or reservation. Depositories of arms have, it is said, been discovered; a host of the conspirators, colored and colorless, have been arrested, and correspondence implicating leading men at the North has been found.

abstract: We are glad to perceive that Mr. DOUGLAS is giving himself a respite from his labors as a stump candidate for the Presidency. It is now several days since we have received a speech from him, and we believe he has suspended operations for the present, and is enjoying the repose of an exhausted patriot at Sachem's Head. He will naturally have an opportunity and strong inducements for meditation; -- and we trust he will resolve, as the result of his reflections, to wholly abandon stump-speech-making so long as he is a candidate.

abstract: The steamship Europa, from Liverpool via Halifax, arrived at Boston last evening, and her mails will arrive in this City to-day. Some additional European intelligence is telegraphed from Boston. The town of Melazzo was attacked on the 20th of July by GARIBALDI, with the bayonet, and after a desperate struggle the Neapolitans were forced to retire to the citadel, with the loss of 580 men put hors de combat. GARIBALDI's losses were also very heavy, he himself being wounded in the foot. The statement that the whole of Sicily had been evacuated by the Neapolitans was premature.

abstract: George Barnes et al. vs. James C. Willett.  This was an action brought against the defendant, as Sheriff of the City and County of New-York, to recover the amount of a debt owed the plaintiff by one Jacob Cohen, who escaped from the custody of the Sheriff.
lead_paragraph: George Barnes et al. vs. James C. Willett. -- This was an action brought against the defendant, as Sheriff of the City and County of New-York, to recover the amount of a debt owed the plaintiff by one Jacob Cohen, who escaped from the custody of the Sheriff. The defendant put in an answer, averring that the escaped debtor had been in some respects wronged by the plaintiffs, and that Cohen was insolvent and could not have paid the debt, even had he been detained longer.

abstract: The undersigned, in compliance with the spontaneous desires of many benevolent friends, as well as their own, would respectively invite those gentlemen who feel interested in behalf of the tens of thousands of Christians in Syria who have been made wretched wanderers, shelterless, and ready to perish with famine by a most ruthless and fanatical war, to meet at the American Tract Society's House next Monday, at 3 P.M., to devise measures for having the subject of sending relief to these poor people brought, as soon as possible, before the Churches in an effective and responsible manner.

abstract: In the House of Commons, on the 27th ult. Mr. M. MILNES asked the Home Secretary what measures had been taken to bring about a Convention with the Government of the United States to remedy the impunity with which crimes are committed on board vessels trading between the United States and ...
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons, on the 27th ult. Mr. M. MILNES asked the Home Secretary what measures had been taken to bring about a Convention with the Government of the United States to remedy the impunity with which crimes are committed on board vessels trading between the United States and this country, and called the attention of the House to some recent circumstances bearing on the question. It would be recollected that last year he called attention to the horrible atrocities committed on board American vessels trading between England and the United States, the perpetrators of which atrocities, in consequence of the defective state of the law, were able to escape with entire impunity. At that time the Foreign Minister undertook to do everything in his power to remedy that great evil, but the noble Lord, at the beginning of the present session, informed the House that he had handed the matter over to the Home Secretary, considering the question to be one of domestic legislation. Since that period the House had not heard one word of the matter, although the atrocities were still frequently committed. A sailor lately died in a hospital in Liverpool in consequence of injuries received on board the Ocean Monarch. An inquest was held upon his body, and the jury returned a verdict of manslaughter against the second and third mates; but these men escaped under the Extradition Treaty during the inquest, and were now free from the consequences of their brutality. What rendered the case worse was that the parties in question were the same men who, three years ago, were found guilty of manslaughter on board a ship bearing the pacific name of John Bright. [A laugh.] It seemed that the crime of manslaughter did not come within the terms of the Extradition Treaty. If this sort of proceeding was to go on, he asked what quantum of murder would be sufficient to induce the Government of this country and of the United States to put a stop to such transactions? Was the great Atlantic to be a place where every kind of outrage might be committed with impunity, and did not the Government of this country and the Government of the United States see that as regards two civilized nations such a state of things was a great calamity and opprobrium to humanity?

abstract: The sympathy for GARIBALDI expressed at the late Newport meeting will, we hope, be reechoed throughout the whole country to some practical purpose. In England very large sums of money have been raised for the cause of freedom in Italy, and the greatest enthusiasm for GARIBALDI prevails among the people, Not content ...
lead_paragraph: -- The sympathy for GARIBALDI expressed at the late Newport meeting will, we hope, be reechoed throughout the whole country to some practical purpose. In England very large sums of money have been raised for the cause of freedom in Italy, and the greatest enthusiasm for GARIBALDI prevails among the people, Not content with a general fund, the people have expressed a desire to have boxes placed in situations of public resort so that all may contribute their mite. This has been done recently in London, Liverpool, Manchester, and other large towns. There are also in the large towns Committees of "the Ladies' Garibaldi Benevolent Association" to whom subscriptions are forwarded. The object of this Association is not to supply munitions of war to GARIBALDI, but to furnish aid to the poor fellows who are lying in hospital and to the families who have suffered from the barbarities committed at Palermo and elsewhere by the Neapolitan troops. We trust and believe that in the United States there will be an equal amount of practical sympathy shown for the cause of freedom in Italy; and at the present time it is only necessary to organize a movement, similar to any of those already organized in England, to insure the contribution of very material aid from America to GARIBALDI and his noble compatriots.

abstract: The new "Wigwam" recently erected by the Republicans of South Brooklyn, in Court-street, opposite Douglass, was dedicated last evening with great eclat.
lead_paragraph: The new "Wigwam" recently erected by the Republicans of South Brooklyn, in Court-street, opposite Douglass, was dedicated last evening with great eclat. Not less than a thousand of the sachems, chiefs, and young warriors of the party assembled in council, and some thirty or forty of the most beautiful squaws of Brooklyn graced the occasion with their presence. The "Rocky Mountain Glee Club," the "Prarie Songsters," and an excellent brass band furnished music for the fete.

abstract: A letter in the Cologne Gazette states that Pope has refused to adopt any of the measures suggested by the French Minister and has declared if these charges are forced on him, he will abandon his States. The Papal Government is still in constant alarm by the rapid organization of an army in Sicily. The rumor that GARIBALDI had embarked with a strong force, with the intention of landing on the Italian coast, has increased the alarm of the Roman authorities. It is feared that GARIBALDI may suddenly appear on the papal territory his real purpose being quite unknown, LAMOBICIERE is doing his utmost to bring the Pope's land force into a condition that may enable him to attempt some defensive movement.

abstract: The Europa's mails reached this City last evening from Boston. We derive from our correspondence and foreign files, which extend to the 28th ult., some additional details of interest.
lead_paragraph: The Europa's mails reached this City last evening from Boston. We derive from our correspondence and foreign files, which extend to the 28th ult., some additional details of interest. Owing to the Porte's remonstrances, the French expedition to Syria has been postponed, though there is every reason to believe that the Emperor NAPOLEON has not relinquished his intention of dispatching a formidable body of troops to the Levant. The intelligence from Sicily is important. Several severe engagements had been fought near Melazzo, in which the Sicilians were victorious. GARIBALDI himself, as before reported, was slightly wounded. Contradictory reports are rife as to whether the Neapolitans have or have not evacuated Sicily. The greatest uneasiness prevailed at Naples and at Rome, and we may be prepared to hear at any moment that Francis II. or the Pope, or both, have fled from their dominions.

abstract: Coroner GAMBLE yesterday concluded an investigation of the circumstances connected with the death of ROBERT FOSTER, an infant four days old, who area alleged to have been the victim of malpractice on the part of Dr. MACDONALD ALLEN, of No. 447 Grand-street, the attending physician.
lead_paragraph: Coroner GAMBLE yesterday concluded an investigation of the circumstances connected with the death of ROBERT FOSTER, an infant four days old, who area alleged to have been the victim of malpractice on the part of Dr. MACDONALD ALLEN, of No. 447 Grand-street, the attending physician. The testimony demonstrated that the death of the child had been caused by an overdose of opium, administered at the Doctor's direction, and a verdict was given to hat effect. The jury also charged Dr. ALLEN with having been culpably careless in prescribing the medicine, and censured the druggist who made up the prescription for not warning the father of the child of the danger of using so powerful a drug in the case in question. Coroner GAMBLE, under these circumstances, deemed it to be his duty to require Dr. ALLEN to furnish bail for his appearance to answer before the Grand Jury, should any action be taken against him. In extenuation of his error the doctor stated that of late he had been much troubled in mind, and that unwittingly he wrote the word, "opium," instead of "rhubarb," which he had intended to have done. He says that he feels very keenly the result of his error, but does not himself attribute the child's death to the opium, and gives the reason for his opinion in his examination. In the account of the case which was published on Thursday it was stated that Dr. ALLEN had said that the child did not require any medicine, but that he prescribed it merely to gratify the mother; but he denies having made any such remark.

abstract: Mr. George Robinson was robbed of a gold watch and chain a few nights since, as he was passing through Chatham street, by two men known as Thos, Price and Henry Bourget, alias "Frenchy." Mr. Robinson managed to detain Price until the arrival
lead_paragraph: Mr. George Robinson was robbed of a gold watch and chain a few nights since, as he was passing through Chatham street, by two men known as Thos, Price and Henry Bourget, alias "Frenchy." Mr. Robinson managed to detain Price until the arrival of a policeman, who conducted him to the Station-house, but Bourget escaped with the booty. Yesterday Price revealed the name of his associate in the robbery, and made an affidavit before Justice WELSH, charging him with the offence. The magistrate thereupon issued a warrant for the arrest of the accused, and placed it in the hands of Officer McCord, of the Lower Police Court, who found the object of his search at Police Headquarters, where he was in custody of the Detectives, who had apprehended him for the purpose of "showing him up." Having been taken before Justice WELSH, he was committed to answer the charge.

abstract: By way of illustrating the remarkable truth never before discovered or set forth, that there are "monsters in the moral as well as in the material world," our moral contemporary the Tribune, yesterday morning laid before its readers a full, true, and particular account of ...
lead_paragraph: By way of illustrating the remarkable truth never before discovered or set forth, that there are "monsters in the moral as well as in the material world," our moral contemporary the Tribune, yesterday morning laid before its readers a full, true, and particular account of the "interior life" of a most unhappy lady, Mrs. JOHN HENRY GURNEY, once the wife of a highly respectable member of the British Parliament, and now the paramour of her former groom. This interesting document appears to have been sent in the form of a letter from Mrs. GURNEY to some friend of her childhood, from whom she still hoped for love and pity in the hour of her profound social degradation. How it came to be published as a pamphlet in London is not quite clear. But how it comes to be republished in the columns of the New-York Tribune it needs no extraordinary astuteness to surmise. It receives this honor because, as our contemporary naively remarks:

abstract: HON. A.J. HAMILTON, of Texas, spoke at Austin on the 26th. After discussing local topics at some length, he turned to the consideration of the political issues involved in the present canvass. Mr. BRECKINRIDGE he called the candidate of the Democratic Secession
lead_paragraph: -- HON. A.J. HAMILTON, of Texas, spoke at Austin on the 26th. After discussing local topics at some length, he turned to the consideration of the political issues involved in the present canvass. Mr. BRECKINRIDGE he called the candidate of the Democratic Secessionists. Mr. DOUGLAS, on the other hand, was the nominee of the National Democracy. He had not changed his position since 1850, and was the only reliable Union man before the people. Mr. HAMILTON's next choice was Gen. HOUSTON, and his third Col. BELL. If compelled to choose between LINCOLN and BRECKINRIDGE he would reluctantly support the later. He spoke at length regarding the secession influences by which Mr. BRECKINRIDGE was surrounded, and denounced Mr. YANCEY and the members of the Constitutional Contention, whom he styled his followers, in the severest terms. "Whom the gods love," as the proverb goes, "die young." Mr. BRECKINRIDGE was young, and he considered him politically dead. Mr. HAMILTON said, further, that he would not give his own chances for the Presidency for those of BRECKINRIDGE. He might, when he was very dry, dispose of them for a glass of lager, but he would not exchange even with BRECKINRIDGE; he would rather start like old SAM HOUSTON, "go it alone and get eucred." He ridiculed Gen. LANE as an ignorant and illiterate man, one who had fought well for his country, and deserved well in an humble way; but he was so very ignorant that he would venture the assertion that unless he had been drilled since his nomination, he could not mention the names of half a dozen Governments existing at the present time, outside of the limits of the United States. Mr. HAMILTON concluded by denouncing all who were not in favor of submission to the election of LINCOLN, or any other man elected with the necessary constitutional majority, and declared it they should go about with halters in their hands for those who were in favor of submitting to the constitutional authorities of the land, that they themselves would furnish both the victims and the halter. He also advocated a coalition, by means of one Electoral ticket, of the friends of DOUGLAS, HOUSTON and BELL, and said that with the conservative element which would thus be united against the Secession candidate, there could be no doubt that Texas would give twenty thousand majority against BRECKINRIDGE, and that he was willing to meet the champion of Secession upon any of these issues.

abstract: QUARANTINE AND THE PUBLIC HEALTH. Mr. CYRUS CURTISS has addressed several interrogatories to Dr. A.H. GUNN, the Health Officer of the Port, touching the enforcement of Quarantine regulations upon emigrant and other vessels arriving with passengers after long voyages, and also relative to the facilities which he has, under the present Quarantine regime ...
lead_paragraph: QUARANTINE AND THE PUBLIC HEALTH. -- Mr. CYRUS CURTISS has addressed several interrogatories to Dr. A.H. GUNN, the Health Officer of the Port, touching the enforcement of Quarantine regulations upon emigrant and other vessels arriving with passengers after long voyages, and also relative to the facilities which he has, under the present Quarantine regime for the detention and treatment of passengers exposed on their voyage to contagious or infectious diseases. To these questions Dr. GUNN replies, first, that the utmost vigilance is exercised to ascertain the sanitary condition of all such vessels, and, when necessary, the most rigid quarantine measures are enforced. Second, that vessels arriving from ports where malignant, contagious or infectious diseases are known to prevail are quarantined. Ship fever, small-pox and cholera generally occur in emigrant passenger ships from European ports. Third, he has a hospital ship well equipped for the treatment of yellow-fever patients, where the disease can be as successfully treated as on land. Cases of small-pox are treated on Blackwell's Island, and the vessels on which such cases arrive are detained at Quarantine until they are fumigated and well cleansed. Cholera and ship fever, he says, have become almost extinct.

abstract: George C. Jordan vs. Laura Keene -- In the Marine Court, before Judge MAYNARD, the plaintiff in this action now obtained another judgment against I aura Keene for $108 48, being for one week's service and costs. He has obtained two former judgments of the same sort, all based upon the charge that he was called upon to take a humbler part upon the stage of the defendant than that of "leading young man." He refused to play, and did not play, and resorted to the Courts for redress with such success. In one former case, however, judgment was given for the defendant.
lead_paragraph: George C. Jordan vs. Laura Keene -- In the Marine Court, before Judge MAYNARD, the plaintiff in this action now obtained another judgment against I aura Keene for $108 48, being for one week's service and costs. He has obtained two former judgments of the same sort, all based upon the charge that he was called upon to take a humbler part upon the stage of the defendant than that of "leading young man." He refused to play, and did not play, and resorted to the Courts for redress with such success. In one former case, however, judgment was given for the defendant.

abstract: It appears that the massacre at Damascus commenced in the afternoon of the 9th, and that before night 500 Christians had been killed. The first consulate attacked was that of Russia. The Russian and Greek consuls took refuge with ABD-EL KADER. All the Catholic and Greek churches and convents, as well as the consulates, are burnt. The American vice consul was wounded, and the Dutch vice-consul said to be killed.

abstract: The United States corvette Jamestown is to be taken in hands at once and prepared for active squadron duty. She is at Philadelphia, where operations will be immediately commenced on her.
lead_paragraph: The United States corvette Jamestown is to be taken in hands at once and prepared for active squadron duty. She is at Philadelphia, where operations will be immediately commenced on her. The Jamestown is a first-class sailing sloop-of war, 985 tons burden. She will have on board 22 guns and about 300 men. The station to which she is to go has not been named.

abstract: SUICIDE AT GREENVILLE. -- Yesterday morning a man, named SAMUEL W. ELLIS was found suspended by the neck by a rope attached to a tree, at Saltersville. The night previous he stopped at NEWKIRK's Hotel, in Hudson City. After singing one or two songs, he bade the party good night and went away. It is said that he belonged to the Metropolitan Police force until within a year past, and was located in the Third Ward.

abstract: Yesterday was the last day of the August Term of this Court. The business was brisk. He is liable to be tried on other charges when he is released, but, of course, being a politician, he will not.

abstract: SUNDAY SCHOOLS IN MONROE COUNTY. The Sabbath School teachers of Menroe County held a Convention in Rochester a few days ago. The number of Protestant schools in the County is 187, an increase of 11 over last year.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY SCHOOLS IN MONROE COUNTY. -- The Sabbath School teachers of Menroe County held a Convention in Rochester a few days ago. The number of Protestant schools in the County is 187, an increase of 11 over last year. They embrace 2,185 teachers, end 16,798 scholars. The average attendance of scholars has been 12,402. abstract: The Charleston Mercury the other day said that LINCOLN would certainly be elected, unless the North could be made to believe that in such an event the South would dissolve the Union.
lead_paragraph: The Charleston Mercury the other day said that LINCOLN would certainly be elected, unless the North could be made to believe that in such an event the South would dissolve the Union. In the effect of this menace the Mercury places its last hope of defeating the Republican candidate. Southern Pro-Slavery Democrats evidently take the same view of the case, and are trying to act upon it. They have planned a regular political campaign, based on making the North believe that Disunion will follow LINCOLN's election. A Committee has been appointed to catechise Southern members of Congress, and elicit from them letters in favor of dissolution. First came KEITT's ferocious manifesto -- full of sound and fury, written in the Ercles vein and proclaiming the instant secession of South Carolina in case LINCOLN should be elected. It was the first gun in the general bombardment, -- but it scared nobody but the poor old woman who edits the Herald, and whose nerves have been for a long time so shattered that the noise of a pop-gun gives her spasms. Everybody else laughed -- and there it ended. Next came Speaker ORR's pronunciamiento, in which the menace was slightly modified. He was in favor of secession, -- quite as much so as Col. KEITT, -- but he was more judicious: -- he was opposed to South Carolina's going out alone: -- when she could get four or five States to keep her in countenance, then he waa in favor of her departure, -- but not before. This, so far as it goes, is sensible, -- and everybody saw at once that, if the Union lasted until Mr. ORR could get everything comfortably arranged for its dissolution, the peril of that event was not immediate. Mr. BOYCE is the next customer: and his fulmination will be found in full in another column.
headline: {'main': 'More Disunion Nonsense.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'More Disunion Nonsense.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: The Union Camp Meeting of various denominations, near Yonkers, N.Y., which has continued about a week, closed yesterday with most interesting services. The propitious weather drew an unusual number of visitors from the City. The cordial union of the various denominations participating in the occasion during the week, has been a source of great gratification to all, and has engendered a spirit of conciliation among evangelical Christians which cannot but be productive of good results. Among the clergymen who have participated in the religious ceremonies have been Rev. Washington Gladden, Congregational Methodist; Professor Matteson, Congregational Methodist; Lawson, the Baptist boy preacher; Dr. Mitchell, Episcopal Methodist; Rev. Dr. Pennington, Baptist; Rev. N. Platt, Protestant Methodist; Rev. W.S. Bell, Graham-avenue Church, Brooklyn, Wesleyan Methodist; Rev. J.J. Murray, D.D., Methodist Protestant; Rev. T. Easton, Wesleyan Methodist; Rev. P. Weaver, Methodist Protestant; Rev. J.Q. Adams, Baptist; Rev. Ezra Withey, Protestant Methodist; Rev. Wm. Irving, Independent Methodist; Rev. R. Hanks, Methodist Protestant; Rev. J.J. Smith, Methodist Protestant; Rev. S.A. Baker, Wesleyan Methodist; Rev. Mr. Curry, of New-York, and others. The attendance has been very fair, though at no time so large as the grounds could easily accommodate. Yesterday witnessed probably the largest gathering of the week -- upwards of a thousand having visited the camp during the day. The Committee have been much gratified at the strict order preserved on the ground, through the efficacy of Sergeant JOHNS and a squad of Metropolitan Police. They had not only the pleasure of seeing intoxicating liquors summarily removed, and the owners fined, but even the omnipresent lager, which at first graced either side of the entrance, was dispensed with.

abstract: "Conversions from the Democracy to Republicanism are reported with a frequency well calculated to alarm the most confident Douglasite, and the reports emanate from sources, and relate to parties about whom no manufactured story could live a day. In Indianapolis, since the Breckinridge Convention, ...
lead_paragraph: "Conversions from the Democracy to Republicanism are reported with a frequency well calculated to alarm the most confident Douglasite, and the reports emanate from sources, and relate to parties about whom no manufactured story could live a day. In Indianapolis, since the Breckinridge Convention, CHARLES COULON, the most prominent German Democrat in the city, and one of the marshals at the Douglas Convention of the 18th, has declared his intention to support LINCOLN. Following in his wake, and influenced by the same reasons, (the impossibility of electing DOUGLAS, and their preference for LINCOLN next,) twelve other active German Democrats have marched into the Republican camp. In, the Fourth District, many recruits, mainly from the German Democracy, are reported -- no less than fifty in one township of Ripley County, being of the number. Though heretofore esteemed nearly hopeless, the most sagacious Republicans begin to feel that the Fourth District will be redeemed this Fall. In Wabash County, the Plaindealer, the leading Douglas paper of the Eleventh District, has hauled down the Douglas flag, and run up that of LINCOLN, assigning as a reason that, with the Wickliffe resolutions as his platform, DOUGLAS is only a Northern man with Southern principles; while BRECKINRIDGE is a Southern man with Southern principles; BELL is a Southern man with no principles; and LINCOLN is a Northern man with the nearest approach to national principles of all of them. A very satisfactory reason. Nearly all the candidates -- State, Congressional and county -- are now busily engaged in the canvass. Every local paper is full of reports of 'enthusiastic rallies' that have been, or of appointments for those to be. Though by no means up to the mark of 1856, yet the enthusiasm is visibly and rapidly rising. Big meetings are becoming common, and crowds of 5,000 and 10,000 have been addressed by leading speakers at least ten times in the last two weeks. Up in the Ninth District COLFAX is having a perfect ovation at every appointment. Even the township meetings he is holding in the 'outermost parts' of Miami and Cass show crowds of 1,000 and more."

abstract: The correspondence of the Foreign Office in London relative to the present critical state of affairs in the East having been presented to Parliament, we are enabled to give an extract from a letter addressed to the British Consul at Beyrout by Rev. W. BIRD, an American ...
lead_paragraph: The correspondence of the Foreign Office in London relative to the present critical state of affairs in the East having been presented to Parliament, we are enabled to give an extract from a letter addressed to the British Consul at Beyrout by Rev. W. BIRD, an American Missionary residing at Deir-el-Kamar, the Christian capital of the Lebanon, respecting the state of that place. Previous to the receipt of Mr. BIRD's letter, which is dated May 28th, the Consul had mentioned the matter to RESCHID PASHA, who promised to do all in his power to open the communication with Deir-el-Kamar, which was intercepted by the Druses. The letter was sent to Sir H. BULWER, and by him inclosed to Lord J. RUSSELY; the extract is as follows:

abstract: In pursuance of instructions forwarded by the Earl of CLARENDON in 1857 to all Her Britannic Majesty's Secretaries of Embassy and Legation, that they should send in half-yearly reports on the commerce, industry, and sta- ...
lead_paragraph: In pursuance of instructions forwarded by the Earl of CLARENDON in 1857 to all Her Britannic Majesty's Secretaries of Embassy and Legation, that they should send in half-yearly reports on the commerce, industry, and statistics of the countries in which they respectively reside, Mr. IRVINE, Her Majesty's Secretary of Legation at Washington, has forwarded one report to the Foreign Office in London, which is included in the Blue Book of such reports, just presented to the British Parliament. Mr. IRVINE gives a tabular statement of the revenue and expenditure of the fiscal year, which ended June 30, 1859, and of the commerce and navigation of the United States for the same period, drawn from the official report of the Treasury Department, and a brief statistical view of American manufactures, compiled from the digest made in 1858, of the returns of the census of 1850, and presented to the Senate. As Mr. IRVINE makes no comment on these statistics, there is nothing original in the portion of his report which relates to them; but his remarks on the agriculture of the United States are interesting, both because the subjects which he notices have recently engaged the attention of the Patent Office at Washington, and for the important bearing which they have on the export trade of the country. After noticing the variety and productiveness of our soil, and stating, as an instance of the latter quality, that in Ohio an acre of land planted with vines, will, in a favorable year, produce two hundred and fifty gallons of wine, whereas the best vineyards in the Bordeaux district, of France, do not furnish more than one hundred and twenty-six gallons per acre, Mr. IRVINE remarks upon the low state of agriculture among us, and the consequent disparity between the produce of the soil on the one hand, and the extent of the land and number of the population on the other. "The immense extent of territory," he observes, "and the comparative scantiness of the population, have induced a good deal of carelessness in the cultivation of the soil. The price of land being low, the proprietors have found it more economical to work out their land than to expend their capital in manures and other means for preserving its productive qualities; and when the soil has become exhausted, the owners have left it for some new settlement. The consequence of this has been that, instead of full and abundant crops, in many parts of the older settled portions of the country, the fields do not yield at present half as much as formerly, and in many localities not a third, nor even a quarter, as much; and that, notwithstanding the advantages of climate, the facility of transport to available markets, and the lightly taxed condition of farmers and planters, the ratio of increase in the agricultural products of the United States is not in proportion to the increase of population."
headline: {'main': 'An English Diplomatist on American Agriculture.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'An English Diplomatist on American Agriculture.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The steamship Adriatic, from Havre and Southampton on the 1st inst., arrived at this port on Saturday morning. Her advices are four days later. The most important feature in the news is a letter on the state of Europe from the Emperor NAPOLEON to the Count DE PERSIGNY, French Ambassador to the Court of London. On the two great leading topics of the day the Emperor gives it, as his "innermost thought," that he desires peace for Italy without foreign intervention, and withes to undertake the Syrian Expedition in conjunction with other Powers. Particulars are received of the two actions fought on the 20th and 21st inst. at Melazzo, in which the Garibaldians were perfectly successful. GARIBALDI has entered Messina, and has concluded a military convention with the Neapolitan commander. It is confirmed that the General has refused to grant the truce asked for by the King of Sardinia, and that he expresses a firm intention to march upon Naples as soon as he has taken Messina. We have details of the massacre of Christians in Damascus. The accounts give the number of victims at three or four thousand. It was fully expected that a convention of the Great Powers, with regard to the Syrian question, would be signed on the 1st inst., and that immediately afterwards an embarkation of a combined Russian, French, and English expedition would take place. We publish divers opinions of the German Press on the late interview at Toplitz, between the Emperor of Austria and the Prince of Prussia. They all seem to agree in thinking that the meeting has been successful, and that a better understanding between the two Cabinets has been promoted.

On the two great leading topics of the day the Emperor gives it, as his "innermost thought," that he desires peace for Italy without foreign intervention, and withes to undertake the Syrian Expedition in conjunction with other Powers. Particulars are received of the two actions fought on the 20th and 21st inst. at Melazzo, in which the Garibaldians were perfectly successful. GARIBALDI has entered Messina, and has concluded a military convention with the Neapolitan commander. It is confirmed that the General has refused to grant the truce asked for by the King of Sardinia, and that he expresses a firm intention to march upon Naples as soon as he has taken Messina. We have details of the massacre of Christians in Damascus. The accounts give the number of victims at three or four thousand. It was fully expected that a convention of the Great Powers, with regard to the Syrian question, would be signed on the 1st inst., and that immediately afterwards an embarkation of a combined Russian, French, and English expedition would take place. We publish divers opinions of the German Press on the late interview at Toplitz, between the Emperor of Austria and the Prince of Prussia. They all seem to agree in thinking that the meeting has been successful, and that a better understanding between the two Cabinets has been promoted.

abstract: TERRIBLE TORNADO IN WAYNE COUNTY. -- About 4 o'clock on Tuesday, 7th inst., a most destructive hurricane swept through the towns of Walworth, walidon, and Sodus, in Wayne County, doing frightful damage to everything in its way. Houses were unroofed, barns demolished, trees torn up by the roots, completely devastating a large section of country. Its path was over two miles wide, and was in nearly a straight line from Walworth to about the centre of the town of Sodus, when it suddenly turned toward Lake Ontario, which it probably struck not far from Sodus Point. Our informant came from Sodus village yesterday, and tells us that the south part of that town presents the most frightful spectacle he ever witnessed. Extensive tracts of woodland were leveled with the ground, and large orchards completely uprooted. Scarcely a rod of fence is left standing throughout the whole district over which the whirlwind passed. In some cases fence-rails were carried more than thirty rods by the terrific force of the wind. Trees more than two feet in diameter were twisted into splinters. We have not yet heard of any lives being destroyed, but it will be a marvel if there be none. The trees are fallen in ail directions, showing that it was a whirlwind, and not a gale. It was accompanied by a tremendous storm of rain and hail. We are not informed how far west it extended -- certainly 15 or 20 miles. -- Syracuse Journal, Aug. 9.
lead_paragraph: TERRIBLE TORNADO IN WAYNE COUNTY. -- About 4 o'clock on Tuesday, 7th inst., a most destructive hurricane swept through the towns of Walworth, walidon, and Sodus, in Wayne County, doing frightful damage to everything in its way. abstract: Owing to the prevalence of the heated term, or to some other equally satisfactory cause, dullness has reigned supreme throughout the Departments during the past week, although the clerks have been tied to their desks, and gave replies in very languid terms to any inquiries as to business. ...
lead_paragraph: Owing to the prevalence of the heated term, or to some other equally satisfactory cause, dullness has reigned supreme throughout the Departments during the past week, although the clerks have been tied to their desks, and gave replies in very languid terms to any inquiries as to business. A little variation from that monotony has, however, been caused by the decision of Judge INGRAHAM, pronounced on Saturday, settling the "West Washington Market Controversy," by deciding that the title to the property was vested in the City, and not in the State. Immediately upon the rendition of the decision, the Comptroller issued the following circular to all the tenants on the disputed territory, which will, of course, command respect and obedience. The back rents for two years, which have been paid into the hands of Cyrus Curtiss, Esq., special receiver, will probably also be paid into the City Treasury, and will prove quite an acceptable addition:

abstract: Capt. WALLING recently received information from the authorities of New-Brunswick, N.J., that a series of robberies had been committed at that place, chiefly of harness, sleigh robes and stable equipments, the wealthy residents of the village being the sufferers, but no clue to the thief had been obtained.
lead_paragraph: Capt. WALLING recently received information from the authorities of New-Brunswick, N.J., that a series of robberies had been committed at that place, chiefly of harness, sleigh robes and stable equipments, the wealthy residents of the village being the sufferers, but no clue to the thief had been obtained. Detectives Slowey and Sease were detailed to inquire into the matter, and, with scarcely any information upon which to base their proceedings, have been fortunate enough to effect the arrest of the robber, besides recovering the stolen property, which is valued in the aggregate at $600. These officers having learned on Saturday that one of the public porters at the Cortlandt-street ferry had been employed by a stranger to convey a barrel and a bag, containing harness to a certain house in Washington-street, went to the number indicated and found concealed in the garret a set of silver mounted double harness and a ladies' saddle and bridle. Instead of immediately taking possession of the property the detectives determined to await the appearance of its claimant, who, after the lapse of a few hours, came in. His looks corresponding with the description which had been given by the porter of the person who had employed him to bring the property to the place, he was taken into custody. He gave the name of William Ross, and made a full confession of the robberies in which he had been engaged, besides giving information which subsequently led to the recovery of all the property. He will be sent to-day to New-Brunswick for trial.

abstract: An inquest was held on Saturday by Coroner JACKMAN, upon the body of an unknown woman, of extreme age, who died at Bellevue Hospital, in consequence of abscess on the brain. During the progress of the investigation testimony was adduced ...
lead_paragraph: An inquest was held on Saturday by Coroner JACKMAN, upon the body of an unknown woman, of extreme age, who died at Bellevue Hospital, in consequence of abscess on the brain. During the progress of the investigation testimony was adduced which reflects strongly upon the authorities of Taunton, Mass., who, to relieve themselves of the burden of supporting their paupers, forward them to this City and desert them in our streets. The circumstances attending the admission of the deceased to the Hospital thus appeared in evidence:
