abstract: The Mercantile Courier, of Genoa, publishes an authentic account of the massacre at Damascus up to the 10th of July, inclusive, 3,000 Christians had taken refuge in the citadel occupied by the Algerines under ABDEL KADER. The town was in the power of the murderers and incendiaries to the number of 24,000, principally Druses and Bedouins. ...
lead_paragraph: The Mercantile Courier, of Genoa, publishes an authentic account of the massacre at Damascus up to the 10th of July, inclusive, 3,000 Christians had taken refuge in the citadel occupied by the Algerines under ABDEL KADER. The town was in the power of the murderers and incendiaries to the number of 24,000, principally Druses and Bedouins. The Turkish garrison consisted of 5,000 men, who were inactive or hostile. The soldiers had driven the Christians into the flames of the burning houses. Same account computes the number of victims at three to four thousand, but states that this may be exaggerated owing to the prevailing terror.

abstract: The Tammany Hall Delegation to the Democratic State Convention to be held at Syracuse, held a meeting at Tammany Hotel Saturday evening, in order to organize previous to leaving for that city.
lead_paragraph: The Tammany Hall Delegation to the Democratic State Convention to be held at Syracuse, held a meeting at Tammany Hotel Saturday evening, in order to organize previous to leaving for that city. The organization was completed by the election of Thos. B. TAPPAN, President, and JOHN HARDY, Secretary. The list of delegates and alternates is as follows: District 1, Michael Halpin, delegate. District 2, John Clancy, delegate. District 3, James B. Dupignac, delegate. District 4, Henry P. West, delegate; William McCaffil, alternate. District 5, Ralph Bogert, delegate; John Lynch, alternate. District 6, Moses D. Gale, delegate; George A. Jeremiah, alternate. District 7, John Richardson, delegate; William M. Giles, alternate. District 8, Francis B. O'Keefe, delegate. District 9, James Murray, delegate; James P. Dunn, alternate. District 10, Smith Ely, Jr., delegate. District 11, John Hardy, delegate; James G. Dimond, alternate. District 12, F.I.A. Boole, delegate; Richard H. Bishop, alternate. District 13, Michael Conolly, delegate; William H. Doherty, alternate. District 14, John R. Briggs, delegate. District 15. Abram S. Vosburg, delegate; George W. McLean, alternate. District 16, Terence Farley, delegate; William J. Hamilton, alternate. District 17, Thomas B. Tappan, delegate; William Harris, alternate.

abstract: The Emperor NAPOLEON has once more held  out the right hand of peace and friendship to his proud and suspicious ally beyond  the channel. ...
lead_paragraph: The Emperor NAPOLEON has once more held out the right hand of peace and friendship to his proud and suspicious ally beyond the channel. Departing once more from the traditions of diplomacy and of royalty, he has spoken his mind freely on the principles by which his policy has been guided in the past and will be governed in the future. To the warlike call of Lord PALMERSTON upon the English Parliament for more ships to hold the English seas, and more guns to arm the English coasts, NAPOLZON III. replies, by the most direct imaginable denial, either that France has armed herself beyond the proportions prescribed by her rank among the nations, or that her policy tends, at any point whatever, to a hostile collision with the policy of Great Britain.

abstract: Shortly after 5 o'clock on Saturday evening a fire was discovered in an office, situated in the rear of the second floor of MOFFAT's Building, corner of Broadway and Worth-street, occupied by Mr. J. ROSENTHAL, importer of paintings, and manufacturer of jewelry. The flames were soon extinguished, but the pictures were damaged by the heat, probably to the extent of $500, which is said to be covered by an insurance of $3,000 in the Excelsior and other companies. The origin of the fire has not been ascertained. Mr. ROSENTHAL had only been absent from the place a few minutes when it broke out. There are suspicions connected with the fire which the Fire Marshal intends to investigate.

abstract: The Petersburgh Express gives an account of a serious insurrection among the 200 negroes who are emlployed to load vessels at Sombrero Guano Island. The regular overseer had been temporarily superseded by one SNOW, a man of energy and determina
lead_paragraph: The Petersburgh Express gives an account of a serious insurrection among the 200 negroes who are emlployed to load vessels at Sombrero Guano Island. The regular overseer had been temporarily superseded by one SNOW, a man of energy and determination. He had long been accustomed to exact implicit obedience from the sailors whom he had formerly commanded as mate, and did not change his system of discipline on the Island. The negroes, who were principally English and Danish, and were obtained from the neighboring islands of the West Indies belonging to those nations, and were consequently always hostile to Americans, on account of the latter's slavery proclivities, grew dissatisfied with the management of their new superintendent and meditated every variety of revenge. Only four of them, however, seemed to have brought their designs to a concerted measure, and on the 24th of July, one of them was delegated to murder him, while the others were near to see that it was effectively done. They were engaged in loading a car, on this day, and the chosen murderer being on the top of it, took advantage of the foreman as he was stooping on the ground below, and hurled a tremendous lump of guano at his head, crushed his skull with the blow, and left him for dead on the ground. Considerable commotion followed among the whites upon the discovery of the attempted murder, and the negro who committed the deed was immediately attested by Capt. BURNELL, of the Emma Tuttle, and "Capt. BENTHALL of the bark Warren, of Baltimore, placed in irons and conveyed on board the latter vessel. It was their determination to take him into a United States port for trial. The arrest created the wildest excitement among the negroes, who rose en masse, and took possession of the island. The white employes, who numbered only twelve, were compelled to submit to the revolt, but were unharmed, since they remained non-committal, being too much intimidated to attempt to suppress the rage of 200 half-savage negroes, and at the same time afraid to join with them against the vessel, knowing that punishment was sure to follow from the United States authorities as soon as intelligence should have been conveyed to the nearest American port. The negroes threatened to sink the two vessels if their comrade was not given up; and when Capt. BENTHALL attempted to return to shore from the Warren they collected on the wharf and stoned him until he was forced to take refuge back upon his bark. Capt. BURNELL got ashore safely, but was met with savage demonstrations from the insurgents, who were armed in their right hands with huge clubs, and in their left with heavy blocks of guano. He with difficulty made his way through them, and was compelled to surrender all the English money he had in his possession, to appease them sufficiently to admit of his escape from their murderous clubs. Getting safely into the office of the agent, Mr. ELLIOTT, who is owner of a large interest in the island, and is well known in this city, he succeeded in making ready for his departure next day, having already taken his road for this city, and of returning unharmed to his vessel. Mr. ELLIOTT expected in the course of a few days fifty Irish hands from Richmond, with as many revolvers and other instruments of government and civilization, through means of which he would be able to subdue the revolters, and effectually prevent any further outrages, should it be his good fortune to escape their fury until that time.

abstract: DID NOT COMMIT SUICIDE. -- The report that a man named SAMUEL W. ELLIS was found suspended by the neck from a tree, near Saltersville, on Friday last, proved to be untrue. ELLIS started the rumor himself by sending a note to a person in Hoboken, stating that the body of a man was found in the woods, and that the name of "S.W. ELLIS" was marked in India ink on one of his arms. On Friday Mr. J. TREADWEL, of Hudson City, for whom ELLIS had formerly worked, ordered a mahogany coffin, of Mr. SPEER, undertaker in Jersey City, and directed that carriages should be in readiness at 4 A.M. on Saturday, [???] the purpose of giving the supposed deceased a decent burial. Some time in the evening the fact became known that ELLIS was still alive, and a messenger was at once dispatched to inform the undertaker that his coffin and carriages could be dispensed with. Mr. SPEER had just completed the trimming of the coffin, and was about retiring to get an early start for the burial. On Saturday ELLIS was about Hoboken, and pretended that until that morning he had no recollection of anything for several days previous.

abstract: The visitors at Long Branch were shocked on Saturday by the occurrence of a disaster, which threw a gloom over the place and for a time put an end to festivities among the people temporarily sojourning there. ...
lead_paragraph: The visitors at Long Branch were shocked on Saturday by the occurrence of a disaster, which threw a gloom over the place and for a time put an end to festivities among the people temporarily sojourning there. At the customary hour for bathing, Dr. EDWARD O. DUMMER, of Jersey City, Mr. JOHN WHITTAKER, of Trenton, and a party of ladies, proceeded to the beach and were engaged in bathing. The ladies, it is said, by some means got beyond their depth, and becoming alarmed called loudly for assistance, when Dr. DUMMER and Mr. WHITTAKER went to their relief. In their efforts to place the ladies in safety they were so much exhausted that a powerful undertow swept them away, and before they could be reached both the unfortunate men perished. A skiff which was near at hand was launched by Mr. GREEN, one of the fishermen, who succeeded in getting Dr. DUMMER into the boat, and carried him to the shore, where several physicians at once adopted the usual restoratives, but he was found to be beyond resuscitation. The body of Mr. WHITTAKER was also soon recovered, and every means tried to restore him to life, but without avail. The wife and a son of Mr. WITTAKER were with him at the place, where he had been a visitor for many years. He is said to have been an expert swimmer. Mr. WHITTAKER was engaged in the in the glass manufactory, and was very highly respected. His age was about 60 years.
headline: {'main': 'Distressing Accident at Long Branch.; TWO PERSONS DROWNED.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Distressing Accident at Long Branch.; TWO PERSONS DROWNED.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: MR. GUSTAVUS A. RATZ, SECRETARY OF THE LIQUOR DEALERS' ASSOCIATION, DROWNED. Yesterday Mr. GUSTAVUS A. RATZ, the well-known Secretary of the Liquor Dealers' Association, was drowned while bathing off the Pavilion Hotel, at the Nevasink Highlands. ...
lead_paragraph: MR. GUSTAVUS A. RATZ, SECRETARY OF THE LIQUOR DEALERS' ASSOCIATION, DROWNED. -- Yesterday Mr. GUSTAVUS A. RATZ, the well-known Secretary of the Liquor Dealers' Association, was drowned while bathing off the Pavilion Hotel, at the Nevasink Highlands. Mr. RATZ, his wife and several gentlemen and ladies were bathing in the surf, when the swift under[???]ment carried them beyond their depth. Through the assistance of those present all were rescued but Mr. RATZ, who became exhausted in his efforts to save his wife, and, sinking, was drowned before assistance reached him. Several physicians were early on the ground, when all the available means to resuscitate him were resorted to, but without avail. For some time the life of his wife was despaired of, it haying taken over half an hour to restore her to consciousness. A young man named GARDNER who was bathing with a party of lads near by at the same time, was also drowned, his death being the result of the strong undertow. Coroner MOUNT held inquests on the bodies, when verdicts of accidental drowning were rendered. The body of Mr. RATZ was brought to this City last evening by the steamboat Long Branch, and taken to his late residence, the Philadelphia Hotel, in the Bowery, of which he was the proprietor. Mr. RATZ was only twenty-seven years old. He was a native of Germany, and came to this country very young. For several years he was the Secretary of Commodore PERRY, and at one time was clerk in the office of Mr. AUGUSTE BELMONT. He was a member of the Seventh Regiment, as also of the Free Masons. Arrangements for his funeral will be made to-day. The young man GARDNER lived in Buffalo, and was on a visit to this City.

abstract: The Camden and Amboy Railroad is generally conceded to be a credit to New-Jersey. The cars are new and comfortable, the engines whirl their attendant trains along at quite a respectable rate of speed, the sleepers lie quietly in their beds, and the conductors generally conduct themselves in a proper manner. ...
lead_paragraph: -- The Camden and Amboy Railroad is generally conceded to be a credit to New-Jersey. The cars are new and comfortable, the engines whirl their attendant trains along at quite a respectable rate of speed, the sleepers lie quietly in their beds, and the conductors generally conduct themselves in a proper manner. The necessity for these appliances to increase the popularity of a railroad may be seen at a glance, but the necessity for constructing ex-tempore guillotines along the line is not so easily to be perceived. At one station of the Camden and Amboy road, however, -- Rahway, we think -- a line of posts is placed so ingeniously near to the passing train that the inadvertent protrusion of a head or an arm would produce as complete a decapitation or amputation as could be obtained in a College of Surgeons. The Company have sagaciously distributed notices through their cars, warning passengers of the danger of standing on platforms, looking out of windows, &c.; -- this is all very well as far as it goes, but a goodly proportion of those that travel are, unfortunately, unable to read. Children are proverbially thoughtless, and many adults are constitutionally careless. Safety demands that the line of posts referred to be either uprooted permanently, or else removed to a respectable distance from the passing trains. Unless this suggestion is complied with the Camden and Amboy Railroad may some day find a "dead head" on the train unprovided with a pass from the proper authorities.

abstract: Miriam Sherwood vs. The Mayor,  This was an action to recover the amount of a certain mortgage on two lots now appropriated as a portion of the site for the new reservoir. The plaintiff, who was mortgagee, had no notice of the proceedings, except by publication, by which the lots were taken into possession by the City. ...
lead_paragraph: Miriam Sherwood vs. The Mayor, &c. -- This was an action to recover the amount of a certain mortgage on two lots now appropriated as a portion of the site for the new reservoir. The plaintiff, who was mortgagee, had no notice of the proceedings, except by publication, by which the lots were taken into possession by the City. The Commissioners appointed by the Supreme Court to appraise the lands, awarded the value of the two lots to the owner of the fee, without satisfying the mortgage -- of the existence of which they were not aware. The owner of the fee obtained the entire award on the coming in of the report of the Commissioners, and the mortgagee being left unprovided for, brought this action against the City to recover the value of her interest in the lots for which her recorded mortgage vouched. The action was brought to the Superior Court before Justice WOODRUFF, sitting at Special Term.

abstract: The rescued BOOTH has not yet escaped beyond the reach of the law. At Ripon, Wis., he addressed a crowded meeting on Saturday evening. He showed his pistol now and then, and called it his "little ha beds corpus." While he was pitching into the Marshals pretty strong, and into one who had offered to arrest him for $1,000 with special vehemence, FRANK MCCARTY, of Fond du Lac, stepped from the crowd on the side of the platform, and saying, "Mr. BOOTH, I have a writ for you," grasped his coat collar. The melee which followed, and subsequent proceedings, are thus related in a letter from Ripon, Aug. 5, in the Madison Journal: "BOOCH dashed his hand in his pocket for his 'haheas corpus,' but before he could get it out a dozen men had jumped between them, and FRANK was twenty feet off before he knew what touched him. A cry of 'Put him out,' 'Kill him,' arose from all parts of the house, and what with the shrieks of the women and the shouts of the men, and the upsetting of benches, and the rush of everybody to the centre, we had a perfect Pandemonium for a few minutes. FRANK looked down the barrels of a number of revolvers in a marvelous short time. A stalwart person strode through the thick, of the fight and hustled poor FRANK to the door, and thence to the street, some thirty feet. It was some time before matters got quiet inside; but when order was restored, the people organized a "League of Freedom" to protect BOOTH from the Marshals. A committee of safety was appointed and then the whole crowd escorted BOOTH to Prof. DANIEL's house. They then selected a guard -- armed them, and agreed to meet the next day, (Sunday,) at 3 P.M., and then dispersed. To-day a fresh arrival of Marshals added to the excitement. BOOTH was escorted to the meeting to-day by some twenty men, armed with rifles and an uncounted crowd. He made a speech, repeating the story of his persecutions. Resolutions pledging protection to him, and not very complimentary to the Marshals, was passed. The City Hall was offered them, andthey accepted it as their head-quarters, and the people, in immense procession, adjourned thither. Sentinels and guards were distributed around and within it, and it was placed in a state of siege. After some deliberation, a committee was sent over to the Marshals McCarty, Henry, Striker, and Garlick, advising them to leave town. The Marshals refused to receive any message unless it was in writing. A long discussion ensued between them. The committee finally reduced their proposition to writing, and the Marshals gave a written answer, the substance of which was, that they were here to arrest Booth, and that they would go away when they had completed their business. The committee came back and reported, whereupon the people organized a club of minute men. The precise object is known only to its members -- whether to mob the Marshals or merely to protect Booth. These proceedings occupied until 10 o'clock this evening. Monday morning. -- Booth has left town. Marshals ditto.

abstract: Rev. W.A. Bartlett, of Brooklyn, is improving his Summer vacation by lecturing and preaching in the West. His efforts do not meet universal approbation. One of the Milwaukee papers moderates its  praise with the following criticism: "The gentleman has talents of no mean order, and what is very much to be regretted, knows it as well as anybody. ...
lead_paragraph: Rev. W.A. Bartlett, of Brooklyn, is improving his Summer vacation by lecturing and preaching in the West. His efforts do not meet universal approbation. One of the Milwaukee papers moderates its praise with the following criticism: "The gentleman has talents of no mean order, and what is very much to be regretted, knows it as well as anybody. What struck us as objectionable in his lecture was the frequent repetition of the stale newspaper jokes or 'gags,' which, though apropos, were in bad taste, and contrasted too strongly with the fine ideas which were original. He alluded in one place to the lazy Christian who pinned his devotions to the bed-post, and said to the Lord 'them's my sentiments;' and in another place told the story of the inconstant teetotaler who broke the pledge in hot weather, after signing it repeatedly, and excused himself by saying that all signs failed in a dry season. It may be that those patent witticisms were thrown in as a mere incidental spice, and without any design to have the audience suppose that they were original; but there are always those who pick out these very bits of spice as evidences of "smartness," and we were prepared to hear the things repeated afterwards as specimens of Mr. Bartlett's talents."

abstract: MASS., REFORM SCHOOL. We have before alluded to the charges which have been made against the managers of the State Reform School at Westboro', of inhuman and cruel treatment of the boys under their care, and to the fact that a Committee of the Executive Council had been appointed to investigate the truth of these charges. ...
lead_paragraph: MASS., REFORM SCHOOL. -- We have before alluded to the charges which have been made against the managers of the State Reform School at Westboro', of inhuman and cruel treatment of the boys under their care, and to the fact that a Committee of the Executive Council had been appointed to investigate the truth of these charges. This Committee consisted of Lieut.-Gov. TRASK, Hon. JACOB SLEEPER and Hon. J.M. CHURCHILL. They have investigated the matter, and yesterday submitted their report, which we publish in full below, and by which it will be seen that the charges are sustained -- to this extent -- that boys 17 or 18 years of age have been kept confined in dark, impure cells -- "black holes" the Committee term them -- from eight to sixteen weeks, a portion of the time with their hands manacled behind them and with no food but bread and water. There were three cases which came directly before the Committee, but in their investigations they found that others -- the Superintendent admits to the number of twenty -- had been similarly punished for terms ranging from one month downward. The Committee seem to imply that the number may have been larger than that, and there was some evidence to show that in some cases the punishment had been extended as long as sixteen weeks. The Committee blame the Superintendent, WM. E. STARR, for this state of things, and also say that the Trustees are scarcely less culpable than their servants, and have been wanting in a proper discharge of important public trusts. They recommend an immediate and thorough reorganization of the government of the institution. The report was unanimously accepted. It is proper to remark that the Superintendent is chosen by the Trustees, who are appointed by the Governor and Council. The present Trustees are Parley Hammond, Simon Brown, Thomas A. Green, Josiah H. Temple, Henry W. Cushman, Judson S. Brown, Theodore Lyman. -- Boston Journal, August 9.

abstract: A Richmond paper, with happy oblivion of the logical reaction of the position upon the case of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE argues the unfitness of Mr. DOUGALS for the Presidency from his obtuseness failing to see the impossibility of his election.
lead_paragraph: A Richmond paper, with happy oblivion of the logical reaction of the position upon the case of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE argues the unfitness of Mr. DOUGALS for the Presidency from his obtuseness failing to see the impossibility of his election. No reasoning could be more simple or striking. Hero is a candidate, whose prospects of carrying even one State of the Union in the Electoral College are to the last degree dubious; and who can in no circumstances secure the suffrages of the House, should he even be able to make the requisite showing for admission as a candidate before that body. The evidence to this effect is so palpable that either blindness or obstinacy must account for his final perseverance; and neither of those qualities, even in the eyes of a supporter of the actual administration, is desirable in an occupant of the Presidential office. Therefore Mr. DOUGLAS, by virtue of his persistence, is clearly unentitled to the distinction. If sound reason does not point to this conclusion, what in the name of reason, asks this greater than ARISTOTLE, and more subtle than Duns Scotus, is reasoning worth? What, indeed!

abstract: THE GREAT EASTERN.--According to previous announcement, the Great Eastern was yesterday reopened to exhibition, at the usual rate of fifty cents, and during the day about one thousand persons went on board.
lead_paragraph: THE GREAT EASTERN. -- According to previous announcement, the Great Eastern was yesterday reopened to exhibition, at the usual rate of fifty cents, and during the day about one thousand persons went on board. The steam J.L Lockwood, and the Peck-slip ferry-boat Ethan Allen, were employed during the day in conveying the people from Hammond-street pier to the ship. To-morrow and Wednesday will positively close the public exhibition, and on Thursday the consignees, Messrs. GRINNELL, MINTURN & Co., state that she will leave, as advertised, for Milford Haven, England, via Halifax. At Annapolis, only 1,500 of the 2,500 tons of coal engaged were delivered in season for the ship. The balance required for the home trip -- about 1,000 tons -- is now going on board, by purchase of the Company, from our City coal barges alongside. During the heavy southeast blow, yesterday, the ship lay broadside across the stream, and at times apprehensions were felt that the immense strain might part her chains. According to the official report of the first officer, the Great Eastern made excellent running time from Annapolis and the Capes of Virginia. The following is the record of the trip:

abstract: Our citizens, says the Jacksonville (Ill.) Journal, of the 8th inst., were started, last Monday morning by the report of a double murder, commited Some five miles south west of town. A number of persons immediately repaired to the spot, when the following facts were disclosed.
lead_paragraph: Our citizens, says the Jacksonville (Ill.) Journal, of the 8th inst., were started, last Monday morning by the report of a double murder, commited Some five miles south west of town. A number of persons immediately repaired to the spot, when the following facts were disclosed. The deed was committed in the house-yard of Mr. MEGGINSON, a farmer who lives between this town and Lynnville. Mrs. MEGGINSON was waked from her sleep about 1 o'clock on Monday morning, by the cry of "Murder, murder!" She immediately sprang to her window, and looking out saw in the yard, and about thirty feet from the house, a man stamping the head of a woman with his heels. Mr. MEGGINSON and his son ran out, and on approaching the man he ran into a patch of corn. They began to turn their attention to the woman, when he came out of the corn again, and armed with a large club with which he seemed about to assail them. On this Mr. MEGGINSON urged his dog upon the fellow, and the dog having laid hold of his leg, gave Mr. MEGGINSON opportunity of hitting him across the back of the head and felling him to the ground. The son now held him till the father procured a rope with which he was effectually tied. Having thus disposed of him, they took the woman up and carried her into the house, supposing her to be badly injured but still alive. On striking a light, she was found to be dead. Her eyes were protruding from their sockets, her cheeks were cut open and her jaws broken, her tongue hanging nerveless from her mouth, presenting a most appalling spectacle. To make she tragedy still more dreadful, a little boy was found in the yard, about four years old, his face dreadfully mangled with blows from the same instrument which tad Killed his mother. He was taken into the house, and although perfectly insensible, he may possibly recover from the shock and live. The murder was perpetrated with a thin oak clapboard. The wretch struck the woman with the sharp edge of it, every blow sinking into her flesh to the bone. The board was brought to town, and left in Mr. C. DALTON's office. It bears abundant evidence of the diabolical was to which it was put. It was stained with blood. It appears, from papers found on the person of the murderer, that his name is MICHAEL REDMAN, an Irishman by birth. He was seen in Lynnville on Sunday last, where, with his wife and child, he bagged some food, with which certain persons there amply provided him. He left Lynnville, as he said, to go to JACOB STRAWN's, he having worked for Mr. STRAWN some ten years ago. The murder was committed some few miles West of STRAWN's. As the house Mr. MEGGINSON is some distance from the road, it is thought that the crime was committed in his yard in the expectation of throwing suspicion upon him, or at least vailing it in impenetrable mystery. The man acknowledged that he committed the murder, and says that he intended to kill them both. He says "she was not very smart, and was in his way." Mr. MEGGINSON says that there was no smell of liquor upon him, and that an empty bottle which was found in his carpet bag "had no smell of whisky about it." The wretch does not seem to be crazy at all. The deed was seemingly prompted by a desire to rid himself of the burden of supporting his wife and child. There was some talk upon the streets of Synching him upon the spot, and some suggested even after he was put in jail that he should be taken out and hung; happily, setter counsels prevailed, and he ^will have to suffer the penalty of the law.

abstract: On the 6th inst., Archibald Nichols, a boatman, living at Rye, Westchester County, disappeared under circumstances which gave rise to the belief, on the part of his friends, that he had been the subject of violence at the hands of Mary Given and Jacob Chatham, both of whom resided at the time in that village.
lead_paragraph: On the 6th inst., Archibald Nichols, a boatman, living at Rye, Westchester County, disappeared under circumstances which gave rise to the belief, on the part of his friends, that he had been the subject of violence at the hands of Mary Given and Jacob Chatham, both of whom resided at the time in that village. It seems that Mary, who is pleasant looking Irish girl, about 17 years of age, some two months ago engaged herself in the family of a respectable resident of Rye, as a domestic. She soon made the acquaintance of deceased and received an offer of marriage from him. His suit, however, she rejected, on the ground of his intemperate habits, and the match was also opposed by his friends. Subsequently Jacob Chatham, another young man, offered himself as a candidate for the girl's hand, and was accepted. After Nichols learned this fact he became very jealous of Chatham and is said to have availed himself of every opportunity to annoy both him and the young woman. At the time of his disappearance, having learned that the young couple had gone out in a small boat for a pleasure excursion on the Sound, he procured a skill and went in pursuit of them. He was never seen alive again, and a few days since his body was found in the water so much decomposed, however, as to make it difficult to decide whether his death had resulted from violence or from drowning. The friends of Nichols had their suspicions excited against Chatham and Mary as being in some way cognizant of his death, and these were heightened by the fact that the young woman, immediately after her return from the excursion, left Rye for this City, where she has since been living with her mother, Accordingly, a day or two subsequent to her arrival; here, some of them followed her and represented the affair to Inspector Carpenter, who sent for the young woman and questioned her as to her knowledge of the matter. She denied that she had seen anything of Nichols after going into the boat, and her manner seemed so truthful, that all who heard the examination became convinced of her innocence, particularly as her story coincided with that given by Chatham. Since the remains of Nichols have been discovered, however, a thorough investigation of the circumstances attending his death has been determined upon by the Coroner of Westchester County, and a warrant having been issued for the arrest of the young woman, Detective Bennett, yesterday, took her Into custody, pending the result of the inquest, which will be held to-day, at Rye. Some of the friends of deceased state that he was heard to scream "Murder" and others say that his boat was seen to approach that which contained the lovers, while the majority of those who know all the parties are of opinion that Nichols, being under the influence of liquor, fell overboard and was drowned.

abstract: Mr. Robert Gibson, of Nashville, Tenn., is the happy owner of a hat which once belonged to Gen. Jackson. It is a fine white beaver, with high crown and broad brim, and bears the maker's name as follows: "Orlando Fish, Broadway, 137, New-York, and Brown's Hotel, Pennsylvania-avenue, Washing...
lead_paragraph: Mr. Robert Gibson, of Nashville, Tenn., is the happy owner of a hat which once belonged to Gen. Jackson. It is a fine white beaver, with high crown and broad brim, and bears the maker's name as follows: "Orlando Fish, Broadway, 137, New-York, and Brown's Hotel, Pennsylvania-avenue, Washington, D.C. Made expressly for His Excellency, Gen. Andrew Jackson. "This hat was presented to Mr. Gibson by Gen. Jackson some minutes before his death. From the fact that it has lately been in the possession of the artist Healy, we should infer that he had designs upon the memory of the "Old Hero."

abstract: Madame DE STAEL'S sareastic remark that Heaven in giving to France the dominion of the land and to England the dominion of the seas, had left, nothing for Germany but the air, has not yet lost all its point.
lead_paragraph: Madame DE STAEL's sareastic remark that Heaven in giving to France the dominion of the land and to England the dominion of the seas, had left, nothing for Germany but the air, has not yet lost all its point. So long indeed as thirty sovereignties distract the allegiance and dissipate the forces of the German people, it is as nearly impossible as anything in the realm of modern politics can be said to be, that the German States should succeed either in arranging their domestic relations on a harmonious system, or in making themselves felt as a formidable presence in the diplomacy of Europe. The upshot of the recent interview at Toplitz between the two natural chiefs of North and South Germany has only brought this impossibility more clearly out into the light of day. Thanks to the portentous etiquette which broods from the Baltic to the Adriatic over all the German Courts, and invests the movements of German Sovereignty with an awful mystery, the world is still considerably in the dark as to the real origin of this interview and the objects with which it was solicited on the one hand and accorded on the other. The best information, however, seems to point to the Emperor FRANCIS JOSEPH as the moving spirit of the meeting. Either alarmed or merely excited by the interview of NATOLZON III. at Baden Baden with the German Princes, the young Emperor seems to have urged the Prince of Prussia to invest the meeting at Toplitz also with the character of a quasi-Congress, and to join him in convoking upon the august occasion all the German rulers who had taken a part in the discussions which have immortalized the Duchess of HAMILTON's German villa. The Prince-Regent, it is understood, categorically refused his assent to this proposition. In like manner, the prince-Regent declined to sign any preliminary papers in the nature of a convention.

abstract: In response to a public call, signed by a number of influential citizens, a meeting was held at the Tract-Society House yesterday afternoon, to consider the subject of the Christian massacre in Syria, and to adopt measures for rendering assistance to the sufferers. About twenty persons were present, among them some of our most prominent clergymen.
lead_paragraph: In response to a public call, signed by a number of influential citizens, a meeting was held at the Tract-Society House yesterday afternoon, to consider the subject of the Christian massacre in Syria, and to adopt measures for rendering assistance to the sufferers. About twenty persons were present, among them some of our most prominent clergymen. After prayer by Rev. GEO. W. WOOD, Rev. Dr. BAIRD stated the objects of the meeting, and alluded to the fact that meetings for the same purpose were being held in England and France by Jews as well as Christians. The main purpose of the present meeting was to appoint a committee to prepare an appeal to the people of the United States and to designate persons to receive contributions.

abstract: BOAT CAPSIZED -- NARROW ESCAPE OF FIVE LADIES AND THREE GENTLEMEN. -- On Saturday last JAMES SHERMAN, with a party of friends, consisting of five ladies and two gentlemen besides himself, hired a boat near Countyville, for a sail on the Great South Bay, and when off Pelican Bar, near Shor beach, the boat, by a sudden flaw of the wind, was capsized and the whole party was thrown into water. The accident was witnessed by she crews of several fishing smaks, who immediately went to the rescue of the unfortunate party, and reached them in time to prevent loss of life. The rescued party was taken to Fire Island where a handsome purse was made up for the rescuers, but they refused to accept it.

abstract: Matter of Ellen McManus -- This was an application to have the daughter of the realtor discharged from the Juvenile Asylum. The particulars of the case were stated in the Times of Aug. 9. The child in question, a girl of seven years of age, was taken out of the streets by a police-officer, who questioned her concerning her parents. She told the officer that bar mother was frequently intoxicated. Upon this statement she was taken before Justice KELLY, who committed her to the Asylum. This application was then made by the mother, and was adjourned until now by JUSTICE SUTHERLAND, for consideration. On coming up again the Court now held that the commitment was regular and that it could not go behind that instrument. The child was, therefore, remanded to the Asylum. A certiorari was given counsel, upon which to take the record of the Police Court before the General Term for review. The writ was made returnable at the next General Term of the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Matter of Ellen McManus -- This was an application to have the daughter of the realtor discharged from the Juvenile Asylum. abstract: --A remarkable case of very "early piety" has just been found in Brussels. The Police, making their rounds at midnight, found an ordinary clothes-line hanging near a door, several feet above the ground, and tracing its history discovered that it came out of a garret-window above.
lead_paragraph: -- A remarkable case of very "early piety" has just been found in Brussels. The Police, making their rounds at midnight, found an ordinary clothes-line hanging near a door, several feet above the ground, and tracing its history discovered that it came out of a garret-window above. They entered the house, convinced that they were on the track of some daring burglar, searched all the premises, and at last on walking into the garret were horrified to find themselves confronted by a housemaid, in a very easy evening dress, who, with many tears, explained that the mysterious clothes-line was attached to her left arm, in order that a young waiter to whom she was herself attached, coming early in the morning, might call her with a jerk to prayers at the Cathedral. As this explained this clothes-line, and there was not much else in the line of clothes before them, the discomfited and blushing Police beat a hasty-retreat.

abstract: The Special organ of Ex-Governor WISE iS at a loss to determine the expediency of the State contracting for arms to shoot Abolitionists with Abolitionists themselves, or with Virgiaia parties who would be compelled to fall back upon Abolitionist ingenuity.
lead_paragraph: The Special organ of Ex-Governor WISE iS at a loss to determine the expediency of the State contracting for arms to shoot Abolitionists with Abolitionists themselves, or with Virgiaia parties who would be compelled to fall back upon Abolitionist ingenuity. The controversy is of no light moment. The State Commission is of one mind in recommending the purchase of arms from a Connecticut Company, which stands ready, in the true commercial spirit, to supply weapons alike to Jew and Greek, Turk or Tartar. The Enquirer, forsaking its impersonality, has explored those depositions of arms, opened at Richmond, chiefly for the supply of duelists of the type of Messrs. PREYOR and JENNINGS WISE, and has found the shop-keepers generally willing to undertake the manufacture of anything between a pop-gun and a Paixhan. Without inquiring into the resources of these enterprizing people; but with controversial promptitude admitting their little statements to be mature truths, the Enquirer scorns the intimations of a correspondent, who believes that Tredegar cannot turn out such ordnance as West Point, or Richmond such rifles as SHARP'S and revolvers as COLT's.

abstract: PRIZE FIGHT NEAR LOUISVILLE, KY. -- CARNEY and MADDEN, two bruisers belonging to Louisville, went down the river with three steamboat loads of friends, on Tuesday last, to have a prize fight at Twelve-mile Island. The Democrat says: "About 10 1/2 o'clock CARENY entered the ring, where he remained several minutes, MADDEM not appearing. He then left the ring, and about noon again entered it, when MADDEN followed. They took their corners, bet soon changed, when the friends of MADDEN began shooting right and left. One ball struck near CARNEY, when he left the ring and made for his best, the crowd running in all directions. In the general feu de joie, six persons, we understand, were wounded, and two or three were cut with knives. Once on board, negotiations were begun to have the fight recommence, but unavailingly, and the boats turned towards home, a part of the crowd angry, turbulent and dangerous. The three boats landed near the foot of Fifth-street, an immense crowd being assembled on the levee to witness the return of the victor. The passengers rushed ashore, and all at once pistol shots were heard, and JAMES WALSH fell pierced with five bullet or shot wounds, and instantly expired. In the excitement it was not known at first who the assassin was, those in the vicinity scattering to escape any random shots. But subsequent testimony disclosed that when WALLSH had fallen, PETE MCGUIRE and JOHN BOHAN brutally kicked the bleeding body. Officer BLIGH came and at once arrested BOHAN. Officer GALLAGHER took JAMES KEEGAN, the assassin, who resisted, and was stabbed by the officer, and finally rescued by his friends and carried off. Officer GALLAGHER then took JOHN BOHAN, and the two arrested men were lodged in jail. The Coroner held an inquest on the body and the jury rendered a verdict implicating all three of the prisoners.
lead_paragraph: PRIZE FIGHT NEAR LOUISVILLE, KY. -- CARNEY and MADDEN, two bruisers belonging to Louisville, went down the river with three steamboat loads of friends, on Tuesday last, to have a prize fight at Twelve-mile Island. The Democrat says: "About 10 1/2 o'clock CARENY entered the ring, where he remained several minutes, MADDEM not appearing. He then left the ring, and about noon again entered it, when MADDEN followed. They took their corners, bet soon changed, when the friends of MADDEN began shooting right and left. One ball struck near CARNEY, when he left the ring and made for his best, the crowd running in all directions. In the general feu de joie, six persons, we understand, were wounded, and two or three were cut with knives. Once on board, negotiations were begun to have the fight recommence, but unavailingly, and the boats turned towards home, a part of the crowd angry, turbulent and dangerous. The three boats landed near the foot of Fifth-street, an immense crowd being assembled on the levee to witness the return of the victor. The passengers rushed ashore, and all at once pistol shots were heard, and JAMES WALSH fell pierced with five bullet or shot wounds, and instantly expired. In the excitement it was not known at first who the assassin was, those in the vicinity scattering to escape any random shots. But subsequent testimony disclosed that when WALLSH had fallen, PETE MCGUIRE and JOHN BOHAN brutally kicked the bleeding body. Officer BLIGH came and at once arrested BOHAN. Officer GALLAGHER took JAMES KEEGAN, the assassin, who resisted, and was stabbed by the officer, and finally rescued by his friends and carried off. Officer GALLAGHER then took JOHN BOHAN, and the two arrested men were lodged in jail. The Coroner held an inquest on the body and the jury rendered a verdict implicating all three of the prisoners.

abstract: The meteoric Benicis Boy, whose corruscations have been temporarily eclipsed by the Japanese, the Great Eastern, and the Zouaves, reappeared in a blaze of glory yeaterday afternoon at Jones' Wood-- not for the purpose of engaging in a sanguinary "mill," but, to preserve the astronomical simile--as Messrs. WOOD and NIXION'S bright particular star.
lead_paragraph: The meteoric Benicis Boy, whose corruscations have been temporarily eclipsed by the Japanese, the Great Eastern, and the Zouaves, reappeared in a blaze of glory yeaterday afternoon at Jones' Wood -- not for the purpose of engaging in a sanguinary "mill," but, to preserve the astronomical simile -- as Messrs. WOOD and NIXION's bright particular star. The owner of the terrible "left," that told so fearfully upon the sconce of the Champion of England, has been engaged for an exhibition tour of the principal cities, for which it is said he is to receive the sum of ten or twelve thousand dollars and expenses. Yesterday he commenced his engagement, assisted by the friends of the Fancy who are to accompany him on his tour, and the occasion was signalized as a public welcome home to the hero of the day, and the presentation of several substantial testimonials.

abstract: Too much discussion on the subject of "Reciprocity" with Canada is characterized by far more zeal than knowledge. Of the two reports submitted to Congress, that of Mr. HATCH, from the Western part of this State, advocates abrogation of the existing treaty, but for no other purpose than to obtain the reality of reciprocal free trade; and-the seemingly adverse ...
lead_paragraph: Too much discussion on the subject of "Reciprocity" with Canada is characterized by far more zeal than knowledge. Of the two reports submitted to Congress, that of Mr. HATCH, from the Western part of this State, advocates abrogation of the existing treaty, but for no other purpose than to obtain the reality of reciprocal free trade; and-the seemingly adverse report of Mr. TAYLOR, from Minnesota, advocates also "reciprocal free trade" as the proper aim of legislation, but erroneously regards the present treaty as conferring the mutual advantages of which he is desirous. Yet it recommends a complete extension of its provision, and in this general idea the reports of the two Commissioners agree. Both wish to arrive at the same practical result, and differ only as to the method of attaining it.

abstract: THE CENTRAL RAILROAD AND THE STATE. -- By way, we presume, of aiding the Southern Railroads in their competition with New-York, for the carrying business between the Great West and the Atlantic, the New-York Central Railroad is, it seems, to be sued for back tolls due the State, and all its profits enjoined to pay them. We have already expressed an opinion in season and out of season, upon the subject of the extraordinary policy of "tolling" in general, but we cannot refuse our word of admiration for the wisdom which selects the earliest season of revival in a great public interest of the Commonwealth to bring down upon it the hammer of the law. Future generations will wonder, if they read the history of our days, as perhaps they may, how railroads were ever introduced at all into the Empire State, and still more profoundly how, being introduced, they were ever maintained.

abstract: It has often been remarked that, under all the superficial crust of civilization, the primitive barbarity of man remains. The cruelty that prompts the Indian to torture his captives and the cannibal to eat his enemy, is smothered, not extinguished, by the refinements of life. Man cannot rid himself of the disposition to put his fellows to pain, and to shield himself under the plea of necessity.
lead_paragraph: It has often been remarked that, under all the superficial crust of civilization, the primitive barbarity of man remains. The cruelty that prompts the Indian to torture his captives and the cannibal to eat his enemy, is smothered, not extinguished, by the refinements of life. Man cannot rid himself of the disposition to put his fellows to pain, and to shield himself under the plea of necessity. But in civilized life, as death and bodily affliction seldom follow as the immediate and visible consequences of this propensity to torture, the cruelty is often so managed that it is concealed from those who inflict it, and in a measure from those who suffer from it. Both parties try to persuade themselves that it does not hurt so very much, after all. Many of the small tortures of life also fall only on those who are possessed of at least moderate riches, or are acquainted with their possessors; and the voice of general and popular indignation is therefore never raised against the authors of the torment. An excellent instance is afforded by "At Homes," which yearly cause so much pain and annoyance in London, and are yet borne very meekly and gently. At no one moment of the process do the tormentors or tormented exactly realize what the amount of suffering is; and as the pain is treated as inevitable, and is spread over a considerable space of time, there is no violent feeling of antagonism awakened by it. Besides, there is no real danger, no lasting inconvenience or misery connected with it; and so the sufferers are able to cheer themselves with the thought that it will soon be over. In all these respects it resembles the toothache more than a really serious disease. The toothache is hard to bear, but the pain is distributed over many hours, and it does not injure the constitution or shorten life. We can learn to go through "At Homes" with the same sleepy and melancholy courage that we can bring to confront the toothache, and the end of all reflection on "At Homes" is the conviction that to acquire this courage is the true aim of the wise. There is no chance that "At Homes" will cease; and the only thing to do is to endure them in a proper spirit.

abstract: ROW ON THE GREAT EASTERN. -- Complaints in numerable have been lodged against several of the officers of the Great Eastern, on account of the rudeness displayed, and the want of that proper respect for the feelings of ladies which every gentleman is possessed with. On Thursday one of the officials of "John Bull," who no doubt thought himself something extraordinary on account of his position in "her Majesty's Kingdom," took the liberty of insulting a gentleman residing in South Baltimore, when he was taught better manners by a well-directed blow from a loaded cane, which felled the young "English blood" to the floor of the deck, Yesterday afternoon another like affair took place on board of the ship between WASHINGTON GOODRICH and one of the officers, in which the latter was roughly handled. It appears that GOODRICH observed the officer practice rudeness towards two ladies, and reproved him for such conduct, when the officer replied to him in an insolent manner. GOODRICH knocked him down and administered a few kicks. The affair created quite an excitement, which, however, soon quieted down -- Baltimore Patriot, Aug. 11.

abstract: Gen. HOUSTON has retired to private life. In making this announcement, we are fully sensible of the responsibility involved. Gen. HOUSTON has on several iterated occasions announced his final and irrevocable withdrawal from the distraction and arduous labors of public service. In a speech before the Senate two years ago, in which with a dignity, and solemnity not wholly unworthy of WASHINGTON, he announced his resolve never again to appear as a candidate for popular favor, he was resolute as to the point of privacy. He was a spirituous veteran lagging on the stage. His farewell words uttered, there was nothing for the orator but vacuous old age and posterity. He accordingly sought solitude in governing Texas; and became a hermit to prepare himself for the Presidency in 1860. And yet once more with the positiveness and finality of a disgusted Timon, the General with an abundant appreciation of the consequences, now announces his determination to stand as a candidate for the Chief Magistracy of the Union, assured that if no others support him, the people of Texas may at least be relied upon to sustain his most authentic pretensions. It is needless to say this act is the becoming close of a career, which has been distinguished by fortuitous but undeserved honors, and has been clothed with historical attributes wholly the property of other meritorious claimants.

abstract: The steamship Anglo-Saxon, from Liverpool on the 2d inst., vid Londonderry on the 3d, passed Father Point yesterday, from which place her advices, which are two days later, are telegraphed.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Anglo-Saxon, from Liverpool on the 2d inst., vid Londonderry on the 3d, passed Father Point yesterday, from which place her advices, which are two days later, are telegraphed. A convention had been signed at Messina, between Gen. CLARY, on the part of the King of Naples, and Col. MEDICI for GARIBALDI, in which it was agreed that Sicily should be evacuated by the Neapolitans -- from motives of humanity. The convention, the text of which is published by the Paris Moniteur, is solely of a military character. The losses of GARIBALDI, at the taking of Melazzo, are put down at one thousand men, principally among his best corps. The Great Powers have agreed upon the conditions of a European intervention in Syria, and a conference of their respective representatives was to assemble at Paris on the afternoon of Friday, the 3d inst., to sign a convention in reference to the measures to be taken in common. The question of the paper duty in Parliament was still being agitated, but it was considered improbable that the Palmerston Ministry would either dissolve or resign, if defeated. The English funds are reported firm, with an increased demand for discounts. The Liverpool Cotton market was firmer and more active, but with unchanged prices. Consols were quoted at 93 1/2@93 5/8.

abstract: MEETING OF THE BOARD OF DELEGATES OF AMERICAN ISRAELITES. The Board of Delegates of American Israelites has been in session two evenings at the Cooper Institute, comprising representatives of thirty congregations in various parts of the country  nine out of eighteen New-York City congregations were represented.
lead_paragraph: MEETING OF THE BOARD OF DELEGATES OF AMERICAN ISRAELITES. The Board of Delegates of American Israelites has been in session two evenings at the Cooper Institute, comprising representatives of thirty congregations in various parts of the country nine out of eighteen New-York City congregations were represented. It was reported to the Board that of the $55,000 received by the English Board, for the relief of the Morocco sufferers, $20,000 came from American congregations. The Committee reported that through the instrumentality of Mr. GERSHON KURSHEEDT, they had received five hundred copies of an address to young children, of which Lady Baroness ROTHSCHILD is the authoress. Ten copies were ordered to be presented to each delegate, for the use of his congregation. At the meeting, last evening, it was resolved that a census of the Israelites in this country be taken, and measures devised for the purpose of establishing local schools and seminaries for Israelites. A spirited discussion took place last evening on the adoption of the by law. The large congregations favored a plan of taxation, re-presentation, and power in the small, according to the representation of members. So that small congregations could not outvote the large ones. Boston, Philadelphia New-Orleans and other small places were afraid of being swallowed up by New-York, and wanted their congregations to have equal power with those of New-York. The country towns gained their point, and struck out the by-law which the New-Yorkers proposed. The provincial towns also succeeded in having Philadelphia named as the place for the next annual meeting, on the second Monday in August next. The following officers were elected for the year 5021, (1861:) President. HENRY I. HARR of New-York. Vice-Presidents, Rev. Isaac Leaser, of Philadelphia; J.J. Jones, Mobile. Treasurer, A.S. Saroni, of Roston, Mass. Executive Committee, S. Wilzinski, of Richmond. Va.; J. Conrad, of Hartford, Conning J. Einstein, of Philadelphia, Penn.; I. Schriver, of Richmond, Va.; B.W. Hart of New-York City; B. Levy, of New-York City; M.S. Cohen, of New-York City; J. Reinheumer, of New-York City; Ellis Joseph, of New-York City; M. Woltsohn, of New-York City; A. Mansell, of New-York City; J.L. Levy, of New Orleans; Bennet King, of New-York City; B. Russack, N.Y.: Joseph Levy, N.Y.; A.J. Ratz, St. Louis; L.M. Morrison, N.Y.

abstract: THE CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION THE GYMNASIUM. The monthly meeting of the Brooklyn Young Men's Christian Association was held last evening at their rooms, in the Washington-street Institute. The attendance was comparatively small, on account of the inclement weather and the absence of many members from the City.
lead_paragraph: THE CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION -- THE GYMNASIUM. -- The monthly meeting of the Brooklyn Young Men's Christian Association was held last evening at their rooms, in the Washington-street Institute. The attendance was comparatively small, on account of the inclement weather and the absence of many members from the City. There was admitted during the evening ten active, six associate and one life member, and the names of several applicants were received. A somewhat lengthy but not uninteresting discussion was had on the question. "Is a Christian nation justifiable in forcing its institutions on the people of a barbarous country?" The usual essey was dispensed with early in the Fall, the Committee having in charge the duty of making arrangements to erect a suitable building for the use of the Association, in which will be prominent a well-appointed gymnasium, intend to continue their exertions heretofore so auspiciously commenced. The building, according to the plans submitted, will be 50 by 100 feet, and will cost about $50,000. There are now 500 active and associate members of the Association, and 1,300 volumes in the-Library.

abstract: For many a long year we have enjoyed the enthusiasm of affection and the intensity of admiration manifested by our solid brethren of Boston town toward their Common. No malls can compare, say they, with our Common's malls, no grass is so green ...
lead_paragraph: For many a long year we have enjoyed the enthusiasm of affection and the intensity of admiration manifested by our solid brethren of Boston town toward their Common. No malls can compare, say they, with our Common's malls, no grass is so green as that which covers the sloping hill-side and the flowery sweeps of our glorious Common, and no frog-pond ever yet equaled the world-renowned frog-pond in the Common for clearness of water, for symmetry of shape or quantity and quality of frogs. No strick on chord so quickly responds with grateful melody as that which connects a Bostonian's heart with his well-beloved Common, and no surer entrance to the confidence of our Eastern friends can be found than can be gained by a well-timed and appreciative compliment paid to the aforementioned pride and boast of our modern Athens.

abstract: The fate of that eccentric but determined man, Dr. VOGEL, whose reputation as a learned traveler is world-wide, is as yet uncertain. The Duke of SAKE-COBURG has decided to send an expedition to Africa in search of him, or of information concerning his disappearance.
lead_paragraph: -- The fate of that eccentric but determined man, Dr. VOGEL, whose reputation as a learned traveler is world-wide, is as yet uncertain. The Duke of SAKE-COBURG has decided to send an expedition to Africa in search of him, or of information concerning his disappearance. Baron STEUGLIN, of Wurtemburg, will be at the head of the undertaking, and we may expect not only to know definitely concerning the more immediate object of search, but also many new and interesting facts from that dark and seemingly unexplorable territory.

abstract: A meeting of the prominent merchants, bankers, and other well-known citizens of the City was held yesterday, at the Merchants' Bank, in Wall-Street, to adopt measures for extending and appropriate reception and welcome on behalf of the poeple of NewYork to the Prince of WALES on the occasion of his  visit to this City. Among the distinguished citizens present was Lieutenant General WINFIELD Score.
lead_paragraph: A meeting of the prominent merchants, bankers, and other well-known citizens of the City was held yesterday, at the Merchants' Bank, in Wall-Street, to adopt measures for extending and appropriate reception and welcome on behalf of the poeple of NewYork to the Prince of WALES on the occasion of his visit to this City. Among the distinguished citizens present was Lieutenant General WINFIELD SCOTT. PELYTIAH PERIT, Esq., was chosen Chairman, and Mr. M.B. FIELD Secretary. Mr. PERIT briefly stated the objects of the meeting, and said that as the British residents in New-York had made arrangements for a ball in honor of the Prince, it had been thought best that the demonstration on the part of the citizens of New-York should take the form of a public demonstration at the Academy of Music. The main purpose of the meeting to-day was to appoint a Committee and to make other necessary arrangements for carrying out the objects contemplated.

abstract: The man who was found by Officer Petty, of the Fourth Precinct, early on Sunday morning last, in an insensible condition in the halfway of the premises No. 38 Madison-street, has been recognized as James Cusick, a laborer, living at No. 73 Cherry-street. He still remains at the New-York Hospital in a very precarious condition, his skull being fractured, and the bone of his lower jaw shattered.
lead_paragraph: The man who was found by Officer Petty, of the Fourth Precinct, early on Sunday morning last, in an insensible condition in the halfway of the premises No. 38 Madison-street, has been recognized as James Cusick, a laborer, living at No. 73 Cherry-street. He still remains at the New-York Hospital in a very precarious condition, his skull being fractured, and the bone of his lower jaw shattered. So far no statement has been obtained from the sufferer wits reference to the manner in which he received his injuries, as most of the time he is unconscious; but should he be restored sufficiently for the purpose, one of the Coroners will visit him, and take his ante-mortem deposition. Officer Petty has been engaged, ever since the occurrence became known, in obtaining information as to who inflicted the violence, and his investigations have resulted in the arrest of four persons named John Ryan, Jas. Wilson, Elizabeth Barry and Mary Hart, who have been identified as participants in the transaction. John Maloy, a lad, residing at No. 91 Monroe-street, has made an affidavit before Justice KELLY to the effect that about 1 1/2 o'clock on Sunday morning he was standing with some of his companions at the corner of New Bowery and Madison-street, when their attention was attracted by a cry of "Murder" and "Watch" proceeding from the vicinity of James and Madison streets. They ran to the place as quickly as possible, and there saw Cusick, who appeared to be badly hurt, staggering about like a drunken man. The four prisoners and another man stood near Cusick, seemingly much excited, and one of them asked for a pistol, but was not successful in procuring one, when all of them dispersed. Information has been received by the Police that the entire affray was witnessed by several persons for whom a search is in progress, and it is hoped that their testimony will be procured.

abstract: Coroner SCHIRMER yesterday held an inquest upon the body of THOMAS FOX, an Irishman, 60 years of age, who was found in the water near Pier No. 15 North River. Deceased was a peddler of nuts and candies, and when last teen, on Monday night, was grossly intoxicated. It is supposed that while in that condition, he fell into the liver, and was drowned.... The same Coroner investigated the circumstances attending the death of a man who was found in the water at the loot of Robinson-street. No evidence respecting deceased could be obtained, and as no appearances of violent treatment were discernible, a verdict of "Death from drowning" was rendered. He was probably a sailor, and appeared to be about 35 years of age.

abstract: Under the modest title of a Campaign Text-Book, Mr. W.H. FRY has just published a condensed and thorough compendium of the Slavery question in all its aspects, political, historical, religious and economicai. Of course, Mr. FRY assumes that the Presidential campaign of 1860 is virtually a conflict of Slavery against Freedom and he writes with the earnest conviction of a man who believes that the pacific but absolute de feat of Slavery is essential to the future perpetuity and, indeed, the very existence of the nation. But his treatise is more than a political tract. It deals with the phenomena of Slavery from the earliest times to our own day, in a judicial spirit, and with all the power of weighty and well-arrayed facts. The work is divided into thirty-two chapters, some of which as, for instance, the chapters on "Slavery under the Jews," and on "Slave-burnings at the South," are strikingly new and Impressive.

abstract: Philadelphia was visited, on Monday, by a thunder-storm of remarkable severity. At noon the rain, which had commenced about 11 o'clock, seemed to be falling as rapidly as it was possible for it to do, ...
lead_paragraph: Philadelphia was visited, on Monday, by a thunder-storm of remarkable severity. At noon the rain, which had commenced about 11 o'clock, seemed to be falling as rapidly as it was possible for it to do, ut it continued to descend, in greater abundance until 2 o'clock. Then the storm reached its height, although it did not cease until 11 o'clock in the evening. About 2 o'clock, P.M., says the Enquirer, a most extraordinary occurrence took place, resulting in the death of one boy, and the severe, if not fatal, injury of another. The two parties were at work in a brickyard on Long-lane. The lot was open and exposed. The storm made its approach, and was unheeded. Almost without any knowledge of their position, or of the danger, the boys continued their occupation, and sought no shelter. In an instant, one of them, named DANIEL HUTTER, was struck by lightning, and fell, although not dead. As he lay upon the grass, Mr. SREETZ, the owner of the yard, directed the remaining lad, JAMES HUGHES, to go for a cart, whereon to convey the body of the sufferer to the nearest house. HUGHES started to run, but had only gone a few-steps when another blast struck him down dead. HUTTER was taken to a place of safety, and it is hoped will recover, if proper care is used. The deceased was 17 years of age, and assisted his brother to support a widowed mother. He resided at No. 1,238 Federal-street, to which place the body was at once conveyed. It presented a terrible appearance, the skin being apparently scorched, and the face somewhat disfigured.

abstract: The Times City Article, of Monday evening, the 6th, says: "The English Funds continue to show depression. On the state of the weather, and the business on the Paris Bourse, the Corn market was heavy, at an occasional reduction of 1s @2s. quarter for wheat. About  4,000 in bar Gold was taken from the Bank to-day, for export. These small withdrawals are chiefly for transmission to Spain.

abstract: The chief topic here is the singular letter which the Emperor has written to his Ambassador at London. The extreme peace party, of course, receive it with acclamation. By Englishmen generally it is thought to be too civil by half, undignified, somewhat false, and very suspicious. On the principle of qui s'excuse s'exeuse, the letter is open to criticism, and the motives of the writer to doubt.
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 4, 1860.

abstract: The slave-brig Wm.R. Kibby, which was captured by the United States steamer Crusader, Lieut. Commanding MAFFIT, off the Island of Auguilla, on the 23d of July, and which was afterwards taken into Key West, as before reported, arrived at this port on Monday, in charge of Lieut. J.M. DUNCAN. This vessel, it will be remembered, is reported to have landed over 400 slaves in Cuba. When suddenly surprised by the Crusader, she was deserted by the officers and crew, leaving their breakfast uneaten upon the table, and in their precipitate flight three negro boys were left on board, who had stowed themselves away in the forward part of the hold. These young Africans were brought here in the brig, and were yesterday delivered into the custody of the United States Marshal, who had them removed from the vessel and lodged in Eldridge-street jail, where they will be comfortably quartered until they are wanted as witnesses against the vessel. To protect them against the cold, to which they appear very sensitive, warm clothing has been provided for them. They are, apparently, about twelve or fourteen years of age, very intelligent and lively, and manifest great attachment to Lieut. DUNCAN, in whose care they have been since they left Key West. Their necks are ornamented with trinkets of brass and copper, which they evidently prize very highly.
lead_paragraph: The slave-brig Wm.R. Kibby, which was captured by the United States steamer Crusader, Lieut. Commanding MAFFIT, off the Island of Auguilla, on the 23d of July, and which was afterwards taken into Key West, as before reported, arrived at this port on Monday, in charge of Lieut. J.M. DUNCAN. This vessel, it will be remembered, is reported to have landed over 400 slaves in Cuba. When suddenly surprised by the Crusader, she was deserted by the officers and crew, leaving their breakfast uneaten upon the table, and in their precipitate flight three negro boys were left on board, who had stowed themselves away in the forward part of the hold. These young Africans were brought here in the brig, and were yesterday delivered into the custody of the United States Marshal, who had them removed from the vessel and lodged in Eldridge-street jail, where they will be comfortably quartered until they are wanted as witnesses against the vessel. To protect them against the cold, to which they appear very sensitive, warm clothing has been provided for them. They are, apparently, about twelve or fourteen years of age, very intelligent and lively, and manifest great attachment to Lieut. DUNCAN, in whose care they have been since they left Key West. Their necks are ornamented with trinkets of brass and copper, which they evidently prize very highly.

abstract: An important letter from Lord JOHN RUSSELL will be found in the foreign intelligence this morning published. It is a circular letter, addressed to the British Ambassadors at the different European Courts and at Washington, making fresh representations of the increased activity of the Slave-trade, and suggesting measures for its suppression. The British Minister proposes that Cuba be watched by a combined American, English and Spanish fleet; that laws of protection and registration be passed in Cuba, so that all slaves imported contrary to law may be detected; and, finally, that a legalized plan of emigration from China be regulated by European agents, in conjunction with Chinese authorities.
lead_paragraph: An important letter from Lord JOHN RUSSELL will be found in the foreign intelligence this morning published. It is a circular letter, addressed to the British Ambassadors at the different European Courts and at Washington, making fresh representations of the increased activity of the Slave-trade, and suggesting measures for its suppression. The British Minister proposes that Cuba be watched by a combined American, English and Spanish fleet; that laws of protection and registration be passed in Cuba, so that all slaves imported contrary to law may be detected; and, finally, that a legalized plan of emigration from China be regulated by European agents, in conjunction with Chinese authorities.

abstract: To-day is the day fixed by the order of Judge INGRAHAM for the City to take possession of the Washington Market property, now held by J.B. TAYLOR as the lessee of the State. We observe a paragraph in nearly all our cotemporaries stating that the tenants have declared their readiness to pay the rents to the City under Judge INGRAHAM's order. This may be so, but it is not usual for a claimant thus readily to obtain possession of property occupied by an adverse party. The law prescribes a mode of ejectment which must be scrupulously followed. We apprehend that the City will find it necessary to observe these formalities in this case also.

abstract: We learn, by the Persia, that the representatives of the European Powers, lately assembled in Paris, have agreed upon the conditions of intervention in Syria. This intervention will doubtless be complete, and will fully attain the end in view. It is understood that, as soon as the Porte's assent is obtained, 20,000 troops will be dispatched to the Levant. One half of this force will be French, and the other half Russian and English.
lead_paragraph: We learn, by the Persia, that the representatives of the European Powers, lately assembled in Paris, have agreed upon the conditions of intervention in Syria. This intervention will doubtless be complete, and will fully attain the end in view. It is understood that, as soon as the Porte's assent is obtained, 20,000 troops will be dispatched to the Levant. One half of this force will be French, and the other half Russian and English. A large fleet of British and French men-of-war have been for some time assembled at Beyrout; a Russian fleet, of which the General Admiral, built in this City, is the flag-ship, is already on its way thither; Spain will be also represented; and Holland, whose Consul was murdered at Damascus, has sent to Syria several vessels for the protection of its subjects.

abstract: George D. Bulen and Wife vs. William Burdell et al. -- This was an application for leave to the plaintiffs to serve an amended complaint. The object of amending the complaint is that the plaintiffs may allege and claim a larger amount than that originally demanded. The action is for partition of the estate of the late Dr. Harvey Burdell, whose death created so great an excitement in 1857. The case was stated in the TIMES of April 17, at which time it was before Justice BONNEY, of Chambers of the Supreme Court.

abstract: Again the military spirit is aroused in France by the departure of soldiers for another war. A year ago it was to Lombardy; six months later to China, and to-day it is to the Holy Land. The cry' "Partant pour la Syrie!" has been sounded by every trooper's horn throughout the Empire, and is to-day the war-cry of the French army. What was to the Queen HORTENSE a romance is to her son a reality.
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Monday, July 30, 1860.

abstract: In the House of Commons, Aug. 3, Mr. RICH called attention to the papers laid before the House respecting the disturbances in Syria, considering that before the separation of Parliament there should be an expression of the opinion of that House upon the subject, and a declaration on the part of the Government as to the course they were prepared to adopt. He then proceeded to trace the course of events by reading at much length (amid some indications of impatience on the part of the House) extracts from the papers in the hands of members, and contended that the House had a right to demand what was to be done to vindicate the wrongs inflicted and to prevent their recurrence.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Commons, Aug. 3, Mr. RICH called attention to the papers laid before the House respecting the disturbances in Syria, considering that before the separation of Parliament there should be an expression of the opinion of that House upon the subject, and a declaration on the part of the Government as to the course they were prepared to adopt. abstract: The collector, of the City revenues has not as yet received any portion of the back rents due the City from the West Washington Market, which have been paid to the special receiver during the past two years. They amount to over $30,000, and this being a sum worth fighting for, it is quite probable that the parties who entered into the speculation, Messrs. BRENNAN & TAYLOR, will carry the case to the Court of Appeals. Thus far, however, no steps have been taken with that view, and the ten days allowed by the Supreme Court are passing away very rapidly. If the notice of appeal and ponds which must accompany it, are forthcoming on Monday, the tenants of the "disputed territory" will, of course, pay their rents into the City Treasury. As it has been rumored that the City Inspector proposed a change in the rents heretofore charged, it is well enough to say he has no such intention, but that tenants will continue to pay the rates fixed by Messrs. BRENNAN & TAYLOR.
