abstract: The United States steam-frigate Powhatan, late flag-ship of the East Indies Squadron, has arrived at Philadelphia, as announced by a telegraphic dispatch published this morning. The Powhatan has been in commission over two years, about nine months of which were spent in going out to and returning from the East. She relieved the San Jacinto a short time before the outbreak of hostilities between the British and Chinese; and in the engagement of the Pei-ho, Commodore TATNALL rendered assistance to the English Admiral -- an act that caused him to become notorious for a while. The Powhatan has visited more harbors on the China Station than any flag-ship we have ever had there, and has had quite a narrow escape from total destruction. In consequence of the shallowness of the waters and of exceedingly tempestuous weather, near the Rugged Islands, passing which, while she had in tow the little steamer chartered by the United States Government for navigating the rivers of China, she was driven aground on the 27th of May, 1859, and badly injured. It was necessary to throw over a quantity of coal to lighten her, and arrangements were also made to throw over some of the guns, if necessary, to get her off. At 2 1/2 o'clock a Chinese furnishing boat was hauled alongside, and three officers started in her to find assistance. The crew of the boat consisted of fifteen Chinamen -- a piratical looking set of fellows -- but they proved to be better than they looked. After five and a half hours' sail in this open boat, exposed to a drenching rain, the relief party reached Woosing. The Mississippi and another vessel were dispatched the following morning to the relief of the Powhatan, but fortunately a pilot had gone to her assistance, and by his boldness and energy was enabled to get her off the banks, with the loss only of one anchor, a boat and some coal. She was, however, again forced upon another shoal, about three-fourths of a mile long, and had for a time a fearful humping and thumping upon it.
lead_paragraph: The United States steam-frigate Powhatan, late flag-ship of the East Indies Squadron, has arrived at Philadelphia, as announced by a telegraphic dispatch published this morning. The Powhatan has visited more harbors on the China Station than any flag-ship we have ever had there, and has had quite a narrow escape from total destruction. In consequence of the shallowness of the waters and of exceedingly tempestuous weather, near the Rugged Islands, passing which, while she had in tow the little steamer chartered by the United States Government for navigating the rivers of China, she was driven aground on the 27th of May, 1859, and badly injured. She was, however, again forced upon another shoal, about three-fourths of a mile long, and had for a time a fearful humping and thumping upon it.

abstract: Two steamers have already left Liverpool for the Garibaldian service -- one a paddle-wheel, the Independance, of 330 tons register; and the other a screw, the Queen of England, of 1,449 tons register. The Independance took out no arms or ammunition, but a very large quantity of coal. The Queen of England, which sailed on the 2d of August, took out over 30,000 rifles, rifled cannon, tents, revolvers, cartridges, cutlasses, shot and shell. The value of her cargo amounts to upwards of $250,000. Gen. GARIBALDI is said to be waiting for these vessels before he makes his descent upon Calabria. Some of the Witworth guns will be sent to GARIBALDI by another steamer soon to leave Liverpool for the theatre of war.
lead_paragraph: Two steamers have already left Liverpool for the Garibaldian service -- one a paddle-wheel, the Independance, of 330 tons register; and the other a screw, the Queen of England, of 1,449 tons register. abstract: The steamship Persia, from Liverpool on the 4th and from Queenstown on the 5th inst., arrived at this port yesterday. Telegraphic advices by her, received via Queenstown, are two days later; our foreign files and correspondence are three days later than those previously to hand. The steamship Parana, from Liverpool on the 7th, arrived at St. Johns, N.F., yesterday, en route to Boston. The advices are two days later than those by the Persia. It is stated that the representatives of the European Powers, in conference at Paris, have agreed upon the conditions of intervention in Syria. The intervention will only last as long as the Porte shall deem advisable. It is understood that 12,000 men will be dispatched to Syria. The military convention between Gen. GARIBALDI and the Commander-in-Chief of the Neapolitan troops provides for the evacuation of Sicily from motives of humanity. Late dispatches state that GARIBALDI had already invaded the Peninsular Territory of the Neapolitan King -- a body of his men having landed in Calabria. Two bodies of reinforcements for the revolutionists had left Genoa for Sicily -- one numbering one thousand and the other five thousand. A telegram from Genoa states that two regiments of Neapolitan troops had mutinied, with the cry of "Viva GARIBALDI" British Parliamentary proceedings have been of an interesting character. An attempt to defeat Lord PALMERSTON's resolutions on the defence question was put down by a vote of 268 to 39. The paper duty resolution had been passed by a majority of 33 in the Commons. The affairs of Syria had formed the subject of discussion in both Houses. In the Upper House, Lord BROUGHAM had moved that immediate steps be taken to compel Spain to carry out her engagements for the suppression of the Slave-trade. An important circular dispatch from Lord JOHN RUSSELL, in which a way to suppress the Slave-trade is pointed out, together with divers interesting documents on the Coolie-trade, have been laid before Parliament. At a public meeting held in London on the evening of the 1st inst., to celebrate the anniversary of British West India Emancipation, Dr. CHEEVER made a speech, and spoke violently against the support which is given to Slavery by the Churches of America.

abstract: PRIMARY MEETINGS. -- The Republicans in the several Wards and towns embraced within the limits of Kings County last evening elected five delegates each, to compose the Assembly Conventions, which will be held on Saturday afternoon next. The Assembly Conventions will each select two delegates and two alternates to represent the county in the State Convention to be held at Syracuse on the 22d inst. The polls were not closed until 9 o'clock last evening, so that it is impossible to tell the preferences of the delegates as to Governor, but it is generally conceded that a large majority are decidedly in favor of selecting delegates to the State Convention whose first choice will be Gov. MORGAN. The primary meetings passed off very quietly, and there was but little competition in any of the Wards.
lead_paragraph: PRIMARY MEETINGS. -- The Republicans in the several Wards and towns embraced within the limits of Kings County last evening elected five delegates each, to compose the Assembly Conventions, which will be held on Saturday afternoon next. MORGAN. The primary meetings passed off very quietly, and there was but little competition in any of the Wards.

abstract: -- The average British snob is an unpleasant creature certainly, but we are inclined to think that he is as much inferior to his American counterpart in all the salient points which make manodious to his fellows as the Thames is inferior to the Mississippi in grandeur. A clerical Yankee, BAYLIES by name, is now writing letters from England to a paper in this country which bears the pious name of Zion's Herald. In one of his latest effusions this Paul Pry of the Church announces that he visited Ascot Races, not for the purpose of bearing his testimony against the ungodliness of gambling, but in order to inspect the royal family of England. He says of himself:

abstract: The Douglas Democrats have completed their State ticket, and their selection indicates a disposition not to give up the State without a trial. Their nominee for Governor, WILLIAM KELLEY, is a gentleman of estimable character and of wide influence beyond the circle of politics. He has wealth, culture, rural tastes and habits, and considerable acquaintance with political life and public affairs. He served in the State Senate in 1853 and 1854, and won universal confidence and esteem. The other names on the ticket embody a good deal of local strength.
lead_paragraph: The Douglas Democrats have completed their State ticket, and their selection indicates a disposition not to give up the State without a trial. abstract: THE LAST DAY OF THE GREAT EASTERN -- HER DEPARTURE FOR ENGLAND. -- Yesterday the mammoth ship was exhibited for the last time -- at least for the present -- in New-York. Whether she will ever return to this port is undecided, though it is rumored that the Cunard Company are not indisposed to purchase her. Nearly 6,000 people visited her yesterday, the dock at the foot of Hammond-street being crowded all the time with carriages. Two steamboats conveyed the visitors from the dock to the ship every fifteen minutes, and were inconveniently thronged on each successive trip. A large number of these visitors appeared to be from the country. Several coal-barges were alongside the ship throughout the day, making up the deficiency in the stock of coals, which, in accordance with her arrangements, she was unable to wait for and receive at Annapolis Roads. The services of the donkey engines were brought into requisition for hauling them on board. To-day, shortly after 4 P.M., the Great Eastern will start for Milford Haven, England, calling at Halifax on her way. Rather over one hundred tickets have, so far, been sold for the entire voyage, and nearly forty for Halifax. At Milford Haven she will be drawn upon a "gridiron," which is now being prepared for her, and her bottom cleaned. The great ship arrived in our harbor on June 28, and certainly her directors have had no cause to complain of want of interest on the part of the American public. Now that she is about leaving us, we can forgive them the sad blunders of the Cape May trip. They lost several thousand dollars thereby, and probably will learn in future to bestow better treatment on those who put their trust in them. The ship, of course, is not to blame for their gross mismanagement. We wish her a good and swift voyage, and all imaginable success always.

abstract: Judge DOUGLAS has been rusticating at Newport. He attends balls, goes to dinners, bathes in the surf, and talks politics. According to one of our Newport correspondents he expresses his sentiments with the utmost freedom, and does not hesitate to state precisely what he expects to accomplish in the pending Presidential canvass.
lead_paragraph: Judge DOUGLAS has been rusticating at Newport. He attends balls, goes to dinners, bathes in the surf, and talks politics. According to one of our Newport correspondents he expresses his sentiments with the utmost freedom, and does not hesitate to state precisely what he expects to accomplish in the pending Presidential canvass. We gather from our correspondent's letter that Judge DOUGLAS has not the slightest expectation of achieving his own election, -- and very faint hopes of preventing the election of LINCOLN. But he does expect and intend, not only to render the election of BRECKINRIDGE impossible, but to crush out utterly and forever the wretched Pro-Slavery faction which has made him its candidate. He does not believe that BRECKINRIDGE can possibly get votes enough to carry him into the House as one of the three highest candidates, and doubts whether he will receive the support of more than one or two States. South Carolina will vote for him, and so may Mississippi; but no other Southern State, in Judge DOUGLAS's opinion, will give him its support. BELL will carry part of them, and Mr. DOUGLAS himself expects to carry the rest.

abstract: If any care of earthly things possess the spirits of the dead, two royal ghosts, at least, must be strangely perturbed in looking down upon our planet at the present hour. To CHARLES V. and PHILIP II., once arbiters of Europe, and masters of the commerce of the world, the spectacle of Castile and Leon knocking for readmission to the great Council of the European States, must be a marvel without a name.

abstract: Of the entire equity of the award made by the Paraguay Commission in reference to the claims of a Rhode Island Company against the Government of Gen. LOPEZ, there will be little question in the minds of any who take the trouble to peruse the Opinion and Report of Mr. CAVE JOHNSON, the American referee. That document has just appeared in print. Stating fairly the points raised by counsel in favor of claimants and respondents, it proceeds to a careful review of the evidence, to which the main contributors were not, as might have been anticipated, citizens of Paraguay, but citizens of the United States, familiar with the operations of the Company, and many of them members of the Company itself. The award may in fact be said to proceed upon the showing of the claimants themselves. Their case was its own refutation. "Out of their own mouths they are condemned."

abstract: I am well aware that in the recent contest the support which I received at your hands is simply an evidence of your devotion to the cause of freedom, and would have been rendered as freely and enthusiastically to any other man who had approved his fidelity to that cause, as it has been given to me; yet I cannot allow the occasion, signalized by so great a triumph to our common cause; to pass without tendering to you the homage of my gratitude for selecting me as the representative of your principles and the instrument of achieving a victory for their maintenance and advancement.
lead_paragraph: I am well aware that in the recent contest the support which I received at your hands is simply an evidence of your devotion to the cause of freedom, and would have been rendered as freely and enthusiastically to any other man who had approved his fidelity to that cause, as it has been given to me; yet I cannot allow the occasion, signalized by so great a triumph to our common cause; to pass without tendering to you the homage of my gratitude for selecting me as the representative of your principles and the instrument of achieving a victory for their maintenance and advancement.

abstract: Yesterday Mr. THOMPSON, private secretary of the Mayor, left for Quebec, with letters of introduction to Lord LYONS, the British Ambassador, and the Duke of Newcastle, his purpose being to ascertain the views of his Royal Highness with reference to his visit to and reception in the City of New-York. Mr. THOMPSON is also authorized to express the views of the Mayor in this regard, which, however, are not yet to be made public.

abstract: These two New-York clubs met on Thursday last, at Hoboken, to settle the question of superiority, and after a very closely-played game of nine innings, the Champions were declared victors. There was not much difference in the play of the two clubs in the field, but the Champions batted more safely, and thus won the game. The pitching on both sides was quite irregular, but particularly in the case of Rowland, of the Jeffersons, thus making the game a very slow one. The proportion of ladies in attendance was quite large. On the Champion side, Goldie and Kelly on the base were safe and active, W. Kelly excellent as catcher, Glover and Rowe very efficient in the field, both making most admirable catchers, while Decker, at the third base, made a very difficult bound catch on a foul ball. Dunphy played steadily at centre field, as did Graham at short. For the Jeffersons, Greer at left field made some some very good catches, and played well otherwise. Reed at third base was very active, making some very difficult catches, Tyson rivaling him at the second base. Totten at centre field, and Raymond at right field, were very fair, as were also Calvert and Connor as short and catcher. The following is the score:

abstract: On Monday next the paving of Chambers-street from Chatham-street to the Hudson River will be commenced, the contract being for trap-block pavement. Early during the ensuing week, the paving of West-street from Battery-place to Gansevoort street will be commenced, as also the paving of the Ninth-avenue, from Forty-fifth to Fifty-second street -- all works of importance, and demanded by the necessities of parties on the line of the streets. The matter of laying the pipes through the Fourth-avenue, from the receiving to the distributing reservoir, has not yet been decided, an official communication of much importance, and connected with this work, having been unavoidably delayed; and meanwhile some three hundred men are awaiting the dictum, of one official, while the health and comfort of the City are endangered by the delay.

abstract: A strange and almost romantic interest surrounds the history of the three little African boys who have just been cast upon our shores from on board the slave brig William R. Kibby. Out of a cargo of over 400 of their countrymen, stolen from their African homes, they alone remain not indeed to tell ...
lead_paragraph: A strange and almost romantic interest surrounds the history of the three little African boys who have just been cast upon our shores from on board the slave brig William R. Kibby. Out of a cargo of over 400 of their countrymen, stolen from their African homes, they alone remain -- not indeed to tell the story of their cruel capture, of the forced march to the coast, the tortures of the branding-iron, and the horrors of the middle passage, for they have no language in which they can convey these things to us, which we can understand. In their precipitate fight from the brig to escape arrest, as the Crusader was approaching her, the slave-trader left their breakfast untouched upon the cabin table, and these three lads, who had concealed themselves beneath the forecastle floor, from some strange fear of what was to be done with them, were overlooked.

abstract: Hon. ELI THAYER, of Massachusetts, is fighting his own battles vigorously in Massachusetts. On Monday evening last he appeared a second time before his constituents, to reply to an attack made upon him by Mr. P. EMORY ALDRICH. In the course of his address he discussed the present Territorial policy of the Government, claiming that it was all wrong. Mr. THAYER asserted that the administration of the affairs of the different Territories was entirely under the control of politicians, and all a broken down fellow had to do was to gather a dozen companions and emigrate to the borders of civilization, and there set himself up. A Territorial government would then be asked for, and the fellow would next be heard from as a delegate to Congress. Our Indian wars, said he, have always followed in the track of Government officials; and the millions that the Government has paid on this account has gone principally into the pockets of these leeches. The speaker said he had the authority of Hon. EDWARD WADE, of Ohio, for these statements, and as Mr. WADE had given the subject much attention, he was assured they were truthful. This course has encouraged an unhealthy emigration, which is the curse of our border settlements. Mr. THAYER said he would fully set before his constituents, before the campaign closed, the reason why there should be a change in our Territorial government.
lead_paragraph: Hon. ELI THAYER, of Massachusetts, is fighting his own battles vigorously in Massachusetts. abstract: John Dougherty, a very receut importation from Ireland, was accosted a few days since at the emigrant landing depot, Castle Garden, by a man who asked if he desired employment. That was just what Dougherty, who is both young and strong, most wanted to get, and he told his interrogator he would be most happy to go to work immediately. He followed the man to a place near by, where he was left alone for a few minutes, and when the stranger returned he requested Dougherty to change a $100 bill.

abstract: The circumstances attending the decease of MARY HALLIGAN, an Irish woman, 35 years of age, who was fatally injured on the evening of the 5th inst. by her husband, MARTIN HALLIGAN, were yesterday investigated by Coroner SCHIRMER. RICHARD MARTIN, a patrolman of the Twenty-second Precinct, testified that on the evening the violence was committed, he was informed by a woman, whose name he did not ascertain, that deceased was lying upon the floor at her residence. No. 317 West Forty-third-street, apparently dying. He went to the place indicated and found the woman's statement was true, deceased being covered with blood, perfectly insensible, and having scarcely a piece of clothing upon her. Witness questioned the other occupants of the house with reference to the matter, but was unable to learn anything, each of the parties declaring that no disturbance had been heard. He at once had the suffering woman removed to the Hospital, and later in the evening, Sergeant MURPHY, also of the Twenty second Ward Police, met her husband at the corner of Tenth-avenue and Forty third-street. The officer immediately arrested him and charged him with having beaten his wife. The prisoner replied that "he could not deny it," adding that he did so because she was almost always drunk, and he could have no peace with her. He was thereupon locked up to await the result of his violence. It was ascertained, after the admission of deceased to the Hospital, that two severe wounds had been inflicted upon her head, apparently with a sharp instrument, and she became delirious from their effects, in which condition she remained until Tuesday night last, when she died. A verdict was rendered that deceased had died of meningitis, the result of wounds inflicted by her husband, Martin Halligan. The accused was then examined by the Coroner, in the prescribed manner. He stated that he was 35 years of age, and a carpenter by trade. With reference to the charge, he said: "I never raised a deadly weapon to her in my life -- I never had a weapon of any kind in my hand." He was committed to prison to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: POLICE. Sergeant BOYCE, in command of the Sanitary Police, yesterday, laid before the Commissioners his first report, for the quarter ending 1st instant, from which it appears that 3,970 complaints were made, against persons for maintaining nuisances, of which number 2,998 were promptly abated. In all the cases legal proceedings have been commenced. The complaints are classified as follows: Cow-stables and yards, 131; hog-pens and goats, 112; slaughter-houses, ...
lead_paragraph: POLICE. -- Sergeant BOYCE, in command of the Sanitary Police, yesterday, laid before the Commissioners his first report, for the quarter ending 1st instant, from which it appears that 3,970 complaints were made, against persons for maintaining nuisances, of which number 2,998 were promptly abated. In all the cases legal proceedings have been commenced. The complaints are classified as follows: Cow-stables and yards, 131; hog-pens and goats, 112; slaughter-houses, 6; hide and fat establishments, 7; bone-boiling, 8; factory nuisances, 8; tenement houses, 311; yards of tenement houses, 426; cellars and basements. 161; privies and cesspools, 1,802; garbage and ash deposits, 8; manure, 9; stagnant water in vacant places, 10; cisterns, 45; vacant lots, 9; unsafe buildings, 33; unsafe privies, 5; market nuisances, 6; diseased meat seized, 1; distillery-yards nuisances, 1; dangerous chimney, 1; fish-smoking establishments, 1. The Sanitary Police also report the whole number of vessels arrived during the quarter, to be 666 of which 210 arrived in May, 235 in June and 221 in July. The cargoes are classified as follows: Sugar and molasses, 391; naval stores, 123; coal, 16: iron, 5; guano, 3; dyewood, 33; wood and number, 29;cotton, 8; hides and wool, 36; coffee, 6; merchandise, 6'; copper ore, sulphur, 2 each; pot and pearl ashes, salt, tobacco, linseed and flour 1 each.

abstract: The Republicans of this State do not seem to be quite harmonious in regard to their local nominations, although they are perfectly united in support of their Presidential candidate. The election of a Governor occasions a good deal of ill-feeling in various quarters. Gov. MORGAN is a candidate for reelection, and, in spite of the hostility of sundry local interterests and the disaffection of many friends of Gov. SEWARD, who charge him with indifference, or, at least, inactivity, in the matter of his nomination at Chicago, he will unquestionably receive the nomination. His repeated veto of the Susquehanna Railroad bill, -- after his virtual pledge to sign it if divested of certain obnoxious features contained in the bill as first passed, -- has created a very bitter hostility to him in that section of the State; -- while his zealous advocacy of the Tolling and Pro-Rata projects, made the Railroad interest his active enemy.
lead_paragraph: The Republicans of this State do not seem to be quite harmonious in regard to their local nominations, although they are perfectly united in support of their Presidential candidate. The election of a Governor occasions a good deal of ill-feeling in various quarters. Gov. MORGAN is a candidate for reelection, and, in spite of the hostility of sundry local interterests and the disaffection of many friends of Gov. SEWARD, who charge him with indifference, or, at least, inactivity, in the matter of his nomination at Chicago, he will unquestionably receive the nomination. His repeated veto of the Susquehanna Railroad bill, -- after his virtual pledge to sign it if divested of certain obnoxious features contained in the bill as first passed, -- has created a very bitter hostility to him in that section of the State; -- while his zealous advocacy of the Tolling and Pro-Rata projects, made the Railroad interest his active enemy.

abstract: The Douglas Democratic State Convention closed its labors yesterday, with the selection of an electoral ticket in fusion with the Bell and Everett men, and the adoption of a series Of resolutions expressive of the sense of the Convention relative to the questions at issue in the campaign, and the duty of the Democracy in the premises.
lead_paragraph: The Douglas Democratic State Convention closed its labors yesterday, with the selection of an electoral ticket in fusion with the Bell and Everett men, and the adoption of a series Of resolutions expressive of the sense of the Convention relative to the questions at issue in the campaign, and the duty of the Democracy in the premises. The Douglas Committee of Conference, it is understood, had considerable difficulty in arranging the terms of fusion with the Bell Committee, and the Convention was obliged to adjourn once or twice, to await the result of their deliberations, but everything was finally arranged satisfactorily. The ticket was applauded vehemently when it was read to the Convention, and was adopted unanimously.

abstract: The changed aspect of this gay and brilliant watering-place on Sunday arrests the attention of every visitor. No railway trains arrive or depart. The business of the place is entirely suspended. The churches are thronged. The splendid equipages which crowd Broadway, near the large Hotels, on other days, are mostly unseen and unused on the Sabbath. A subdued air steals over the groups that gather in the long verandahs.
lead_paragraph: SARANTOGA, Monday, Aug. 13, 1860.

abstract: After one of the most turbulent and bitterly  contested elections which it has ever been my fortune, good or bad, in an experience of thirty years, to participate, the community has relapsed into a quletude, from its contrast almost startling in its intensity. In communicating its coincident results, the telegraph will, of course, have long anticipated me; but upon its inside history I may perhaps let in a ray or two of particular sunshine.

abstract: -- One of the best executed counterfeits that we have seen for a long time has just been put into circulation. It is a $5 on the Bull's Head Bank, of this City. The vignette is a drove of horses, &c., with a red figure 5 on either side. In the counterfeit the red figures extend on to the vignette, the one on the right touching the heels of a horse. In the genuine the red 5s barely touch the vignette. The paper of the counterfeit is heavier; and the engraving is darker than the genuine. As these are the only points of difference, it is difficult for the unskillful to decide which is the good, and which is the bad bill. Counterfeit $5 bills are also in circulation on the Lime Rock Bank, Smithfield, Rhode Island. The photographs are so well executed that one of them was yesterday taken at the Tradesmen's Bank. Information was telegraphed from Head-quarters to all the Police Stations, and store-keepers were notified. No arrests have been reported.
lead_paragraph: -- One of the best executed counterfeits that we have seen for a long time has just been put into circulation. It is a $5 on the Bull's Head Bank, of this City. As these are the only points of difference, it is difficult for the unskillful to decide which is the good, and which is the bad bill. abstract: The Common Council is taking a resting spell on the Japanese swindle. It is waiting for the storm to blow over. When the Press has done talking of the subject and the public is supplied with some new topic of comment and curiosity, the nice little bill of $105,000 will be called up, -- passed, signed and paid. This is evidently the calculation of the parties interested. Experience justifies them, probably, in relying upon a relapse in the public system.

abstract: The Democratic Convention at Syracuse yesterday completed its labors. Having thrown Tammany Hall overboard the day before, and rushed into the arms of Mayor WOOD, it consummated its work of self-immolation by burying itself in the embraces of Messrs. HUNT and BROOKS. And yet its sacrifice is not complete enough to be magnanimous, nor bold enough to be effective.
lead_paragraph: The Democratic Convention at Syracuse yesterday completed its labors. Having thrown Tammany Hall overboard the day before, and rushed into the arms of Mayor WOOD, it consummated its work of self-immolation by burying itself in the embraces of Messrs. HUNT and BROOKS. And yet its sacrifice is not complete enough to be magnanimous, nor bold enough to be effective. It went just far enough to give the rump of the old American Party an excuse for abandoning their own ground, and going over, bag and baggage, to the Democrats. And if it had not gone half so far, the result would have been precisely the same.

abstract: The unseasonable character of the weather has almost entirely prevented the adoption of those light and elegant toilettes prepared in anticipation of warm days and sunny skies. Hence the fashion (which we hoped was but for a day) of large silk paletots, or burnous with sleeves, is still almost universally followed, and we can scarcely wonder under the circumstances, that appearance is less studied than comfort. We cannot, however, help regretting that the pretty muslin mantles, embroidered with so much skill and taste, or those of Chantilly, so rich and elegant, with the grenadine shawls, so light and harmonious in color, that all these charming and gracefull novelties should be doomed to remain in their boxes, and to give place to the winterly looking garments already named, or shawls of black cachemire, embroidered in silk or jet, and trimmed with lace.

abstract: The great ship left us yesterday. Her arrival at this port on the 28th of June will long dwell in the memories of the multitude who assembled, at every convenient and inconvenient spot, on both sides of the bay, from New-York and Jersey cities to the Narrows, to see her steam up the harbor and reach her dock.
lead_paragraph: The great ship left us yesterday. Her arrival at this port on the 28th of June will long dwell in the memories of the multitude who assembled, at every convenient and inconvenient spot, on both sides of the bay, from New-York and Jersey cities to the Narrows, to see her steam up the harbor and reach her dock. It will be remembered equally by those on the river, who, in row-boat, sail-boat, tugboat, yacht and steamer, laid wait for her and followed in her wake, like porpoises after a whale. The booming of the cannon from the forts, and from various vessels at the docks, is still in their ears. Men, who are middle-aged, will tell of the scene when they are grown old, and boys will recall it when they are middle-aged men.

abstract: The Dexter (Michigan) correspondent of the Detroit Advertiser tells a strange story of one CHARLEY BOSTWICK, who, it says, came to that place from New-York nearly 18 months since. BOSTWICK's reputed father was a respectable citizen of Dexter, and was possessed of considerable property. The young man had become quite dissipated by his residence in this city, and his father, hoping to reform him, induced him to remove to the West with his wife. Among the first acquaintances he formed was that of Mr. GEORGE W. HAYES. He immediately became intimate with the family, and was quite marked in his attentions to Mrs. HAYES. Meantime the young man's father died, and the sympathy which Mr. HAYES felt for him afforded him a better opportunity to carry on the intrigue which he had commenced. Finally matters reached such a pass that Mr. HAYES could not shut his eyes to the evidences of infidelity on the part of his wife, which were continually thrust upon him, and he forbade BOSTWICK entering the house. The prohibition was again and again disregarded until the people of the town took the part of the injured husband and threatened to lynch, his betrayer. On one occasion he was about to receive a coat of.. tar and feathers, when Mrs. HAYES walked over to.. the hotel where he was staying and placed a pair of loaded revolvers in his hands, with which he protected himself. This demonstration frightened BOSTWICK away from Dexter for several months, but on the right of the 3d Mr. HAYES, on going horns from business, could find nothing of his wife. His sister-in-law, in answer to his questions, said that she had gone to bed sick with a headache. Mr. HAYES finally prepared to go to bed himself, and bad retired to his room for that purpose, when he heard whispering in his wife's apartment. He immediately went to the door of his room and demanded admittance. After some parley, the door was opened, and Mr. HAYES looking under the bed discovered BOSTWICK there wrapped up in a sheet. No sooner had he made this discovery than Mrs. HAYES blew out the light, leaving the room in total darkness. BOSTWICK immediately came out from his hiding place, and the two belabored Mr. HAYES with a chair until it was broken to pieces. His cries finally attracted the attention of the neighbors and passers by, but BOSTWICK managed to make good his escape before they could apprehend him. The only article of clothing which the fugitive had on at the time was his shirt, but he managed to supply the deficiencies in his wardrobe and to escape arrest until the Wednesday succeeding, when the officers found him secreted near Ann Arbor. He was returned to Dexter next day, and is now awaiting trial on charges of assault and intent to kill, and of adultery. Mrs. HAYES is held to answer similar charges.

abstract: Notwithstanding evil prognostications, and despite the weak meshes of some petty lawsuits which threatened to detain her, the Great Eastern departed yesterday promptly at the hour advertised. Besides the claims for an alleged infringement of an American patent in the arrangement of the screw and sidewheels, and the attachment issued against the luck- ...
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding evil prognostications, and despite the weak meshes of some petty lawsuits which threatened to detain her, the Great Eastern departed yesterday promptly at the hour advertised. Besides the claims for an alleged infringement of an American patent in the arrangement of the screw and sidewheels, and the attachment issued against the luckless Cox, who was responsible for many abdominal aching voids on the Cape May excursion, there were a number of small charges against people who had been directly or indirectly engaged for the ship, and each prosecutor seemed to think he had a right to claim the marine monster until his demands were satisfied. However, after having been bonded by her consignees to answer all judgments obtained against her, the sailed triumphantly at the appointed hour. Even Cox, upon whose devoted head so many maledictions have been heaped, who had the audacity to let the Directors go without a dinner, and to incur he ire of an unpaid author, dodged the Sheriff and participated in the triumph of the floating city. The sheriff had searched Cox's room in vain, for there was no Cox there; and as a dernier resort he had seized some of Cox's moveables to satisfy the indignant creditor, end was in the act of leaving the ship in the tug when he beheld Cox, in propria persona, climbing the ladder from a small boat. It would probably have been in vain had he searched for him in the labyrinths of the ship; and so, contented with the property, the Sheriff and the debtor left Cox to meditate whether it would not be better next time to pay his bills than to allow his goods to be seized on attachment.

abstract: Several of the staple amusements of Newport have lost their attraction, in no small degree, this season. Fishing expeditions, for example, are much less in vogue partly because "luck" is more uncertain than formerly, and partly on account of the lack of Southern sportsmen, who once frequented this "Isle of Peace." The former fact is attributed to the great use of seines by the professional fishermen, whereby the stock is materially lessened.

abstract: Between 9 and 10 o'clock last evening, Officer MERRITT, of the Fifteenth Precinct, was summoned to remove a drunken man who had stretched himself on the sidewalk, near the doorway of the porter-house No. 282  Bowery, kept by JAMES MASSEY, the champion of the "feather weights." When the officer reached the place he found a crowd had collected, and MASSEY, who was himself very much intoxicated, ...
lead_paragraph: Between 9 and 10 o'clock last evening, Officer MERRITT, of the Fifteenth Precinct, was summoned to remove a drunken man who had stretched himself on the sidewalk, near the doorway of the porter-house No. 282 1/2 Bowery, kept by JAMES MASSEY, the champion of the "feather weights." When the officer reached the place he found a crowd had collected, and MASSEY, who was himself very much intoxicated, standing in the doorway, brandishing a club in one hand and a revolver in the other. He demanded in an insulting way that the drunken man should be removed, and also insisted that two boxes which stood in front of a shoemaker's shop adjoining his premises should be taken away. Anticipating trouble, the policeman called to his assistance Officer PATTERSON, of the Fourteenth Precinct, and they were about to remove the man when MASSEY called them opprobrious names, and defied them to arrest him. He also fired his pistol several times in the air by way of intimidating the officers. PATTERSON then told him that he would take him into custody for disorderly behavior, whereupon he pointed his revolver at the officer's breast, and snapped it twice. PATTERSON immediately rushed upon him, and attempted to wrest the pistol from his grasp, but before he could do so the weapon was discharged, and the ball passed into the pugilist's groin, inflicting a serious wound. Although badly injured, MASSEY would, not acknowledge himself conquered, and the officer had to use his club upon his sconce. The blow brought him to the ground, and he was conveyed in an insensible condition to the Station house. The noise incident to the fracas had caused a large crowd to collect, and the prisoner was followed to the police station, and there was much excitement in the Ward.

abstract: The presence in our waters of two captured slavers is ample evidence of the existence and flourishing condition of the African slave traffic. We say flourishig, because both of the vessels brought into this port had safely landed their human freights on the Island of Cuba. The adventurers who bought, equipped and dispatched these ships have reaped the handsome profits of their daring enterprise.
lead_paragraph: The presence in our waters of two captured slavers is ample evidence of the existence and flourishing condition of the African slave traffic. We say flourishig, because both of the vessels brought into this port had safely landed their human freights on the Island of Cuba. The adventurers who bought, equipped and dispatched these ships have reaped the handsome profits of their daring enterprise. The United States, at a formidable cost, has arrived after the fact, and secured the shell, after the kernel has abundantly repaid the hazards of the business. The shipping may possibly be condemned; the owners, jubilant at their profits and their security, will laugh at the adjudication of Admiralty Courts, and the sales of Marshals. Their market is already made.

abstract: The movement of the City to take summary possession of the Washington Market property yesterday, as we anticipated, proved a failure. The tenants declined to pay rent to anybody but the landlord from whom they held their leases. They had never known the City in the matter at all: -- they rented their premises from TAYLOR, who was formally put in possession of the premises last November by the Sheriff, in pursuance of the decision of the case in which he appeared as plaintiff, and claimed the property under a lease from the State, which was the owner. The trial resulted in his favor: the title to the land was declared to be in the State, and the Sheriff put the State's lessee in possession. And it is from him that the tenants have leased their stands.
lead_paragraph: The movement of the City to take summary possession of the Washington Market property yesterday, as we anticipated, proved a failure. The trial resulted in his favor: the title to the land was declared to be in the State, and the Sheriff put the State's lessee in possession. And it is from him that the tenants have leased their stands.

abstract: Gov. HUNT ought to be more careful of what he says. In his recent speech at Buffalo, he is reported to have made some remarks as to the relation of his Constitutional Union party to the interests of freedom.
lead_paragraph: Gov. HUNT ought to be more careful of what he says. In his recent speech at Buffalo, he is reported to have made some remarks as to the relation of his Constitutional Union party to the interests of freedom. "We," said he, "are safer friends to freedom than the Republicans are." Readers of Kenilworth will recollect RALEIGH's answer to Queen ELIZABETH when she quoted the proverb, "In the multitude of counselors there is safety" -- that he had heard it intimated that the safety was for the counselors, rather than for the patient. In that sense, perhaps, Gov. HUNT and his party may be said to be "safer friends to freedom" than the Republicans. He doubtless meant, however, that the interests of freedom were safer in their hands than in Republican hands. What effect does he suppose it would have upon Mr. BELL's electoral vote, in those States where alone even Gov. HUNT can expect such a vote for him, if the people of the South should really be convinced that the interests of slaveholders were less safe with him than with Mr. LINCOLN? He knows, as we all know, that it would be injurious to the last degree, if not absolutely ruinous, and he never would have made such a statement, if he had thought for a moment that the people of those States would accept that view of the case. They know to the contrary, if he does not.

lead_paragraph: Simon Musina and Jacob Musina vs. Charles Stillman et al. -- This is the case in which the plaintiffs sue to recover $500,000 damages, alleged to have been suffered by them in consequence of certain frauds charged upon the defendants. There are two cases of the kind now pending, of which this is one, the other being brought against Judge Watrous, of Texas, and others, with whom it is charged he was engaged in a conspiracy to defraud the plaintiffs. This case was stated at some length in the TIMES of Nov. 12, and that against Judge Watrous in the issue of the 16th of that month, at which time they were respectively before the Court on a motion for permission to leave the City, the defendant Stillman alleging that the condition of his property in Brownsville, Texas, required his immediate attention.

abstract: The number of candidates for the United States Senate is increasing with great rapidity. Our neighbor GREELEY is openly in the field.
lead_paragraph: The number of candidates for the United States Senate is increasing with great rapidity. Our neighbor GREELEY is openly in the field. He makes no secret of the fact, -- but frankly avows his determination to "test his popularity" on that issue. He withdraws from the canvass for Governor, partly because he does not see his way very clearly to that post which Gov. MORGAN's coach stops the way, and partly because the Senate seems on the whole the most attractive place. Then, too, it would be such a splendid climax to his Chicago campaign, -- to follow up SEWARD's defeat for the Presidential nomination by taking the chair from under him at Washington! The temptation is too strong for mere humanity to resist; and since he abandoned the vegetarian diet, there's a great deal of human nature in GREELEY.

abstract: If Dr. CHEEVER has failed to excite the sympathy of his own countrymen by his ferocious onslaughts upon America and her institutions, he does not seem destined to much better fortune in England.
lead_paragraph: If Dr. CHEEVER has failed to excite the sympathy of his own countrymen by his ferocious onslaughts upon America and her institutions, he does not seem destined to much better fortune in England. This is not his fault by any means, for he is surpassing himself in his efforts to wring supplies from the pockets of Anti-Slavery England. His first public discourse in London, which we published a day or two since, is quite a miracle of bad taste and bad feeling, and ought to have brought on quite a harvest of guineas to the mendicant martyr of the Church of the Puritans. Unhappily, however, for Dr. CHEEVER, the English public is gradually beginning to comprehend the position of affairs in America, to respect the grave difficulties of the question of Slavery, and to feel that the moral impertinence in which Exeter Hall has so long indulged on this subject, is really something worse than an impertinence.

abstract: We have advices from China to the 15th inst. One thing only is clear in the chaos of uncertain intelligence which reaches us by this arrival, and that is the more than moral certainty that the Chinese authorities have prepared ...
lead_paragraph: We have advices from China to the 15th inst. One thing only is clear in the chaos of uncertain intelligence which reaches us by this arrival, and that is the more than moral certainty that the Chinese authorities have prepared themselves for a vigorous defence of the Pei-ho forts and of the road to Peking. The rumors of last year, which filled the Taku forts with gray-capped Russians, have given place now to stories of Chinese astuteness and capacity, and to pictures of the preparation which China is making to repel by force of arms the insolent assumptions of the Western Powers. It seems to be commonly conceded that the forts of the Pei-ho have been well and sagaciously armed since the attack of last year, and that the Chinese troops, having once "smelt powder" in actual warfare with Western forces, are not to be despised as combatants in the now impending strife. They have at least learned that if British and French balls carry death with them, Chinese balls, when equally well-aimed, may be equally trusted to disturb and disorganize hostile ranks. When we consider that the Chinese population numbers more than three hundred millions, and that Europe itself with America, is no more safe from a military movement of this colossal mass than the Roman Empire was from the awakened energies of the Germanic barbarians, it is easy to see that the Chinese war, of 1860, may possibly take its place among the great secular convulsions which have changed the face of human history.

abstract: Some of our Republican friends seem to be sadly bewildered by the divisions of the Democracy. They have apparently forgotten who the candidates are against whom they are expected to wage war, and are turning ...
lead_paragraph: Some of our Republican friends seem to be sadly bewildered by the divisions of the Democracy. They have apparently forgotten who the candidates are against whom they are expected to wage war, and are turning their batteries upon private parties who are not candidates for any office whatever. THURLOW WEED seems to be the target for a good deal of this random practice. Some of the Republican clubs in Brooklyn have devoted themselves with great zeal and energy to his extinction. They denounce him in speeches and resolutions, and canvass his character and claims on public confidence, a good deal more zealously than those of DOUGLAS, BELL or BRECKINRIDGE.

abstract: On the morning of the 22d of April last a fire occurred in the building No. 869 Broadway, occupied as a liquor and cigar store by a man named Wm. H. Purley, and the building, with most of the stock, was destroyed.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of the 22d of April last a fire occurred in the building No. 869 Broadway, occupied as a liquor and cigar store by a man named Wm. H. Purley, and the building, with most of the stock, was destroyed. Connected with the fire were many circumstances which warranted a supposition that it was not of accidental origin, and Fire-Marshal Baker has given the matter a thorough investigation. The testimony implicates Purley and one Wm.G. Lambert, Jr., as having designedly set fire to the place with the object of obtaining the sum of $16,000, for which amount the stock had been insured in the Standard, American and Home Insurance Companies. Purley stated at the time of the fire that his loss reached the snug little sum of $16,888 27, but the investigation has demonstrated that the value of his stock was scarce one-fourth of that sum. Two young men, named James Peevers and Daniel Wilson, testified that they were both employed by Purley, and that for five or six weeks prior to the fire they suspected that it was the intention of the proprietor to burn the place. Peevers states that on one occasion at Lambert's office, No. 26 Broad-street, he heard Lambert say to Purley, "That d _____ d store is not paying -- I wish I could sell it or get rid of it in some way." Purley replied, "I'll tell you what to do with it: get a cheap stock into it, get it fully insured, and buns it up." Witness from that time made up his mind that they intended to burn the store. On other occasions Lambert had said to witness, "What a fine fire that store would make," and ask it he believed it would burn out quickly. About a week previous to the fire, Lambert had all the liquors put into bottles, which were not corked, and on the afternoon of its occurrence he sent witness to procure some oysters, stating that he intended at 10 o'clock that night to have some company there to supper. Shortly after 12 o'clock that night witness left the place, but, suspecting something wrong, he loitered near the premises until all had left. He afterwards looked through a crack in the shutter, and saw a glare of light, but was unable to decide whether it proceeded from the gasburners or something else. He did not give an alarm, but walked off a couple of blocks, and returned in a few minutes to find that the light had disappeared. He then went home, and next morning, on coming down to work, he ascertained that the store had been burned up. This formed the substance of the testimony against the parties, and it was fully substantiated by the evidence of many other witnesses. After the testimony had been submitted to Justice KELLY, he issued warrants for the arrest of the parties implicated. Lambert was yesterday apprehended by Capt. Cameron, of the Eighteenth Precinct, and, having been taken before the magistrate, was required to furnish bail in the sum of $10,000 to answer the charge. His father became his surety. Purley has not yet been arrested.

abstract: INTERESTING TO BIOGRAPHERS. In the Sixth District Court, before Justice FONDA, the case of WHITLEY against CRAIG, was to have been heard yesterday, but after some conversation, it was postponed to Monday.
lead_paragraph: INTERESTING TO BIOGRAPHERS. -- In the Sixth District Court, before Justice FONDA, the case of WHITLEY against CRAIG, was to have been heard yesterday, but after some conversation, it was postponed to Monday. It is an action brought by Judge T.W. WHITLEY, magistrate, author, artist and editor, of the village of Hoboken, against D.C. CRAIG, Esq., the New-York Telegraphic Agent-of the Associated Press, for services rendered in writing a biographical sketch of Mr. ROBERT W. RUSSELL, the Secretary and legal adviser of the American Telegraph Company. It seems that in the late controversy about the management of the American Telegraph Company, it became a matter of interest to Mr. CRAIG to learn some thing of the personal history of Mr. RUSSELL, and hearing that Judge WHITLEY was in possession of the facts relative to his former career, both in this country and England, he applied to him through an agent to write a sketch of his life. The Judge complied with the request, and wrote a biographical sketch of Mr. RUSSELL, covering ten or twelve pages of foolsca[???], in which the leading incidents of his life were duly set forth. The manuscript was forwarded to Mr. CRAIG, who, after perusing it, returned it to the author with a note stating that it contained nothing not previously know, and was therefore of no value. The author replied that the greater portion of the sketch was new, and not "previously known," and demanded $50 as a reasonable remuneration for his services. The demand was refused, unless the amount were reduced to $5, and hence the action at law. The case was called by Judge FONDA, yesterday morning, when the plaintiff with his counsel, R.D. DEMING. Esq., appeared with their witnesses ready for trail. The defendant's counsel, GALPIN & SKINNER, asked for a postponement, stating at the same time that they should plead the general is the "with a special plea that the contract between the parties was contra bonos mores." Plaintiff's counsel wished to know what was intended by the special plea of "contra bonos mores," but the Judge said it was of no consequence, that the plea of the general issue was quite sufficient, and that the case might stand over until Monday next at 11 o'clock A.M.

abstract: In Massachusetts, in Webster County, they have a lake which is unrivaled for scenery and chowder. The only difficulty is, how to get there  not that the way is not plain enough to horses and oxen, but to men it is difficult the reason ...
lead_paragraph: -- In Massachusetts, in Webster County, they have a lake which is unrivaled for scenery and chowder. The only difficulty is, how to get there -- not that the way is not plain enough to horses and oxen, but to men it is difficult -- the reason being that they cannot pronounce its name. A great many people have nearly accomplished the lockjaw in the experiment. It is called Lake Chaubunagungamaug.

abstract: The Book Publishers' Association have issued their September Trade Sale Catalogue. The invoices are enormously heavy, the list occupying 524 large octavo pages. The sale will begin at the Trade Sale Rooms, GEO. A. LEAVITT Co., Auc- ...
lead_paragraph: -- The Book Publishers' Association have issued their September Trade Sale Catalogue. The invoices are enormously heavy, the list occupying 524 large octavo pages. The sale will begin at the Trade Sale Rooms, GEO. A. LEAVITT & CO., Auctioneers, on Tuesday, Sept. 4, and continue daily in the order of the catalogue. The largest invoice is that of DERBY & JACKSON, to which 26 pages are given. The next largest is that of the APPLETONS, occupying 24 pages. Boston houses are represented by LITTLE & BROWN, TICKNOR & FIELDS, THAYER & ELDRIDGE, CROSBY & NICHOLS, and BROWN & TAGGARD; Philadelphia houses by J.B. LlPPINCOTT & CO., CHILDS & PETERSON, E.H. BUTLER & CO., and others. Three or four English invoices also appear in the Catalogue. The sale will commence with the list of THAYER & ELDRIDGE, of Boston.

abstract: The Prince of Wales will arrive at Quebec today. On Wednesday and Thursday he went up the Saguenay River the latter day on a fishing excursion. The voyage up the St. Lawrence was marked by the usual enthusiastic demonstrations of welcome on the part of the people on both banks of the river.
lead_paragraph: The Prince of Wales will arrive at Quebec today. On Wednesday and Thursday he went up the Saguenay River -- the latter day on a fishing excursion. The voyage up the St. Lawrence was marked by the usual enthusiastic demonstrations of welcome on the part of the people on both banks of the river. Salutes were fired at various points, and flags were displayed profusely. The Hero, the Prince's vessel, ran on the rocks at the mouth of the Saguenay, and was considerably injured, causing her to leak at the rate of three feet per hour. The pilot, who is considered one of the best on the river, was subsequently put in irons. At Montreal, it is understood, considerable jealousy exists between the English and the French Canadian residents, growing out of the preparations for the reception, and serious difficulties, it is feared, may result. This apprehension is so great that the officers of the garrison there are not permitted to absent themselves, it being thought probable their services may be required to prevent tumult.

abstract: ern politicians continue to beat the disunion gong, and here and there a Northern man may be found who is frightened at it. The most direful consequences are predicted as certain to follow a Republican victory. The Herald insists that all the slaves will be instantly liberated, and that we shall have a general carnival of plunder, butchery and unbridled lust. If the Herald believed any such thing, it would instantly advocate LINCOLN's election; for it lives and thrives in the midst of just such commotions as it predicts. But it only hopes to frighten silly old women in dress-coats by its blatant nonsense, and therefore keeps it up.

abstract: ALLEGED ROWDYISM AMONG CHURCH MEMBERS  THREATENING TO TEAR DOWN A CHURCH ARRESTS,   Yesterday forenoon Rev. JAMES GUBBY, Pastor of the Third Presbyterian Church in Jersey City, and JOSEPH WELLWOOD, a member of the same Church, ...
lead_paragraph: ALLEGED ROWDYISM AMONG CHURCH MEMBERS -- THREATENING TO TEAR DOWN A CHURCH -- ARRESTS, &c. -- Yesterday forenoon Rev. JAMES GUBBY, Pastor of the Third Presbyterian Church in Jersey City, and JOSEPH WELLWOOD, a member of the same Church, appeared before Justice BEDFORD and preferred complaints against SAMUEL STERLING, JOHN WILSON and WM. ATCHISON, who are, or were, members of the Third Presbyterian Church, charging them with assault and disorderly conduct at a session meeting on Thursday night. One of them is also charged with having threatened to tear down and destroy the edifice. A feud has existed for many months between certain members of the Church, the cause of which is not made public. Several persons have been expelled from the Society. Rev. Mr. GUBBY makes two affidavits. In one he testifies that he is the minister of the Church; that on the evening of the 16th of August a meeting of the Session of the Church was held, and while in session, SAMUEL STERLING, who was present, without cause or provocation, put his fist to the face of deponent and threatened to make him suffer, thereby putting Rev. Mr. GUBBY in bodily fear. He further complains that said STERLING wilfully and unlawfully interrupted and disturbed said meeting by rude and noisy behavior. The reverend gentleman made another affidavit, charging JOHN WILSON with having, on the 23d of July last, threatened to pull down and destroy the Church, and further, that on the evening of the 16th inst., at a meeting of the Session, Mr. WILSON interrupted and disturbed said meeting, by making a great noise and by rude and indecent behavior. Mr. JOSEPH WELLWOOD made an affidavit, that on Thursday evening, while reading a document, charging one of the members of said church with selling liquor on the Sabbath, WM. ATCHISON made a violent assault and struck deponent with a fan, and greatly interrupted the business of the meeting. Warrants were placed in the hands of Constable MCANALLY, who arrested the parties, and on going before Justice BEDFORD they entered into bonds for their appearance at Court, should the Grand Jury find a bill against them.

lead_paragraph: Our readers probably remember the unscrupulous attempts that were made to inculpate Gov. SEWARD in the Harper's Ferry affair. Col. FORBES, who was the principal witness relied on to sustain this view of the case, asserted that he called on Mr. SEWARD and told him of BROWN's plans. This statement was seized upon by the Southern and the Democratic Press as proof that he was one of the original conspirators, and that BROWN was only putting in execution a plot to which Mr. SEWARD was a party.

lead_paragraph: Last evening there was a large gathering of those favorable to the election of the Bell and Everett ticket. During the evening Clubs arrived from all sections of the lower part of the State. Each one was accompanied by a large bell and pyrotechnics, and in marching through the city, made a grand display. The meeting was called to order at 8 o'clock, at Metropolitan Hall, which was thronged in every part, when WILLIAM H. JANEWAY was called to the chair, and a long list of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries was approved.

abstract: At a public meeting held in this City on the 18th instant,the undersigned were appointed a Committee to devise measures whereby the sympathy of our American people in behalf of the sufferers in Syria may find practicable and effective expression.
lead_paragraph: At a public meeting held in this City on the 18th instant,the undersigned were appointed a Committee to devise measures whereby the sympathy of our American people in behalf of the sufferers in Syria may find practicable and effective expression. In the discharge of this duty they beg leave to submit to THE CHRISTIAN AND BENEVOLENT PUBLIC the following APPEAL in behalf of 75,000 people, most of whom are women and children, and many of them widows and orphans, reduced to the greatest misery by a dreadful war, that partakes of both a civil and a religious nature. This war has been raging for more than six weeks on the sides of Lebanon and anti-Lebanon, and in the valleys between them, in the middle part of the Turkish Province of Syria, and serious fears are entertained that it may soon extend as far north as Aleppo, and southward to Joppa and Jerusalem.

abstract: Judge BUEL died at his residence in Troy, on Thursday night, aged 76 years. For more than a  generation, says the Troy Daily Whig, Judge BUEL has been one of the best known and highly esteemed citizens of Troy.
lead_paragraph: Judge BUEL died at his residence in Troy, on Thursday night, aged 76 years. For more than a generation, says the Troy Daily Whig, Judge BUEL has been one of the best known and highly esteemed citizens of Troy. Prominent at the Bar, he was as well for many years very active and efficient in all public concerns, in both city and country. He always enjoyed public confidence, and was most faithful and devoted to any cause which enlisted his energies. In 1821 he was a member of the Convention which revised the Constitution of this State. He distinguished himself in that body in the discussion of several important questions. He held the office of Judge of the Court of Common Pleas for several years, receiving the office first from the old Council of Appointment. Ill health obliged him to resign this position in 1827. Spending some three years in the South, soon after, in pursuit of health, he returned, and devoted himself to his profession, avoiding public life. In 1842 he was appointed one of the State Regents of the University, which office he held at the time of his death. We cannot enumerate the various positions of honor and trust, connected with business, charitable and religious interests, which the deceased held in later years. They were numerous, and every duty belonging to them was discharged with rigid fidelity. In religious faith he was an Episcopalian, and for many years, to the time of his decease, he was senior Warden of St. Paul's Church.

abstract: -One of  our religious exchanges dwells upon the evil consequences of the regattas, which are becoming so fashionable among the students of several of our leading colleges. It remarks that they lead to betting upon the speed of boats, sometimes to drinking beer and other stimulants for recovery from fatigue and exhausted strength, and to heavy expenses from the paternal pocket.
lead_paragraph: -One of our religious exchanges dwells upon the evil consequences of the regattas, which are becoming so fashionable among the students of several of our leading colleges. It remarks that they lead to betting upon the speed of boats, -- sometimes to drinking beer and other stimulants for recovery from fatigue and exhausted strength, and to heavy expenses from the paternal pocket. It rejoices to learn, therefore, that the Faculty of Yale College have taken steps to remedy the evil and have forbidden the students to engage in sports of this kind.

abstract: BURGLARS ARRESTED -- A SHREWD BOY. -- Yesterday afternoon, during the temporary absence of the inmates, two burglars forced their way into house No. 21 Vine-street, and stole property valued at $100. As they were leaving the premises, a little son of the occupant saw them, and without saying anything followed in their wake. At the first street corner reached the thieves separated, taking different directions. The lad was somewhat puzzled at first what to do, but finally followed one of the men until he came across officer REILY, of the First Precinct Police, to whom he said, "There is a man who robbed my mother's house," and he was at once arrested. Nothing was said about another thief, but it seems the boy kept his eyes open, and soon after espied the companion of the man under arrest, and meeting officer HOUGH, of the First Precinct Police, he quietly said to him, "There is a man who robbed my mother's house," and he also was arrested. Upon his person the stolen property was found. Both of the prisoners were committed for trial.
lead_paragraph: BURGLARS ARRESTED -- A SHREWD BOY. -- Yesterday afternoon, during the temporary absence of the inmates, two burglars forced their way into house No. 21 Vine-street, and stole property valued at $100. abstract: A letter from Marseilles of the 3d inst. announces the arrival there, by the mail steamboat Mersey, of the P re Est ve, superior of the missionaries in Syria. He has come to France to give an account to the French Government of the massacres and plunder which have taken place in the Lebanon.
lead_paragraph: A letter from Marseilles of the 3d inst. announces the arrival there, by the mail steamboat Mersey, of the P re Est ve, superior of the missionaries in Syria. He has come to France to give an account to the French Government of the massacres and plunder which have taken place in the Lebanon. He states that at Damascus alone more than 8,000 Christians have been put to death. The number of victims to Mahomedan fanaticism throughout Syria amounts to from 15,000 to 16,000.

abstract: -- We print this morning some curious intelligence from China, received by way of St. Petersburg. The source from whence it comes has been generally found reliable, and it is to be presumed that it is equally trustworthy on the present occasion. We always knew that the rebels were a formidable power in China, but we were scarcely prepared to hear that they have almost accomplished the destruction of the Flowery Kingdom. Our Russian authority states that the Empire is in a most ruinous condition through internal dissensions; that the rebels have the Government virtually in their own hands, and that they are within fourteen miles of the Imperial city of Peking. If this be true, the French and English forces, now on their way to the Pei-ho, will find their work accomplished for them before their arrival. At any rate, there is every prospect of a triangular fight, in which the unfortunate Emperor is sure to be worsted. If he is the sagacious monarch that report asserts, him to be, he will make peace with the French and English, and, by their aid, destroy the rebellious multitudes that are threatening to take from him his sovereignty and his life.
lead_paragraph: -- We print this morning some curious intelligence from China, received by way of St. Petersburg. The source from whence it comes has been generally found reliable, and it is to be presumed that it is equally trustworthy on the present occasion. We always knew that the rebels were a formidable power in China, but we were scarcely prepared to hear that they have almost accomplished the destruction of the Flowery Kingdom. Our Russian authority states that the Empire is in a most ruinous condition through internal dissensions; that the rebels have the Government virtually in their own hands, and that they are within fourteen miles of the Imperial city of Peking. If this be true, the French and English forces, now on their way to the Pei-ho, will find their work accomplished for them before their arrival. At any rate, there is every prospect of a triangular fight, in which the unfortunate Emperor is sure to be worsted. If he is the sagacious monarch that report asserts, him to be, he will make peace with the French and English, and, by their aid, destroy the rebellious multitudes that are threatening to take from him his sovereignty and his life.

abstract: Henceforth let it be remembered that there are two Blondins, not in the field, but on the ropes. The long-heralded Faring made his d but at Niagara Falls on Wednesday last. The cable on which he performed was stretched across the river a third of a mile below the Clifton House, and was in length nearly double that on which Blondin has been exhibiting.
lead_paragraph: Henceforth let it be remembered that there are two Blondins, not in the field, but on the ropes. The long-heralded Faring made his d but at Niagara Falls on Wednesday last. The cable on which he performed was stretched across the river a third of a mile below the Clifton House, and was in length nearly double that on which Blondin has been exhibiting. At first Farini stepped nervously upon the cable; his pole, which was two slender for its weight and length, caught in the guy-ropes, and for a few moments the adventurer was in a rather embarrassing condition. He soon regained his confidence, however, and completed the trip to the Canada side in safety. On his return he stopped midway, lowered a cord to the Maid of the Mist, which was waiting in the stream, and by it raised a rope which he fastened to his cable. By means of this he descended to the steamboat, a distance of 70 or 80 feet, and then, having climbed up again, completed his transit. The crowd was much disappointed that FARINI did not add another to the many risks which he ran of breaking his neck by going down to the Maid of the Mist head foremost, as he had advertised; but the narrow escape he had in the earlier part of his performance nearly compensated for this. Who dare say that this method of crossing Niagara River, will not ultimatelely supersede both boats and suspension bridges?

abstract: "Twenty minutes allowed for dinner!" Who, that has traveled, and that means everybody, along any of our lines of railroad, has not waited for a long time in earnest and hungry expectation of that sound?
lead_paragraph: "Twenty minutes allowed for dinner!" Who, that has traveled, and that means everybody, along any of our lines of railroad, has not waited for a long time in earnest and hungry expectation of that sound? How many pages of APPLETON's and BRADSHAW's Guides have been worried to pieces in searching for the place where the twenty minutes were to be allowed, and the dinner to be furnished? How many conductors -- not irate, but slightly impatient -- have said: "Gentlemen and ladies, fifty-six miles yet; arrive there in an hour and a half, unless a cow is on the track, or we get off the track ourselves, or get run into, or the boiler explodes."

abstract: We have news of our old friends, the Japanese Ambassadors. On the 16th of July they had got as far as the Cape de Verde Islands, on their way home. The skies had been propitious. They had had but little wind, and consequently but little sea-sickness.
lead_paragraph: We have news of our old friends, the Japanese Ambassadors. On the 16th of July they had got as far as the Cape de Verde Islands, on their way home. The skies had been propitious. They had had but little wind, and consequently but little sea-sickness. According to the reports of our correspondents, they had good appetites, good spirits and pleasant recollections of their visit to the United States. We don't see why they should not have. They had their fill of the best the country afforded -- and none of the bills to pay.

abstract: We learn from Havana, by the Quaker City, whose arrival is elsewhere reported, that a new decree has been issued by the Spanish  Government upon the subject of Chinese immigration. There are eighty-four articles in the decree, and a plan for regulating the introduction of Chinese laborers is elaborately drawn out.
lead_paragraph: We learn from Havana, by the Quaker City, whose arrival is elsewhere reported, that a new decree has been issued by the Spanish Government upon the subject of Chinese immigration. There are eighty-four articles in the decree, and a plan for regulating the introduction of Chinese laborers is elaborately drawn out. The reforms established by the new law are chiefly in favor of the laborer, and a form of protection is extended to him while under contract of service. His position is at least so far ameliorated that he will be permitted to complain of ill-treatment, and at the expiration of the term of his indenture he will be permitted to go free.

abstract: The Cincinnati Gazette is sanguine regarding the result in Indiana. It says that the result is now as certain as any political calculation can be. One of the "Pocket" counties in particular could be named where the vote will be as one-sided for LINCOLN as it was BUCHANAN at the last election. A careful canvas of eight counties gives a total majority for LINCOLN of 8,500.
lead_paragraph: The Cincinnati Gazette is sanguine regarding the result in Indiana. It says that the result is now as certain as any political calculation can be. One of the "Pocket" counties in particular could be named where the vote will be as one-sided for LINCOLN as it was BUCHANAN at the last election. A careful canvas of eight counties gives a total majority for LINCOLN of 8,500. In the same countries four years ago, FREMONT's majority was only 5,385. Republican gain, 3,115. These are facts, not conjectures. It is believed that every county north of the National road will give a majority for LINCOLN. Should the balance of the State give the same relative gains as these counties, the Republican majority in Indiana will exceed 30,000.

abstract: SUICIDE BY HANGING. Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest on Sunday upon the body of Mrs. ARABELLA TUKEY, who committed suicide on Saturday worning at the Water-Cure establishment, No.15 Laigh street, by hanging herself in the bed chamer.
lead_paragraph: SUICIDE BY HANGING. -- Coroner JACKMAN held an inquest on Sunday upon the body of Mrs. ARABELLA TUKEY, who committed suicide on Saturday worning at the Water-Cure establishment, No.15 Laigh street, by hanging herself in the bed chamer. Mr. STEPHEN H. TUKEY, her husband, testified that for eight months past his wife had been greatly depressed in mind on account of continual sickness. On Saturday morning he left her to go to his business, and on returning found her suspended by the neck to a spike in the wall, and dead. The jury rendered a verdict of "Suicide by hanging, while laboring under mental derangement." Deceased was a native of this country 30 years of age.

abstract: By the steamer Etna from Liverpool, we have received letters from our Correspondents on board the U.S. frigate Niagara on her way to Japan with the Ambassadors. She left this port on the 30th of June and the 17th of July had reached the Cape de Verde Islands, from which points our dispatches were forwarded to England and thence to this country.
lead_paragraph: By the steamer Etna from Liverpool, we have received letters from our Correspondents on board the U.S. frigate Niagara on her way to Japan with the Ambassadors. She left this port on the 30th of June and the 17th of July had reached the Cape de Verde Islands, from which points our dispatches were forwarded to England and thence to this country. They give a detailed and interesting report of every thing which has occurred during the voyage of the frigate thus far. The Japanese seem to have been highly delighted with their reception in America, and predict from it the most important results to their own country.

abstract: If GARIBALDI has latterly met with the success that crowned his efforts at the commencement of the war of Italian independence, he is probably in Naples at the present time. According to the accounts elsewhere published, a formidable advance guard of Italian troops had landed in Calabria, and were received with the greatest enthusiasm by the people. Whole regiments of Neapolitan troops are said to have deserted from the King's service, and to have joined GARIBALDI's army. All accounts agree in stating that the General will be received with open arms by the people; and it has come to be a settled belief in men's minds that he has only to appear in the Neapolitan capital to insure and complete the victory begun at Palermo.
lead_paragraph: If GARIBALDI has latterly met with the success that crowned his efforts at the commencement of the war of Italian independence, he is probably in Naples at the present time.
