abstract: PEOPLE AND THEIR RELATIVES IN ENGLAND. -- In the English Civil Pension List, for the year ending June 20, 1860, we find six unmarried sisters of the late Dr. DIONYSIUS LARDNER, who, "in consideration of their late brother's labors in the cause of science, and their scanty means," are almoners on the public purse to the sum total of £125, "is equal proportions," making, among the six ladies, a trifle more than £20, or about $100 each, per annum. Their "late brother's labors in the cause of science" will just keep them from starving, but nothing more EDWARD ATHEZSTONE, the post, who wrote the "Fall of Nineveh," and some other ambitious works, "in consideration of his great services in literature, and of his advanced age," is rewarded with a yearly subsidy of £25. To Miss JULIA PARDOE, a writer well known in this country, "in consideration of thirty years' toil in the field of literature, by which she has contributed both to cultivate the public taste and to support a number of helpless relations," the sum of £100 annually is awarded. Rev. HENRY LOGAN, "in consideration of his contributions to mathematical and scientific literature, and his present state of destitution, in consequence of the loss of his, eyesight," £100. Mrs. CHARLOTTE ROWCROFT, widow of CHARLES ROWCROFT, the author, and some time British Consul in this country, who died on board the steamer on his return voyage from New-York to England, the sum of £50, "in consideration of the services of her late husband," is granted. Dr. ROBERT BLAKEY, the historian of philosophy, in consideration of his straitened circumstances, gets £100, and Mrs. ELLEN BEECROFT, "in consideration of the services of her late husband, Capt. BEECROFT, for the advancement of British interests and of science, during 25 years on the coast of Africa, where he ultimately fell a victim to the climate, £50." These respective sums seam altogether inadequate. If the parties named are worthy of such recognition by the Government, the pensions awarded them should have been large enough to keep them a little more removed from want than these alms -- far such they really are -- can possibly do. Considering the large sums given as retiring annuities to officers and others, who can boast aristocratic connections, or to their widows and children, "labors in the cause of science and literature," would not seem to be of much consideration. Even the widow of THOMAS HOOD only received £100 a year from the Royal Fund, while some gouty old Admiral -- we forget his name -- on the same day was pensioned at £3,000.

abstract: James Jay Howard vs. Henry P. Raymond. -- This is an action for libel against the editor of the TIMES, and is brought in the Superior Court. The article complained of appeared in the TIMES of May 29, 1860. It stated in substance that the plaintiff, a lawyer, had suddenly departed, carrying with him money belonging to a Mrs. Hull, which he had collected as her attorney; also, that he had "forgotten" to deposit money entrusted to him by her, to deposit in the Savings' Bank.

abstract: CONFEDERATION. -- We learn, by an arrival from the La Plata, that Buenos Ayres has formally consented to reenter the Argentine Confederation. This is the proper position for Buenos Ayres to take. Her separation was an unanswerable casus belli to the other States, and it became their duty to compel her to return to the Union.

abstract: -- We are glad to see from the Twelfth Annual Report of the American Dramatic Fund Association that, after having contributed largely to the relief of unfortunate but meritorious members, and the widows and children of former members and actors of notability, their funds are still flourishing, and that there is "cash in the Bank" But what does the Association mean by placing our old friend Dr. SHELTON MACKENZIE among the dead members, (which it does in two places by distinct asterisks,) while it leaves WASHINGTON IRVING among the living? Dr. MACKENZIE is alive, and duly transmits his subscription. IRVING, alas, is not alive, but his memory will keep the Society ever green in the memory of its friends, while his visit to SHAKESPEARE's tomb at Stratford is read in the Sketch Book.

abstract: This is rather an exceptional season with us. Usually by this time of year our fashionables are thinking of clearing off into the country, and the "dead season" has begun; but this year we have scarcely noticed anything like a cessation in the usual bustle of London. This may be accounted for in two ways. The upper classes stop because they can't help it.
lead_paragraph: LONDON, Saturday, Aug. 4, 1860.

abstract: In the House of Commons, Aug. 6, Mr. BERKELEY asked the Chancellor of the Exchequer whether, in consequence of the failure of the Atlantic Telegraph Company in their attempt to lay down a submarine line to America, the agreement entered into between them and Her Majesty's Government had not become void; and whether the Government would be prepared to entertain applications from other parties willing to undertake the same enterprise, subject to the conditions set forth in the report of the Select Committee on Packet and Telegraphic Contracts which had been recently affirmed by the House.

abstract: French political pamphlets fall thick as snow-flakes, and melt away quite as rapidly. The last absurdity of the kind is entitled La Syrie et L'Alliance Russe, from which it would appear that, according to the Emperor's present programme, Russia is to be bribed by the offer of Constantinople, to assist France in the revendication of the Rhine frontier.
lead_paragraph: -- French political pamphlets fall thick as snow-flakes, and melt away quite as rapidly. The last absurdity of the kind is entitled La Syrie et L'Alliance Russe, from which it would appear that, according to the Emperor's present programme, Russia is to be bribed by the offer of Constantinople, to assist France in the revendication of the Rhine frontier. Prussia is to receive a portion of Austria, by way of compensation, and Syria is to be turned into a field for ABD-EL-KADER. If England should object, Malta, Gibraltar, and the Ionian Islands are to be taken from her, and Europe will then be allowed to enjoy the blessings of peace.

abstract: In the House of Commons on the 6th inst., the subject of the paper duty was taken up. Mr. GLADSTONE moved the first of his resolutions fixing the duties on paper, books, &c., imported from France, in accordance with the commercial treaty. He spoke at length in explanation of his proposition, and urged its adoption, that the last remnant of the protective system might be thereby destroyed.

abstract: -- We are not requested -- though we feel fully authorized -- to state, in reference to a rumor which is going the rounds of the Press, -- that Mr. H. GREELEY is not a candidate for the French Mission. We are not at liberty to add that he will not accept it if President LINCOLN should tender it to him, for it is an article of his creed never to decline anything in the shape of public office. But he would much rather have something else. He is not on very good terms personally with the Emperor, whom he has more than once called a thief and a perjurer -- terms which his Imperial Majesty might consider disrespectful. Besides, he does not speak French, -- the wine of the country doesn't agree with him, and the society of the capital is completely under the dominion of sundry prejudices on the subject of costume, which would keep him in a constant state of perplexity. Some little experience, moreover, at the large public institution of Clichy, has disgusted him with the Government functionaries. On the whole, Mr. GREELEY would prefer not to go to France. Those enterprising gentlemen who are arranging the Cabinet and distributing the offices at Washington; in advance of Mr. LINCOLNï¿½s advent, will oblige H.G. by either leaving him out of their little arrangements entirely, or else, (if he must leave his native shores,) sending him to some country -- like Hayti or Ethiopia, where he can speak the language, and not be constantly annoyed by uncongenial social usages and companionships.

Some little experience, moreover, at the large public institution of Clichy, has disgusted him with the Government functionaries. On the whole, Mr. GREELEY would prefer not to go to France. Those enterprising gentlemen who are arranging the Cabinet and distributing the offices at Washington; in advance of Mr. LINCOLN�s advent, will oblige H.G. by either leaving him out of their little arrangements entirely, or else, (if he must leave his native shores,) sending him to some country -- like Hayti or Ethiopia, where he can speak the language, and not be constantly annoyed by uncongenial social usages and companionships.

abstract: Messrs. J.C.W. BAILEY  Co., of Chicago, have just issued the Illinois State Business Directory, for 1860; a handsome volume of over nine hundred pages, comprising ample details of the mercantile, manufacturing, mechanical and professional departments of the Industry of the State.
lead_paragraph: -- Messrs. J.C.W. BAILEY Co., of Chicago, have just issued the Illinois State Business Directory, for 1860; a handsome volume of over nine hundred pages, comprising ample details of the mercantile, manufacturing, mechanical and professional departments of the Industry of the State. It furnishes an alphabetical list of all the business firms in Illinois, with their addresses, besides a classification of trades and tabular statements concerning banks, insurance and railroad companies, &c. Prof. HEWETT, of the State Normal University of Illinois, contributes a succinct sketch of the history of Chicago. The work seems to have been compiled with care. The publishers have a branch office in this City, at No. 175 Broadway.

abstract: The steamship Glasgow, from Liverpool on the 8th, and Queenstown on the 9th, passed Cape Race on Friday night. A brief summary of her news, which is two days later, has been telegraphed. We have also London journals to the 7th inst., by the Cunard steamship Etna, which arrived at this port yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Glasgow, from Liverpool on the 8th, and Queenstown on the 9th, passed Cape Race on Friday night. A brief summary of her news, which is two days later, has been telegraphed. We have also London journals to the 7th inst., by the Cunard steamship Etna, which arrived at this port yesterday. It is confirmed that a large number of Garibaldians had landed on the Neapolitan Coast. They were received by the people with great enthusiasm. Naples is making great preparations to repel the invasion. It is stated that GARIBALDI expects to be in the City of Naples by the 15th of August. The French expedition to Syria left Marseilles on the 5th and 6th inst. England will not actively join in the expedition. Russia, it is understood, will send a very large fleet to the Levant. The Emperor of the French has conferred on ABD-EL-KADER the Grand Cross of the Legion of Honor. The Paper Duty bill passed the House of Commons on the 6th inst. During the same evening, in answer to the question of a member, Mr. GLADSTONE said that, through the failure of the Atlantic Telegraph Company, the contract had become inoperative.

abstract: DEATH FROM INJURIES RECEIVED AT A ROPEWALK. Coroner MURPHY, on Saturday, held an inquest on 'the body of HENRY NOLAN, who died on Friday. Three years since, the deceased, then 18 years of age, worked in THURSBY'S rope-walk, in the Eastern District.
lead_paragraph: DEATH FROM INJURIES RECEIVED AT A ROPEWALK. -- Coroner MURPHY, on Saturday, held an inquest on 'the body of HENRY NOLAN, who died on Friday. Three years since, the deceased, then 18 years of age, worked in THURSBY'S rope-walk, in the Eastern District. Some boys, employed in the same establishment, struck for higher wages, but NOLAN would not consent to join them. One of them, named "Dutchy," took NOLAN into a retired part of the building, tied him up by the neck and feet, and left him hanging thus for about three hours. He has never recovered from the injuries then received. The jury rendered a verdict of death from consumption, superinduced by the circumstances related.

abstract: -- A series of interesting services were held in the large tent near the Central Park yesterday, commencing in the morning and afternoon with a children's Sabbath sceool. There was a great scarcity of teachers. A gentleman from the south offered a premium to any child who would bring the most children on the next Sabbath. The prospect is that there will be a tent full, and we earnestly hope that competent teachers will offer their services and aid in this movement. The same gentleman gave a liberal donation towards the enterprise. At 3 o'clock Rev. ROBT. THOMAS preached an interesting sermon to a very attentive audience. Rev. ANTHONY TIEMANN addressed the audience in English and then in German, followed by other services in German, which brought a large concourse of Germans to the tent. In the evening a prayer meeting was held, notice was given that arrangements were made to hold every Wednesday evening a temperance meeting, and Col. STONE, the converted infidel, was engaged to take charge of the prayer meeting every Thursday evening.

abstract: We have advices from Buenos Ayres, via England, to the 27th of June.  The compact of Union between the Argentine Confederation and province of Buenos Ayres, was celebrated at Parana on the 6th of June, and ratified by both Governments on the 19th. This second compact settles at once the grand question of the day.
lead_paragraph: We have advices from Buenos Ayres, via England, to the 27th of June. The compact of Union between the Argentine Confederation and province of Buenos Ayres, was celebrated at Parana on the 6th of June, and ratified by both Governments on the 19th. This second compact settles at once the grand question of the day. Buenos Ayres effectually renounces her quast independence, and becomes once again part of the Argentine nation. The Convention is now to be summoned without delay, and as they are allowed only thirty days for their sittings, it is not likely any very great innovation will be made in the National Constitution -- probably none at all. The result of their deliberations being submitted to Congress, Buenos Ayres will immediately accept and swear the Constitution as it may then be, and will proceed without delay to the election of Senators and deputies to Congress, which shall not proceed to legislate concerning the affairs of this province until such time as these shall have taken their seats.

abstract: The prospects of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE even in the South, which at the outset he was expected to carry by acclamation, are not increasing in brilliancy. Indeed, the elections of the past few weeks have covered them with clouds and doubt.
lead_paragraph: The prospects of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE even in the South, which at the outset he was expected to carry by acclamation, are not increasing in brilliancy. Indeed, the elections of the past few weeks have covered them with clouds and doubt. The party Conventions in the same quarter are of the same complexion, and it looks very much as if some of his most prominent partizans in the South were looking about for some safe and not ignoble retreat. Judged from this distance the result of the Charlottesville (Va.) Convention has a strong squinting towards a coalition with BELL. There was much less of the secession element in that body than the nomination of BRECKINRIDGE at Baltimore was supposed to imply. We see it intimated, that but for the adoption of the resolution of instruction to the Breckinridge electors to so cast their vote as to defeat LINCOLN, the Convention could not have harmonized. It would scarcely be reasonable to infer that this alternative means the promotion of DOUGLAS, after the declaration of Senator MASON, that his course tends "to the Abolition camp." It must, therefore, mean that Mr. BELL would be acceptable to the Breckinridge Democracy in the event -- now almost certain -- that they cannot have their first choice. There are collateral circumstances also which go to strengthen this intention, which we may as well glance at.

abstract: On Saturday over a thousand spectators assembled on the Empire ground at the Elysian Fields, Hoboken, to witness a contest between these two leading clubs.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday over a thousand spectators assembled on the Empire ground at the Elysian Fields, Hoboken, to witness a contest between these two leading clubs. Shortly before three o'clock the Excelsiors made their appearance on the ground in a large omnibus drawn by eight horses, and the ground having been cleared, the game begun, the Excelsiors having the "in hand." Their strong batting, aided by some loose fielding on the part of the Empires, gave them seven runs in the first innings, but their opponents also batted heavily, and the Excelsior fielding being weak, they got five tallies. The fielding in the remaining innings was somewhat improved on both sides, while the batting was equally good. At the end of the third innings the westerly shower that had been threatening for some time begun to sprinkle the ground, and when the fourth Excelsior innings had ended the rain fell so fast that it was impossible to continue the match. On the Excelsior side, Pearsall and Holden, the first and second basemen, were absent, their places in the nine being filled by Young and F. Whiting, both of whom batted finely and fielded fairly. Russell pitched well, as did Creighton, in the third innings, while Leggett stopped well behind and made two good fly catches. Creighton, Flanly and Russell made also good fly catches, while Brainerd put out two men on the second base on balls well thrown by Leggett. In batting, Flanly showed a decided improvement, making a fine home run.
headline: {'main': 'Base Ball.; EXCELSIOR, OF BROOKLYN, VS. EMPIRE, OF NEW YORK.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Base Ball.; EXCELSIOR, OF BROOKLYN, VS. EMPIRE, OF NEW YORK.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: BEATING AN OFFICER. Between 11 and 12 o'clock on Sunday night, a desperate fight occurred between a party of drunken men who were assembled at a lov, unlicensed groggery, at No. 14 Morganstreet, Jersey City, kept by PATRICK RAHAN. Officer WARD, hearing the cry of "murder," and "watch," proceeded to the place and took into custody JOHN SULLIVAN and WM. WELCH, and endeavored to take them to the lock-up.
lead_paragraph: BEATING AN OFFICER. -- Between 11 and 12 o'clock on Sunday night, a desperate fight occurred between a party of drunken men who were assembled at a lov, unlicensed groggery, at No. 14 Morganstreet, Jersey City, kept by PATRICK RAHAN. Officer WARD, hearing the cry of "murder," and "watch," proceeded to the place and took into custody JOHN SULLIVAN and WM. WELCH, and endeavored to take them to the lock-up. While on his way, JOHN WELCH came up behind and snatched the officer's club, dealt him a heavy blow on the back of the head, when the two prisoners joined in and assisted in beating him. WARD subsequently procured assistance, and succeeded in arresting John Welch, John Sullivan, Timothy Lane, Wm. Welch, and Patrick Rahan. The parties were taken before Recorder TILDEN yesterday, who fined three of them $10 each, and the two WELCH's were fined $2 each, and held to bail to appear at Court for assault on the officer.

abstract: To-day the Missouri and Western Telegraph Company commenced stretching their wire westward in the direction of Fort Kearney. The poles are set 160 miles out from here, and the wire will be up that distance in two weeks. A large party is at work further west getting out and setting the poles. It is expected that the line will be finished to Fort Kearney by the middle of November.

abstract: The Republicans hold their State Convention at Syracuse to-morrow. All the other parties have their candidates in the field, and it only remains for them to complete the preparations for the great campaign. So far as their nominations are concerned they will probably have an easy task.
lead_paragraph: The Republicans hold their State Convention at Syracuse to-morrow. All the other parties have their candidates in the field, and it only remains for them to complete the preparations for the great campaign. So far as their nominations are concerned they will probably have an easy task. Gov. MORGAN will be renominated, if not by acclamation, at least by general acquiescence. There is not likely to be any serious opposition to him from any quarter: and it is probable that all the State officers, whose terms now expire, will also be again put in nomination.

abstract: A fatal accident to the artillery volunteers of Dover occurred on Thursday evening. abstract: We publish, this morning, Mr. YANCEY'S great speech made on Tuesday last, at Memphis, Tenn., in support of the Secession ticket. We receive it from our Special Reporter, sent by us for the express purpose of laying before the readers of the TIMES the views and sentiments, by which this great leader of the Breckinridge Party endeavors to induce the Southern States to give that ticket their votes.
lead_paragraph: We publish, this morning, Mr. YANCEY's great speech made on Tuesday last, at Memphis, Tenn., in support of the Secession ticket. We receive it from our Special Reporter, sent by us for the express purpose of laying before the readers of the TIMES the views and sentiments, by which this great leader of the Breckinridge Party endeavors to induce the Southern States to give that ticket their votes. Mr. YANCEY spoke for over four hours, and long as is our report of his remarks, we are compelled to omit a very large portion of what he said. We give, however, all the important part of his speech, omitting only some of the quotations and detailed arguments by which he endeavored to vindicate his positions.

abstract: A genius who writes for the Philadelphia North American, tries to make out that the City of Brotherly love is the metropolis of the Western hemisphere. He bases his argument on the assertion that Philadelphia has more houses, more churches, and more public schools than NewYork.
lead_paragraph: -- A genius who writes for the Philadelphia North American, tries to make out that the City of Brotherly love is the metropolis of the Western hemisphere. He bases his argument on the assertion that Philadelphia has more houses, more churches, and more public schools than New-York. Our cotemporary does not go so far as to compare New-York houses, churches, and schools with those of Philadelphia, for if he did he would find that the former can accommodate and do accommodate about four times as many people as the latter. We do not wish to hurt the feelings of this ingenious and candid writer, but we suggest, for his benefit, that accuracy in all matters statistical is an important object to be kept in view. Thus, when he allows that New-York has 209 churches, he should have said 297; and when he gives us 118 public schools, he might have added several score to that number and still have been below the mark. Our village friend should travel -- let him visit the metropolis -- and see what it is like.
headline: {'main': 'Minor Topics.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Minor Topics.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: We copied some time since a paragraph from the Levant Herald warning the American public against two young men, natives of Syria, who were about to visit this country to collect money for the ostensible purpose of founding a hospital on Mount Lebanon. abstract: HON. GERRIT SMITH Sir: You and I are antipodes on the subject of Slavery. I believe it to be a divine institution created by Heaven, and such is the doctrine of the Bible. abstract: CONSOLIDATION OF WIDE-AWAKE CLUBS. In view of the fact that the various Wide-Awake Clubs of this City have heretofore acted without unison, it occured to certain members of the organization that it would be advantageous to have a consolidation of the fraternity under a general government, so that all could be called out on parade if necessity should require.
lead_paragraph: CONSOLIDATION OF WIDE-AWAKE CLUBS. -- In view of the fact that the various Wide-Awake Clubs of this City have heretofore acted without unison, it occured to certain members of the organization that it would be advantageous to have a consolidation of the fraternity under a general government, so that all could be called out on parade if necessity should require. The second preliminary meeting to effect this object was held at No. 618 Broadway last evening, SILAS B. DUTCHER acting as Chairman, and Messrs. GAVIT and TUCKER as Secretaries. Three delegates were received from each of the Wide-Awake Clubs and the Ward associations, with the exception of the Second, Fourth, Sixth, Seventh, Eleventh, Thirteenth, Fifteenth, Eighteenth and Twenty-second Wards. Two sets of delegates were received from both the Nineteenth Ward and the Rail-Splitters battalion. After a very long and tedious debate, the meeting decided to receive delegates from all organizations present, regardless of there being more than one in each Ward. This course was emphatically necessary, in order to include all the working Republicans, and was adopted by an overwhelming majority. Messrs. Ritterhand, Ward, Gillespie, Van Orden, Gavit, Jackson and Tucker, were appointed a Committee to draft a constitution and by-laws. After due deliberation the Committee reported that the name of the Society be the " Republican Wide-Awake General Committee of the City and County of New-York; that the officers be a President, two Vice-Presidents, Treasurer, Secretary, Sergeant-at-Arms, and a Marshal; that three delegates be received from each ward association, and each independent Wide-Awake Club having fifty members or more; that no general parade be ordered without the sanction of the Committees. The various recommendations of the Committee were taken up section by section. The meeting decided that independent clubs, to be entitled to representation, should have at least thirty members in uniform, and adjourned at a late hour.,

abstract: In November, 1855, James Cassin was accused, before Justice BRENNAN, of embezzling $15 from Mrs. Delany, keeper of a grocery store at No. 124 Houston-street. The charge was a trumpery one, without any foundation in fact, and was dismissed by the Grand Jury. Mr. Cassin sued the complainants for a maligious prosecution, and the referee declared in his judgment that the original charge made against Mr. Cassin "was malicious and wicked, and without any reasonable or probable foundation." The Referee awarded Mr. Cassin $1,000 damages and costs of suit.
lead_paragraph: In November, 1855, James Cassin was accused, before Justice BRENNAN, of embezzling $15 from Mrs. Delany, keeper of a grocery store at No. 124 Houston-street. The Referee awarded Mr. Cassin $1,000 damages and costs of suit.

abstract: Alexander Smith, et al. vs. Alva Higgins et al.  This case was an action at law for the infringement of a patent. It was tried before Judge BETTS and a jury, in 1856. The jury found for the defendants, but  the verdict was afterwards set aside, and a new trial ordered.
lead_paragraph: Alexander Smith, et al. vs. Alva Higgins et al. This case was an action at law for the infringement of a patent. It was tried before Judge BETTS and a jury, in 1856. The jury found for the defendants, but the verdict was afterwards set aside, and a new trial ordered. On this second trial, which took place before Judge NELSON, in 1858, the jury disagreed, and on the matter coming up again, the whole case was by consent of parties, submitted to Judge NELSON to pass upon the law and the facts, as if it were laid again before a jury. abstract: The steamship North American, from Liverpool on the 9th and Londonderry on the 10th inst., passed Father Point yesterday morning, and the steamship Arabia, from Liverpool on the 11th, and Queenstown on the 12th, was intercepted off Cape Race by the news-yacht of the Associated Press. We are thus put in possession of advices from Europe two days later than that by the Glasgow, published yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The steamship North American, from Liverpool on the 9th and Londonderry on the 10th inst., passed Father Point yesterday morning, and the steamship Arabia, from Liverpool on the 11th, and Queenstown on the 12th, was intercepted off Cape Race by the news-yacht of the Associated Press. We are thus put in possession of advices from Europe two days later than that by the Glasgow, published yesterday. Parliament was doing nothing of importance. A subsidy had been voted to the Galway line by the House of Commons, and the contract was thus confirmed. Great anxiety was felt relative to the crops, on account of the continued cold and stormy weather. The British Government, it was reported, proposed to send Lord STRATFORD DE REDCLIFFE as a special envoy to Constantinople with the Sultan. The French Emperor, after reviewing the troops destined for Syria, made them a stirring address. Over four hundred arrests are reported as having taken place at Damascus, of persons implicated in the late masacres. The culprits were immediately tried, and those found guilty were speedily executed. GARIBALDI was reported to be still at Messina preparing his expedition against the mainland -- the report of his having already landed in Calabria proving untrue. It is probable, however, that some of his forces had landed. Gen. LAMORCIEIRE had suppressed demonstration in favor of GARIBALDI at Lodi, had taken the leaders prisoners, and had levied a war contribution of 44,000 crowns An expedition from Piedmont, destined for the Roman States, was said to have been arrested by FARINA, though a letter from Rome asserts that 15,000 Piedmontese had landed at San Stefano. The Liverpool Cotton Market is reported steady and firm, at an advance. Consols are quoted at 93 1/8@93 3/4 for money.

abstract: A man named Gotleib Tindenmuller yesterday afternoon entered the store of Chas. H. Swords & Co., No. 6 Park-place, under pretence of wishing to purchase goods, but was soon detected in the act of secreting a box of millinery goods valued at $50. On being charged with the theft he dropped the box and ran into the street, but was pursued and arrested. Justice WELSH locked him up for trial.

abstract: At the Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, appeared Signor Julian Martinetti, leading acrobat of the Ravel Troupe, who was arrested on Saturday, at the suit of his wife, on a charge of abandonment The husband produced a certified copy of the record of an Indiana Court, showing that he had been regularly divorced from her, and previous articles of separation signed by both parties and their trustee, and proved that his wife had received under it the sum of $3,000 and an annual allowance of $200, which had been regularly paid for the support of the children left in her custody. The complaint was dismissed and the defendant discharged.

abstract: We published yesterday the official reply of the American Government to Lord JOHN RUSSELL'S circular dispatch on the Coolie-trade and the Slave-trade. The President's objections to the British Minister's three propositions have been well taken.
lead_paragraph: We published yesterday the official reply of the American Government to Lord JOHN RUSSELL'S circular dispatch on the Coolie-trade and the Slave-trade. The President's objections to the British Minister's three propositions have been well taken. They are objections which have been urged over and over again in the columns of the TIMES, and are not new to its readers. The first proposition is to establish a systematic plan of cruising for English, American, and Spanish vessels. It is very properly represented in this respect, that the American Government has been faithful to its duty and to its treaty stipulations. We have kept up, at a large expense, the fleet that we promised to keep up, and we have done all in our power to intercept the traders between the African coast and the Island of Cuba.

abstract: A ninety-cent postage-stamp, expressly intended for the accommodation of merchants, has been prepared. The centre of the stamp has a representation of WASHINGTON, from a portrait taken at the time when he resigned the command of the army, and differs materially from all other likenesses of him. The color of the ground is blue. The stamps now in use are of the following denominations: One three, five, ten, twelve, twenty-four, thirty and ninety cents. The amount generally paid on foreign letters, not covered by the above, are fifteen, twenty-seven and fifty-four cents, for which a combination of the stamps now supplied will suffice.

abstract: MILITARY EXCURSIONS Yesterday morning, several of the officers of the Fifth Regiment left the City, to attend the inspection of the Eighth Regiment of Connecticut, at Bridgeport. The drum corps of the Fifth and the Turners' Brass Band left the day previous. They are all expected to return this morning.
lead_paragraph: MILITARY EXCURSIONS. -- Yesterday morning, several of the officers of the Fifth Regiment left the City, to attend the inspection of the Eighth Regiment of Connecticut, at Bridgeport. The drum corps of the Fifth and the Turners' Brass Band left the day previous. They are all expected to return this morning. A movement is going on among the officers of the Eleventh Regiment to abolish their drum corps, and establish a corps of signalists, which is more appropriate to a rifle corps, as they generally receive their orders by horn signal. The National Blues of New-Haven, Capt. WILLIS BRISTOL, Jr., are expected in this Cityon the 29th inst., when they will be received by the Highwood Guards of Hoboken, Capt. J.P. NEWKIRK, at the foot of Peck-slip. Both companies will then proceed to Hoboken, accompanied by Dodworth's full band, where the Blues will be entertained with a dinner. Both companies will return to the City, and leave at 5 o'clock in the steamer Vanderbilt, of the Norwich and Worcester line, for Boston. On their arrival there they will be received by the second Regiment, Col. COWDIN, and remain two days, returning home by the way of New-Haven. The Highwood Guards will, during their stay in New-Haven, be the guests of the Blues, and it is expected will leave for home on Saturday morning.

abstract: The reply of Prussia to the demand of France that Spain should be readmitted to her seat in the great council of Europe, as it comes to us in the columns of the Cologne Ga  zette, affords a curious commentary on the paeans which the Anti-Gallican Press ...
lead_paragraph: The reply of Prussia to the demand of France that Spain should be readmitted to her seat in the great council of Europe, as it comes to us in the columns of the Cologne Ga zette, affords a curious commentary on the paeans which the Anti-Gallican Press of Germany and England have just been singing over the interview of Toplitz and its precious fruits. The "united front" which Germany was henceforth to present to all foreign aggressors, divides at the first touch of a practical question, and the harmony in which it was so pompously proclaimed that FRANCIS JOSEPH and the Prince Regent were to fulfill their joint mission as the protectors of German independence and the combined balance-weights of Europe, resolves itself into a very meagre and dismal agreement of the two rulers to keep an eye on the suspicious man???uvres of that arch mischief maker, the Emperor of the French. Austria having signified her perfect readiness to welcome back Spain to the rank of a great Power, Prussia discovers an alarming number of very excellent reasons for hesitating to follow the example of her imperial sister. She does not, indeed, positively pronounce against the claims of a monarchy which awed the world while the ancestors of FREDERIC the Great were hustling for a livelihood among the petty Courts of Northern Germany, but she cannot hail the return of Spain to the concert of Europe as heartily and as frankly as the Court of Vienna. Of course Prussia and Austria are the best of friends, but then Prussia is a Protestant Power; and although she confides entirely in the good Germen feeling of the Kaiser, still she remembers that His Imperial Majesty prefers mass in St. Stephen's to the hymns of LUTHER; and reflecting that ISABELLA of Spain inherits, if not the faith, at least the fame of the most Catholic of Queens, Prussia cannot resign herself to the presence at the common Council-board of another Roman Catholic Power. Prussia accordingly suggests the propriety of admitting Sweden as a Protestant make-weight in the grand Continental balance -- of course, without any consideration of the circumstance that in the possible future revival, at no distant day, of the question of Schleswig-Holstein as a matter of European debate Sweden might be relied on with tolerable certainty to give her vote and her weight against Denmark and in favor of the annexation to Prussia of the German Duchies now attached to the Danish Crown, in return for the influence which Prussia and England might then be induced to exert in favor of the incorporation of Denmark itself with Sweden and Norway in a new Scandinavian Kingdom able to hold the Baltic gate aginst Russia.

abstract: The property holders of Fifty-second-street, between Ninth and Twelfth avenues, are in trouble. They called a meeting last evening for the purpose of considering their grievances in the matter of opening,...
lead_paragraph: The property holders of Fifty-second-street, between Ninth and Twelfth avenues, are in trouble. They called a meeting last evening for the purpose of considering their grievances in the matter of opening, grading, paving and sewering their street. Notwithstanding the inclemency of the weather, and the retired spot selected for the meeting -- corner of Fifty-second-street and Twelfth-avenue -- about forty lots were represented. In a conversational way, it was stated that Fifty-second-street has been graded about three years; that the assessments have been made and paid long since; that now, when the curb and gutter is about to be laid, it appears that the level of the street, between Eleventh and Twelfth avenues, is several feet above the grade; that instead of making sundry rock excavations and laying a gravel bed for the street, the contractors for grading left the rock so near the surface that more rock excavations are necessary in order to set the curb; that the contract for paving was given out one week before the contract for building the sewer between Tenth and Eleventh avenues; that the plan is evidently to pave the street, and then immediately tear it up for the purpose of building the sewer; that from Ninth to Eleventh avenues is already paved, (in the roadway.) and that the work is culpably bad -- not at all according to the specifications; that the stones are nut culled, and are, some of them, very soft; that there is no sand-bed for them; that they are not properly rammed down, but are loosely set in the sand; that crevices are left between them of unusual size; and that, in short, the entire work of paving is a gross violation of contract, and an attempted swindle on the property holders; that the Croton Board had been appealed to in vain to redress these grievances, and that more flagrant outrages on the rights of the property holders were contemplated. Various plans had been talked over for a remedy, and those present decided that whatever legal protection they could obtain, by injunctions, mandamuses, protests or other devices of the law, should be secured. They were evidently awakened to the necessity of immediate action, and bitterly denounced the course of the Street Department and the Croton Board in the matter.

abstract: Hon. George T. Hodges died at his residence in Rutland, Vt., on the 9th. He was born on July 4, 1789, in Clarendon, and removed to Rutland in 1808, where he has lived ever since. For more than a quarter of a century he was President of the Bank of Rutland.
lead_paragraph: Hon. George T. Hodges died at his residence in Rutland, Vt., on the 9th. He was born on July 4, 1789, in Clarendon, and removed to Rutland in 1808, where he has lived ever since. For more than a quarter of a century he was President of the Bank of Rutland. He was an efficient supporter of the State Agricultural Society, and contributed largely to the success of the Burlington Railroad. He was repeatedly sent to represent his town in the House, and his county in the Senate of his native State, and on the death of Mr. Meacham, the Congressional Representative of the Rutland District in 1846, was selected to fill his unexpired term in the national councils.

abstract: Families, on quitting the City for the Summer months, entertain the highest notions of Bridget's integrity, when they leave her in charge, with instructions not to open a front blind, and to make her ingress and egress, as carefully as she can, from the rear basement.
lead_paragraph: Families, on quitting the City for the Summer months, entertain the highest notions of Bridget's integrity, when they leave her in charge, with instructions not to open a front blind, and to make her ingress and egress, as carefully as she can, from the rear basement. We speak of fashionable families, the-go-out-of-town-in-the-Summer-families, who bring annual profit to the hotel-keepers of Mountain heights, Seaside watering-places, and Spas and Springs. Bridget, as a matter of course, intends to do her duty, but Bridget has relation. She has a father and a mother, and a sister and a brother, and an uncle and an aunt, and such a number of cousins. And Bridget is, moreover, amenable to the influence which, as the old song tells us, "makes the world go round." Nor is it "still love" with her. A walk around the block with the swain of her choice, which, as the house is "all locked up," and secured moreover, with bolt and chain, extends itself into several blocks, and is so congenial, and comfortable, and collateral, in warm weather that she forgets to be home early, and when she does return and retires to bed, she courts "tired Nature's sweet restorer, balmy sleep" as ardently as her Patrick courted her. Then is the burglar's time. Then skeleton-keys are of service, and broken panes of glass are not heard. The dreams of Bridget carry her back to childhood, or onward to that blissful moment when the good priest makes one of twain. Meanwhile, stealthily, securely, steals the stealer. Up stairs, in this chamber, and in that, disturbed only by Bridget's snores, he selects the stock he wants, parcels it out, and ties it up in bundles. Father of family, mother of family, the family entire, are sleeping in peace at Newport or elsewhere. When they return, which will be when it is no longer fashionable to stay away, they will find Bridget disconsolate, her relations and even her lover vanished, and the plate and other valuables gone.

abstract: That pestilent and persevering fillibuster, Gen. WILLIAM WALKER, has again disturbed the repose of a peaceful community. If telegraphic dispatches from New-Orleans are to be relied upon, the "General" has landed at Truxillo, in Honduras, and captured the town.
lead_paragraph: That pestilent and persevering fillibuster, Gen. WILLIAM WALKER, has again disturbed the repose of a peaceful community. If telegraphic dispatches from New-Orleans are to be relied upon, the "General" has landed at Truxillo, in Honduras, and captured the town. The inhabitants must have been intensely surprised at his appearance, for, according to the report, they yielded up their fortress after firing one solitary gun. Further particulars of this piratical raid will be awaited with interest.

abstract: At an early hour on Monday morning a servant girl of Dr. Moffat observed two men leave the residence of Judge Pierrepont, No.103 Fifth-avenue, with a large well-filled willow basket. She gave information at the Eighteenth Ward Station-house, and Officers Syphers, Shaw and Kinnard were dispatched to examine the premises.
lead_paragraph: At an early hour on Monday morning a servant girl of Dr. Moffat observed two men leave the residence of Judge Pierrepont, No.103 Fifth-avenue, with a large well-filled willow basket. She gave information at the Eighteenth Ward Station-house, and Officers Syphers, Shaw and Kinnard were dispatched to examine the premises. They soon discovered that not only Judge Pierrepont's residence had been broken into, but also that of Mr. H.A. Johnson, next door, both of which had been ransacked from top to bottom and robbed of a large amount of property; but how much could not be ascertained, as both families were out of town. The burglars had gained access by forcing the back basement-door of Judge Pierrepont's house, and then ascending to the roof, had forced open the scuttle of the house of Mr. Johnson. Supposing that the burglars would return for more plunder, Detective Elder obtained permission of Dr. Moffat to allow the officers to watch from his parlor windows for them, and at 5 o'clock yesterday morning two men were seen to enter the dwelling of Judge Pierrepont. The officers immediately rushed upon them, and the burglars made for the street, but were closely pursued, and after three shots from a revolver had been fired at them, they were brought to a stand and arrested. The prisoners names are John Smith, alias Cahill, and George Waters, alias Baker, and in their possession were found two lock-picks, a jimmy, and $60 in bank-bills. Both are known to the Police, and Waters is but recently out of State Prison, and they were both locked up by Justice CONNOLLY for trial. During the day Detectives Slowey and McCord visited Cahill's residence, were they found a very large amount of stolen property, burglarious implements, crucibles for melting up silver ware, &c. After having secured Cahill's wife, the officers removed the stolen goods, amounting to about $5,000 worth, to head-quarters. Mrs. Cahill then informed Officer Slowey that she had pawned numerous articles which her husband had given her, and which she supposed to have been stolen. She had not received any pawn tickets for the goods she had disposed of, and she was accordingly taken to Essex Market, where, on her affidavit, search warrants were obtained for the pawn shops mentioned by her. These warrants will be executed this morning early, when, if her story be true, another valuable lot of goods will be recovered. The arrest of these notorious burglars is of great importance, and will doubtless lead to the recovery of many articles stolen from other places, if not to the conviction of some of the receivers.

lead_paragraph: The Texas papers continue to furnish items regarding the alleged conspiracy in that State. The Huntsville Item of the 8th says an old gentleman, who has lived in that county for some time, dealing. in lands and land claims, and who has also stood fair with the community, has been arrested and taken to Montgomery, on a charge of being connected with the insurrection plot there. The citizens of Huntsville, at a large meeting on the 2d inst., adopted strict measures for guarding the town and watching the slaves, prohibiting preaching to them, and otherwise exercising a due vigilance.

abstract: The last European mail furnishes us with accounts of the crops in those countries where the harvest is terminated. It is only in the North of Italy that the wheat crop is considered satisfactory; in Lombardy it is middling, and in the provinces of Modena, Parma and Bologna it is indifferent. In Venetia results differ in various localities; in Naples the crop is less than was at first expected.
lead_paragraph: -- The last European mail furnishes us with accounts of the crops in those countries where the harvest is terminated. It is only in the North of Italy that the wheat crop is considered satisfactory; in Lombardy it is middling, and in the provinces of Modena, Parma and Bologna it is indifferent. In Venetia results differ in various localities; in Naples the crop is less than was at first expected. The harvest in the Two Castiles and La Mancha, in Spain, has been satisfactory; but in Andalusia the quantity has not equaled expectation. Accounts from Odessa say that the wheat crop there will be excellent. In Ireland the harvest will be late, but it is expected to be fully equal to an average crop.

abstract: Valentine Deifenthaler vs. Wm.G. Chase et al. -- This is an action on foreclosure, in which there was a surplus, and a referee appointed to ascertain priority of claims to the surplus. The reference is now going on. It seems that there has been a certain judgment put in evidence before the Referee, which judgment is alleged to have been paid by a co-defendant on joint liability, but it is not canceled of record, and the alleged payment is disputed. The question now is as to making the judgment a lien on the surplus, and this motion is for a stay of proceedings until the determination of a suit by the party alleged to have been paid the judgment against the co-defendant, who is alleged to have paid it. The hearing was postponed until Friday.

abstract: BROECK is not disposed to give it up so. He has just purchased from Mr. B. ATCHISON ALEXANDER, of Lexington, Ky., two yearlings, -- one a bay filly, Annette, by imp. Scythian out of Lexington's dam: the others a bay colt by Lexington, out of Ducatoon by Wagner and out of Picayune. The price paid for these yearlings was $1,500 each. The filly Annette is to be returned to this country after her racing career is over. W.A. DUDLEY, Esq., has also sold to Mr. TEN BROECK his yearling colt Knight of the Garter, the full brother of Rurick, for $2,000. Mr. TEN BROECK's man came to this country to see these animals safely to their destination.

abstract: A shocking affair occurred on Sunday afternoon in Rondont, Ulster County, which has created considerable excitement. A man, named JOHN CRUMMING, residing in Meadow-street, in that village entered his dwelling, and wihout saying a word to his wife, who sat with her back towards him, approached her and ...
lead_paragraph: A shocking affair occurred on Sunday afternoon in Rondont, Ulster County, which has created considerable excitement. A man, named JOHN CRUMMING, residing in Meadow-street, in that village entered his dwelling, and wihout saying a word to his wife, who sat with her back towards him, approached her and drew a razor across her throat, inflicting a terrible wound. She sprang up, and rushing out of the door, run to the house of her parents, a short distance from her own. She was followed by her husband, who carried the razor in his hand, and on the way he cut his own throat. Arriving at his father-in-law's he showed the wound to his wife. A physician was immediately sent for, who dressed the wounds of both. They were alive at the last accounts, but it is very doubtful whether either will recover. CRUMMING and his wife are both young people, and have been married only about a year. His wife, it is said, betrayed some of his faults to strangers, and believing it was a wife's duty to shield her husband rather than to expose him, he adopted this method of revenge.

abstract: A piece of the margin of a newspaper, on which was written in lead pencil the following -- "The steamer Pacific; the walkingbeam fell and stove a hole in her bottom -- we are sinking -- S.B. DAVIES" -- was found in a bottle which was picked up last Wednesday, on Cape Henlopen. The strip of paper was a piece torn from a newspaper, and the pencil writing quite fresh, and recently written. The steamer Pacific, it will be remembered, was lost, on her way from Liverpool, four years ago. The frequent attempts to play off such silly hoaxes as this show how little brains will suffice to keep some individuals above the condition, of an ape. -- Philadelphia, Ledger, Aug. 21.

abstract: ARREST OF COUNTERFEITERS. On Monday night a young man named JAMES WELSH and a Mrs. MARTHA WHITNER, keeper of a boarding-house at No. 206 Chatham-street, New-York, were arrested at the Jersey City ferry depot, by Officer VALADE and Alderman DECKER, charged with passing counterfeit $1 ...
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF COUNTERFEITERS. -- On Monday night a young man named JAMES WELSH and a Mrs. MARTHA WHITNER, keeper of a boarding-house at No. 206 Chatham-street, New-York, were arrested at the Jersey City ferry depot, by Officer VALADE and Alderman DECKER, charged with passing counterfeit $1 bills of the Metacomet Bank of Fall River, Mass. They were locked up for the night, and yesterday morning, upon being brought before Recorder TILDEN, several trades-people appeared and made affidavits against the prisoners, in which they charged them with having passed the above-named money upon them. At the time of the arrest WELSH attempted to pass a small roll of counterfeits to Mrs. WHITNER and was detected in the act. The Recorder committed the accused parties to jail in default of bail.

abstract: It is an unpleasant thing to say, but it is nevertheless true that the Prince of Wales is destined to be lynched in New-York. Of course his Royal Highness will not object to the process; in the first place, because he is as polite a person as the first gentleman of England ought to be; and, in the second ...
lead_paragraph: It is an unpleasant thing to say, but it is nevertheless true that the Prince of Wales is destined to be lynched in New-York. Of course his Royal Highness will not object to the process; in the first place, because he is as polite a person as the first gentleman of England ought to be; and, in the second place, because lynching is an American institution, and he comes to the United States expressly to see our institutions. But surely no New-Yorker can reflect without a sentiment of shame and humiliation upon the doom which impends over our illustrious young visitor; a doom which yet no respectable citizen can have the heart to wish averted from its destined victim. For in the case of the Prince as in most other cases of lynching, all the best portion of the community will be united in perpetrating the deed. Lynch law, as we all very well know is simply a return of society to first principles. It is put into force only when the constituted authorities have proved themselves unequal to their duty, or unfit to be trusted with official responsibility. When justices of the peace turn brigands, and judges hob-nob with highwaymen, decent people seeing their lives and their purses in daily peril, are compelled to erect themselves into a Supreme Court, and to carry their own judgments into execution. It is in this way that horse-thieves and gamblers come to be lynched out of the world on the wild frontiers of the West. In like manner will the Prince of Wales come to be lynched in the civilized metropolis of the Union. The City of New-York, in its corporate capacity, has extended an invitation to the Prince of Wales, which invitation the Prince has accepted. Had such a correspondence passed between the heir of England and the Corporation of New-York twenty years ago, the consequences would have been as simple as possible. The Prince would have come to New-York, where all proper arrangements to receive and entertain him comfortably and honorably would have been made by the Mayor and the City Government. They would have represented their fellow-citizens in all ways of hospitality, convenient to the occasion His Royal Highness would have eaten a civic dinner, danced at a civic ball, seen the great City in the light of civic wisdom and civic courtesy, just as he would go into Guildhall on the invitation of the City of London, or into the Parisian Hotel de Ville at the prayer of the Prefect of the Seine.
headline: {'main': 'Lynching the Prince of Wales.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Lynching the Prince of Wales.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The great Mexican question, which the people of the United States have so often and so obstinately refused to answer, promises now to answer itself. Entangled by the heat of Southern extremists, and the hypocrisy of Northern politicians, with the all-confusing ...
lead_paragraph: The great Mexican question, which the people of the United States have so often and so obstinately refused to answer, promises now to answer itself. Entangled by the heat of Southern extremists, and the hypocrisy of Northern politicians, with the all-confusing snarl of Slavery, this question has been once and again deliberately strangled out of sight and hearing in the National Legislature. It has been talked about, written about, fought over, used as a hobby-horse, used as a scarecrow used as a battering-ram, now by one and now by another of our own parties; but by neither of our parties has it ever been taken up honestly, with a view to practical action of the kind and on the scale demanded by its real political, social, and historical importance. So far as any policy can be said to have been indorsed by the public sentiment of the United States in regard to Mexico, the negative policy of affirming that nobody but ourselves should ever settle the anarchy of Mexican affairs may be conceded to have been. And if the anarchy of Mexican affairs would only have been polite enough to wait on our movements, and to keep itself simmering along as comfortably as might be, till we were quite ready to attend to it. things would no doubt have been made very pleasant in the end to everybody. The case indeed singularly resembles that of the great European invalid, the Ottoman Empire. The hostile political and sectional camps of American opinion represent fairly enough the European Powers which have stood around the death-bed of the Sultans ever since the treaty of Adrianople, each one bent on disposing of the patient after getting everybody else cleverly out of the way. As in the case of Turkey, too, the disease of the sufferer has shown a most discreditable impatience of diplomacy. The Druses of the Lebanon and the fanatics of Damascus, are not symptoms to be watched with tranquillity, and Europe finds itself drifting, with a rapidity alarming to nervous statesmen, onward to the absolute necessity of settling issues which nervous statesmen had hoped still to be able to use to their own advantage for a number of years to come.

abstract: Geo. Strang and Wm. H. De Groot were arrested yesterday, charged with stealing a box of female wearing apparel valued at $532, the property of Mrs. Benjamin Hamilton, who had stored it at No. 160.
lead_paragraph: Geo. Strang and Wm. H. De Groot were arrested yesterday, charged with stealing a box of female wearing apparel valued at $532, the property of Mrs. Benjamin Hamilton, who had stored it at No. 160. West Houston-street, whence it was removed, as alleged, by the prisoners. A man named Frederick F. Durkee, was also arrested on a charge of having feloniously received a portion of the property. About $200 worth of it has been recovered, and the Police expect to obtain the rest. The prisoners were committed by Justice CONNOLLY for examination.

abstract: FELLOW CITIZENS: The election of the next President and Vice-President of the United States is at hand. Four distinct organizations are in the field  the Republican Party, making bold and open war upon the institutions of fifteen sovereign States of this Union; the Constitutional Union Party, repudiating all platforms, and standing simply on the catch-words, ...
lead_paragraph: FELLOW CITIZENS: The election of the next President and Vice-President of the United States is at hand. Four distinct organizations are in the field -- the Republican Party, making bold and open war upon the institutions of fifteen sovereign States of this Union; the Constitutional Union Party, repudiating all platforms, and standing simply on the catch-words, "Constitution and the Union" -- two parties, each calling itself Democratic; one, however, following the fortunes of one man, Mr. DOUGLAS, and differing from the Republicans, in making insidious, instead of open war upon the South -- the other standing inflexibly on the Constitution of the country, makes no concealments as to its interpretation of that instrument, its rallying cry being the equality of the States. We purpose, calmly and impartially, to survey the field, and to give the reasons why the latter party should be considered as the Democratic Party, and how the dearest interests of country, race, and of human progress, are concerned in its success.

abstract: Our correspondent at Vera Cruz, writing on the 8th inst., transmits important intelligence. The Spanish Naval Commander has peremptorily demanded from the Juarez Government the rendition of a bark which belonged to MARIN'S fillibustering expedition, and which was captured and taken to Vera Cruz.
lead_paragraph: Our correspondent at Vera Cruz, writing on the 8th inst., transmits important intelligence. The Spanish Naval Commander has peremptorily demanded from the Juarez Government the rendition of a bark which belonged to MARIN'S fillibustering expedition, and which was captured and taken to Vera Cruz. Twenty-four hours were granted to consider the Spanish demands, and in the event of refusal a bombardment was threatened. Though the Government of JUAREZ refused to deliver up the bark or to salute the Spanish flag, a bombardment was not attempted. The most effectual measures were taken to resist the threatened violence. It is intimated by our correspondent that this is the basis of an attempt at future interference on the part of Spain between the Government of JUAREZ and the Miramon faction. The general news by this Mexican arrival is of an unimportant character.

abstract: The Committee appointed at the meeting held at the Merchants' Bank last week to proceed to Canada and invite the Prince of Wales to accept of a public dinner on behalf of the citizens of New-York during his stay in this City, left for Quebec on Tuesday evening. The Committee consists of John Jacob Astor, Jno. A. King, Wm.F. Havemeyer, Wilson G. Hunt, Hamilton Fish, Robert B. Minturn and Robert L. Kennedy. In case the invitation is accepted, the dinner will be given at the Academy of Music. The demonstration on the part of the British residents of New-York is to be in the shape of a ball, which will also be given at the Academy of Music. It will, therefore, be impracticable to unite the two ovations, or to give them both on the same day.

abstract: We have already published several letters from gentlemen in South Carolina, urging secession in the event of LINCOLN'S election. But these eminent persons do not fully concur in the means of arriving at this result. Col. KEITT is for disunion Pure and simple, and does not bother his chivalric head aboat details, whether one State secedes, or ten, whether anybody dissolves beside himself, is to him a matter of supreme indifference. Col. ORR, a
lead_paragraph: We have already published several letters from gentlemen in South Carolina, urging secession in the event of LINCOLN's election. But these eminent persons do not fully concur in the means of arriving at this result. Col. KEITT is for disunion Pure and simple, -- and does not bother his chivalric head aboat details, whether one State secedes, or ten, -- whether anybody dissolves beside himself, is to him a matter of supreme indifference. Col. ORR, a cooler politician, who has the sagacity to perceive that talk alone will not accomplish the results at which they aim, is in favor of secession, but only in case several other States will unite with South Carolina in such a movement. And Mr. BOYCE would have South Carolina leave the Union, even if she leaves it "solitary and alone."
headline: {'main': 'The Secession Outcry.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Secession Outcry.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The first prize-fight which has created any great interest among the "sporting men" of this City, since the "great international" affair between HEENAN and SAYERS, was fought on Tuesday last, near Island Pond, in the town of Brighton, Essex County, Vermont, between JAMES KELLY and DANIEL KERRIGAN, to $1,000 a side. Both the men are well known here to their class. KERRIGAN, who is an Irishman, 25 years of age, has heretofore been the victor in many fights, not considered of great importance by the fraternity and therefore not elaborately reported in the sporting papers. KELLY is also an Irishman, 28 years of age, and is reported to have made the "longest prize-fight on record" while in Australia, since which time he has been known as "Australian KELLY" among his associates. KERRIGAN is 5 feet 8 inches in height, and, when in fighting condition, weighs 141 pounds; while KELLY is 5 feet 10 inches in height, and on Tuesday weighed 154 pounds. The preliminary arrangements for the fight were made some six weeks ago, and from that time until the meeting near Island Pond, both men had been in active training. The party of men who left here to witness the encounter, and those who joined them on the route, all succeeded in reaching the Island Pond Railway station, without any unpleasant interference from the authorities, and at 4 o'clock on the morning of Tuesday, they proceeded to the ground, and soon after their arrival there the men were ready for the fray. The friends of KERRIGAN were far more numerous on the ground, and were offering large odds on their man, as high as 100 to 75, and in some instances 100 to 80 being freely offered on KERRIGAN, but even this tempting offer found no takers. KELLY's friends had all been estranged or discouraged by the result of his battle with ED. PRICE, and the few that were on the spot did not seem disposed to make investments. The owner of the farm lent his aid in the selection of a level spot, and soon a decision was made. The accommodating farmer learned his scythe and rake, to get the spot in condition, and speedily all was ready to set up the ring. JACK MONTGOMERY produced a set of stakes, that had been elaborately finished in a lathe. Under his distinguished supervision the ring was soon pitched, and an outer ring formed; and to his personal care, the reporters are indebted for the best places from which to see the combat. Prof. MONTGOMERY was assisted in pitching the ring by the High Sheriff of the County, who swung a sturdy sledge during the stake-driving ceremonies, and also three select men of the town, and divers Grand Jurors of the county, looked on with approving smiles. The mistress of the farm-house near by loaned all her chairs to the distinguished strangers, and, in fact, so kind were both the farmer and his wife, that MONTGOMERY stepped into the ring, and, in a short speech, proposed a subscription for their benefit. The hat went around, and the result was fifteen good and lawful dollars, which were at once handed over to the woman, to her great joy.

abstract: The Royal mail steamship Arabia, from Liverpool via Halifax arrived at her dock in Boston at 2 P.M. yesterday. Her mails were forwarded by the steamboat train via Stonington, due in New-York this morning. The newspaper bag of the Associated Press, however, was got off by the land train, via New-Haven, and arrived in this City at midnight. We subjoin a few details of interest, in addition to the dispatch received from Cape Race.
lead_paragraph: The Royal mail steamship Arabia, from Liverpool via Halifax arrived at her dock in Boston at 2 1/4 P.M. yesterday. Her mails were forwarded by the steamboat train via Stonington, due in New-York this morning. The newspaper bag of the Associated Press, however, was got off by the land train, via New-Haven, and arrived in this City at midnight. We subjoin a few details of interest, in addition to the dispatch received from Cape Race.

abstract: The first nines of these two Clubs met on Wednesday last on the grounds of the former Club at South Brooklyn, and played one of the most protracted games of the season, two hours being consumed by the first three innings, and the remaining three taking over an hour.
lead_paragraph: The first nines of these two Clubs met on Wednesday last on the grounds of the former Club at South Brooklyn, and played one of the most protracted games of the season, two hours being consumed by the first three innings, and the remaining three taking over an hour. The fielding was poor on both sides, and, with the exception of the excellent batting of the Harlemites, the whole game was very unsatisfactory to the spectators, though its closeness up to the sixth innings created a little interest. On the Harlem side Wood caught well, but was unable to throw to the bases; he also batted well. Mackellar pitched powerfully and efficiently, while Liscomb Dunn and Marsh on the bases were very active. Hughes made three catches -- one very good indeed --but otherwise his fielding was poor. Dunn Marsh and Hyatt batted in splendid style. For the Charter Oaks the there bases were finely manned; S. Patchen Caught finely; the three fielders were also very fair, white the pitching of Fuller and Shields was very creditable. Shields, J. Patchen, Randolph and Rennison were most prominent at the bat.

abstract: This match, which was begun yesterday on the St. George's cricket-ground, Hoboken, bids fair to re  sult in another victory for St. George. The first innings of East New-York for nine men, with two absent, amounted to 84 runs, the bowling of Gibbes, Waller and Bailey being very good, but not as effective as usual on account of the deadness of the ground owing to the heavy rain.
lead_paragraph: This match, which was begun yesterday on the St. George's cricket-ground, Hoboken, bids fair to re sult in another victory for St. George. The first innings of East New-York for nine men, with two absent, amounted to 84 runs, the bowling of Gibbes, Waller and Bailey being very good, but not as effective as usual on account of the deadness of the ground owing to the heavy rain. Bedford's score of five were well got; as was Beach's -- who was caught in splendid style by Walker -- for four 2's and singles in his 16, principally for leg hits and drives. Watson's 29 were well got by a 4, two 3's, four 2's and singles; Watson run out Cuyp badly, when he was well in to the bat, and had made a fine leg hit, and two drives for two each, and singles for his 9. Light and Stokes played well for 5 each, and North and Van Sickles were absent. Burnett long-stopped well against the few balls that passed Lang, the wicket-keeper, who, as usual, filled that position finely. St. George sent Lang and Waller in to the bowling of Cuyp and Swerdna, both of whom bowled excellently; Wardle was wicket-keeper, and good in his position; Watson long-stopping, and acting as Captain, in which position he took off Swerdna from bowling, when he was bowling dead on the wicket, and put on Light, who gave some wides -- a want of good judgment, which told against his side; Bedford and Beach were also put on in place of Cuyp, who was being hit away.

abstract: Coroner SCHIRMER held an inquest on Wednesday, at Bellevue Hospital, upon the body of JOSEPH RAWSON, a boy 9 years of age, who lost his life by being caught in the machinery at the workshop of A.B. CHAPMAN, foot of Twenty-fourth-street, E.R. It appears that the deceased placed his hand upon the shaft while it was in rapid motion, and was caught by the belt and dashed violently to the floor. The accident occurred on Tuesday and death ensued yesterday morning. The jury rendered a verdict of "accidental death."

lead_paragraph: POLICE COMMISSIONERS. -- This Board met at Police Head-quarters yesterday afternoon, all the members being present. It having been reported that Capt. SQUIRES and Sergeant LAFFLIN took a too active part in the recent Republican primary election in their Ward, the General Superintendent was instructed to inquire into the matter and report to the Board. Officer MCCARTY, of the Twenty-first Ward was dismissed from the force for sleeping on his post. Capt. SEAMAN, of the Fourth Ward, who was suspended from duty two or three months since for alleged insubordination and disobedience of order, was brought to trial before Commissioners BOWEN and ACTON. Sergeants WILLIAMS and BROOKS, of the Fourth Ward, testified that the Captain had been absent from the Station-house for a whole day at a time on sundry occasions. Once his family came to the Station-house in search of him. Superintendent KENNEDY testified that the Caption had no permission to absent himself from duty on those occasions. Capt. SEAMAN swore that he was sick on the day his family inquired for him, and that supposing his wife had gone to Troy, he had spent the night at a friend's house. He declined to give the name of his friend. Dr. JOHNSON testified to having visited Capt. SEAMAN on that day, and found him lying in bed, quite sick. The case was brought to a close, but to decision was rendered. Capt. SEAMAN, during his suspension of many weeks, has frequently demanded a trial, but did not succeed in getting it until to-day.

abstract: SUICIDE. -- A man named THOMAS MENRY, 'longshoreman, residing at the corner of Elizabeth and Doughty streets, committed suicide last night by cutting his throat from ear to ear with a razor. The deceased had been intoxicated for several days past and last evening he called his wife and child to him and made an attempt upon their lives. His wife having her suspicions aroused, was able to avoid the blow aimed at her and escaped from him with their child. He immediately went to a glass in his room and cut his throat in such a manner as to cause death in a very few minutes.

abstract: The recently detailed flag ship of the Mediteranean Squadron has been unexpectedly vacated by Commodore BELL, whose baggage was removed from her yesterday previously to her dropping down to the Battery. The Susquehanna's destination is now understood to be Vera Cruz, and not Syria, as supposed. She was to have sailed this morning for the Eastern Hemisphere, but in consequence of the change in the programme will leave to-morrow for the Gulf of Mexico. We hear that the unsettled state of affairs in Central America has caused this action of the Navy Department. We reprint the list of the Susquehanna's officers.

lead_paragraph: The plaintiff in this case, brought in the Supreme Court, was a Miss Tayleur, a danseuse at Niblo's. She was married in 1852 to the defendant, her husband, who is the principal dancer of the Martinetti family with the Ravel troupe. The lady commenced a proceeding for divorce against her husband, on the ground of adultery on the 8th of August last. The Ravels left this city for Boston on Monday. Prior to their departure, the plaintiff obtained a writ of ne exeat from Judge SUTHERLAND to detain her husband, on the ground that he was about to leave the State and not to return. This writ keeps the defendant in the custody of the Sheriff till a bond is given, in the sum of $2,000, as security for his appearance. Yesterterday morning a motion was made to discharge the prisoner from the effects of the writ. The papers of the defendant claimed that he did not earn more than was necessary for his own support and that of a son in France.

abstract: The world has already been informed that negotiations area on foot between a "distinguished citizen " of New York and his Grace the Duke of Newcastle, with the object of securing the presence of his Royal Highness the Prince of Wales at a brilliant fete to be given in September, among the umbrageous groves which surround a "palatial villa" on the banks of the Hudson at Washington Heights.
lead_paragraph: The world has already been informed that negotiations area on foot between a "distinguished citizen " of New York and his Grace the Duke of Newcastle, with the object of securing the presence of his Royal Highness the Prince of Wales at a brilliant fete to be given in September, among the umbrageous groves which surround a "palatial villa" on the banks of the Hudson at Washington Heights. Of course the progress of these negotiations has been watched with the deepest anxiety by everybody who can advance any claims to recognition as a member of polite society in the metropolis, from the millionaires who adorn the "avenue" with their "distingue mansions" of brown stone, down to those less opulent members of the aristocracy who merely ornament it with their mustaches. In England events of this kind commonly cast their shadows before them in the public Press, under the form of an intimation that the "Duke and Duchess of Omnium will shortly entertain a distinguished circle at Gatherem Castle." How the Amphitryons of the British peerage contrive to "entertain" the said distinguished circles, is a matter not here to be discussed. Whether the Duke out-witches ROBERT HOUDIN and Professor ANDERSON with noble legerdemain, or the Duchess delights her friends with private performances in the style of VESTRIS, or of Mrs. BARNEY WILLIAMS, is not at all to our present purpose. Suffice it that nothing could possibly "entertain" any distinguished circle in this benighted land more thoroughly and agreeably than the notion of a fete champetre, given to the Prince of Wales at Washington Heights. It is with the deepest regret, therefore, that we gather from the New-York Herald of yesterday intimations of a coming disappointment in this most important affair.
