abstract: Wm. Cummings, an Irishman, who keeps a drinking-saloon at No. 259 West Twenty-sixth-street, was admitted last night to the New-York Hospital, suffering severely from a pistol-shot wound in the ankle. It would appear that Cummings had some words with a man named John Burns, who lives in the second story of the same house, in regard to the sum of $15, which the latter owed him. After quarreling for some time, Burns left the saloon, when Cummings took a horse-pistol and followed him to the sidewalk. Hastening up to Burns he struck him a violent blow on the head with some heavy instrument, inflicting a severe scalp wound. Burns immediately turned upon his assailant and clinched with him. During the scuffle which ensued, Burns became possessed of the pistol and discharged it at his antagonist. The charge, consisting of five or six slugs, took effect in the lower portion of Cummings' right leg, penetrating the ankle joint. One or more of the slugs were forced down into the foot. Officer O'Reilley, of the Sixteenth Precinct, hearing the disturbance, hastened to the spot, and succeeded in separating the men. Burns was taken to the Station-house, where his wound was dressed by the Police Surgeon, while Cummings was conveyed to the Hospital. His injuries are considered extremely serious, as there are four distinct wounds, which will probably render the amputation of the foot necessary. The slugs were extracted by Drs. Wier and Tuttle. Cummings and Burns both have families, who reside in the house where the affray occurred, and both had been drinking considerably. Burns was locked up for examination.
lead_paragraph: Wm. Cummings, an Irishman, who keeps a drinking-saloon at No. 259 West Twenty-sixth-street, was admitted last night to the New-York Hospital, suffering severely from a pistol-shot wound in the ankle. It would appear that Cummings had some words with a man named John Burns, who lives in the second story of the same house, in regard to the sum of $15, which the latter owed him. After quarreling for some time, Burns left the saloon, when Cummings took a horse-pistol and followed him to the sidewalk. Hastening up to Burns he struck him a violent blow on the head with some heavy instrument, inflicting a severe scalp wound. Burns immediately turned upon his assailant and clinched with him. During the scuffle which ensued, Burns became possessed of the pistol and discharged it at his antagonist. The charge, consisting of five or six slugs, took effect in the lower portion of Cummings' right leg, penetrating the ankle joint. One or more of the slugs were forced down into the foot. Officer O'Reilley, of the Sixteenth Precinct, hearing the disturbance, hastened to the spot, and succeeded in separating the men. Burns was taken to the Station-house, where his wound was dressed by the Police Surgeon, while Cummings was conveyed to the Hospital. His injuries are considered extremely serious, as there are four distinct wounds, which will probably render the amputation of the foot necessary. The slugs were extracted by Drs. Wier and Tuttle. Cummings and Burns both have families, who reside in the house where the affray occurred, and both had been drinking considerably. Burns was locked up for examination.

abstract: By a fixed law of Saratoga every one, on first arrising in the morning, is compelled to repair to the rural temples in the grove, and bow down at the shrine of two twin constellations--the Little Dipper and the Great Dipper. This duty your correspondent has this morning faithfully performed. I am proud to say that so villainous a mixture as this mineral water, has never before passed the threshold of my throat.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA, Saturday, Aug. 18, 1860.

abstract: A CLERGYMEN UNDER ARRESTY. -- A few days since, Rev. Mr. GUBBY, pastor of the Third Presbyterian Church of Jersey City, together with one of the members of the church, caused the arrest of Rev. SAMUEL STERLING, and two other gentlemen, on charges of disorderly conduct. Rev. Mr. STERLING was charged with putting his fist under his (Rev. Mr. GUBBY's) nose, and threatening to make him suffer; also by his acts and conversation, endeavoring to create a disturbance at a meeting of the session. Yesterday, Rev. Mr. STERLING caused the arrest of Rev. Mr. GUBBY, on a charge of perjury, and the latter-named gentleman was held in $500 bonds to answer.

abstract: The Republicans completed their work yesterday at Syracuse. The Governor and Lieutenant
lead_paragraph: The Republicans completed their work yesterday at Syracuse. They did it in a manner which will probably disappoint the hopes of their opponents, arid the intention of some of their over-ambitious friends. The rumors of hostility to Gov. MORGAN prove to have been unfounded, or else that hostility was merged in devotion to the interests of the party, and a determination to carry the State for the Republican ticket. The Governor and Lieutenant Governor were renominated by acclamation, and the State ticket was completed without any exhibition of feeling or even any protracted contest.

abstract: The Republican State Convention assembled at Syracuse yesterday, and organized temporarily by the election of JAMES C. SMITH, of Ontario, to preside. The list of delegates was then called, and the matter of credentials was settled satisfactorily, when the President appointed a Committee to select permanent officers, and the Convention took a recess. On reassembling, the Committee reported in favor of JAMES M. COOK, for permanent President, with the usual number of Vice-Presidents and Secretaries. A Committee on Resolutions was then appointed, after which the Convention proceeded to the nomination of candidates for State officers, with the following result:

abstract: --The piety of the Western Roman Catholics seems to be like Mr. Pogram's patriotism, as expansive as the pararies. A certain good Sister of Charity received a kind of ovation recently at Emmetsburgh, which is duly chronicled by the Cincinnati Catholic Telegraph. Among other incidents of the occasion, we are informed that the lady in question received "a letter from St. Vincent of Paul, just arrived from Heaven, by mail."
lead_paragraph: -- The piety of the Western Roman Catholics seems to be like Mr. Pogram's patriotism, as expansive as the pararies. A certain good Sister of Charity received a kind of ovation recently at Emmetsburgh, which is duly chronicled by the Cincinnati Catholic Telegraph. Among other incidents of the occasion, we are informed that the lady in question received "a letter from St. Vincent of Paul, just arrived from Heaven, by mail." Of course we cannot suspect a religious journal of blasphemous joking, and we are sorry to suggest mere mundane thoughts in the presence of so remarkable an instance of celestial favor. But we feel bound to call the attention of the Postmaster-General to the circumstance that no authorized mail-route between Emmettsburgh and the locality designated exists. Perhaps Archbishop HUGHES, when despises human laws in general, excepting as convenient instruments for Archiepiscopal martyrdom, has made a private contract of his own with some enterprising angel, on a reservation of a certain per centage of postages for the benefit of the Papal army.

abstract: Last evening this body had a meeting and drill at No. 275 Bleecker-street. About fifty persons executed a series of simple military evolutions before Capt. H.C. ROBE. A large number of members, who were thorough military men, occupied the side seats. Among the parties subjected to the drill were a Supervisor, a candidate for Member of Congress, a candidate, for Alderman, and an indefinite number of embryo Councilmen. The officers of this Company are men well known among our City Military:

abstract: The return game between these two Clubs was played last Saturday, each being represented by eight "disc-iples." It is ordinarily a difficult thing to "kick against the pricks" of a "thistle," but the sons of "St. Andrew," from their thorough knowledge of that well-known "touch me not;" on this, as on a former occasions, managed to do it successfully. They scored 100 to their opponents' 66.

abstract: The rain this morning caused great damage to the Chestnut Hill Railroad. A culvert over Cresham Creek was carried away with the embankment, fiftyeight feet high. A large stone bridge on the same creek was carried away. There was much other damage to farms in the vicinity, and many houses were flooded. No lives were lost as far as ascertained. Very little rain fell in the city.

abstract: The debt of the A.B.C.F.M., in behalf of which special efforts have been made, is provided for within about $2,000. This sum is a portion of the amount which was assumed by the friends of the Board in this City. The undersigned, as a Committee, having the matter in charge, have been unable to see personally many who, as they suppose, wish to aid this good work, and they respectfully ask that, without personal solicitation, contributions or pledges be sent to either of them without delay, as the time has arrived for closing the account.

This sum is a portion of the amount which was assumed by the friends of the Board in this City. abstract: About 9 o'clock last evening a most singular explosion occurred in the tenement house No. 155 East Twenty-ninth-street, by which six persons of one family were burned severely. This building is one of a row of houses now being built near the corner of Second-avenue, by JAMES G. BURCHELL.
lead_paragraph: About 9 o'clock last evening a most singular explosion occurred in the tenement house No. 155 East Twenty-ninth-street, by which six persons of one family were burned severely. This building is one of a row of houses now being built near the corner of Second-avenue, by JAMES G. BURCHELL. A day or two since DAVID TUCHS, a German, moved into the second story of No. 155, for the purpose of guarding the houses. Yesterday, Messrs. MAHONEY and MILLIGAN had engaged about the house, putting in gas pipes. They had run half inch pipes up through the basement floor into a dark closet, where the meter was to be placed. In the ceiling of the closet a small hole had been cut for the purpose of carrying the pipe to the second floor, but the pipe had not been inserted. On leaving their work, the laborers had forgotten to seal up the pipe, and the consequence was that the closet became filled with gas. The only means of escape for it was up through the little hole in the ceiling, and here it diffused itself between the ceiling and the floor overhead. About 9 o'clock Mr. FANCH had occasion to pass through a close bedroom on the second floor, from one room to another with a lighted lamp. Immediately on entering the bedroom an explosion took place, the concussion throwing Mr. FUCHS to a considerable distance. It was subsequently learned that the gas between the floor and ceiling having been ignited, it exploded with such force as to throw down the partition wall, tear up the flooring, shaking the lathe and plastering all down, and leaving the whole interior of the building a perfect wreck. Mr. FUCHS was seriously burned about the hands and face, and his wife SOPHIA, his three sons, WILLIAM, FREDERICK and JACOB, aged respectively 14, 10 and 2 years, were also burned severely. ADAM FINCH, a brother of DAVID, was burned in a similar manner. The neighbors, who had been called to the spot by the terrific explosion, hastened to render every assistance to the sufferers. A physician was immediately summoned and he pronounced the youngest son's injuries of such a nature as to lead him to fear a fatal result. None of the others are considered dangerous. An alarm of fire immediately followed the explosion, and several fire companies hastened to the spot, but their services were not required, as the fire had been extinguished by the neighbors. The interior of the building was almost completely destroyed, the damage being estimated at $1,200 or $1,500. The gas-fitters are charged with the most culpable careless in leaving gas escaping in the manner they did.

abstract: It seems to be universally conceded that a larger number of the people of this State are in favor of the Republican than of any other ticket. The great point aimed at now, therefore, by the friends of BELL, DOUGLAS and BRECKINRIDGE, ...
lead_paragraph: It seems to be universally conceded that a larger number of the people of this State are in favor of the Republican than of any other ticket. Each of the three other parties confesses its inability to carry the State. But they all hope that by uniting their forces they may defeat their common foe. The great point aimed at now, therefore, by the friends of BELL, DOUGLAS and BRECKINRIDGE, is to combine their votes so as to defeat LINCOLN. The work has been partly accomplished. The Douglas Democrats have put up an electoral ticket of which ten places, out of 33, are given to the friends of BELL; -- and it is confidently believed that before the election the Breckinridge party will accept a similar position on the same ticket.

abstract: The steamship Ariel, from Aspinwall on the 15th inst., arrived at this port yesterday. She brings two weeks' later news from the South and Central American States, and nearly $800,000 in specie from San Francisco. The Ariel's California advices have been anticipated by the Overland Mail; but the details given in our correspondent's letter will be found interesting and important.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Ariel, from Aspinwall on the 15th inst., arrived at this port yesterday. She brings two weeks' later news from the South and Central American States, and nearly $800,000 in specie from San Francisco. The Ariel's California advices have been anticipated by the Overland Mail; but the details given in our correspondent's letter will be found interesting and important. There is little change to be noted in the state of the civil war now distracting New-Granada. Communication between Bogota and the coast has been cut off, so we have no late intelligence from the capital. Hostilities had commenced in the State of Magdalena. MOSQUERA is said to be in command of 6,000 men. The discovery of valuable silver mines in Chili is the chief item of information from that Republic. From Peru we learn that a despicable attempt had been made to assassinate the President. The would-be murderer escaped. Peru has not yet adjusted the American claims, and it is feared that to obtain satisfaction our Minister will be compelled to resort to extreme measures. The news from other South American States and from Central America is not of an important character.

abstract: The Second Ward Republicans temporarily organized last evening by the election of GUERDON ROBBINS as Chairman and J.G. ABBE as Secretary. abstract: The Philadelphia North American is hugely disturbed by the size of New-York, and without the fear of AEsop before its eyes, is determined to swell the straight waistcoat of Quakerism to the uttermost. It is sure that Philadelphia is a "much larger city" than New-York, and relies as a reason for the faith that is in it upon the "number of houses, churches and schools" in which the home of brotherly love rejoices.
lead_paragraph: -- The Philadelphia North American is hugely disturbed by the size of New-York, and without the fear of AEsop before its eyes, is determined to swell the straight waistcoat of Quakerism to the uttermost. It is sure that Philadelphia is a "much larger city" than New-York, and relies as a reason for the faith that is in it upon the "number of houses, churches and schools" in which the home of brotherly love rejoices. Of the insignificant item of population it takes no account, probably feeling that Philadelphia would be quite as great a place without as with its inhabitants, which, for aught we know, may be a true, but is certainly not a pretty thing for a Philadelphia journalist to say or even to imply. The North American is severe, too, upon our poor children, exulting in the thought that more teachers are required to keep 61,475 small Philadelphians from running away to the metropolis than are necessary to instruct 171,768 little Gothamites in all sound learning. Our homes and hearths also come in for a tremendous "taking down." What New-Yorker can see his beloved "English basement" as our clear-sighted cousins behold it without a shudder of self-contempt:

abstract: BURSTING OF WATER PIPES. In digging the trenches for the sewer pipes in different parts of the city, the water pipes are often exposed. In several of the districts these pipes were thus exposed during the recent heavy rains, and the water washing the earth from under them, has frequently caused the pipes to settle and become disjointed.
lead_paragraph: BURSTING OF WATER PIPES. -- In digging the trenches for the sewer pipes in different parts of the city, the water pipes are often exposed. In several of the districts these pipes were thus exposed during the recent heavy rains, and the water washing the earth from under them, has frequently caused the pipes to settle and become disjointed. The water rushing suddenly upon the street and into the [???]ellars, has caused much loss to the contractors and private individuals, and much annoyance to citizens generally in the districts where these accidents haye occurred, by the shutting off of the water to enable the necessary repairs to be made. An accident of this kind took place in Columbia, near Orange-street, yesterday afternoon. Had it happened in the night time much property would have been destroyed in the vicinity. Fortunately the agents of the Water Commissioners were on the spot, and quietly shut off the water from the district, so that the loss falls mainly upon the sewer contractor. A similar accident occurred a few days since on Sands-street, at two points -- one near Washington-street and the other near Pearl-street. At both places considerable damage was none to private property in the vicinity.

abstract: According to all accounts, the crisis in Mexico will be hastened by events not generally foreseen some months ago. Senor PACHECO, the new Spanish Minister in Mexico, has made certain peremptory demands on the Constitutional Government at Vera Cruz, to which demands the Constitutional Government refused compliance in a firm and decided manner.
lead_paragraph: According to all accounts, the crisis in Mexico will be hastened by events not generally foreseen some months ago. Senor PACHECO, the new Spanish Minister in Mexico, has made certain peremptory demands on the Constitutional Government at Vera Cruz, to which demands the Constitutional Government refused compliance in a firm and decided manner. The most recent advices to private parties in this City, state that the inhabitants of the city were in a high state of excitement, hourly expecting some warlike demonstration on the part of the Spanish forces before their walls. All the able-bodied males in that neighborhood were rushing to the headquarters of the Constitutional Government, and offering their services against the Spaniards.

abstract: It is a reproach, well applied, that correspondents are too fond of talking about the weather; but if ever weather deserved to be talked about, it is surely that with which we have been favored for the past four weeks. abstract: Mr. D.U. MARTIN, whose progress in his two-oared wherry from Boston to New-York has been chronicled from time to time, arrived here safely about 5 1/2 o'clock last evening. Harbor Police boat No. 8, Coxwain SMILEY, was the first who discovered him pulling his little skeleton boat at a smart pace down the East River. He wore nothing but an undershirt, with short sleeves, a light pair of pants, and a close-fitting white cap. As he pulled past the Police boat. the coxswain, suspecting from the bronzed appearance of the rower's face and arms that he was the identical Wherry man, politely hailed him, and remarked that it was rather rough. "Yes," said the rower, "I am a stranger here." "Where are you from?" inquired the coxswain. "Boston," replied the stranger. "Then you are the man we have been looking for," said SMILEY. Mr. MARTIN desired to be shown the boat-shop of Messrs. WM. H. & J.S. DARLING, and by the direction of the policemen he was soon at the place -- No. 371 South-street. Quite a crowd was gathered to witness the landing of the singular looking stranger. Mr. DARLING, who has several days anticipated his coming, was soon at hand, and the little boat which had breasted so many waves, and borne its navigator in safety to the end of his journey, was deposited in the boat-house. This boat was built to order for Mr. MARTIN and sent to Boston by the way of Fall River, about two months ago. It is 21 feet long, and is a neat, lap-streak shell boat, having air-tight compartments at each end. Mr. MARTIN appeared in good condition, and nothing except his arms, which were somewhat burnt by the sun, indicated the protracted and tiresome physical effort which he had just accomplished. According to his "log," he has performed the whole distance from Boston to New-York in about 80 hours of rowing, which, allowing the distance to be four hundred miles, is about five miles per hour. He left Eastham on Thursday, and reached Hyannis the same evening, where he put up on board of a schooner which was anchored inside of the breakwater. On Friday he stopped at Falmouth for a short time, and then pushed into Wood's Hole, which he reached at noon. Here he made some slight repairs of his boat. He then replenished his stock of berries at the store of Capt. FISH on the wharf, and started on his journey, reaching Cuttyhunk, at the west end of the Elizabeth Islands, late in the evening. Here he was hospitably entertained by Mr. SMITH, keeper of the light, who manifested much interest in his journey. He remained here over Saturday night and left on Sunday morning, arriving at Stonington that night. He dined on apples, and that day rowed nearly to Guilford. On Tuesday he called at New-Haven and took dinner -- this time having the ill-luck to get hold of some unripe fruit which did him no good. He crossed the sound and slept in a point of land some twelve miles east of Sand's Point, and yesterday morning rowed to the Sand's Point Light-house and ate breakfast on his accustomed berries. Having laid in a water-melon, he again embarked, and reached New-York at 5 1/2 o'clock P.M., pulling over forty miles during the day. Half his water-melon was still left when he arrived.

abstract: The somewhat sudden departure for Vera Cruz of the steam-frigate Susquehanna, which takes place at 10 o'clock to-day, and the order of the Navy Department for the immediate equipment of the Pouchatan, have caused naval people to expect brisk times in the Gulf. The Pouchatan's destination has not officially transpired, but the fact that she has not been in any way overhauled or repaired since her recent return from an active cruise of over two years, is sufficient to warrant the conclusion that she is destined to remain for the present in the Western Hemisphere. We append a correct list of the vessels now attached to the home squadron, all of which could of course be concentrated at any point in the Gulf within a few days:

abstract: Twelve hundred poor fellows, on whom has unhappily fallen the State's uniform of striped trowsers and jackets, are now cramped within the stone walls and iron doors of the Prison at Sing Sing. The larger part of these are young men, under thirty years, who are now suffering their first sentence, and repenting their first crime. Hundreds of them have good-natured, intelligent, honest-looking faces, showing fewer features of the rogue than many a man's that never was seen inside a State's Prison. Their crimes in a great majority of instances, have grown out of an over glass of wine, rather than any cool forethought of knavery. But now that the criminals are safely housed against any further opportunities of wrongdoing, their human feelings need to be met with human sympathies; their minds need to receive culture like other men's minds; their hearts need to be touched like other human hearts.

abstract: ILLUMINATED DIALS FOR THE CITY HALL CLOCK -- The City Hall is at length receiving the finishing touch to its restoration from the serious disaster which occurred to it, at the first jubilee into which New York broke forth, at the successful laying of that Atlantic Cable, which turned out so unsuccessful. After remaining in ruins for more than a year, the cupola was rebuilt, and once more the clock, one of the "old familiar faces" of the city, was replaced by a young and vigorous time-keeper, -- the poor man's chronometer, and rich man's regulator.
lead_paragraph: ILLUMINATED DIALS FOR THE CITY HALL CLOCK -- The City Hall is at length receiving the finishing touch to its restoration from the serious disaster which occurred to it, at the first jubilee into which New York broke forth, at the successful laying of that Atlantic Cable, which turned out so unsuccessful. abstract: An accident oc  curred to the early Newspaper Express train, yesterday morning, which delayed it for some time, but caused no serious damage. This is the first mishap which has befallen this train since it was started. Considering the very high rate of speed at which it is run, this fact affords marked testimony to the vigilance and care which distinguish the management of the Hudson River Railroad.

abstract: last few days homicides and deeds of blood seem to have become epidemic in our city, and the impression must go abroad that we have become a blood-thirsty and turbulent people, or that our police regulations are lame and inefficient. Yesterday, another terrible homicide was committed in our public streets. About 5 1/2 o'clock in the evening, a German, named JACOB WAGNER, was in the grocery store of F.J. BELLEDEN, at the corner of Fifth and McAllister-streets, settling with some countrymen for some hay which he had just purchased. While there an Irishman, named JOHN MCILVAINE, appeared at the door of the grocery and commenced a controversy with WAGNER concerning an ancient feud which it appears existed between them. WAGNER went on the sidewalk, when the altercation was renewed, and, as it is alleged, WAGNER struck at MCILVAINE, when the latter, who had a pocket knife in his hand, suddenly stabbed WAGNER in five different places -- one on the left breast, one under the left breast, two in the right side toward the back, and one in the back. WAGNER was taken into the grocery store, and died in about fifteen minutes. MCILVAINE, after the stabbing, walked down McAllister to Fourth, thence on Broadway to the landing, where he was arrested by Officers LEWIS and MATTHEWS. He made no resistance, but said he killed WAGNER in self-defence. He was much intoxicated at the time. -- Cincinnati Inquirer, 21st.

abstract: Frank Ward, formerly a bar-keeper in San Francisco, was arrested yesterday afternoon, by officer Elavin of the First Ward, charged with having, in connection with John Sweeny, a sea captain, forged the name of Mr. Edward Bissel, a lawyer, doing business over the Shoe and Leather Bank, to a check on the Chemical Bank for $730.
lead_paragraph: Frank Ward, formerly a bar-keeper in San Francisco, was arrested yesterday afternoon, by officer Elavin of the First Ward, charged with having, in connection with John Sweeny, a sea captain, forged the name of Mr. Edward Bissel, a lawyer, doing business over the Shoe and Leather Bank, to a check on the Chemical Bank for $730. It is said that on the 8th inst. Ward and Sweeny presented the check to Mr. A.B. Yates, one of the proprietors of the Washington Hotel, No. 1 Broadway, and asked him to cash it, as it was after bank hours. Mr. Yates, having previously transacted business with them, acceded to the request, after both had indorsed the check; but on presenting it, on the following day, at the Bank, the signature of Mr. Bissel was pronounced to be a forgery. Mr. B. was then applied to, and he also pronounced [???]t a forgery, and being acquainted with the hand-writing of Ward he made affidavit that the filling up and the signature of the check was in his hand-writing. A warrant for the arrest of the two men was then issued, but Ward only could be found, Sweeny having gone to sea. Ward was taken before Justice WELSH and held for further examination. The house Ward was formerly connected with at San Francisco was at one time reputed to be worth about $3,000,000, but two fires and other heavy losses swept it mostly away.

abstract: It was a very peaceably disposed body was this Convention especially on the face. It was an orderly Convention, in which though there might have been diverse purposes, there was such a respect for the obverse necessity of keeping within the bounds of decorumr, that nobody ventured to overstep them. If there were two sides, the two sides very carefully refrained from giving or taking offence at what was proposed, or at what was done.

abstract: We give place in another column to a new plan for saving the Union. Mr. ALEXANDER PARKINS, Editor of the Clarke Journal, in Virginia, is its author. He is a gentleman of ability, independence, and sincere convictions. His language and style of thought are quite different in some respects from those which we generally find in Southern writers on this subject: -- but his scheme of salvation is quite as wild and impracticable as the wildest of them all.

abstract: The storm of Tuesday night. did considerable damage in Herkimer County. At Little Falls a barn was struck by lightning and was entirely consumed. together with a dwelling-house attached. About the same time a house at Mohawk was also struck and burned to the ground. The storm was very severe, and the darkness so great (except during the flashings of the lightning) that the boats, along the line of the canal were compelled to lay up. Railroad bridge culverts were carried away by the rain in almost every direction in the eastern portion of the State. The damage done is roughly estimated at several hundred thousands of dollars.

abstract: We learn from Washington that a special messenger, with dispatches of importance from the Spanish Minister in Mexico, both for the Spanish Legation there and for the Government at Madrid, arrived at New-Orleans, from Vera Cruz, on the 16th inst. The Picayune has an inkling of the contents of the dispatches, and presumes that they are of such a character as will, when our Government shall be apprised of the same, induce it to increase the naval force of the United States in the Mexican Gulf. The presumption is, that Spain has determined to press her demands both upon the Juarez Government and the Miramon Government, for an adjustment of claims and redress of alleged grievances, and in the event of noncompliance, to bombard Vera Cruz, &c. How the Spanish naval commander can reach MIRAMON, where he is somewhere locked up, it does not appear. But he can blockade Vera Cruz. England and France are apparently acting in cooperation with Spain, in matters relative to Mexico. The coercive measures which are proposed by Spain will not, probably, be opposed by the other two European Powers, who have also made large reclamations upon the Mexican Government. Whether the United States Government will feel itself called upon to interfere is very doubtful.

abstract: If this rain continues it is feared that the pattern of this little Island will be washed out, like a badly printed cotton. Seriously, the most disastrous consequences are to be apprehended, for it is now impossible for a great portion of the grain crop to be restored by any sort of weather. On Monday last I saw wheat resembling the rushes formerly strewn, in default of carpets, in the halls of our Saxon forefathers.
lead_paragraph: From Our Own Correspondent.

abstract: The Democratic State Central Committee met on Monday, in this town, and after counting heads, and studying the aspects, adjourned for the day. abstract: President FELTON, of Harvard College, was then introduced to the audience and delivered an interesting address on the present state of education in Greece. Referring briefly to the ancient achievements of that renowned race, in arts and in arms, he rehearsed the political events which gave the kingdom its present form of Government, and proceeded to say that the genius of the old Greeks still survived among their ...
lead_paragraph: President FELTON, of Harvard College, was then introduced to the audience and delivered an interesting address on the present state of education in Greece. Referring briefly to the ancient achievements of that renowned race, in arts and in arms, he rehearsed the political events which gave the kingdom its present form of Government, and proceeded to say that the genius of the old Greeks still survived among their descendants -- that the perfection of form which we admire in the works of the ancient sculptors, is still found in breathing loveliness, among the youthful generation of the Greeks; and that the Greek language, restored to almost Attic purity, is heard in the society of Athens, in the pulpit, in the professor's chair. In the closing portion of his lecture, President FELTON gave a very interesting narrative of his own observations and experience in Greece during two visits that he made in 1853 and in 1858. The labors of EUGENIUS and of CORAY in preparing the people for the revolution were related. The latter, who was an able man and comprehensive scholar, guided for a time the affairs of his countrymen, though he was himself in Paris. Referring to the scenes in Scio, during that revolution, he said the Powers of Europe ought to have united against the Turks then and driven them not only into Asia, whence they came, but into the remotest parts of it Among the influences that have favored the education and the progress of the Greeks is the fact that the Priests have always favored the study of the Scriptures in the Septuagint version. Another thing favorable to their progress is the fact that they have no permanent head of the Greek Church. The Patriarch of Constantinople is Patriarch of Turkey and the Ionian Islands only. The Kingdom of Greece is under Bishops of tie Greek Church, and Russia is under still another Ecclesiastical organization. He said he coincided perfectly in the opinion of those who think that the most proper course for the. missionaries to take there, is not to attack the Church; for it is a Christian Church, and though it has superstitions it may be reformed from within.

abstract: About twenty thousand persons assembled on the Putnam ground at Gates and LaFayette-avenues; Brooklyn, to witness the deciding contest between the Atlantic and Excelsior Clubs, on Thursday, Aug. 23d. The only cause of regret on this occasion is that any body of men should so far forget themselves as to act in the shameful manner that characterized the conduct of those individuals that were instrumental in break  ing up the game.
lead_paragraph: About twenty thousand persons assembled on the Putnam ground at Gates and LaFayette-avenues; Brooklyn, to witness the deciding contest between the Atlantic and Excelsior Clubs, on Thursday, Aug. 23d. The only cause of regret on this occasion is that any body of men should so far forget themselves as to act in the shameful manner that characterized the conduct of those individuals that were instrumental in break ing up the game. It would not be entirely correct to say that this result was unlooked for, as statements have been openly made within the last few days that the Excelsiors would not be allowed to win in a close contest. That the Atlantic Nine were privy to any such plot, we are unwilling to believe, but a little stricter enforcement of order on their own ground would undoubtedly tend to greater quiet and more agreeable results when their hangers-on follow them to other grounds. The following is a detail of the innings as far as played:

abstract: Great Britain has not yet condescended to offer any decent excuse for the attitude she has assumed with regard to the Syrian outbreak. Individual Englishmen, in common with the whole civilized world, have been moved to wrath at the outrages committed in the Lebanon; but their Government, over- ...
lead_paragraph: Great Britain has not yet condescended to offer any decent excuse for the attitude she has assumed with regard to the Syrian outbreak. Individual Englishmen, in common with the whole civilized world, have been moved to wrath at the outrages committed in the Lebanon; but their Government, overcome by a miserable jealousy of Russian influence, refuses actively to aid in the suppression of the outbreak. Lord JOHN RUSSELL recently stated in the House of Commons that the only intervention contemplated by England was the landing of marines from men-of-war, if their presence was necessary for the protection of British subjects.

abstract: We advise those who suppose, or are told, that the South will dissolve the Union in the event of LINCOLN'S election, to read carefully the admirable letter from Col. B.F. PERRY, of South Carolina, which was published in the TIMES of yesterday morning.
lead_paragraph: We advise those who suppose, or are told, that the South will dissolve the Union in the event of LINCOLN'S election, to read carefully the admirable letter from Col. B.F. PERRY, of South Carolina, which was published in the TIMES of yesterday morning. They will learn rom that epistle that the Disunionists do not monopolize all the thinking or all the speaking, and that they will not have it all their own way, even in South Carolina. The differences of opinion between Messrs. KEITT, ORR and BOYCE, to which we have already referred, in regard to the proper time and mode of seceding, indicate a corresponding diversity of sentiment among the people. This letter, however, shows conclusively that it is not merely a difference of opinion in regard to details, but that there is a strong, intelligent and influential public sentiment in South Carolina which is utterly opposed to secession under any form, upon such a provocation as the election of a Republican President would give them.

abstract: A short time since a woman named Elizabeth Berry, was incarcerated by Justice WELSH, on a charge of larceny preferred against her by a barber living in Brooklyn, named Daniel Biggs; but on an examination on Friday, she proved her innocence and was dis- ...
lead_paragraph: A short time since a woman named Elizabeth Berry, was incarcerated by Justice WELSH, on a charge of larceny preferred against her by a barber living in Brooklyn, named Daniel Biggs; but on an examination on Friday, she proved her innocence and was discharged. It appears that a few weeks ago she was about starting in a boat from Cape May to Philadelphia, when she was accosted by Biggs, who told her that she was on the wrong boat, and showed her another that she should take. Biggs appeared very friendly, gave her his card, and invited her, if she ever came to New-York, to call and see his family. She then left him, and proceeded on board the boat designated, and the following day, to her surprise, found herself in this City instead of Philadelphia. Soon after landing she, again to her surprise, met Biggs, and was induced to accompany him home. Here he showed her every attention, and made her a present of some clothing, but failing in his purpose towards her, he became angry, accused her of stealing the clothing he had given her, and caused her arrest on a charge of larceny. On an affidavit to the above effect being made, Justice WELSH discharged the accused, and sent Officer King, of the Lower Police Court, to arrest Biggs. The latter was soon before the magistrate, and was committed to prison to answer a charge of perjury.

abstract: SONS OF TEMPERANCE. The Temperance organizations were never, perhaps, in a more flourishing condition, in this city, since the great revulsion which followed the legislative enactment known as the Maine law, than at the present time.
lead_paragraph: SONS OF TEMPERANCE. -- The Temperance organizations were never, perhaps, in a more flourishing condition, in this city, since the great revulsion which followed the legislative enactment known as the Maine law, than at the present time. The different Divisions of Sons of Temperance are particularly prosperous. They hold regular weekly meetings, and additions are constantly being made to their ranks. The admitting of ladies to the public proceedings of this Order has had a good effect, and many young men are by them induced to join the cold-water army. Brooklyn Division No. 13 held an interesting meeting, Thursday evening, at their rooms, No. 166 Fulton-street, at which Ex-Mayor HALL presided, when addresses were made by Mr. HALL, of Myrtle Division No. 115; Mr. JOCELYN, of New-York; Rev. SHADRACH LEADAR, of Massachusetts; and JOHN LEAVENS. Between each address there was singing by members of the Order. The next meeting will be held Sept. 20.

abstract: Farini came very near breaking his neck on Wednesday. He attempted to cross his cable at Niagara Falls, enveloped in a sack of glazed muslin. Hardly had he taken a dozen steps before he found that his feet were slipping.
lead_paragraph: Farini came very near breaking his neck on Wednesday. He attempted to cross his cable at Niagara Falls, enveloped in a sack of glazed muslin. Hardly had he taken a dozen steps before he found that his feet were slipping. Carefully he retreated to the point of departure, when he put on his India-rubber shoes outside of the bag. Then he attempted the perilous transit successfully. He advertises to carry a man across the chasm next Wednesday.

abstract: The last number of the Freewill Baptist Quarterly has a curious and interesting article on the "Advantages and Disadvantages of a Permanent Ministry." In favor of a permanent pastorate, it is said that it saves the expense of frequent removals.
lead_paragraph: The last number of the Freewill Baptist Quarterly has a curious and interesting article on the "Advantages and Disadvantages of a Permanent Ministry." In favor of a permanent pastorate, it is said that it saves the expense of frequent removals. The Freewill Baptist ministry, numbering 1,246, are supposed on an average to change locations once in four years. Calculating the expense of each removal at $30, the total amount expended in this way would be $9,445. A more important consideration is, that a permanent pastorate "tends to stability of mind," on the part of both pastor and people; "it deepens the affections and tends to establish mutual confidence." On the contrary, it may be said that a permanent pastorate "lacks the inspiration of new faces," -- it results often in despondency on the part of the pastor, forbids extended effort to enforce and impress some particular truth which a roving ministry can set before a variety of congregations, and prevents the pastor from pursuing that extended system of visitation in his congregation, which often results in much good. The Evangelist, in commenting on this article, remarks that a permanent ministry is essential to the highest type of Christian development -- to stability of Christian character, and to mutual confidence between pastor and people. Allusion is also made to the causes or occasions of change in the pastoral relation. The people are frequently, but not always, responsible for them. Greater care is recommended in the selection and settlement of ministers. The ease with which the pastoral relation may be dissolved should not be allowed to act as a premium on hasty settletlements, for the intimate relations which must exist between a pastor and his people are of too sacred a nature to be treated lightly.

abstract: Mr. D.U. MARTIN, whose arrival was reported in the TIMES yesterday, and who has earned the sobriquet of "the Wherry Man," by successfully row-ing a small skeleton boat from Boston to New-York, subsisting wholly on fruit and vegetable diet, was, ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. D.U. MARTIN, whose arrival was reported in the TIMES yesterday, and who has earned the sobriquet of "the Wherry Man," by successfully row-ing a small skeleton boat from Boston to New-York, subsisting wholly on fruit and vegetable diet, was, yesterday, rendered an appropriate reception by his friends of the vegetarian school, at the Water-cure establishment in Light-street. Besides the regular guests and patients of the house, several gentlemen who take an interest in the regatta clubs, Mr. DARLING and his associates, who built the now celebrated wherry, and several representatives of the Press, attended by invitation. Several ladies were also present, who appeared to take considerable interest in the row-mantic adventurer. The dinner consisted wholly of vegetables and the fruits of the season, well-cooked and served up in abundance. After a brief explanation by the Superintendent, of the design of the dinner, Mr. MARTIN was introduced, and the party, consisting of about sixty persons, sat down. Ample justice was done to the repast, and there was no complaint on account of the absence of meat. The dinner being disposed of, the wherry-man was desired to give an account of his adventures.

abstract: Travelers in China report of that unique and interesting country that it is the custom of the people when they entertain strangers to make them a little speech in praise of the various dishes set before them, and to urge ...
lead_paragraph: Travelers in China report of that unique and interesting country that it is the custom of the people when they entertain strangers to make them a little speech in praise of the various dishes set before them, and to urge their guests with repeated and most pressing arguments to that great duty of eating their dinners which in other lands is commonly performed under the silent stress of an inward law. A mandarin is not content to offer you a puppy-steak or a rat-soup; but he eloquently and forcibly entreats you to fill yourself with food, and not unfrequently pushes his importunities to the point of cramming a quantity of rice or meat into your mouth, and patting it off at the edge with a chop-stick, as masons pat off mortar with a trowel.

abstract: STREET CLEANING AND ITS COST. The great decrease in the comparative expenses of cleaning the streets for the week ending Aug. 11, and that ending Aug. 18, amounting to nearly a thousand dollars, has excited some comments among tax-payers.
lead_paragraph: STREET CLEANING AND ITS COST. -- The great decrease in the comparative expenses of cleaning the streets for the week ending Aug. 11, and that ending Aug. 18, amounting to nearly a thousand dollars, has excited some comments among tax-payers. The explanation is furnished by the tables of Mr. DOWNING, Superintendent of Sanitary Inspection. For the week ending Aug. 11, there were 297 men employed, who performed 1,074 1/2 hours' work, and who removed 14,182 loads of dirt, ashes and manure, at a cost of $4,631. During the week ending Aug. 18, the number of men employed was 284, who performed only 713 1/4 hours' work, there having been two days during which no work could be done. These removed 11,742 loads of dirt, ashes and manure, at a cost of $3,627, and as there was a diminution in the number of men, and a large decrease in the number of hours' work, the decrease of the week is accounted for. The streets generally are in a respectable condition, and are cleaned at an expense far less than that called for by the contract with Mr. WATERBURY and his associates, passed last year by the Common Council. The following table shows the amount of semi-monthly payments from March 24, when the heaviest work commences, up to Aug. 18, the last return:

abstract: The steamship City of Baltimore from Liverpool on the 15th and Queenstown on the 16th inst., passed Cape Race on Thursday, and her advices have been briefly telegraphed from that point. The news is four days later than that brought by the ...
lead_paragraph: The steamship City of Baltimore from Liverpool on the 15th and Queenstown on the 16th inst., passed Cape Race on Thursday, and her advices have been briefly telegraphed from that point. The news is four days later than that brought by the Arabia, at Boston, and is of an interesting character. It is stated now, in contradiction to previous reports, that the English intend to land fifteen hundred men in Syria; but whether this force is to act in concert with the French or merely to protect British subjects, the telegram does not say. Naples had been declared in a state of siege, in preparation, no doubt, for GARIBALDI's anticipated attack. The daring Italian Chief had in person entered the Capital of his enemy to hold council with the revolutionary leaders. There is a report current that Austria will so far forget the obligations imposed upon her by the treaty of Villafranca as actively to oppose the progress of the Italian Revolution in Naples; but we can scarcely credit the statement. She has, however, demanded explanation from Piedmont of that part of GARIBALDI's letter to the King, in which he says that he means ultimately to free Venetia. In consequence of these warlike rumors there had been a slight decline in Consols.

abstract: These Clubs played a match at Elysian Fields, on Friday, in which their second nines were the contestants. The game was protracted so late that the eighth innings of Gotham scored 18 runs in the twi- ...
lead_paragraph: These Clubs played a match at Elysian Fields, on Friday, in which their second nines were the contestants. The game was protracted so late that the eighth innings of Gotham scored 18 runs in the twilight. Independent of this addition to their score, the Gothams did some pretty heavy business in the batting line. They are rapidly preparing themselves to take their places in the first nine. The Jeffersons, also, did some good batting, but were outfielded by the Gothamites, whose pitcher and catcher were also something superior.

abstract: The Alpine Club played their first Base Ball match, since their organization at the beginning of the season, on Friday at the Elysian Fields; it was with a Jersey Club and resulted in a victory for the Alpines after a very pleasant and well contested game.
lead_paragraph: The Alpine Club played their first Base Ball match, since their organization at the beginning of the season, on Friday at the Elysian Fields; it was with a Jersey Club and resulted in a victory for the Alpines after a very pleasant and well contested game. The Alpine Club is composed of young men connected with the Jane street Methodist Episcopal Church, who take pleasure in healthy out-door exercise. Although all played very well, the Alpines outbatted the Unions; Westervelt, Selmes, and Shipman making the best show; while Westervelt, Shepherd, Selmes, Ryder, and Simms were the most distinguished in their several positions in the field. For the Unions, Bowford, Moses, and Clark were the most prominent fielders. There is no reason why the next match of this young club, should not be graced with the presence of some of their fair friends, who would no doubt be highly pleased with the doings of their brethren.

abstract: THE STATEN ISLAND RAILROAD. The extension of the track of this road from the depot at Vanderbilt's Landing down to the wharf, is in rapid progress, and will be completed in a few days. Passengers will then be enabled to step from the boat directly aboard ...
lead_paragraph: THE STATEN ISLAND RAILROAD. -- The extension of the track of this road from the depot at Vanderbilt's Landing down to the wharf, is in rapid progress, and will be completed in a few days. Passengers will then be enabled to step from the boat directly aboard the cars, instead of walking several hundred yards through the sand, as they are now obliged to do. It is also in contemplation to establish a new ferry line to New-York, to run in connection with the cars, and to afford the public better accommodations than are now furnished by the miserable boats which ply between this City and the Island, under the auspices of Mr. LAW. The success of the Staten Island Railroad, which has now been running three months, has exceeded the most sanguine hopes of its projectors, and is proving to be of inestimable advantage to the residents of the interior and lower end of the Island. The cars make eleven stoppages between Vanderbilt's Landing and Tottenville, a distance of 15 miles, thus accommodating every hamlet on the route, and enabling those who live at the extreme end of the Island to reach New-York in 1 1/2 hours. The Company has secured the services, as conductors, of Mr. GEO. BARKER, well known to travelers on the Erie road, and of Capt. FRAZER, formerly of the steamboat Thomas Nelson, who, notwithstanding the frequent stoppages, contrive to put their trains through with the usual "railroad speed," and at the same time render the trip agreeable by their urbanity and accommodating spirit. The opening of this road renders the whole interior of that beautiful Island easy of access from New-York, and there is no doubt that in a few years, not merely the shores, but the entire surface of the Island will be thickly dolled with suburban villas.

abstract: Don Vicente Antonio Larranga, Spanish Consul at Charleston, whose serious illness, in consequence of exposure to the sun, we have already noticed, died on Sunday evening last. He was a native of Biscay, in the North of Spain. Early in life he became engaged in mercantile pursuits, and was led first to Mexico, and afterwards to New-Orleans. Nearly thirty years ago King Ferdinand VII. of Spain, conferred upon him the appointment of Spanish Consul for the States of North and South Carolina. Since that time he has resided in Charleston, and with such fidelity did he discharge the duties of his office that he received some years ago from his Government the decoration of the royal order of Isabella Segunda y Carlos Tercera. By his integrity and uniform courtesy Senor Larranga had gained the confidence and esteem of the whole community in which he resided. Senor Moncada, Spanish Consul at Savannah, was with Senor Larranga during the last days of his illness. He leaves a widow and four children.

abstract: The body of an unknown man, about 35 years of age, was found floating in the dock foot of Fifteenth-street, East River, and Coroner O'KEERE held an inquest upon it. Deceased was five feet eight inches in height, and was dressed in light colored pants, blue overalls, blue cloth coat, and white muslin shirt. No marks of violence were found upon the body and a verdict of "Death by drowning" was rendered. The body had been but two or three days in the water.

abstract: MORE MAMMOTH FOSSILS FOUND IN ULSTER COUNTY. A number of workmen have been engaged for some time past in making excavations in a swamp at Ellenville, Ulster County, for the purpose of discovering the remains of mammoth fossils.
lead_paragraph: MORE MAMMOTH FOSSILS FOUND IN ULSTER COUNTY. -- A number of workmen have been engaged for some time past in making excavations in a swamp at Ellenville, Ulster County, for the purpose of discovering the remains of mammoth fossils. For the last four or five years several portions of these pre-Adamite monsters have been discovered, and the New-York Geological Society are now going to considerable trouble and expense for the purpose of procuring, if possible, a full skeleton of the mammoth. Already an immense tusk has been taken out which measures ten feet in length, as well as several immense bones. They were found to be much decomposed, but with care may be united. The agent of the Society is now superintending the work, and he states that he feels quite confident of taking out a complete skeleton.

abstract: The Library for women, our readers will be glad to learn, is no longer a speculation, but a reality. Two years ago the subject was brought to public attention by a large public meeting, held in Dr. CHAPIN'S Church, at ...
lead_paragraph: The Library for women, our readers will be glad to learn, is no longer a speculation, but a reality. Two years ago the subject was brought to public attention by a large public meeting, held in Dr. CHAPIN'S Church, at which HENRY WARD BEECHER and JAMES T. BRADY made earnest and effective appeals in its behalf. The project took such strong hold upon the judgment and the sympathies of those present, that over $3,000 were contributed on the spot to carry it into execution. Since that time, although little pains have been taken to keep it before the public, practical and energetic measures have been prosecuted for the establishment of the library. A charter was procured from the Legislature, the Board of Trustees named in it was organized, books were purchased, rooms engaged, furnished and filled, and, thanks exclusively to the steady and intelligent efforts of the lady in whose sympathetic convictions the project had its origin, the WOMAN's LIBRARY is now an established fact.
headline: {'main': "The Woman's Library.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The Woman's Library.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Judge DOUGLAS arrived here at 1 o'clock this afternoon. He was met at the depot by a few friends, and conducted to the Gilmor House. There he interchanged congratulations with his friends and dined. The number of visitors was very limited, and he made no speech. He departed at 4  o'clock this afternoon for Norfolk, where he expects to address the citizens to-morrow.

abstract: Turkey, for a nation said to be in the article of death, has a pretty strong army and navy. She has actually under arms a total of 150,000, but, in two months' time and with funds, this number could be increased to 400,000 fighting men.
lead_paragraph: -- Turkey, for a nation said to be in the article of death, has a pretty strong army and navy. She has actually under arms a total of 150,000, but, in two months' time and with funds, this number could be increased to 400,000 fighting men. The Ottoman Navy consists of six line-of-battle ships, eight frigates, ten screw corvettes, ten gunboats and sixty brigs, sloops and other small craft -- making a total of 30,000 sailors and marines and 1,080 guns actually afloat, besides four ships of the line and two frigates in course of construction.

abstract: The purchase of the old Atlantic Garden by the Hudson River Railroad Company, and the announcement of the Company's purpose to place upon the site a freight and passenger depot, for the more convenient transaction of its business, are not the only indications of the shrewd tact of those in control of that corporation.
lead_paragraph: The purchase of the old Atlantic Garden by the Hudson River Railroad Company, and the announcement of the Company's purpose to place upon the site a freight and passenger depot, for the more convenient transaction of its business, are not the only indications of the shrewd tact of those in control of that corporation. Not only is an eligible proximity to the emigrant depot at Castle Garden thus obtained, but a freight repository still nearer to the great shipping centres than the landings of the river steamboats is secured, and the odds of competition turned, for the moment, in favor of the railroad. It is also represented that with its present facilities for business the Company is necessarily at the cost of employing trains to carry freight to its up-town depots, and of handling all its goods twice -- a serious deduction, it is needless to say, from the profits of carriage. With the projected arrangements in the First Ward these inconveniences and expenses will terminate, and another important step will be taken towards that millenial period when stockholders in the road shall realize a dividend.

abstract: We have the best authority for stating that the Mexican question is on the point of being peremptorily settled by a decisive intervention of four of the Great Powers most deeply interested in the restoration of order throughout the dominions of our distracted neighbor. France, England, Spain and Prussia have signed a convention for the pacification of Mexico, to which they invite the adhesion of the United States, but which they propose to carry into effect without that adhesion should the United States refuse it.

abstract: CASUALTIES. At 2 o'clock yesterday morning JOHN BRENNAN, a laborer, fell from the third story of house No. 26 Jay-street, and sustained a fracture of both legs and other injuries. He was conveyed to the New-York Hospital.
lead_paragraph: CASUALTIES. -- At 2 o'clock yesterday morning JOHN BRENNAN, a laborer, fell from the third story of house No. 26 Jay-street, and sustained a fracture of both legs and other injuries. He was conveyed to the New-York Hospital. His residence is at Haverstraw....An unknown lad, about 16 years of age, was drowned on Saturday evening while bathing at the foot of Fifty-fourth-street, East River, he having been seized with cramps. His body has not been recovered. The police took his clothes to the Ninteenth Ward Station-house....PATK, DIVINE, while skylarking on Saturday night, fell and fractured one of his legs. He was tahen to his residence in Thirty-eighth-street, near Tenth-avenue, and thence to Bellevue Hospital....CHAS. HALSEY, residing at No. 217 West Thirty-fourth-street, fell from a ladder in Twentieth-street, near Sixth-avenue, and fractured his collar-bone. He was conveyed to his residence.

abstract: The steamship Vanderbilt, from Havre and Southampton on the 15th inst., arrived at this port yesterday. We obtain, from our files and correspondence, details of the intelligence telegraphed from Cape Race, and published in our impression of Saturday.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Vanderbilt, from Havre and Southampton on the 15th inst., arrived at this port yesterday. We obtain, from our files and correspondence, details of the intelligence telegraphed from Cape Race, and published in our impression of Saturday. They are of considerable interest and importance. It is confirmed that 1,800 Garibaldians had landed in Calabria, and a French telegram states that they had been repulsed. This however, is not generally credited. Great preparations were going on in Naples to meet the anticipated invasion; but nearly all the newspaper correspondents agree in stating that, unless supported by foreign aid, the King will be compelled to abandon his dominions, as neither his army nor navy will fight for him. The Paris Patrie and other French papers assert, in positive terms, that in the event of GARIBALDI taking possession of Naples, Austria will not wait for his attack upon Venetia, but will meet the Garibaldian troops at whatever point of the mainland she may deem necessary for her own interests. We publish, from the special correspondence of the London Times, some very interesing accounts of the Italian General's projects of invasion. The French force destined for Syria will now, it is said, exceed 12,000men. The British have empowered their Commissioner to land 1,500 seamen and marines on the Syrian Coast, in case of need. In regard to this question, Lord STRATFORD DE REDCLIFFE made some important statements in the House of Lords on the evening of the 14th inst. His Lordship, who was for many years British Ambassador at Constantinople, and may be presumed to understand thoroughly the condition of Turkey, frankly admitted that the Syrian disturbances "were not referable to local causes alone, but were immediately connected with the general condition of the Ottoman Empire." Telegrams from Vienna state that Prince DANIELO, of Montenegro, was shot by an assassin on the 11th, and died on the 13th inst. Further intelligence is received by the Vanderbilt of the great progress made by the rebel factions in China, and much surprise is expressed that the Emperor does nor at once come to terms with the Western Powers. By way of England we learn that the African King DAHOMEY was about to sacrifice two thousand human beings in honor of the late King, his father. More slavers had been captured on the coast.

abstract: In another column will be found the announcement of the death of this accomplished officer. Entering the Navy in earliest boyhood, his whole career during a term of service of almost half a century, has reflected honor upon himself as well as upon the flag to which he was so loyal a servant.
lead_paragraph: In another column will be found the announcement of the death of this accomplished officer. Entering the Navy in earliest boyhood, his whole career during a term of service of almost half a century, has reflected honor upon himself as well as upon the flag to which he was so loyal a servant. After a period of active sea-service much longer than the generality of his brother officers were called upon to perform, disease, contracted originally in the discharge of duty upon the Coast of Africa, confined him for years past to his bed, where the latter portion of his life has been passed in patient endurance and meek submission to the will of his Maker.

abstract: The results attendant on the journey of M. BERTANI (the Piedmontese agent Of GARIBALDI) are very serious. Our Government is about to receive a note from Austria conceived in most energetic terms. This note exposes in its way the events that have happened in Southern Italy, and seeks to establish and to show the connection of our Government with the expedition of Garibaldi.
lead_paragraph: The results attendant on the journey of M. BERTANI (the Piedmontese agent Of GARIBALDI) are very serious. Our Government is about to receive a note from Austria conceived in most energetic terms. This note exposes in its way the events that have happened in Southern Italy, and seeks to establish and to show the connection of our Government with the expedition of Garibaldi. M. DE RECHBERG declares that the Austrian Government will not by any means permit Gen. Garibaldi or his partizans to descend, on Neapolitan territory. It censures our Government for not preventing every attempt of this kind, and adds that any disembarkation of Garibaldians on the coast of Southern Italy will immediately provoke the armed inter edition of Austria in Italy, and be the signal for the march of Austrian troops to the defence of Francis II. across the Roman territory.

abstract: In the House of Lords, Aug. 14, Lord STRATPORD DE REDCLIFFE, late British Ambassador at Constantinople, said: I have given notice in writing to my noble friend the Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, of certain questions which I wish to put to him before your lordships proceed to the business of the day. The first relates to the state of affairs in Syria.
lead_paragraph: In the House of Lords, Aug. 14, Lord STRATPORD DE REDCLIFFE, late British Ambassador at Constantinople, said: I have given notice in writing to my noble friend the Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs, of certain questions which I wish to put to him before your lordships proceed to the business of the day. The first relates to the state of affairs in Syria. I wish to ask my noble friend whether any orders have been given directing one of the aimed vessels belonging to Her Majesty's squadron in the Mediterranean to proceed to Smyrna, and other large towns on the coast of the Archipelago, for the protection of British subjects and property. I received only yesterday a letter from Smyrna which, although it is of a private kind, goes so much to the point, that in justification of my question I will venture to read it to your lordships. My correspondent residing in Smyrna writes in these terms:

abstract: It seems to be pretty well settled that Gen. WALKER is again on his way to Nicaragua. He has selected rather a circuitous route, to be sure, and is pretty certain to encounter some very serious obstacles, growing out of the nature of the country to be traversed, in the round-about crusade in which he has embarked.
lead_paragraph: It seems to be pretty well settled that Gen. WALKER is again on his way to Nicaragua. He has selected rather a circuitous route, to be sure, and is pretty certain to encounter some very serious obstacles, growing out of the nature of the country to be traversed, in the round-about crusade in which he has embarked. He directed his first attack against Honduras, where he is reported to have espoused the cause of the Ex-President CUBANAS, under whose flag he landed at Truxillo. This city he is said to have captured, but whether with a view to a conquest of the whole country, or with the intent merely to make it the starting-point for his crusade against Nicaragua, does not yet appear. The general report, however, is that he intends to march through Honduras into the northern part of Nicaragua, and penetrate thence to the capital of that country.

abstract: The rumors which reach us to-day by the Vanderbilt of a diplomatic manifestation made by Austria to Sardinia, with the avowed purpose of preparing the way for an armed interference of the Austrian Government in defence of the threatened throne of FRANCIS II., may well intensify the anxious attention with which the world is watching the perilous march of the Italian people to independence and unity.
lead_paragraph: The rumors which reach us to-day by the Vanderbilt of a diplomatic manifestation made by Austria to Sardinia, with the avowed purpose of preparing the way for an armed interference of the Austrian Government in defence of the threatened throne of FRANCIS II., may well intensify the anxious attention with which the world is watching the perilous march of the Italian people to independence and unity. These rumors, which, although they yet lack the consistency of official publication, are formidably confirmed by a renewed and extraordinary activity in the arsenals of France as well as of Sardinia, -- presage complications in the immediate future of European history far more important than any to which the war of 1859 has yet given rise. So serious, indeed, must be the necessary, and so alarming the possible consequences of any overt attempt by Austria to set aside the principle of absolute non-intervention in the affairs of Italy established at Villafranca, and since reaffirmed in the most formal declarations of the English as well as of the French Cabinets, that we cannot choose but hesitate to accord an implicit faith to the accounts which are given in the latest European journals of the language used by Austria in her communications to the Court of Turin on this subject.

abstract: Letters from Monterey state that VIDAURRI had left that city for Saltillo for the purpose of raising men and money. Saltillo was known to be unfavorable to him, and for the purpose of enforcing his demands he had taken about eight hundred men with him.
lead_paragraph: Letters from Monterey state that VIDAURRI had left that city for Saltillo for the purpose of raising men and money. Saltillo was known to be unfavorable to him, and for the purpose of enforcing his demands he had taken about eight hundred men with him. On the 1st day of the present month he left the main body of his troops at Rinconado and proceeded with Gen. ZUAZUA and about thirty men about six leagues further to the Rancho de Sangregorio, where they encamped for the night. It seems that their motions had been watched by ARRAMBEBRI's men, and at 1 o'clock on the morning of the second they were attacked in the midst of their slumbers, and so sudden was the attack and so great the surprise, that they were defeated without resistance, although the force of the attacking party is represented at only half their own. ZUAZUA was shot through the head as he rose in his bed to ascertain the cause of the disturbance. VIDAURRI escaped, it is believed, unhurt, though the bed upon which he was sleeping was penetrated by no less than seven balls.

abstract: The Summer is officially announced to be at an end. A few more days it has to live; a few more hours of flirtation by the seaside, and in the shadow of the mountains; a few more hops on shore, and dips in the briny wave, and moonlight drives, may still be snatched by fashion's votaries from the flying year, and then back to Broadway and the Central Park they must turn their loyal steps.
lead_paragraph: The Summer is officially announced to be at an end. A few more days it has to live; a few more hours of flirtation by the seaside, and in the shadow of the mountains; a few more hops on shore, and dips in the briny wave, and moonlight drives, may still be snatched by fashion's votaries from the flying year, and then back to Broadway and the Central Park they must turn their loyal steps. As farmers swarm bees with the tintinnabulation of bells and saucepans, so the Opera swarms the bees, or drones, or both, of New-York, back to their natural hive each Autumn, with the tremendous fanfaronade of its prophetic proclamations.

abstract: A GANG OF YOUNG BURGLARS BROKEN UP. On Saturday morning, about 4 o'clock, four boys were discovered attempting to break into Mr. JOHN DILLON'S store, No. 9 Jay-street. They were subsequently arrested in a stable in John-street by Offices KERRIGAN, of the Second Precinct.
lead_paragraph: A GANG OF YOUNG BURGLARS BROKEN UP. -- On Saturday morning, about 4 o'clock, four boys were discovered attempting to break into Mr. JOHN DILLON'S store, No. 9 Jay-street. They were subsequently arrested in a stable in John-street by Offices KERRIGAN, of the Second Precinct. They gave their name and ages as follows: JAMES CAMBELL, 15; JOHN MULLIGAN, 14; JOHN CANFIELD, 19; JOHN DILLON, 18. When brought before the Court, MULLIGAN turned State's evidence, and testified to the following burglaries by the boys arrested and others of the gang: Feed-store of JAS. SMITH, corner of Plymouth and Jay streets; brass-foundry in the Fifth Ward, $100 worth of castings stolen; another foundry in the neighborhood, $30 in money stolen; store corner of Bridge and John streets, $6 stolen from the till; sloop foot of Jay-street, $20 in money and a quantity; of clothing stolen. The boys were committed for trial.

abstract: In a letter which Senator PUGH, of Ohio, addressed to the late Douglas State Convention of Kentucky, he says: I wish to applaud the true and loyal Democracy  of Kentucky, face to face, for their noble courage in adhering to the principles and pledges of the Democratic party (even as against the temptation of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE'S candidacy) in regard to the single question which now menaces the stability and perpetuity of our Federal Government.
lead_paragraph: In a letter which Senator PUGH, of Ohio, addressed to the late Douglas State Convention of Kentucky, he says: I wish to applaud the true and loyal Democracy of Kentucky, face to face, for their noble courage in adhering to the principles and pledges of the Democratic party (even as against the temptation of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE'S candidacy) in regard to the single question which now menaces the stability and perpetuity of our Federal Government. I am not. as Mr. YANCEY expressed himself at the Maryland institute, upon the occasion of Mr. BRECKINRIDGE's nomination, merely neutral with respect to the continuance of the Union or its destruction; I am for the Union, and against disunion, at all times, without apology, or contingency, or qualification. The Constitution may be violated (as it often has been) by unfaithful public servants, or in the tempest, of faction, or from other causes; but our plain duty, as patriots, in every such emergency, is to invoke, again and again, and again, until seventy times seven, the sober sense and calm judgment of the people. If our Revolutionary fathers, under Washington could prolong an apparently desperate struggle for seven years -- driven from city to city, from camp to camp, from State to State, by superior numbers -- trampling the snows and ice of mid-winter with bare feet -- suffering two or three disasters for each victory -- and, at last, by sheer fortitude, achieve the liberty and independence we how enjoy, he does little honor to the memory of such ancestors (as it seems to me) who would now in our zenith of national and individual prosperity, abandon the great result of their labors -- the Union which they established -- without an equal exhibition of heroism. What can be more criminal than this modern habit of betaking ourselves, upon every trivial occasion, or even upon solemn occasions, to the jargon of Disunion, and secession, and revolution? I am not only opposed to it, gentlemen, tout I am tired of it, and disgusted with it. I hope to see the day when a public declaration from any man (ever so eloquent and distinguished) that he is "neither for the Union nor against the Union" will, instead of provoking thunders of applause, as in the Breckinridge Convention at Baltimore, be received with universal indignation and abhorrence. I have been a faithful Democrat ever since I had a vote; I love the Democratic Party, its principles, its policy, its usages of organization; I am proud of its history, and have always felt my heart throb with noble pulsations in musing upon Us future achievements; but with all this affection, and even with more than I have expressed, or can express, I declare to you, gentlemen, in all earnestness, that if Disunionists, or those to whom Union or Disunion is an affair of indifference, are now to become the leaders of the Democratic Party -- to prescribe the language of our platform -- to dictate, by means of secessions at Charleston and at Baltimore, whom we shall choose for candidates -- it will be high time for me, at least, to seek another and more congenial association. I am against the "irrepressible conflict" on both sides -- as well that now personified by JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE, as that personified by ABRAHAM LINCOLN.

abstract: A symptom of dramatic revival is notable to-night in the debut, at Wallack's Theatre, of Miss JANE COOMBS, in the Charles Kean play of "A Wife's Secret." Miss COOMBS has earned an enviable reputation on the provincial stage, and the character of Lady Eveline, in which she now appears at Wallack's, is admirably adapted to test her capacity for the most delicate and pathetic walks of the drama. She will be supported by Mr. GEORGE JORDAN, Mrs. STODDART, Mr. YOUNG, and other well-known artists, and by a debutante. Miss JOSEPHINE HENRY.
