abstract: Advices to the 17th inst. have been received from Europe by the arrival of the steamship Nova Scotian off Father Point, on her way to Quebec. The news is two days later than by the Vanderbilt. It is stated, on the authority of the Paris corres- ...
lead_paragraph: Advices to the 17th inst. have been received from Europe by the arrival of the steamship Nova Scotian off Father Point, on her way to Quebec. The news is two days later than by the Vanderbilt. It is stated, on the authority of the Paris correspondent of the Allgemeine Zeitung, that the Pope had written a letter to the French Cardinal, in which he takes a very melancholy and despairing view of the condition of things. He looks upon all as lost, and expects to die by the hands of an assassin, but expresses his determination never to quit Rome upon compulsion. Later advices from Syria represent that FUAD PASHA had surrounded Lebanon with troops, and had threatened to put all the Druse Shieks tco the sword if they did not surrender in two days. Twenty of them had been captured, and about eight hundred other important arrests had been made. A large quantity of plundered property had also been recovered. The Turkish Sultan had made a speech to the foreign Ministers, in which he expressed the determination to punish the Syrian offenders with the utmost severity. It was understood, also, that he was about to address another autograph inter to Queen VICTORIA and the Emperor NAPOLEON, in which he would express a desire to have the sole punishment of the criminals. An important report had been made by a select committee of the British House of Commons, in which they state that the condition of the laws regulating the national intercourse with France, Spain, Portugal and the United States is most unsatisfactory. There had been an advance in the Liverpool cotton market. Consols were quoted at 92 [???]@93.

abstract: Since the commencement of the Quarantine season twelve patients have been put on board the Marine Hospital Falcon. They were all from vessels arriving from the West India ports, with the exception of the vessel from Rio Janeiro, and were supposed to be sick with yellow fever.
lead_paragraph: Since the commencement of the Quarantine season twelve patients have been put on board the Marine Hospital Falcon. They were all from vessels arriving from the West India ports, with the exception of the vessel from Rio Janeiro, and were supposed to be sick with yellow fever. A portion of them, however, proved to be merely cases of bilious or intermittent fever, and only four cases of "real, old-fashioned yellow fever," such as were marked by the bleeding gums and black vomit, have been received. The brig East, from Matanzas, lost her mate on the passage, and sent two to the Hospital with yellow fever. There are now five vessels at the lower Quarantine, all but one from West India ports, which are regarded as unhealty. By means of the steam-propeller Rescue, chartered by Dr. GUNN, daily communication is kept up with the Falcon, and her supplies are sent down twice a week. The expense of the steamer is paid partly by the State, through Dr. GUNN, and partly by the Commissioners of Quarantine. From present indications, the officials at Quarantine predict a healthy season.

abstract: A meeting of this Association was held last evening in front of hall No. 145 Grand-street, E.D., to ratify the nominations made at the Syracuse Convention. CHAS. GODARD, Esq., occupied the chair, and there was a large attendance of people present, representing all parties.
lead_paragraph: A meeting of this Association was held last evening in front of hall No. 145 Grand-street, E.D., to ratify the nominations made at the Syracuse Convention. CHAS. GODARD, Esq., occupied the chair, and there was a large attendance of people present, representing all parties. The Wide-Awake Clubs, as usual, turned out with full ranks, and made a fine display. A number of transparencies, bearing appropriate mottoes, were exhibited in front of the hall, and a banner was suspended across the street, with a representation of a train of cars under full headway, and the names of the Federal and State candidates inscribed thereon. It was intended to hold the meeting in the rooms of the Association, but being inadequate in size, the meeting was held in the street. The Chairman introduced as the first speaker Mr. GREELEY. He first referred to the ordinance of '87, drafted by Mr. JEFFERSON for the government of the northwest territory, and said it truly expressed the sentiment as to Slavery of the Whigs of the Revolution and the founders of the Government. From the doctrine laid down in it, it was now sought to turn the people of the State of New-York, and as usual the attempt was made under a specious pretext. This time the pretext was "Popular Sovereignty." He thought this principle of Mr. DOUGLAS, as practically carried out, did not protect the right of the territories to self-government. The speaker continued at some length, reviewing the political questions of the campaign, concluding by predicting a triumph of Republican principles.

abstract: On Sunday night, Edward Smith, a livery stable keeper at No. 35 North Moore-street, was driving down the Second-avenue, near, Forty-seventh-street, when suddenly, a man rushed up to the carriage, seized the horses by the bridle, stopped them, and bold  ly demanded the life or the money of Mr. Smith.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday night, Edward Smith, a livery stable keeper at No. 35 North Moore-street, was driving down the Second-avenue, near, Forty-seventh-street, when suddenly, a man rushed up to the carriage, seized the horses by the bridle, stopped them, and bold ly demanded the life or the money of Mr. Smith. There were five or six young ladies in the carriage, and they became greatly alarmed, and some of them screamed for help. Mr. Smith instantly jumped from his seat and seized the highwayman by the collar. At that instant officer McKnight, of the Nineteenth Precinct, who heard the screams of the ladies, came up, and the fellow was quickly secured. He gave his name as Walter Smith, and was locked up by Justice OSBORNE for trial. He says he is a moulder by trade, and 20 years of age.

abstract: SERIOUS ACCIDENT AT THE DEPOT. Yesterday forenoon, a man named MORRIS J. WICKHAM, a resident of Goshen, was run over by a train of New-Jersey ears which was entering the depot, resulting in the loss of his right arm and leg. Mr. WICKHAM had just left the Erie train and was passing through Hudson- ...
lead_paragraph: SERIOUS ACCIDENT AT THE DEPOT. -- Yesterday forenoon, a man named MORRIS J. WICKHAM, a resident of Goshen, was run over by a train of New-Jersey ears which was entering the depot, resulting in the loss of his right arm and leg. Mr. WICKHAM had just left the Erie train and was passing through Hudson-street to the ferry, and having his head turned in an opposite direction was not aware of danger until; warned by the brakeman, when he unfortunately jumped in front of, instead of away from the train. Mr. GADDIS, assistant Superintendent, procured a carriage and the injured man was conveyed to the Alms House Hospital, where he received all possible medical aid at the hands of Drs. QUIDCE, CONDICT and VARICK. The arm was amputated and should the patient service, amputation of the leg will also be necessary.

abstract: A DISAPPOINTED LOVER ATTEMPTS SUICIDE.  A young man named JEREMIAH MILLER, residing at Valatie, Columbia County, has for some time past been desperately in love with a young girl of that village, and because she preferred the attention of ...
lead_paragraph: A DISAPPOINTED LOVER ATTEMPTS SUICIDE. -- A young man named JEREMIAH MILLER, residing at Valatie, Columbia County, has for some time past been desperately in love with a young girl of that village, and because she preferred the attention of another to those of JEREMIAH, he attempted to drown himself, and was with difficulty, rescued from a watery grave. A few days since his rival was married to the object of his affections, and the following night JEREMIAH was found hanging by the neck in Mr. ROTHBONE's paper mill, by the fireman of that establishment, who cut him down, and JEREMIAH was once more saved from death.

abstract: The new Journeymen Tailors Protective Association met last evening in Hibernia Hall, No. 42 Prince-street. About 200 persons were present, and the roll of members was increased from 300 names to nearly 400. Mr. JOHN G. WELSH presided, and stated that the object of the organization was to secure advance on the present low rate of wages paid to journeymen tailors. It was proposed to do this, not through the agency of a general strike, but by the formation of shop meetings, and an application from the hands in each shop to the proprietor, for the required increase -- amounting to about 20 per cent. over the rates now paid.

abstract: We find in one of our Philadelphia exchanges a curious letter signed ROBERT A. PARRISH, Jr., addressed to the President, and asking his attention to an extraordinary claim for 15,000,000 of francs, which Mr. P. claims to have upon the French Government, ...
lead_paragraph: We find in one of our Philadelphia exchanges a curious letter signed ROBERT A. PARRISH, Jr., addressed to the President, and asking his attention to an extraordinary claim for 15,000,000 of francs, which Mr. P. claims to have upon the French Government, but which he cannot even prosecute, by reason of the obstacles thrown in his way. The claim, he says, is based upon the Emperor's parole, which was pledged to him in consideration of certain evidence demonstrating the existence of a gold field, similar to that of California, and in a region accessible to the arms of France, which he had the distinguished honor of bringing to his notice. It was to become payable as soon as the authority of France was established in any part of the Territory indicated. This condition has been long since fulfilled, and the French Government is actually employed in working the gold mines.
headline: {'main': 'A CURIOUS CLAIM.; Enormous Demands of an American Citizen Upon the French Emperor.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A CURIOUS CLAIM.; Enormous Demands of an American Citizen Upon the French Emperor.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The steamship Matanzas, from Matanzas, Cuba, in four days and four hours, arrived at this port yesterday. The city and harbor of Matanzas are unusually healthy for this season of the year.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Matanzas, from Matanzas, Cuba, in four days and four hours, arrived at this port yesterday. The city and harbor of Matanzas are unusually healthy for this season of the year. The Matanzas Sugar market, since the 6th inst., has been rather dull, owing principally to the difficulty in procuring vessels, and also in consequence of discouraging advices from the North. Prices remain firm as last quoted. Exchange has advanced on London from 14 1/2@15 cent.; New-York, 2 1/2@3 1/2 cent. discount. The exports to the United States from Matanzas from the 1st of January up to the 22d of August inst., have amounted to 45,068 boxes and 34,498 hhds. of sugar, and 46,146 hhds. of molasses. We are indebted to Mr. J.E. HUERTAS, purser of the Matanzas, for papers, late commercial news, and other polite favors.

abstract: A FIREMAN KILLED IN A FIGHT. EDWARD FLYNN, a fireman attached to Engine Company No. 16, died on Sunday night from congestion of the brain, produced by a blow upon the head with a stone, received on the 3d of July in Chatham-street.
lead_paragraph: A FIREMAN KILLED IN A FIGHT. -- EDWARD FLYNN, a fireman attached to Engine Company No. 16, died on Sunday night from congestion of the brain, produced by a blow upon the head with a stone, received on the 3d of July in Chatham-street. Coroner O'KEEFE, on Monday, held an inquest upon the body, when it appeared in evidence that at the time in question some firemen were fighting among themselves and throwing stones at each other. The members of the Company to which deceased belonged were not engaged in the fight, and when deceased was struck he was standing quietly beside his engine. The stone was thrown by one of the contending parties, but by what particular person could not be ascertained by the Coroner. The deceased, after being struck, was conveyed to the New-York Hospital, where he remained a few days and then left, apparently well; but about a week ago he was attacked with congestion of the brain, which finally terminated his life. The medical testimony showed that the injuries to the head, inflicted on the 3d ult., had caused the congestion, and the jury rendered a verdict to that effect. Deceased was a native of New-York, 23 years of age, and resided at No. 16 Worth-street.

abstract: The steamer Baltimore, recently dispatched from this port to Kingston and Aspinwall, by Messrs.  BREAKSPEAR, FREUND  Co., as the beginning of a regular mail communication with Jamaica, was heard from at Aspinwall, the owners having received letters by the Ariel.
lead_paragraph: The steamer Baltimore, recently dispatched from this port to Kingston and Aspinwall, by Messrs. BREAKSPEAR, FREUND & CO., as the beginning of a regular mail communication with Jamaica, was heard from at Aspinwall, the owners having received letters by the Ariel. The Baltimore made a good run out, and her arrival at Port Royal was greeted with much enthusiasm by the merchants and people, as the harbinger of better mail and passage facilities with New-York. At last accounts over twenty passengers were engaged for the return trip, and there were also liberal freight engagements. The Colonial authorities received the agents of the steamer with great cordiality, and, with a view to insure the early establishment of the line, the Postmaster-General agreed for the present not to insist upon the running of the steamer to Aspinwall. This relieves the enterprise of one great feature of embarrassment. The Baltimore was run to Aspinwall on her first trip only because the Jamaica authorities insisted on that part of the service being joined to the bi-monthly trip from New-York, in order to connect with the English mails to the South Pacific, and also to Australia, when that line shall have gone into operation. The advices from the agent who went out in the steamer, after his interview with the Governor and Postmaster-General, are very encouraging. The steamer is now about due at this port, with a good complement of passengers, and with a handsome return freight. This new enterprise has naturally excited opposition among those who have hitherto held the monopoly of the trade by sailing vessels, and disparaging rumors have been put in circulation, both here and in Jamaica, concerning the steamer now employed in the service. The Baltimore is a snug screw steamer of nearly three hundred tons, with good carrying capacity and cabin accommodations. She is nearly new, having been built in the latter part of the year 1858. She is rigged with three masts, her auxiliary canvas being sufficient to make good headway in case of accident to the machinery. She has also good provision against fire in the shape of force-pumps and other appliances.

abstract: The People vs. Morris Harris. Mr. W.F. Howe yesterday applied for an order that this prisoner (who was arrested for attempting to pick the pocket of a gentleman at a fire, and was committed to Blackwell's Island by the Court of General Sessions) should ...
lead_paragraph: The People vs. Morris Harris. -- Mr. W.F. Howe yesterday applied for an order that this prisoner (who was arrested for attempting to pick the pocket of a gentleman at a fire, and was committed to Blackwell's Island by the Court of General Sessions) should be discharged on bail to await the decision of the Appellate Court. The officer who arrested the prisoner testified that he saw him (the prisoner) attempt to put his hands in the gentleman's pocket, and the Justice sent him on the Island for three months.

abstract: The Columbia (S.C.) Guardian, in reply to our comments on the disunion letter of Mr. BOYCE, insists that that gentlemen is quite correct in asserting that "the vital principle of the Republican party is negro equality,"  ...
lead_paragraph: The Columbia (S.C.) Guardian, in reply to our comments on the disunion letter of Mr. BOYCE, insists that that gentlemen is quite correct in asserting that "the vital principle of the Republican party is negro equality," -- meaning thereby the political equality of negroes and whites. We have denied this and we deny it again. There are men in the Northern States who uphold and advocate that doctrine, -- but they are few in number and are not increasing. The Republican party, as such, has never been committed to it, nor have those among them who accept it as abstractly and theoretically true, ever sought to give it practical effect. No political party ever acts up to the extreme of its theoretical faith. There are obstacles to be overcome in the practical working of political institutions, -- just as in that of mechanical inventions; -- and they can no more be disregarded in the one case than in the other. It is not easy to disprove by argument the right of women to vote, fill high offices, and hold a position of perfect political equality with men; -- but the practical objections to carrying those opinions into practice are so palpable and so cogent, that no attempt is ever made to do so.
headline: {'main': 'The Republicans and the Doctrine of Negro Equality.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Republicans and the Doctrine of Negro Equality.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A very interesting and pleasantly-contested game was played between these two strong Clubs on the Eureka ground at Newark on Monday, Aug. 27, when, after some most excellent batting and fielding being shown on both sides, the Eurekas came forth from the contest victorious. The Enterprise were weakened by the absence of three of their first nine players, their places being filled by substitutes -- one of them, Mr. Sutton, of the "muffin" nine, establishing a good claim to promotion. O'Neil, as catcher, did not allow many balls to pass, and guarded the bases so vigilantly that his opponents were very loth to run the hazard. Oddie pitched fairly, while Cornwell was very active at short, catching several balls and throwing with judgment to the bases; his batting was very successful. Chapman, at the first base, made some misses, but atoned for them by some brilliant, doings; and Start not only batted finely, but was very steady on the third base, making two very neat fly catches on foul balls. Smith and Ibbotson made two good catches each in the field -- one on the fly and one on the bound, and were efficient in other respects. Sutton distinguished himself by two catches, one very excellent, but was unfortunate at the bat. Boyd at the second was uncommonly slow, not distinguishing, himself by anything but his inefficiency. The Eureka fielding and batting were undoubtedly good, but did not equal their usual standard, several unaccountable misses being made in the field, and the batting not showing as successful as in their former contests this season. Pennington's play at the second would have been highly creditable but for two muffs on which bases were made. His pitching was very powerful and effective, but he lost too much time by walking up to receive the ball from the catcher. Davison, in the left field, let a few balls pass him, but distinguished himself by a splendid one-hand fly-catch, and by his excellence at the bat. Rogers, as catcher, did not do himself justice either in this position or in batting. Van Houten had little to do at short, and was out every strike, sometimes very closely indeed. Linen's reputation as a pitcher did not suffer on this occasion while his usual success followed him in batting. Collins, at centre-field, and while relieving Rogers as catcher, fielded most admirably, three well judged fly catches falling to his credit. Northrup, though not as reliable as usual on the first base, was most efficient at the bat, as was Oliver, who in addition made two splendid fly catches. The only demerit of Thomas was a wild throw to the first base, while the remainder of his fielding and his batting were equally praiseworthy. It would be unjust to conclude without commending the umpire, Mr. Dusenberry, who certainly filled that post in an able and satisfactory manner, his promptness being generally noticed. The best feeling was shown on both sides, and the departure of the train was the signal of hearty cheers from both Clubs for their rivals in the game.

abstract: Thirty gentlemen, calling themselves the "Union Electoral Committee," have recently  put forth an "Address to the Union Men of New-York," two columns in length, which was published in the TIMES of Saturday last.
lead_paragraph: Thirty gentlemen, calling themselves the "Union Electoral Committee," have recently put forth an "Address to the Union Men of New-York," two columns in length, which was published in the TIMES of Saturday last. We have examined it with some care. It is remarkable, both for what is in it, and for what is not. The public mind was anxious to know how the ten Union men placed on the Douglas electoral ticket were to cast their votes; whether it was agreed or understood that they were to cast them for BELL, or for DOUGLAS; or whether there was no agreement about it, but only an understanding that they were gentlemen who could be "manipulated." On these points we find, in this report of the result of the Committee's labors, some insinuations, some "generalities," more or less vague and glittering, but no definite and positive information. Perhaps, as it was an address to the "Union men," who were to be called on to vote the ticket, it was deemed unadvisable to be too explicit on this point. However, "all's not lost that is delayed," and, unless we mistake the temper of the public mind, information on that point, definite and positive, must be soon forthcoming, or the people will mark their disapprobation of the transaction in a manner which will be definite and positive enough.

abstract: We are gratified to find, by an article in the Boston Courier, that the Presidential election is over. We had looked forward to six or  eight weeks of contention and political wrang  ling, at the end of which time the problem might be solved.
lead_paragraph: We are gratified to find, by an article in the Boston Courier, that the Presidential election is over. We had looked forward to six or eight weeks of contention and political wrang ling, at the end of which time the problem might be solved. But the Courier announces that "LINCOLN is already defeated," and as the Express copies it with a good deal of exultation, we suppose there must be something in it.

abstract: The American State Council assembled at Schenectady yesterday, pursuant to a call issued by Gen. SCROGGS, the President. A large number of delegates were present--divided, however, into two classes: one, led by ERASTUS BROOKS, AMOS H. PRESCOTT and JESSE C. DANN, in favor of BELL and EVERETT; and the other, led by Messrs.
lead_paragraph: The American State Council assembled at Schenectady yesterday, pursuant to a call issued by Gen. SCROGGS, the President. A large number of delegates were present -- divided, however, into two classes: one, led by ERASTUS BROOKS, AMOS H. PRESCOTT and JESSE C. DANN, in favor of BELL and EVERETT; and the other, led by Messrs. SCROGGS, LOWNSBURY, HUESTED and others, favoring LINCOLN and HAMLIN for the Presidency. The Bell and Everett men were largely in the majority, and eventually had everything their own way. A preliminary caucus was held by them, at which a Committee was appointed to wait on Gen. SCROGGS and request him to resign, but this request he declined to comply with. He also declined various other propositions made by them, in consequence of which it was resolved to meet in Convention with Gen. SCROGGS as President, but to take the business immediately into their own hands. As soon as the regular Convention was called to order a scene of the most ludicrous confusion commenced, which was only ended by the resignation of the Chair by Mr. SCROGGS, who, with his friends, left the Convention. Business then proceeded uninterruptedly, Gen. PRESCOTT being called to preside. A Committee on Credentials and Permanent Officers was appointed, who reported, of course, in favor of giving seats only to those who approved of the union with the Douglas Democracy on an electoral ticket, which union was fully indorsed. Gen. PRESCOTT was selected as President for the ensuing year, and JESSE C. DANN as Vice-President. A State Committee of fifteen also appointed. The question of suitable candidates to be supported for the State officers was referred to the State Committee, with power. Gen. SCROGGS and the other seceding members subsequently met at another hall, and effected a separate organization, of which Mr. SCROGGS was elected President for the ensuing year, and Mr. DUGANNE Vice-President. The action of the other body was denounced, and all union with the Democracy was deprecated. A full report of the proceedings will be found elsewhere.

abstract: On Monday night, the Fourth Ward Police made a descent upon a house of a prostitution kept at No. 6 James-street, by Adolphe Marks and his wife Mary, and arrested the keepers, together with ten abandoned females who were its inmates. Marks and his wife were held to bail to answer at Court, and the others ...
lead_paragraph: On Monday night, the Fourth Ward Police made a descent upon a house of a prostitution kept at No. 6 James-street, by Adolphe Marks and his wife Mary, and arrested the keepers, together with ten abandoned females who were its inmates. Marks and his wife were held to bail to answer at Court, and the others were disposed of as vagrants. The complaint was made by a young girl named Mary Ann Murphy, who stated that about a week ago the woman Marks hired her to do housework, but on the night of her arrival at the house, ordered her to follow the course of the other female inmates of the house. She refused, and on the following night she received a similar order. She refused again, and then started to leave the house, but Marks' wife seized her and beat her unmercifully. One of the vile inmates of the house also made an attack upon her, and bit one of her fingers nearly off. The girl, continuing to resist, the wretches set a large dog upon her. The animal threw her to the floor, and bit her hand completely through the palm. After a desperate struggle she got out of the house, and made her way to the Fourth Ward Police-station, where she told what had occurred. The girl was promptly conveyed to Bellevue Hospital where she lies in a precarious situation. Her hand is terribly lacerated, and it is feared tetanus may set in. The Police then started for the infamous den, and arrested the parties, as above stated.

abstract: A DOMESTIC SQUALL IN THE STREET. -- The residents in the vicinity of Nelson-place and Eighth-street were treated yesterday to a scene which is at least of uncommon occurrence in that neighborhood. A well-dressed and moustached man, while passing up Nelson-place, was overtaken by a plainly but neatly-dressed woman, who accosted him in terms more forcible than polite. He pushed her away, and she screamed "murder" loudly. Windows flew up in every direction, and a crowd soon gathered. The woman, meantime, continued her tirade, and the man tried in vain to stop the flow of words. In return for some remark from him, she dealt him a blow across his face with the handle of her parasol, snapping the handle like a pipestem. Seizing the other end, she continued to belabor him over the face and shoulders until there was very little of it left. He managed to get the remnant from her hand, and tried to quiet her with soft words, but her rage was for some time unappeasable. At length, however, her passion having exhausted itself, she consented to walk along with him, but her countenance did not indicate that she felt any very great pleasure in his company. The accusation which she brought against him was that, after having seduced her from her husband, home and friends, he had deserted her, and left her to prostitution or starvation. The officer on that street was probably on the other end of his beat, or both parties might have found quarters in the Station-house.

abstract: We have said that the main point in the Address of the Union Electoral Committee, was their statement of the substantial similarity of their views on the Slavery question with those of the Douglas men, by way of accounting for their uniting with them in one Electoral ticket.
lead_paragraph: We have said that the main point in the Address of the Union Electoral Committee, was their statement of the substantial similarity of their views on the Slavery question with those of the Douglas men, by way of accounting for their uniting with them in one Electoral ticket. They proceed to admit that they have no expectation of the success of DOUGLAS or of BELL, and that this union is formed not in the hope of electing them; but of defeating LINCOLN, and thus throwing the election into the House. They admit that there will be evils connected with such a result; but without specifying what these evils are, they proceed to say that they will be less than the evils of the election of Mr. LINCOLN, which they equally fail to specify.

abstract: The attempts that have been made to recover the Atlantic Telegraph Cable have proved how erroneously it was constructed. The heavy wire covering, twisted round the central core and  meant to constitute the main stay of strength, was found to be quite rotten, while the copper wires and gutta-percha of the core were always in good condition.
lead_paragraph: -- The attempts that have been made to recover the Atlantic Telegraph Cable have proved how erroneously it was constructed. The heavy wire covering, twisted round the central core and meant to constitute the main stay of strength, was found to be quite rotten, while the copper wires and gutta-percha of the core were always in good condition. In some instances, the cable was lifted solely by the strength of the copper wires. In view of these facts, it is suggested by a London scientific journal that the cable has been prematurely abandoned. Owing to the rottenness of the wire covering it may be impossible to raise the cable, but if the core be sound it may be possible yet to work the line across the entire Atlantic.

abstract: In another column may be seen the announcement of the Eleventh Session of the New-York Medical College, an institution which, if it cannot be legitimately numbered among the time honored of the city, certainly has a just claim to be ranked among the hard-working, useful and energetic of the many ...
lead_paragraph: In another column may be seen the announcement of the Eleventh Session of the New-York Medical College, an institution which, if it cannot be legitimately numbered among the time honored of the city, certainly has a just claim to be ranked among the hard-working, useful and energetic of the many semmaries of learning which, in different forms, fill the city. This, too, has another claim to public attention and sympathy from the care which it gives to the sick poor. Every day during the week its portals are to be thrown open and the "lame, the halt, and the blind" may freely come and fill its large lecture-rooms, at the medical and surgical clinics, where the sick will be carefully examined and prescribed for by the members of the faculty themselves, who are, in their various special branches, ranked among the foremost practitioners of the city, and consequently of the United States and the world.

abstract: A great many people may be out of town, "doing" the Spring, the Mountains, and the Seaside, but it is no less a fact that great numbers of people are in town. The theatres thereto bear witness. Last night, for instance, more persons could possibly by an exhaustive process, have been pushed and squeezed into Wallack's, Niblo's, Laura Keene's ...
lead_paragraph: A great many people may be out of town, "doing" the Spring, the Mountains, and the Seaside, but it is no less a fact that great numbers of people are in town. The theatres thereto bear witness. Last night, for instance, more persons could possibly by an exhaustive process, have been pushed and squeezed into Wallack's, Niblo's, Laura Keene's and the Winter Garden, than were actually there, but, unprovided with seats, and compromised for standing room, they would have had neither entertainment nor accommodation. So far, our places of amusement have not suffered from the Summer emigration, and they have everything to hope, with the great things talked about, from the Autumn immigration. But of that hearafter.
headline: {'main': 'Amusements.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Amusements.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -The Havana journals of the 23d inst. discuss, with some acrimony, the "misconduct of Mexico" in refusing to permit the exportation of "coolies" from Yucatan and other Gulf States to Cuba. The Prensa de la Habana insists that it is necessary for Mexico to devote herself in every possible way to the good of the Spanish colonies, if she is to find internal peace and be restored to consideration abroad. The meaning of all which it is perhaps not very difficult to divine. The Cubans have evidently been inoculated with the hope of a new slave-trade from the Caribbean coast, to be guaranteed under the pleasing name of "An organized emigration," by the supremacy of Spanish influence in Mexico. The Indians of Yucatan, as the Havana journalists naively argue, can be of no possible use to Mexico, which is too much distracted to hope for a remunerative system of national industry in a long time to come. The best thing, therefore, which can be done for both countries, is to allow Spain to export these superfluous arms to her own thriving colony, while she is at work pacifying the Republic and preparing the way for its new destinies, under the benignant restoration of indirect Spanish influence, if not of a direct Spanish authority.

abstract: DETROIT, Saturday, Aug. 25, 1860. SEWARD at Chicago, that the Republicans would enter into the contest with but small enthusiasm for "Old Abe," and that rail-splitting would be anything but popular, at least during the warm months.

abstract: We regret to learn that there is a disposition, on the part of very many young women at service in this City and elsewhere, to look upon all labor-saving machines, and especially washing-machines, with distrust. So far as French's Conical Washing-Machine is concerned, we know that this is a very unwise policy, and positively wrong and injurious, both to the young women and their employers. This machine will lighten the labor, save the hands, and relieve many of the wearing and disagreeable features of hand-washing, but is not designed to, and will not, take the place of a single young woman at service, we feel confident. If young women would improve their condition, they would do well to avail themselves of all such aids for performing household work. We have tried this Washer, and it is already used in several of our institutions in charge of the Sisters, where it is highly spoken of -- Metropolitan Record.
lead_paragraph: We regret to learn that there is a disposition, on the part of very many young women at service in this City and elsewhere, to look upon all labor-saving machines, and especially washing-machines, with distrust. If young women would improve their condition, they would do well to avail themselves of all such aids for performing household work. We have tried this Washer, and it is already used in several of our institutions in charge of the Sisters, where it is highly spoken of -- Metropolitan Record.

abstract: -- Letters to the Leavenworth, K.T. Times, dated at the Camp on Platte River, two miles west of Fort Kearney, Aug. 10, give details of the progress of the Southern Column of the Kioway Expedition. The expedition left the Camp on Arkansas River on the 28th. On the 6th it came up with a party of Indians numbering nearly 500, at Supper Creek. In the skirmish which ensued a number of them were killed, with but trifling loss to the expedition. On the day that the letter was written it was reported that 1,500 Kioways had just crossed the Platte River with 1,000 head of extra ponies. A battle was soon expected.

abstract: The Chicago Press and Tribune tells of two unsuccessful attempts at kidnapping recently made in that city. A party of four men, on Tuesday last, engaged a hackman to take a party to a railroad station three miles out of the city, promising to pay him $50 for the job. It leaked out, however, that some colored persons who had been drugged were to be of the company, and officers attached to the City Marshal's establishment succeeded in frustrating the project. On the same day, BILL, a colored man, who had recently come to Chicago with his two children -- ANDREW and MARTHA -- was persuaded by the man for whom he had been to work to take a ride out of the city with him. BILL was soon got under the influence of liquor, and speedily lost all consciousness. When he came to himself he was still asleep in the wagon in which he had been riding, his companion having left him. He thought it best to make his way home as rapidly as possible, taking with him a small parcel which was lying in the bottom of the vehicle. This package he ascertained was a bottle of chloroform, and around it was this document:

abstract: -- It has been given out that JOE SMITH, Jr., who has recently been made "head of the Mormon Church," has summoned the faithful to return to Nauvoo, Hancock County, in this State, where their ancient temple stands. A large tract of land near the steamboat landing on the Mississippi has been purchased, it is said, for the occupancy of the Mormons, and two hundred are daily expected to arrive. Calls for precinct meetings throughout the county are published in the Warsaw Bulletin of this week, to take "immediate and decided measures" to counteract the Mormon movement, and the excitement among the people in that region is represented as increasing daily, the public peace being threatened, and another Mormon war, like that of several years ago in the same locality, being almost certain, if the proposed movement of young JOE SMITH is carried out. Possibly it is a "false alarm," but the people of Hancock County evidently believe that there is real cause for apprehension. -- Chicago Journal, Friday.

abstract: We have heretofore stated what we understand to be the exact point involved in the present stage of the Slavery controversy among us, viz., whether slave property is to be taken to stand on the same ground as other property under the Constitution of the United States; whether the master's title to his ...
lead_paragraph: We have heretofore stated what we understand to be the exact point involved in the present stage of the Slavery controversy among us, viz., whether slave property is to be taken to stand on the same ground as other property under the Constitution of the United States; whether the master's title to his slave is to he held under that Constitution to he on an equality with his title to his horse, and entitled to the same consideration and protection. Gov. WISE so understands it, for in his recent letter he states that the result of the success of the Breckinridge ticket will be "the triumph of the vital doctrine of protection to persons and property in the common territories of the United States." Of course he means by "persons and property," slaveholders and their slaves. This is plain, from his denouncing non-intervention because it does not "leave slave property alone at the mercy of Federal Power," but "lands, too, are at its mercy." The only answer to this claim for protection to slave property is the denial of its equality with other property.
headline: {'main': 'The Democrats on Slave Property.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Democrats on Slave Property.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Stephen A. Baker et al. vs. Henry C. Cornish. -- This was a motion before Justice SUTHERLAND to discharge the defendant from arrest. The plaintiffs claimed that the defendant came to them and purchased a bill of goods amounting to $662 13 for cash. At the time of purchase the defendant paid $332 on account, but as plaintiffs alleged, the defendant refused to pay the remainder. It was also alleged that at the time of the purchase the defendant made false representations as to his solvency. The defendant now asked to be discharged, as, by the morning papers, it appeared that the purchase was for cash, and therefore there could have been no false representations to obtain credit.

abstract: -- The Fall business ebgins to revive. The City is crowded with strangers. The crowds about the hotels look as if a mass meeting was being held at their doors. The places of amusement are thronged. Merchants are preparing for their annual harvest, and everything indicates the approach of an excellent business season. Fashion, however has not yet returned. The season at the watering-places is later than usual. Saratoga continues to be crowded, though from the cooler sea-exposures of Newport there is a more general flight homeward. The Fifth-avenue houses are still closed, and will be for a fortnight longer. Most of the people who crowd the streets and theatres are strangers -- business men from the West, or Southerners returning from their Northern tour. When the Prince arrives, we shall doubtless have still another rush from the country.

abstract: In re John Stanley. -- The petitioner in this case was convicted before the Court of Special Sessions and sentenced to three months' confinement. abstract: Advices from Illinois inform us that the citizens of Hancock County, Ill., were exercised in spirit, in consequence of a reported intention of the Mormons to reoccupy Nauvoo. If any reliance is to be placed in the declaration of BRIGHAM YOUNG, such a contingency as this is far from probable.
lead_paragraph: Advices from Illinois inform us that the citizens of Hancock County, Ill., were exercised in spirit, in consequence of a reported intention of the Mormons to reoccupy Nauvoo. If any reliance is to be placed in the declaration of BRIGHAM YOUNG, such a contingency as this is far from probable. In a speech delivered very recently, in full conclave of the Saints in Salt Lake City, the Mormon Prophet expressly disavowed any design to change the quarters of the tribe. He declared it to be the settled purpose of the Mormons to occupy the land they now hold, to improve its capacities for the support of a large population, to develop its resources in every way, and to resist any attempt to deprive them of the privileges they enjoy. It is true that Brother BRIGHAM is sometimes insincere, not to say hypocritical, but it is also fair to presume that he is shrewd enough to know when he and his people are well settled. The Mormons have had but too great success in their defiance of the Government and in the resulting confirmation of their own power. They are very unlikely to relinquish the eligible locality which is now in their undisputed possession, or to make rash ventures for the sake of a possible advantage. Least of all, are they likely to return to Illinois, whence they were driven with ignominy and at a serious loss to themselves. The panic of the people of Hancock county, therefore, is needless.
headline: {'main': 'A Needless Panic.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Needless Panic.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: ELI THAYER, Republican Member of Congress from Massachusetts, is a thorough believer in Popular Sovereignty. He scouts the whole system of Congressional intervention in the affairs of Territories.
lead_paragraph: ELI THAYER, Republican Member of Congress from Massachusetts, is a thorough believer in Popular Sovereignty. He scouts the whole system of Congressional intervention in the affairs of Territories. He would have the people thereof left "perfectly five to form and regulate their domestic interference form in their own way, " -- without any interference from Congress or the federal Government. He believes they have a right thus to govern themselves; he think they can do it for more wisely and honestly than the Federal authorities can govern them; and he has not the r[???]est shadow of a doubt that the interest the freedom would he perfectly safe if left in their hands.

abstract: THE MAYOR AND THE FIREMEN'S TORCHLIGHT PROCESSION IN HONOR OF THE PRINCE OF WALES. At a meeting of the Board of Engineers and foremen of the Fire Department, held on Tuesday evening, the  question of having a torchlight procession in honor of ...
lead_paragraph: THE MAYOR AND THE FIREMEN's TORCHLIGHT PROCESS[???] IN HONOR OF THE PRINCE OF WALES, -- AT a meeting of the Board of Engineers and foremen of the Fire Department, held on Tuesday evening, the question of having a torchlight procession in honor of the Prince of Wales, on his arrival in the City, was brought up, and some members having opposed it on the ground of the great expense, one member announced that the Mayor had intimated his readiness to bear the expense of music and torches. A Committee was then appointed to wait upon him, and yesterday, headed by the Chief Engineer, they paid their respects to the Mayor. A long conversation was had, which resulted in the Mayor pledging himself personally for twenty-five hundred dollars -- Viz.; $1,500 tor the music, and $1,000 for the tore[???]res. The Department intend to have a grand torchlight parade on the 13th October, provided he shall arrive at the appointed time. Meanwhile the Committee are to make further arrangements, engage the bands, &c. The Committee are to have a meeting on Saturday evening next, at the house of Chief Engineer DECKER, to perfect the programme. The understanding with his Honor and the Committee seemed to have been satisfactory to all concerned.

abstract: The Quarterly Report of the Inspector of Police, for the quarter ending the 1st inst., was submitted yesterday to the Police Commissioners. By this report it appers that the Police force consists of 6 captains, 32 sergeants, 29 detailed men, 171 patrolmen, and 18 doormen, making a total of 256.
lead_paragraph: The Quarterly Report of the Inspector of Police, for the quarter ending the 1st inst., was submitted yesterday to the Police Commissioners. By this report it appers that the Police force consists of 6 captains, 32 sergeants, 29 detailed men, 171 patrolmen, and 18 doormen, making a total of 256. The whole number of arrests were 4,650, showing an increase of 1,421 over the number embraced in the report of the last quarter. Of the whole number, 3,392 were males and 1,267 were females; 2,673 were married; 3,129 could read and write, and 1,530 could do neither; 1,472 persons were accommodated with lodgings in the Station-houses; 411 lost children were found by the Police and restored to their parents; 222 cases for violating ordinances were reported to the Corporation Attorney; 168 cases of violation of Excise Sunday Liquor laws reported to the District Attorney; $2,663 48 was taken from prisoners and lodgers and returned to them.

abstract: Our special Washington dispatch mentions a rumor which is gaining currency at the Capital, to the effect that the recent increased activity in the Navy-yards indicates an intention on the part of the Administration to pick a quarrel with Spain in the Gulf of Mexico, as an excuse for a descent on Cuba. All the absent Foreign Ministers are  said to have been telegraphed to on the subject.

abstract: Mr. George W. Malcom, residing at Forked River, N.J., was passing the corner of Canal and West streets at a late hour on Tuesday night, when he was assaulted by several men, who knocked him down, beat him, and after tearing nearly all his clothes from his person, robbed him of $35 and then ran away. Malcom went in search of a policeman, and found Officer Robinson, of the Eighth Precinct, who started in pursuit, and soon arrested Michael MCCarty on a charge of being one of the robbers. Malcom identified him as such, and he was locked up to await examination.
lead_paragraph: Mr. George W. abstract: Periodically, a visit to the State Prison at Sing Sing becomes an act of propriety, in view of the ever  changing aspects of the little world that exists within those dreary walls. The crowds who came to the  Camp-Meeting, last week, furnished a continual ...
lead_paragraph: Periodically, a visit to the State Prison at Sing Sing becomes an act of propriety, in view of the ever changing aspects of the little world that exists within those dreary walls. The crowds who came to the Camp-Meeting, last week, furnished a continual influx of curious visitors, anxious to take a peep, if but once in life, at the strange and impressive scenes visible inside the doors where no man seeks to enter except with the express understanding that it is his privilege to retire at will. One of the TIMES' reporters found himself numbered with this curious crowd on a sunshiny afternoon, and, like the rest, presented himself at the guard-house on the [???] before the prison, to await the good pleasure of the presiding griffin, popularly supposed to be pacing a well-worn walk, and hugging a formidable musket at this point. Said griffin presented, on this occasion, the aspect of a handsome, youngish man, with a mustache [???]ommanding the in [???]ant approbation of an eye whose [???] pro[???] were orthodox -- for, in the chi[???] day, [???] of shaven and shorn lips, checks and [???], is no orthodoxy in aesthetics. Presiding griffin was [???] acquainted with our reporter's desire when he [???] immediate and courteous response, in a pleasant tone of voice, "Well, you'll have to wait a [???]." So taking a seat by the side of the griffin, the reporter waited a spell, and employed his eyes [???] [???] the beautiful scene visible from this [???] point. The west shore of the Hudson, with the bright [???]aters between, for[???]ed the piet[???] -- a picture which [???] acquaintance with the various views on the [???] permits us to say is not surpassed on that river, and, consequently, not in the world. On the right hand, Haverstraw Bay : on the left, Tap[???]aan Zee; dotted with innumerable sail, and gleaming in the bright Midsummer sun; on the western shore, Haverstraw dimly visible just above, with the towering [???] of the High Torn Mountain over[???] the [???] [???]ses; directly opposite where we sit, [???} Lake, cuddled picturesquely on the [???], in a nook that set out to make a gap in the mountain range, but for some reason unexplained did not carry out that purpose; below, the Hook Mountain, [???] forward and upward like a type of American [???]gress in civilization (which, report has it, you know, is ever "onward and upward") : and Nyack village lying in beauty near the rugged mountain's side : gradually sloping shore between, and [???] among [???] thousand other American land and water [???].

abstract: DEATH ON THE STEAMER PERSIA. Yesterday forenoon, a short time previous to the sailing of the steamship Persia, from Jersey City, CHARLES KINGSBURY, the steward, was prostrated with a fit, three of  which he had in succession.
lead_paragraph: DEATH ON THE STEAMER PERSIA. -- Yesterday forenoon, a short time previous to the sailing of the steamship Persia, from Jersey City, CHARLES KINGSBURY, the steward, was prostrated with a fit, three of which he had in succession. Some of the employes were ordered to proceed with him in a yawl to New-York for the purpose of having him removed to the hospital, but before gaining the other shore he expired. The body was brought on board the ship again where it was viewed by Coroner GAFFNEY, and on a certificate from the ship's surgeon that deceased died of apoplexy, a certificate of burial was given. Mr. KINGSBURY was about 50 years of age, had been in the employ of the Company about 16 years, and leaves a life and family in England.

abstract: Ashacl A[???]ott vs. The Society for Amcliorating the Condition of the Jews. -- The defendants in thus case applied in the Supreme Court to set aside a judgement for $11,653 cs. Which had been obtained against them by default. From the statement made in the case it appeared that there was a dissension in the Society, which had resulted in a new body of Managers superseding the old body. The plaintiff, as Financial Secretary the party, had served another of his colleagues with the process in the suit. The new body. Who claimed to be the defendants resited the claims as bogus. The [???]udge decided to vacate the judgement.

abstract: One of the most curious of the "signs of the times," with which the public has recently been edified, is the large space occupied by the subject of gymnastics in the debates of the American Institute of Instruction.
lead_paragraph: One of the most curious of the "signs of the times," with which the public has recently been edified, is the large space occupied by the subject of gymnastics in the debates of the American Institute of Instruction. What with the steady preaching of the school of muscular Christianity during the past few years, and the more went practical illustration of the power of the human arm so kindly afforded to the civilized world by our distinguished countryman JOHN C. HEKNAN, Esq., the human body has attained to a dignity and importance in the eyes of instructors of youth which a quarter of a century ago, few people were sanguine enough to hope that it would ever enjoy. From being thoroughly scorned and despised as a, very vile hindrance to the workings of the soul, it has come to he looked upon as something to be petted and developed at any cost -- something which has to be got info thorough order, before anything whatever can ho expected of the intellect.

abstract: A meeting of "front bricklayers" was held at the Jackson House, on the corner of Greenwich-avenue and Thirteenth-street, last evening, for the purpose of resisting the "Bricklayers Protective Union."
lead_paragraph: A meeting of "front bricklayers" was held at the Jackson House, on the corner of Greenwich-avenue and Thirteenth-street, last evening, for the purpose of resisting the "Bricklayers Protective Union." It appears that the front bricklayers are a class of men who do such fine work as the fronts of houses only, and that their wages are from twenty-five to fifty cents per day more than the other class of bricklayers who do other kinds of work. The latter have organized them selves into a Union, and their constitution prohibits any member thereof from working with [???]bers. The consequence is that when a man who is not a member of the Union is working with one who is, the latter insists that he shall either "quit the building" or be will leave himself. The employers sustain those who have not joined the Union, and are generally inclined to prefer them to the other,but the combination is strong against them, and they are, consequently, obliged to protest themselves, as the Union pays something towards the support of such of its members as are out work. The Union at first charged but twenty-five cents initiation fee, and now they have raised it to $2, so that even if the front bricklayers were willing to join the society, they do not feel willing to pay such a sum, nor to have themselves placed on a level with the members as regards wages, which it is allege, is what the latter want. The front bricklayers have therefore, formed a temporary organization to resist the Society, and in imitation thereof give assistance to such men as have not joined it, and who have been deprived of work in consequence. This assistance is, however, by voluntary subscription. One hundred fifty names have already been enrolled, and they meet fortnightly simply to show that they will not join any society which has for its object the dietation to employers or workmen, whom the former shall employ, or at what wages the latter may work. At the meeting last evening, a gentleman from the Society informed the meeting that he intended to resign, and enroll his name with the non-society men. He further stated that he had given notice to the Socicty that unless they came to some arrangement, he should withdraw his name from the roll. The announcement was received with loud cheers. Several other persons signed their names to the roll during the evening, and after a speech from the Chair in support of a union between capital and labor, the meeting adjourned.

abstract: Judge NELSON has sent down the order for the ensuing Special Term of this Court to be held on the 12th of September. The Clerk desires the Bar to take notice that there will be no jury calendar, but an appeal, argument and equity calendar only. The appeal calendar will be taken up on the first day, and parties must order their Copies of Apotics at once, to have them ready at the opening of the Court.

abstract: LAURA KEENE'S. -- Mrs. JOHN WOOD took he[???] bencrit last night. We will not say the house was crowded, for language is at a loss on such an occasion. Before the performance commenced, some hundreds of people, who had bought their tickets, but were unable to obtain seats, exchanged them for another night. Every inch of standing room was appropriated, and probably if the theatre could have benb suddenly doubled, its size would not have had "verge enough" for those who sought admission. The performances were the "American cousin." and a petit comedy. well known to the habitues of theatres, called "Jenny Lind." It was anticipated that Mrs. WOOD would make a speech, but Mr. JEFFERSON said that she was too nervous and very amiably and adroitly addressed the audience in her behalf -- thanking them for the overflowing audience which Mrs. WOOD had deservedly attracted, informing them also that his own benefit would occur on Friday. Mr. JEFFERSON needs no ovation, but he deserves one.

abstract: The Superintendents of the Poor for the County of Kings submitted their annual report yesterday. There were submitted to the Almshouse during the year, 2,816 persons; discharged 2,806; remaining, 307. This institution is supported at a cost of $31,257; received from labor of inmates, $11,060.57; net expense to the county, $20,256.26.

abstract: The Republicans of the Eastern District of Brooklyn held a mass ratification meeting in the Odeon last evening. The principal address was delivered by Hon. HENRY B. STANTON. The proceedings were interspersed with vocal and instrumental music.
lead_paragraph: The Republicans of the Eastern District of Brooklyn held a mass ratification meeting in the Odeon last evening. The principal address was delivered by Hon. HENRY B. STANTON. The proceedings were interspersed with vocal and instrumental music. There was a large audience in attendance, which was increased during the evening by the arrival of the Eight, Ninth, Fourteenth, Fifteenth and Nineteenth Ward Wide-Awake Clubs. The enthusiasm was great. The meeting was held under the auspices of the Eastern District Republican Association. An organization was effected by electing Dr. WARREN chairman, and other officers usual on such occasions. A series of resolutions, indorsing the Federal and State nominations of the Republican Party were presented and unanimously adopted. After a song by the Prarie Songsters, the Chairman introduced the Hon. HENRY B. STANTON. He commenced with a review of the positions of the fragments of parties opposing the election of LINCOLN and HAMLIN. He said they out the negro under one arm and the Constitution under the other, and wherever they went there was slavery established. The last two Administrations had done much to propogate that pernicious idea, and in tins election the people were called upon to decide whether they would explode the heresy that the Constitution carried Slavery into the Territories or not.

abstract: An investigation relative to an alleged attempt to swindle several Insurance Companies out of a very large amount, was commenced on Wednesday, before Justice CONNOLLY. In appears that in May last the bark E.A. Kinsman, with her cargo, was insured for a voyage to the port of Havana, and that before reaching that port the vessel ran on a reof and with her  cargo, was a total loss.
lead_paragraph: An investigation relative to an alleged attempt to swindle several Insurance Companies out of a very large amount, was commenced on Wednesday, before Justice CONNOLLY. In appears that in May last the bark E.A. Kinsman, with her cargo, was insured for a voyage to the port of Havana, and that before reaching that port the vessel ran on a reof and with her cargo, was a total loss. The policies were taken out from the Sun Mutual. the New-York Mutant, the Anchor and the Great Western Insurance Companies, and they wore recently called upon to se[???]le, but declined, on the ground that there had been fraud in obtaining the policies. In an affidavit made by the representatives of the companies before the Magistrate, they charge that the persons interested in the vessel had forged names of respectable mercha[???] to bills of lading and other papers, whereby the insurance companies were led to believe that the cargo was much more valuable than it really was; also that these persons had willfully run their vessel upon the rocks, thus causing her loss, as well as that of the cargo. The following is a copy of the affidavits.

abstract: It is certain that the Austrian statesmen and Generals were convinced, even previous to 1848, of the impossibility of holding the Lombardo-Venetian territory, except by the force of arms; this truth, then applicable to the united two provinces, applies now still more to Venetia alone.
lead_paragraph: It is certain that the Austrian statesmen and Generals were convinced, even previous to 1848, of the impossibility of holding the Lombardo-Venetian territory, except by the force of arms; this truth, then applicable to the united two provinces, applies now still more to Venetia alone. The inhabitants of Venetia do not wish to live under the rule of the House of Ha[???]sburg on any account whatever; the Government, after so many mismanagements, finds it impossible to satisfy them by friendly approaches; and the people, who have fed for so long a time on hopes of liberation, will only submit to be ruled henceforth under compulsion of its force. Such deep-rooted aversion on the part of its subjects would shake the courage of even the most resolute Government, especially when other nations reproach it with the rigor of its policy. And financial reasons make it still more difficult to keep up such a Government. The Lombardo-Venetian Kingdom has always been a source of revenue for the Empire, whatever may have been said to the contrary to the other subjects of the Emperor, in order to arouse their hatred against the Italian possessions of the Crown, which were said to be very ungrateful for the favors they received. These two provinces have paid far more taxes than were expended on their Government and internal development; their contribution to the expenses of the General Government was large in proportion. At present the revenues from Lombardy have ceased to flow into the treasury, while the occupation of Venice still demands an enormous military budget. The prosperity of this province must, under present circumstances, inevitably retrograde,the amount o[???] revenues diminish, and all commercial activity be checked by the insecurity of the future. And whilst the revenues diminish, the Government will be little inclined to, pay the expenses of a province whose future possession is so very doubtful.

abstract: The Detroit Tribune gives some rather start  ling details of Democratic malfeasance and offi  cial corruption. The story is but a repetition of what we have heard from other sources.
lead_paragraph: The Detroit Tribune gives some rather start ling details of Democratic malfeasance and offi cial corruption. The story is but a repetition of what we have heard from other sources. The developments which were brought to light by the energetic efforts of the Co[???] Committee had propared the public to believe at most any story of official mis[???]conduel and to regard the honesty of Federal office -holders the exception other than the rule: so that supplementary disclosures, no matter ho[???]ures markatable, have come to be considered simply as illustrations of the original text The exposures of our Detroit cotemporary refer exclusiverly to the affairs of Wayne County. but the record is sufficiently ample, ospecially when so small an area of territory proved itself able to sustain such grievous burdens as those which were imposed upon it by a Democratic Administration.

abstract: The three African lads brought to this port on board of the derelict slaver Kibby, are still detained at the Eldridge-street Prison, no reply having yet been ...
lead_paragraph: The three African lads brought to this port on board of the derelict slaver Kibby, are still detained at the Eldridge-street Prison, no reply having yet been received, from the President to the benevolent suggestion of the District-Attorney, that they should be transferred to the Colored Orphan Asylum of this City for care and instruction. They occupy a room in the second story of the northwest corner of the building, with a colored seaman named RILEY, and all three sleep in one bed. Although they are made as comfortable as is possible in so small a place, their confined quarters must necessarily be unhealthy.

abstract: -- Gov. Packer, of Pennsylvania, has been unfortunate, On going into his wine cellar a few days since he found that his stock of liquors had decreased in an alarming manner -- that it had in fact vanished entirely. His suspicions at once rested upon a young man Who acted as chief butler. By procuring his speedy arrest he recovered nearly $100 worth of the and branding and $25 in moucy, the proceeds of the sales which had been effected. The Governor did not relish this method of converting him to total abstinence Principles.

abstract: One of those instances which now and then show the silver lining of Slavery, occurred on Tuesday, at Philadelphia. PASSMORE WILLIAMSON, that moral sleuth-bound, whose scent
lead_paragraph: One of those instances which now and then show the silver lining of Slavery, occurred on Tuesday, at Philadelphia. PASSMORE WILLIAMSON, that moral sleuth-bound, whose scent for the slave is as been as that of the most accomplished Cuban beagle, discovered in the person of a female servant, attendant upon a Mr. CONQCEST, of Virginia. How residing in Philadelphia, an involuntary victim of the great wrong. The girl it was reasonable to presume, could not be acquainted with her rights.In the ture [???]vangelical spirit.WILLIAMSON seems to have indoctrinated her with the principles of the Constitution, as interpreted by the Supreme Court: and gaining a momentary in[???] over her mind. Procured her Signature to an application for a writ of habeas [???] addressed to Judge LUPLOW, of the [???]er Sessions. The wrir was granted; the [???] was produced; and there in the pre[???] of the multitude did that faithful colored woman attest her undying loyalty in the best of masters and her determination not only to adhere to him among the actual temptations to liberty, but to return with him if need were to the house of bondage itself. She Started that she had received nothing but kindness from the respondent, -- the latest exhibition of his generous temper being that "he had taken her all around town, and sl[???]wn her the sights:" and with acute sense of the proprieties of life, worthy of the parent Caucasian. She declared that after such delicate attentions "she did not think of would be honorable to leave him."

abstract: The arrival at Madeira of the new steam gunboat Dacotch has been announced. We have a report of her outward trip. lead_paragraph: OPENING OF BIDS FOR CITY WORK. -- In the Street Department, yesterday, the following bids were opened and the awards made: Setting curb, , in One Hundred and Sixteenth-street, from Third-avenue to the Harlem River, and in Sixthavenue from One Hundred and Twelfth to One Hundred and Twenty-fifth streets, eight bids, awarded to WN. BAIRD, at $6,466,23; regulating and grading Fifty-fifty-street from Third to Fifth avenues and from Seventh to Eighth avenues, where not already done, eleven bids, awarded to THOS. CRIMMINS, at $6,320 05; regulating, grading and setting and resetting the curb and gutter stones in Reade-street from Broadway to City Hall-place, and Elm-street from Reade to Duane streets, awarded to WM. BAIRD, at $912 40; building a new engine for No. 39, one bid, awarded to C.E. HARTSHORN, at $1,970; regulating and grading the Eighth-avenue from Eighty-second to One Hundred and Second streets, seven bids, awarded to GEO. A. BUCKINGHAM & Co., at $32,201 77; flagging, &c., in Fifty-third-Street, from Eighth to Tenth avenues, ten bids, awarded to WILLIAM BAIRD, at $2,908. Flagging in Fifty-first-street, between Ninth and Tenth avenues, nine bids -- awarded to Wm. BAIRD, at $1,410 73. No bids were received for building a new steam fire-engine for Hose Company No. 5. The Street Commissioner will make a communication to the Common Council on the subject. Proposals for the purposes named below, were opened at the Finance Department, yesterday, and the contracts awarded as follows: Sewer in Cherry-street, from Gouverneur to Montgomery-street, awarded to THOS. CASEY, with surety in $1,000 -- five bids. Sewer in Thirteenth-street, from Hudson-street running 252 feet east, awarded to S.J. DUNN, surety $1,000 -- seven bids. Sewer in Second-avenue, from Seventy-ninth to Eighty-sixth-street, awarded to P. LYNCH, surety $1,000 -- six bids.

abstract: It is of course a well-recognized canon of esthetic law in all polite circles that it is impossible to make America picturesque or American life poetic. Mr. LONGFELLOW indeed takes us with him into pleasing glimpses of American forest scenery, and touches the heart with the pathetic incidents of an American love-story; but the sorrows ...
lead_paragraph: It is of course a well-recognized canon of esthetic law in all polite circles that it is impossible to make America picturesque or American life poetic. Mr. LONGFELLOW indeed takes us with him into pleasing glimpses of American forest scenery, and touches the heart with the pathetic incidents of an American love-story; but the sorrows of Acadia wear an old-world dress, and Evangeline drifted down the great Mississippi in the days before steam. Who shall dare ask us to look at the nature about us as if there lay upon it the same light that charmed the soul of Claude into his pencil; or to see the dreams of Phidias still breathing in the image of the Almighty as it treads the common ways of the Western World to-day?

abstract: On the 6th of this month, S. Camille Mathicu was arrested on a warrant issued by the Police Court, Second District, under the act of April 17, 1860, on the oath of his wife, who alleged that he had abandoned  her. The Justice, on the hearing, refused to take the ...
lead_paragraph: On the 6th of this month, S. Camille Mathicu was arrested on a warrant issued by the Police Court, Second District, under the act of April 17, 1860, on the oath of his wife, who alleged that he had abandoned her. The Justice, on the hearing, refused to take the evidence of the husband, although he offered himself as a witness to disprove the charges of his wife. The parties have brought reciprocal actions of divorce against each other, on the ground of adultery, the husband was ordered by the Police Justice to find bail in the sum of $300, to be of good behavior, and to secure the Payment of $5 weekly to his wife. Gabriel Ravel entered bail for him, and his counsel appealed to the Court of Special Sessions, where the case was this morning decided, sustaining the appeal, reversing the order of the Police Justice, discharging the bail, and entering an exhoneratur on the bond. It was conceded by the counsel for the Commissioners of Police Charities, &c., and by the Court, that the Justice below erred in refusing to take the evidence of the husband when he offered himself as a witness in his own behalf. This is the second time the defendant has been arrested and discharged. He was arrested once before by his wife, on a writ of ne exeat, just as he was leaving to fulfill his engagement with the Ravel troupe in Boston, and he was, on motion of his counsel, discharged by Judge SUTHERLAND.

abstract: Six or seven persons appeared on Thursday, before Justice CONNOLLY, and made complaints against the bogus Portuguese Countess, Senora Donna Pedro, alias Sarah J. Corkery, from all of which it appears that she has been swindling boarding-house keepers, hotel-keepers, livery-stable keepers, and ...
lead_paragraph: Six or seven persons appeared on Thursday, before Justice CONNOLLY, and made complaints against the bogus Portuguese Countess, Senora Donna Pedro, alias Sarah J. Corkery, from all of which it appears that she has been swindling boarding-house keepers, hotel-keepers, livery-stable keepers, and others, for the past nine year. Mr. Frederick W. Dieterney, of No. 30 New-street, testified that he knew her in 1851, that he believes her real name is Sarah J. Corkery, and that she is about forty years of age. He states that when he became acquainted with her, she represented that she owned a beautiful place on Staten Island, had $10,000 worth of diamonds, which were given her by her "dear father," who, she said, was King of Portugal, besides houses. &c. This valuable information cost him $300, which he loaned her. Mrs. Susan Ramsay, proprietress of the European House, No. 767 Broadway, testified that the lady had boarded at her house to the tune of $125, the first dollar of which she has not as yet seen, nor does she ever expect to be so favored. She told Mrs. Ramsay the old story about the "charming place" on Staten Island, the diamonds, horses. &c. After having boarded the lady for some weeks without receiving any remuneration, Mrs. Ramsay one day expressed an ardent desire to see the "charming place," and the accomplished Senora Pedro actually went with her to Staten Island, and showed her a house belonging to Mr. Thos. Munroe, merchant, of this City, situated about a mile from Vanderbilt's Landing, which she said was her own. When Mrs. R. expressed a wish to go through the house, the Donna told her that she did not like to put its occupants to the inconvenience of showing it. Mrs. Mary Ann Forman, keeping a boarding-house at No. 37 Twenty-seventh-street, testified that the would-be Countess had made similar representations to her in regard to her property, diamonds, &c., and that after the said lady had boarded with her a while and paid nothing, she one day took it into her head to pay a visit to the Island, to see the "charming place." She accordingly did so, and searched the whole island for somebody who knew Senora Donna Pedro, but could find nobody, and finally the tax collector told her that no such person was taxed on the island. She came back and turned the lady out of doors. Mrs. Mary A. Bellinger, keeper of a boarding-house, and Mr. Holland L. Knight, proprietor of the Planter's Hotel, were also victimized out of board bills by the lady, and the general opinion of all the victims in regard to her was, that she is an adventurer, with no means whatever except her tongue and some pretty good clothes. The examination is to be resumed, and, in the meantime, the "daughter of the King of Portugal" lies in a cell in the Jefferson Market Prison.

abstract: The trot between Prince John, entered by HORACE F. JONES, and Native America, entered, by HIRAM WOODRUFF, on the Union Course, yesterday, was well contested. There was a large concourse of spectators, as the race was known to be really between Mr. BENJAMIN WOOD, who favored Prince John, and Mr. MONNOT, who named his Native America, Native America is the horse, which, some five years ago, came from Kentucky, and was purchased by Mr. M. SHUTE for $5,000. Prince John, however, was the favorite previous to starting at the rate of $100 to $30. His driver threw away the first heat to catch outsiders and increase the betting, and the result was a large exchange of money, as he won the last three heats without a struggle. The following is the time:

abstract: In re Fanny Krugg. -- The petitioner in this case applied to Judge INGRAHAM for a writ of habeas corpus for the custody of her infant daughter, Pennie Ephraim. abstract: The People vs. John Dunnigan. -- At the last term of the Oyer and Terminer, held by Judge GOULD, in this City, John Dunnigan was indicted for the murder of William Hickey and John Keevan. He was tried for the murder of Hickey, but the jury failed to agree. On application of his counsel, he was held to bail in the sum of $5,000 in each case. Satisfactory bail was not procured till yesterday morning, when Mr. William Tuarrin, of No. 25 John-street, Brooklyn, gave the required surety, and the prisoner was released by Judge INGRAHAM.

abstract: The intelligence from Washington touching the movements in the Navy Department has created some excitement in naval circles, and there appears to be a general expectation among the officers not in active service that they may be summoned at any hour to report themselves for duty on board of some of the ships about to be dispatched to the Gulf.
lead_paragraph: The intelligence from Washington touching the movements in the Navy Department has created some excitement in naval circles, and there appears to be a general expectation among the officers not in active service that they may be summoned at any hour to report themselves for duty on board of some of the ships about to be dispatched to the Gulf. Unusual activity prevails at the different Navy-yards, much to the relief of the multitudes of workmen who rely upon that kind of employment; and a natural curiosity prevails to ascertain the cause of the sudden stir. It is evidently the intention of the Government to make a demonstration in the Gulf, as there is already concentrated in those waters a larger naval force than we have ever had since the Mexican War. In comparison with England, however, our force is very interior, they having 21 ships of all kinds and 3,470 men, while the French have 8 vessels of war and some 1,500 men. Besides the steamers of the second class, which are regularly employed is cruising for slavers on the coast of Cuba and other islands, we have the following first-class vessels of war already on the ground, or under orders for sailing:
