abstract: Seeing that Texas belongs to this distracted Union, and that its geography, history and statistics have been the topics of elaborate investigation among intelligent inquirers, among whom Mr. F.L. OLMSTED deserves perhaps a foremost place, it is surprising how much ignorance concerning that State is actually prevalent.
lead_paragraph: Seeing that Texas belongs to this distracted Union, and that its geography, history and statistics have been the topics of elaborate investigation among intelligent inquirers, among whom Mr. F.L. OLMSTED deserves perhaps a foremost place, it is surprising how much ignorance concerning that State is actually prevalent. Mr. ELI THAYER, for instance, in that Worcester speech, which was reprinted in the TIMES yesterday, classifies Texas with Kentucky, as a State where the element of Slavery has almost ceased to augment, and where the institution, after a short period of stagnation, must presently begin to decline; whereas, so enormous is the yearly increase of slaves -- the result of immigration and reproduction -- that the number nearly doubles in each period of five years. From indications furnished by the report of the State Comptroller in 1858, there is every reason to anticipate that instead of 58,161, the number in 1850, the census of the present year will present 160,000. This ratio of augmentation is quite equal to that of the most active of the Slave-importing States along the Gulf, and places Texas in a category extremely remote from that occupied by Kentucky.

abstract: The Republican State Central Committee met yesterday at Albany, and was organized by the election of SIMEON DRAPER, Chairman, JAMES TERWILLIGER, Secretary, and G.C. DAVIDSON, Treasurer.
lead_paragraph: The Republican State Central Committee met yesterday at Albany, and was organized by the election of SIMEON DRAPER, Chairman, JAMES TERWILLIGER, Secretary, and G.C. DAVIDSON, Treasurer. It has been quite generally reported in various quarters that the Central Committee was decidedly Anti-Weed in its character. This election does not look like it. An Executive Committee was also appointed, at the head of which is Hon. WM. H. FERRY, of Utica. Arrangements were made for carrying on the campaign vigorously.

abstract: The second contest of the season between the above Clubs took place on Wednesday, Aug. 29, on the Harlem ground a Mount Morris Square, and ended, as did the former game, in the defeat of the Manhattans. On this occasion the Manhattans made the poorest display they have ever shown in the field, while their batting was far below its ordinary standard. A comparatively large number of balls were missed on ...
lead_paragraph: The second contest of the season between the above Clubs took place on Wednesday, Aug. 29, on the Harlem ground a Mount Morris Square, and ended, as did the former game, in the defeat of the Manhattans. On this occasion the Manhattans made the poorest display they have ever shown in the field, while their batting was far below its ordinary standard. A comparatively large number of balls were missed on the fly, while the balls muffed or badly thrown were entirely too frequent. In fact their throwing was so wild that this, more than any other deficiency, lost them the game. With the exception of one miss, Bogart's play at left field was quite creditable, while Saunders and Macdonald exhibited a superiority in throwing. Hudson took a decided lead at the bat, the others doing but little. Of the Harlems, Thompson pitched finely. Hughes was most excellent at short, Liscomb at second base and Wood as catcher, while the three fielders fulfilled creditably all the requirements of their positions. At the bat Dunn, Howard, Thompson, Marsh and Wood were the most successful, Hyatt, Thompson and Dunn making home runs.

abstract: That practical philosopher, Mr. D.U. MARTIN, of Boston, who combines aquatic proficiency and physical vigor with abstemiousness, terminated his visit to New-York, yesterday, by starting in his cockle-shell boat for Albany. The devotees of the aquatic, the physique and the abstemic, therefore sig- ...
lead_paragraph: That practical philosopher, Mr. D.U. MARTIN, of Boston, who combines aquatic proficiency and physical vigor with abstemiousness, terminated his visit to New-York, yesterday, by starting in his cockle-shell boat for Albany. The devotees of the aquatic, the physique and the abstemic, therefore signalized the occasion by bidding him a cordial goodbye, in the way of racing with him, rowing with him, and eating with him, to the great development of the powers necessarily brought into requisition in the process. Messrs. W.H. & J.S. DARLING, the builders of his wherry, were the hosts of the day, and invited some hundred friends to meet around their hospitable board. Their large boat-shop was temporarily transformed into a dining-hall, and the walls that were wont to echo with the noise of hammers, planes and saws, resounded with the grateful music of knives and forks. The odor of fresh shavings was deliciously intermingled with the aroma of hot-corn, and the ambrosial scents of varied fresh fruit. Here and there the table was dotted with sandwiches, (a la VAN TINE,) for the unbelieving, but, in honor, of the guest, the body of the repast was presented fresh from nature's kitchen, whose air is always heavy with sweet perfumes. Preliminary to the feast conversation wiled away the hour from twelve to one, while wistful eyes gazed upon the stores of good things. The lion -- or rather the lamb -- of the day, was, of course, the wherryman -- he who has rowed from Boston, recuperating himself solely from vegetable, and mainly fruit diet. Mr. MARTIN was affable as he was healthy, and good-naturedly responded to the hundred questions with which the listeners plied him. In the course of the interrogation he communicated the interesting information that he had for three years subsisted entirely on vegetable food, and for the last year mainly on fruit; that his health was much improved, his mind clear, his muscles hard, his strength increased, and his hopes for a Methusalehstic life ardent; that he didn't like milk for grown people; favored the grape, but not the juice of it; couldn't tell whether a tomato was a fruit or a vegetable, and seemed rather more inclined to desire the election of LINCOLN and HAMLIN than of any other candidates who have a possibility of being chosen. He thought that fruit diet was the best to train a man for a prize fight, and much more adapted to develop a great race than tough steaks, bean-coffee, sandy sugar, swill-milk, or indigestible cookery.

abstract: REOPENING OF THE OLD BOWERY. Under new management, and very altered circumstances, this theatre, memorable in the history of the City, was reopened last night.
lead_paragraph: REOPENING OF THE OLD BOWERY. -- Under new management, and very altered circumstances, this theatre, memorable in the history of the City, was reopened last night. It has undergone complete renovation, and is as handsomely, and at the same time, as chastely decorated as any theatre to Broadway. To the good taste of Mr. GEORGE WOOD, the now lessee and manager, this improvement is to be credited. Nor was this the only improvement. A much higher order of performances than have usually been exhibited here, were introduced, and instead of the blue fire melodrama, the "Lady of Lyons" was put on the stage, with accessories that would not have disgraced any theatre in the City. Mrs. RYAN (KATE DENIN) personated Pauline, and accomplished the character very much to the satisfaction of the audience, if applause and showers of bouquets are any indications thereof. Claude Melnotte was quite respectably played by Mr. E.L. TILTON. He was, perhaps, not too melodramatic for sensation purposes, but his abilities would be improved by a diminution of muscular power. The whole performance was exceedingly creditable, and Mr. WOOD deserves the praise of the public for his effort, to improve the taste of the patrons of his theatre. As it appeared last night, it was only second to the best of the Broadway establishments.

lead_paragraph: Difficulties originating in politics are becoming quite frequent at the South. On the 16th Dr. MITCHELL and Mr. GANTT, opposing candidates for Congress in the late election in Arkansas, fought a duel in the Indian Nation. Mr. GANTT, the successful aspirant, was killed. R.W. HAYWARD and J.R. MCCANN, Electors on the Breckinridge and Douglas tickets respectively, became very much excited in the course of a discussion at Charlotte, Tenn., when Mr. HAYWOOD charged that in making a certain statement Mr. McCANN had uttered a lie. Mr. McCANN retorted, and was about to strike his opponent when friends interfered. A few days ago, BEN C. YANCEY, Jr., assailed Col. LEIBELS, of the Montgomery (Ala.) Confederation, for an attack which he had made, through the columns of that journal, upon his father. Col. LEIBELS attempted to ward off the blows of the cane which his assailant used with an umbrella, but was only partially successful, for he received a severe out across his eye and temple.

abstract: When the TIMES took occasion about a fortnight ago to warn the investing public against the sudden fever of speculation in railway securities, which seized upon the New-York Exchange at the first moment of reviving hope for the Western railway interests so long and so cruelly prostrated, we were assailed by ...
lead_paragraph: When the TIMES took occasion about a fortnight ago to warn the investing public against the sudden fever of speculation in railway securities, which seized upon the New-York Exchange at the first moment of reviving hope for the Western railway interests so long and so cruelly prostrated, we were assailed by a chorus of extremely dispassionate voices, denouncing us as the enemies, of the national prosperity and as willful prophets of evil under the bluest of all possible skies. We were informed in language more emphatic than polite, and in one and the same breath, that we were exerting a disastrous influence, and that nothing would come of our malignant efforts. We were requested to understand that the more people gambled in the possible future profits of a great investment, the better it would be for all concerned; that the prosperity of great industries depended not on inducing men to take solid interests in them at remunerative rates, but on keeping their securities as high in the air as a whole Exchange of battledores possibly could; and that we might expect to see the stocks of the most dilapidated companies restored by a single season of tolerably profitable employment for their roads, to an unexampled pitch alike of real and of nominal value.

abstract: DESTRUCTION OF A CHEMICAL FACTORY BY FIRE LOSS $30,000 Between 3 and 4 o'clock yester  day morning, the Chemical Factory of Messrs. DURKEE  Co., on Sedgwick, near Columbia-street, was discovered to be on fire in the second story, and be  fore the fire could be stayed the building and contents were entirely consumed. The building was owned by CHARLES KELSEY, and cost $10,000.
lead_paragraph: DESTRUCTION OF A CHEMICAL FACTORY BY FIRE -- LOSS $30,000. -- Between 3 and 4 o'clock yester day morning, the Chemical Factory of Messrs. DURKEE & CO., on Sedgwick, near Columbia-street, was discovered to be on fire in the second story, and be fore the fire could be stayed the building and contents were entirely consumed. The building was owned by CHARLES KELSEY, and cost $10,000. It was made of brick, three stories high, with a front of 60 feet, and two wings extending back 80 feet. Messrs. DURKEE & Co.'s loss is estimated at $20,000 and he is insured in the following named offices $2,500 each: Standard, Firemen's, Friend and Market Insurance Companies, of New-York; and in the Firemen's Trust Company, Brooklyn. Mr. KELSEY is fully insured in the Metropolitan Insurance Company, New-York. The fire is supposed to have been caused by a defect in one of the flues. There was no person in the building at the time the fire broke out.

abstract: If the Austrian Empire were not the most amazing anomaly of the present age, and the Austrian Government the least consequential of political forces, all anxiety as to the maintenance of European peace might be dismissed at once, so far as that peace depends on the ...
lead_paragraph: If the Austrian Empire were not the most amazing anomaly of the present age, and the Austrian Government the least consequential of political forces, all anxiety as to the maintenance of European peace might be dismissed at once, so far as that peace depends on the ability of Austria to uphold in Italy whatever still remains of that odious system of authority which afflicted the Peninsula by the grace of His Imperial Apostolic Majesty, from the peace of 1815 down to the war of 1859; for the Austrian Minister of Finance, the successor of Baron BRUCK in the fearful task under which that gifted statesman broke down into a wreck alike of character and of intellect, has just published his official budget, and in doing this has proclaimed to all the world, from St. Petersburgh to Palermo, that Austria has no choice before her but bankruptcy or peace. Never was the solemn denunciation of the Saviour, "He that taketh the sword shall perish by the sword," more strikingly fulfilled than in the case of this colossal military monarchy. For the last half century, Austria has deliberately undertaken to rule her own dominions and to influence the public policy of Europe by the display of an overwhelming military strength. All the administrative reforms, all the commercial developments upon which she has entered during that time have been completely subordinated to this prime object of her Government. The Empire of which history tells that it grew up under the favor of Venus rather than of Mars, went over to the worship of the God of Battles when the Holy Alliance put Prince METTERNICH virtually at the head of the European system. How the god has rewarded his votary we all know. Hungary, victorious at the gates of Vienna, and reduced to submission only by the humiliating intervention of the Czar; Italy twice wrenched from the grasp of the Hapsburgs, and now menacing the whole line of their dominions, are the results of Austrian fidelity to the law of the bayonet.

abstract: We publish this morning a speech which will be read with interest by that very large class of reflecting men, who regard the public welfare as of more consequence than any mere party victory, and who cannot see clearly the path of duty in the present complications of political affairs. It was made by Hon. R. W. THOMPSON, of Indiana, a few days since, and has been specially reported for the TIMES.
